('1', 0, 7, 10, 595) 1 When Gandhiji was 15, he had removed a bit of gold from his brother’s armlet to clear a small debt of the latter.
('1', 0, 7, 11, 711) He felt so mortified about his act that he decided to make a confession to his father.
('1', 0, 7, 12, 798) Parental forgiveness was granted to him in the form of silent tears.
('1', 0, 7, 13, 867) The incident left a lasting mark on his mind.
('1', 0, 7, 14, 913) In his own words, it was an object lesson to him in the power of ahimsa.
('1', 0, 7, 15, 986) The original not being available; his own report of it, as found in An Autobiography, is reproduced here.
('1', 0, 7, 16, 1092) 2 According to Mahatma Gandhi : The Early Phase, p.
('1', 0, 7, 17, 1144) 212, one of the senten ces in the confession was : “So, father, your son is now, in your eyes, no better than a common thief.” 3 Gandhiji was given a send off by his fellow students of the Alfred High School, Rajkot, when he was leaving for England to study for the Bar.

('1', 1, 1, 2, 1670) 3. LETTER TO LAKSHMIDAS GANDHI
('1', 1, 2, 3, 1701) LONDON, Friday, November 9, 1888
('1', 1, 3, 4, 1734) RESPECTED BROTHER, I am sorry that there has been no letter from you for the last two or three weeks.
('1', 1, 3, 5, 1836) Your silence is due perhaps to your not having heard from me.
('1', 1, 3, 6, 1898) But it was impossible for me to post any letters before I reached London.
('1', 1, 3, 7, 1972) That you should not have written to me on that account is indeed surprising.
('1', 1, 3, 8, 2049) As I am far from home we can meet only through letters.
('1', 1, 3, 9, 2105) And if I do not get letters I feel very much worried.
('1', 1, 3, 10, 2159) Therefore please drop a postcard every week without fail.
('1', 1, 3, 11, 2217) I would not have been anxious if you did not have my address.
('1', 1, 3, 12, 2279) But I am sorry that you have stopped writing after having written to me twice.
('1', 1, 3, 13, 2358) I joined the Inner Temple on Tuesday last.
('1', 1, 3, 14, 2401) I will write in detail after I hear from you next week.
('1', 1, 3, 15, 2457) The cold here is now bitter but such bad weather generally does not last long.
('1', 1, 3, 16, 2536) In spite of the cold I have no need of meat or liquor.
('1', 1, 3, 17, 2591) This fills my heart with joy and thankfulness.
('1', 1, 3, 18, 2638) I am now keeping very good health.
('1', 1, 3, 19, 2673) Please give my respects to mother and sister in law.
('1', 1, 4, 20, 2726) Mahatma, Vol. I; also from a photostat of the Gujarati
('1', 1, 5, 21, 2781) 4. LONDON DIARY 1
('1', 1, 6, 22, 2799) LONDON, November, 12 1888 What led to the intention of proceeding to London?
('1', 1, 6, 23, 2876) The scene opens about the end of April.
('1', 1, 6, 24, 2916) Before the intention of coming to London for the sake of study was actually formed, I had a secret design in my mind of coming here to satisfy my curiosity of knowing what London was.
('1', 1, 6, 25, 3100) While I was prosecuting my college studies in
('1', 1, 7, 26, 3146) 1 When his nephew and co worker, Chhaganlal Gandhi, was proceeding for the first time to London in 1909, Gandhiji gave him his “London Diary” The diary filled about 120 pages.
('1', 1, 7, 27, 3322) Chhaganlal Gandhi gave it to Mahadev Desai in 1920. But, before doing so, he copied out in a notebook about 20 pages of the original.
('1', 1, 7, 28, 3456) The remaining 100 pages were not continuous writing, but merely a chronicle of incidents during his stay in London from 1888 to 1891. The original being untraceable, Chhaganlal’s copy is reproduced here with minimum editing.
('1', 1, 7, 29, 3681) Gandhiji wrote the diary in English when he was 19.

('1', 2, 1, 2, 3765) Bhavnagar 1, I had a chat with Jayshankar Buch.
('1', 2, 1, 3, 3813) During the chat he advised me to apply to the Junagadh 2 State to give me a scholarship to proceed to London, I being an inhabitant of Sorath 3. I do not perfectly remember the answer I made to him that day.
('1', 2, 1, 4, 4021) I suppose I felt the impossibility of getting the scholarship.
('1', 2, 1, 5, 4084) From that [time] I had in my mind the intention of visiting the land.
('1', 2, 1, 6, 4154) I was finding the means to reach that end.
('1', 2, 1, 7, 4197) On 13th April, 1888, I left Bhavnagar to enjoy the vacation in Rajkot.
('1', 2, 1, 8, 4268) After 15 days of vacation, my elder brother and I went to see Patwari.
('1', 2, 1, 9, 4339) On our return my brother said : “We would go to see Mavji Joshi 4“, and so we went.
('1', 2, 1, 10, 4423) Mavji Joshi asked me as usual how I did.
('1', 2, 1, 11, 4464) Then put some questions about my study in Bhavnagar.
('1', 2, 1, 12, 4517) I plainly told him that I had hardly any chance of passing my examination first year.
('1', 2, 1, 13, 4603) I also added that I found the course very difficult.
('1', 2, 1, 14, 4656) Hearing this, he advised my brother to send me as soon as possible to London for being called to the Bar.
('1', 2, 1, 15, 4762) He said the expense will be only Rs. 5,000. “Let him take some urad dal.
('1', 2, 1, 16, 4835) There he will cook some food for himself and thereby there will be no objection about religion.
('1', 2, 1, 17, 4931) Don’t reveal the matter to anybody.
('1', 2, 1, 18, 4967) Try to get some scholarship.
('1', 2, 1, 19, 4996) Apply to Junagadh and Porbandar States.
('1', 2, 1, 20, 5036) See my son Kevalram 5, and if you fail in getting the pecuniary help and if you have no money, sell your furniture.
('1', 2, 1, 21, 5152) But anyhow send Mohandas to London.
('1', 2, 1, 22, 5188) I think that is the only means to keep the reputation of your deceased father.” All of our family members have great faith in what Mavji Joshi says.
('1', 2, 1, 23, 5337) And my brother who is naturally very credulous made a promise to Mavji Joshi to send me to London.
('1', 2, 1, 24, 5436) Now was the time for my exertions.
('1', 2, 1, 25, 5471) On that very day my brother, notwithstanding his promise to keep the matter secret, told the thing to Khushalbhai 6. He, of course, approved of it in case I could observe my religion.
('1', 2, 1, 26, 5655) The very day it was told to Meghjibhai 7. He quite agreed with the proposal and offered to give me Rs. 5,000. I had some faith in what he said.
('1', 2, 1, 27, 5799) And when the matter was disclosed to my dear mother, she reproached me

('1', 3, 1, 3, 6313) On that day I was to (go to) Kevalrambhai.
('1', 3, 1, 4, 6356) I saw him accordingly.
('1', 3, 1, 5, 6379) There I had not a satisfactory chat.

('1', 3, 1, 7, 6628) You will have to eat meat, you must drink.
('1', 3, 1, 8, 6671) You cannot live without that.

('1', 3, 1, 16, 7059) He illustrated his statement by giving example of Mr. Gulam Mahomed Munshi.

('1', 3, 1, 19, 7240) He said he would very gladly do anything except that.
('1', 3, 1, 20, 7294) I told everything to my brother.
('1', 3, 1, 21, 7327) Then I was entrusted with the business of receiving the consent of my dear mother, which I thought was not an arduous task for me.
('1', 3, 1, 22, 7458) After a day or two, my brother and I went to see Mr. Kevalram; there he saw us though he was very busy at that time.
('1', 3, 1, 23, 7575) We had a talk of the similar kind that I had with him a day or two earlier.
('1', 3, 1, 24, 7651) He advised my brother to send me to Porbandar.
('1', 3, 1, 25, 7698) The proposal was agreed to.
('1', 3, 1, 26, 7726) Then we returned.
('1', 3, 1, 27, 7744) I began to introduce the subject to my mother in joke.
('1', 3, 1, 28, 7799) The joke was turned to reality in no time.
('1', 3, 1, 29, 7842) Then a day was fixed for my going to Porbandar.
('1', 3, 1, 30, 7890) Twice or thrice I prepared to go, but some difficulty came in my way.
('1', 3, 1, 31, 7960) Once I was to go with Zaverchand, but an hour before the time of my departure a serious accident took place.
('1', 3, 1, 32, 8069) I was always quarrelling with my friend Sheikh Mehtab 1. On the day of departure I was quite engrossed in thinking about the quarrel.
('1', 3, 1, 33, 8203) He had a musical party at night.
('1', 3, 1, 34, 8236) I did not enjoy it very well.
('1', 3, 1, 35, 8266) At about 10.30 p.m.
('1', 3, 1, 36, 8286) the party ended and we all went to see Meghjibhai and Rami.
('1', 3, 1, 37, 8346) On our way I was buried in the madcap thoughts of London on one side and the thoughts of Sheikh Mehtab on the other.
('1', 3, 1, 38, 8463) Amidst thoughts, I came unconsciously in contact with a carriage.
('1', 3, 1, 39, 8529) I received some injury.
('1', 3, 1, 40, 8553) Yet I did not take the help of anybody in walking.
('1', 3, 1, 41, 8604) I think I was quite dizzy.
('1', 3, 1, 42, 8631) Then we entered the house of Meghjibhai.

('1', 4, 1, 4, 8895) From that [time] I did not know what took place, and after that, I am told by them, I fell flat on the ground after some steps.
('1', 4, 1, 5, 9023) I was not myself for 5 minutes.
('1', 4, 1, 6, 9055) They considered I was dead.
('1', 4, 1, 7, 9083) But fortunately for myself the ground on which I fell was quite smooth.
('1', 4, 1, 8, 9155) I came to my senses at last and all of them were quite joyful.
('1', 4, 1, 9, 9218) The mother was sent for.
('1', 4, 1, 10, 9243) She was very sorry for me, and this caused my delay though I told them that I was quite well.
('1', 4, 1, 11, 9337) But none would allow me to go, though I afterwards came to know that my bold and dearest mother would have allowed me to go.
('1', 4, 1, 12, 9462) But she feared the calumny of other people.
('1', 4, 1, 13, 9506) At last with great difficulty I was allowed to leave Rajkot for Porbandar after some days.
('1', 4, 1, 14, 9597) On my way too I had to encounter some difficulties.
('1', 4, 1, 15, 9649) At length I reached Porbandar to the joy of all.
('1', 4, 1, 16, 9698) Lalbhai 1 and Karsondas 2 had come to the Khadi bridge to fetch me home.
('1', 4, 1, 17, 9771) Now what had I to do in Porbandar [was to] exact consent from my uncle, and, secondly apply to Mr. Lely 3 to render me some pecuniary help, and last, in case of failure to get the State scholarship, to ask Parmanandbhai 4 to give me some money.
('1', 4, 1, 18, 10016) The first thing I did was that I saw uncle and asked him whether he liked my going to London or not.
('1', 4, 1, 19, 10117) Then, naturally, as I had expected, he asked me to enumerate the advantages of going to London.
('1', 4, 1, 20, 10213) This I did according to my power.
('1', 4, 1, 21, 10247) Then he said : “Of course, the people of this generation would like it very much, but, as for myself, I do not like it.
('1', 4, 1, 22, 10367) Nevertheless we shall consider afterwards.” I was not disappointed by such an answer.
('1', 4, 1, 23, 10453) At least I had the satisfaction to know that at all events he liked it inwardly and his deed proved what I thought right.
('1', 4, 1, 24, 10575) Unfortunately for me, Mr. Lely was not in Porbandar.
('1', 4, 1, 25, 10628) It is quite true that misfortunes never come single.
('1', 4, 1, 26, 10681) After his return from the district where he had gone, he was to go at once on leave.
('1', 4, 1, 27, 10766) My uncle advised me to wait for him till the next Sunday.
('1', 4, 1, 28, 10824) And if he did not come up during that time, he said, he would send me where he should be.
('1', 4, 1, 29, 10914) But it gives me much pleasure to write here that he returned from the district on Sunday.
('1', 4, 1, 30, 11004) Then it was settled that I should see him on Monday.
('1', 4, 1, 31, 11057) It was done accordingly.
('1', 4, 1, 32, 11082) For the first time in my life I had an interview with an English gentleman.
('1', 4, 1, 33, 11158) Formerly I never dared to front them.
('1', 4, 1, 34, 11196) But thoughts of London made me bold.

('1', 5, 1, 13, 12300) Don’t you know that I am going on a pilgrimage, and is it not disgraceful on my part to say that I like that people should go to London?

('1', 5, 1, 25, 13733) The letter was shown to him and it actually passed for a letter written by me.
('1', 5, 1, 26, 13812) Then, of course, he was quite puffed up and made a solemn promise of giving me Rs. 5,000. I was not informed of this until I reached Rajkot.

('1', 17, 5, 19, 43282) 7. INDIAN VEGETARIANS I
('1', 17, 6, 20, 43306) India is inhabited by twenty five million 1 of people of various castes and creeds.
('1', 17, 6, 21, 43390) The very common belief among the Englishmen who have not been to India, or who have taken very little interest in
('1', 17, 7, 22, 43504) 1 Obviously, a slip for crores
('1', 18, 0, 1, 43535) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 19
('1', 18, 1, 2, 43568) Indian matters, is that all the Indians are born vegetarians.
('1', 18, 1, 3, 43630) Now this is true only in part.
('1', 18, 1, 4, 43661) Indian people are divided into three main divisions, viz., the Hindus, the Mohammedans, and the Parsis.
('1', 18, 1, 5, 43765) The Hindus are again divided into four chief castes, viz., the Brahmins, the Kshatriyas, the Vaisyas, and the Sudras, Of all these, in theory, only the Brahmins and the Vaisyas are pure vegetarians.
('1', 18, 1, 6, 43964) But in practice almost all the Indians are vegetarians.
('1', 18, 1, 7, 44020) Some are so voluntarily, and others compulsorily.
('1', 18, 1, 8, 44070) The latter, though always willing to take, are yet too poor to buy meat.
('1', 18, 1, 9, 44143) This statement will be borne out by the fact that there are thousands in India who have to live on one pice (11/3d.) a day.
('1', 18, 1, 10, 44267) These live on bread and salt, a heavily taxed article; for even in a poverty stricken country like India, it will be very difficult,if not utterly impossible,to get eatable flesh meat for 11/3d.
('1', 18, 2, 11, 44462) The question who are vegetarians in India being disposed of, the natural question will be what is vegetarianism as practised by them?
('1', 18, 2, 12, 44596) To begin with, Indian vegetarianism does not mean the V.E.M. 1 diet.
('1', 18, 2, 13, 44665) The Indians, i.e., the Indian vegetarians, decline to take, besides fish, flesh and fowl, eggs, for they argue that to eat an egg is equivalent to killing life; since an egg, if left undisturbed would, prima facie, become a fowl.
('1', 18, 2, 14, 44895) But, unlike some of the vegetarian extremists here, they not only do not abstain from milk and butter, but consider them sacred enough to be used on what are called “fruit days”, which occur every fortnight, and which are generally observed by the high caste Hindus; because, as they put it, they do not kill the cow in taking milk from her.
('1', 18, 2, 15, 45237) And certainly the milking of a cow, which, by the way, has been the subject of painting and poetry cannot shock the most delicate feelings as would the slaughtering of her.
('1', 18, 2, 16, 45410) It may be worth mentioning en passant that the cow is an object of worship among the Hindus, and a movement set on foot to prevent the cows from being shipped off for the purposes of slaughter is progressing rapidly.
('1', 18, 2, 17, 45627) The Vegetarian, 7 2 1891
('1', 18, 3, 18, 45652) 8. INDIAN VEGETARIANS II
('1', 18, 4, 19, 45677) Indian vegetarians food generally varies with the parts they live in.
('1', 18, 4, 20, 45747) Thus in Bengal the staple article of food is rice, while in the Bombay Presidency it is wheat.
('1', 18, 5, 21, 45842) 1 V.E.M. probably means vegetables, eggs, milk.
('1', 19, 0, 1, 45890) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 20
('1', 19, 1, 2, 45931) All the Indians generally—and the grown up persons particularly, and among them the high caste Hindus—take two meals a day with a glass or two of water between the meals whenever they feel thirsty.
('1', 19, 1, 3, 46129) The first meal they take at about 10 a.m., which would correspond to the English dinner, and the second meal at about 8 p.m., which would correspond to supper so far as the name goes, though in reality, it is a substantial meal.
('1', 19, 1, 4, 46358) From the above it will have been seen that there is no breakfast—which, seeing that the Indians generally rise at 6 o'clock, and even as early as four or five o'clock in the morning, they would seem to require—nor the ordinary midday meal.
('1', 19, 1, 5, 46598) Some of the readers will no doubt wonder how the Indians go about without anything to eat for nine hours after their first meal.
('1', 19, 1, 6, 46727) This may be explained in two ways, viz., first, the habit is second nature.
('1', 19, 1, 7, 46803) Their religion commands some, and employment or custom compels others, to take not more than two meals in one day.
('1', 19, 1, 8, 46918) Secondly, the climate of India, which except in some parts is very hot, will account for the habit.
('1', 19, 1, 9, 47018) For even in England, it appears that the same quantity of food is not required in summer as in winter.
('1', 19, 1, 10, 47121) Unlike the English, the Indians do not take each dish separately, but they mix many things together.
('1', 19, 1, 11, 47222) Among some of the Hindus it is one of the requirements of their religion to mix all their food together.
('1', 19, 1, 12, 47327) Moreover, every dish is elaborately prepared.
('1', 19, 1, 13, 47373) In fact they don't believe in plain boiled vegetables, but must have them flavoured with plenty of condiments, e.g., pepper, salt, cloves, turmeric, mustard seed, and various other things for which it would be difficult to find English names unless they be those used in medicine.
('1', 19, 1, 14, 47654) The first meal consists generally of bread or rather cakes—of which more hereafter—some pulse, e.g., peas, haricot beans, etc., and two or three green vegetables cooked together, or separately, followed by rice and pulse cooked in water, and flavoured with various spices.
('1', 19, 1, 15, 47927) After this, some take milk and rice, or simply milk, or curdled milk, or even whey, especially in summer.
('1', 19, 1, 16, 48033) The second meal, i.e., the supper, consists of much the same things as the first one, but the quantity is less and the vegetables fewer at this meal.
('1', 19, 1, 17, 48183) Milk is more liberally used at this meal.
('1', 19, 1, 18, 48225) The readershould be reminded that this is not the food that the Indians invariably use nor should he think that the above will be the typical dishes all over India and among all classes.
('1', 19, 1, 19, 48412) Thus, for example, no sweets are mentioned in the specimen meals while they are sure to be used among the well to do classes at least once a week.
('1', 19, 1, 20, 48559) Moreover, while, as
('1', 20, 0, 1, 48579) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 21
('1', 20, 1, 2, 48612) said above, wheat preponderates over rice in the Bombay Presidency, in Bengal rice gets the better of wheat.
('1', 20, 1, 3, 48721) So also with regard to the third exception which must prove the rule, the food among the labouring class is different from what is given above.
('1', 20, 1, 4, 48865) To mention all the varieties would be the fill up volumes and to do so would, it is to be feared, divest the article of all interest.
('1', 20, 1, 5, 48999) Butter, or if you please, clarified butter, is much more used for culinary purposes than in England or, it may be, even in Europe.
('1', 20, 1, 6, 49130) And according to a doctor of some authority, if it would do no good, much use of better, in a hot climate like that of India would do no harm such as it might do in a cold climate like that of England.
('1', 20, 1, 7, 49332) It will perhaps strike the reader that the fruit, yes, the all important fruit, is sadly conspicuous by its absence in the above mentioned specimen dishes.
('1', 20, 1, 8, 49488) Some, among many of the reasons, are that the Indians do not know the proper value of fruit, that the poor people cannot afford to buy good fruit, and that good fruit is not available all over India, except in large cities.
('1', 20, 1, 9, 49712) Indeed, there are certain fruits, not to be found here, which are used by all classes in India; but alas, these are used as superficial things, not as food, and no one knows their value chemically, because no one takes the trouble to analyse them.
('1', 20, 1, 10, 49960) The Vegetarian, 14 2 1891
('1', 20, 2, 11, 49986) 9. INDIAN VEGETARIANS III
('1', 20, 3, 12, 50012) In the previous article “more hereafter” was promised about the cakes.
('1', 20, 3, 13, 50083) These cakes are generally made of wheat flour.
('1', 20, 3, 14, 50130) Wheat is first ground in a handmill—a simple contrivance to reduce the wheat to powder not a mill requiring machinery.
('1', 20, 3, 15, 50249) This powdered wheat is passed through a sieve with large holes, so that the coarsest bran is left out.
('1', 20, 3, 16, 50352) Indeed, among the poor classes it is not passed through the sieve at all.
('1', 20, 3, 17, 50426) Thus the flour, though not the same as that used by the vegetarians here, is far superior to the ordinary flour that is used here for the much abused white bread.
('1', 20, 3, 18, 50589) Some clarified butter, i.e., butter boiled and passed through a sieve sometimes a useless process when the butter is quite pure and then allowed to become cool say a tea spoonful to a pound of flour—is mixed with the flour, a sufficient quantity of water is poured on it, and then it is kneaded with the hands until it forms itself into one homogeneous mass.
('1', 20, 3, 19, 50948) This lump is divided into small equal parts, each as big as a tangerine.
('1', 20, 3, 20, 51021) These are rolled into thin circular pieces about six inches in diameter with a wooden stick made specially for the purpose.
('1', 20, 3, 21, 51145) Each piece is separately and
('1', 21, 0, 1, 51174) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 22
('1', 21, 1, 2, 51215) thoroughly baked in a flat dish.
('1', 21, 1, 3, 51248) It takes from five to seven minutes to bake one cake.
('1', 21, 1, 4, 51302) This cake is eaten while hot with butter, and has a very nice flavour.
('1', 21, 1, 5, 51373) It may be, and is, eaten even quite cold.
('1', 21, 1, 6, 51415) What meat is to the ordinary Englishman, the cake is to the Indian, be he a vegetarian or a meat eater, for in India a meat eater does not, in the writer's opinion, regard his meat as an absolute necessity, but takes it rather as a side dish to help him, so to speak, in eating the cakes.
('1', 21, 1, 7, 51704) Such in outline, and only in outline, is the ordinary food of a well to do Indian vegetarian.
('1', 21, 1, 8, 51798) Now a question may be asked, “Has not the British Rule effected any change in the habits of the Indian people?” So far as the food and drink are concerned “yes”, and “no”.
('1', 21, 1, 9, 51970) No, because ordinary men and women have stuck to their original food and the number of meals.
('1', 21, 1, 10, 52064) Yes, because those who have learnt a little bit of English have picked up English ideas here and there, but this change too—whether it is for the worse or for the better must be left to the reader to judge—is not very perceptible.
('1', 21, 1, 11, 52295) The last mentioned class have begun to believe in breakfast, which usually consists of a cup or two of tea.
('1', 21, 1, 12, 52403) Now this brings us to the question of drink.
('1', 21, 1, 13, 52448) The drinking of tea and coffee by the so called educated Indians, chiefly due to the British Rule, may be passed over with the briefest notice.
('1', 21, 1, 14, 52592) The most that tea and coffee can do is to cause a little extra expense, and general debility of health when indulged in to excess, but one of the most greatly felt evils of the British Rule is the importation of alcohol—that enemy of mankind, that curse of civilization—in some form or another.
('1', 21, 1, 15, 52887) The measure of the evil wrought by this borrowed habit will be properly gauged by the reader when he is told that the enemy has spread throughout the length and breadth of India, in spite of the religious prohibition; for even the touch of a bottle containing alcohol pollutes the Mohammedan, according to his religion, and the religion of the Hindu strictly prohibits the use of alcohol in any form whatever, and yet, alas!
('1', 21, 1, 16, 53312) the Government, it seems, instead of stopping, are aiding and abetting the spread of alcohol.
('1', 21, 1, 17, 53406) The poor there, as everywhere, are the greatest sufferers.
('1', 21, 1, 18, 53465) It is they who spend what little they earn in buying alcohol instead of buying food and other necessities.
('1', 21, 1, 19, 53572) It is that wretched poor man who has to starve his family, who has to break the sacred trust of looking after his children, if any, in order to drink himself into misery and premature death.
('1', 21, 1, 20, 53763) Here be it said to the credit of Mr. Caine1, the ex Member for Barrow, that he, undaunted, is still carrying on his admirable crusade against the spread of the evil, but what can the energy of one man, however powerful, do against the inaction of an apathetic and dormant Government?
('1', 21, 1, 21, 54047) The Vegetarian, 21 2 1891
('1', 22, 0, 1, 54073) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 23
('1', 22, 1, 2, 54106) 10. INDIAN VEGETARIANS IV
('1', 22, 2, 3, 54132) After having known who are vegetarians in India, and what they generally eat, the reader will be able to judge from the following facts how hollow and baseless are the arguments advanced by some people regarding the weak constitutions of the vegetarian Hindus.
('1', 22, 2, 4, 54393) One thing often said about the Indian vegetarians is that they are physically very feeble, and that, therefore, vegetarianism is not compatible with bodily strength.
('1', 22, 2, 5, 54559) Now, if it can be proved that generally in India the vegetarians are as strong as, if not stronger than, the Indian meat eaters, and for that matter even Englishmen, and moreover, that where weakness exists it can be ascribed to many other reasons than that of non flesh diet, the whole structure on which the above argument is based falls to the ground.
('1', 22, 2, 6, 54914) It must at the outset be admitted that the Hindus as a rule are notoriously weak; but an unbiased person—a meat eater—who knows India and her people even superficially will tell you that there are many other causes incessantly at work to account for the proverbial 1
('1', 22, 3, 7, 55181) weakness.
('1', 22, 3, 8, 55191) One of the most important reasons, if not the most important one, is the wretched custom of infant marriages and its attendant evils.
('1', 22, 3, 9, 55325) Generally, children when they reach the great age of nine are burdened with the fetters of married life.
('1', 22, 3, 10, 55430) In many cases they are married at a still younger age and in some cases they are betrothed while yet unborn.
('1', 22, 3, 11, 55539) Thus one woman would promise to marry her child, if male, to another's if female, and vice versa.
('1', 22, 3, 12, 55637) Of course in the two latter cases consummation does not take place before they are ten or eleven years old.
('1', 22, 3, 13, 55745) Cases are recorded in which a wife of twelve had a child by a husband of sixteen or seventeen.
('1', 22, 3, 14, 55840) Will not these marriages tell upon the strongest constitutions?
('1', 22, 3, 15, 55904) Now fancy how weak the progeny of such marriages must be.
('1', 22, 3, 16, 55962) Then look at the cares such a couple have to undergo.
('1', 22, 3, 17, 56016) Suppose a boy of eleven is married to a girl of about the same age.
('1', 22, 3, 18, 56084) Thus at a time when the boy should be, and is, ignorant of what it is to be a husband, he has a wife forced on him.
('1', 22, 3, 19, 56200) He is, of course, attending his school.

('1', 24, 1, 3, 59110) And granting the argument that a substitute is required for vegetables in the present state of society, is it conclusively proved that flesh or meat is that substitute?
('1', 24, 1, 4, 59279) Then take the case of the Kshatriyas, the so called warlike race in India.

('1', 24, 2, 13, 60208) 11. INDIAN VEGETARIANS V
('1', 24, 3, 14, 60233) We saw in the last article that the bodily weakness of the Hindu vegetarians was attributable to other causes than their diet, and also that the shepherds who were vegetarians were as strong as meat eaters.
('1', 24, 3, 15, 60440) This shepherd being a very good specimen of a vegetarian, we may with profit examine his way of living; but before proceeding further, the reader may be told that what follows does not apply to all the Indian shepherds.
('1', 24, 3, 16, 60660) It applies to the shepherds of a certain part of India.
('1', 24, 3, 17, 60716) Just as the habits of the people in Scotland would be different from those of the people in England, so also would the habits of the people living in one part of India be different from those of the people living in another part.
('1', 24, 3, 18, 60946) The Indian shepherd then gets up generally at five o'clock in the morning.
('1', 24, 3, 19, 61021) The first thing he does, if he is a pious shepherd, is to offer
('1', 24, 4, 20, 61085) 1 Prithviraj Chauhan, 11th century king claiming descent from the Sun; famed for his physical prowess
('1', 24, 5, 21, 61187) 2 Second of the Pandava Princes, in the Mahabharata, reputed for his great stature and strength.
('1', 24, 6, 22, 61284) 3 The reference is to the Bhayyas (literally, brothers), a name originally given to the peasantry of Uttar Pradesh
('1', 25, 0, 1, 61399) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 26
('1', 25, 1, 2, 61440) some prayers to his God.
('1', 25, 1, 3, 61465) Then he does his toilet which consists of washing his mouth and face.
('1', 25, 1, 4, 61535) I may be allowed here to digress for a while to acquaint the reader with the brush an Indian uses for his teeth.
('1', 25, 1, 5, 61648) The brush is nothing more than a branch of a thorny tree called babul; one branch is cut up into pieces about a foot long.
('1', 25, 1, 6, 61771) Of course, all the thorns are removed.
('1', 25, 1, 7, 61810) The Indian crushes one end of the stick between his teeth till it is soft enough to brush his teeth.
('1', 25, 1, 8, 61911) Thus he makes for himself every day a new and home made brush.
('1', 25, 1, 9, 61974) When he has well brushed his teeth and made them pearl white he splits the stick into two, and after bending one part into a curve scrapes his tongue.
('1', 25, 1, 10, 62125) This process of brushing probably accounts for the strong and beautiful teeth of the average Indian.
('1', 25, 1, 11, 62226) It is perhaps superfluous to add that he uses no tooth powder.
('1', 25, 1, 12, 62289) Old persons when their teeth are not strong enough to crush the stick use a small hammer.
('1', 25, 1, 13, 62379) The whole process does not take more than twenty or twenty five minutes.
('1', 25, 1, 14, 62452) To return to the shepherd, he then takes his breakfast consisting of a thick cake made of millet—an Anglo Indian name for bajari, a kind of corn much used in India instead of, or in addition to, wheat— clarified butter and molasses.
('1', 25, 1, 15, 62685) At about eight or nine o'clock in the morning he goes to pasture the cattle placed under his superintendence.
('1', 25, 1, 16, 62795) The place of pasture is generally two or three miles from his town.
('1', 25, 1, 17, 62863) It is hilly tract of land studded with a green carpet of luxuriant foliage.
('1', 25, 1, 18, 62939) Thus he has the unique advantage of enjoying the freshestm air with natural scenery thrown in.
('1', 25, 1, 19, 63034) While the cattle are roaming about, he whiles away his time in singing or talking to his companion who may be his wife, brother or some other relation.
('1', 25, 1, 20, 63186) At about twelve o' clock he takes his lunch, which he always carries with him.
('1', 25, 1, 21, 63265) It consists of the ever present cakes, clarified butter, one vegetable, or some pulse, or instead, or in addition, some pickle and fresh milk directly taken from the cow.
('1', 25, 1, 22, 63436) Then at about two or three o'clock he not infrequently takes a nap for about half an hour under some shady tree.
('1', 25, 1, 23, 63549) This short sleep gives him relief from the heat of the scorching sun.
('1', 25, 1, 24, 63619) At six he returns home, at seven he has supper, for which he takes some hot cakes, pulse or vegetables, winds up with rice and milk, or rice and whey.
('1', 25, 1, 25, 63770) After doing some household business, which often means a pleasant chat with the family members, he goes to bed at ten o'clock.
('1', 25, 1, 26, 63897) He sleeps either in the open air, or in a hut which is sometimes overcrowded.
('1', 25, 1, 27, 63975) He resorts to the hut in winter or in the rainy season.
('1', 25, 1, 28, 64031) It may be worthy of remark that these huts, even though miserable in appearance and often without any windows, are not air
('1', 26, 0, 1, 64154) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 27
('1', 26, 1, 2, 64187) Being constructed in a rude state, their doors are made, not as a protection against draughts of wind, but against burglars.
('1', 26, 1, 3, 64312) It cannot, however, be denied that there is much room for improvement in the huts.
('1', 26, 1, 4, 64395) Such, then, is the living of a well to do shepherd.
('1', 26, 1, 5, 64447) His, in many respects, is an ideal mode of life.
('1', 26, 1, 6, 64496) He is perforce regular in his habits, is out of doors during the greater part of his time, while out he breathes the purest air, has his due amount of exercise, has good and nourishing food and last but not least, is free from many cares which are frequently productive of weak constitutions.
('1', 26, 1, 7, 64789) The Vegetarian, 7 3 1891
('1', 26, 2, 8, 64814) 12. INDIAN VEGETARIANS VI
('1', 26, 3, 9, 64840) The only flaw that can be found in his mode of living is the paucity of baths.
('1', 26, 3, 10, 64919) In a hot climate baths are very useful.
('1', 26, 3, 11, 64959) While a Brahmin would have his bath twice a day, and a Vaisya once a day, a shepherd would have only one bath a week.
('1', 26, 3, 12, 65077) I shall here again digress to explain the manner in which the Indian takes his baths.
('1', 26, 3, 13, 65163) Generally, he has his baths in the river flowing near his town, but if he is too idle to go to the river, or is afraid of being drowned, or if there is no river near his town, he has his baths at home.
('1', 26, 3, 14, 65365) There is no bath into which he can plunge.
('1', 26, 3, 15, 65408) He takes water from a large vessel, placed near him, with a goblet and pours it over his body, because he believes that the moment you plunge into stagnant water you render it impure and, therefore, unfit for further use.
('1', 26, 3, 16, 65630) For the same reason he would not even wash his hands in a basin, but have someone to pour it over his hands or do it himself by holding the goblet between his arms.
('1', 26, 3, 17, 65795) But to return, the paucity of the baths does not, it seems, materially affect his health; while it is obvious that if the Brahmin were to go without his baths even for a day, he would feel very uncomfortable, and if he were to continue not taking them a little longer, he would very soon become ill.
('1', 26, 3, 18, 66095) This is, I suppose, an instance of many things which, otherwise inexplicable, can be accounted for by habit.
('1', 26, 3, 19, 66204) Thus while a scavenger, in pursuing his employment keeps good health, any ordinary person trying to do the same will be face to face with death.
('1', 26, 3, 20, 66349) Death would soon be knocking at the door of a delicately nurtured lord trying to
('1', 27, 0, 1, 66430) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 28
('1', 27, 1, 2, 66471) imitate an East End labourer.
('1', 27, 1, 3, 66501) I cannot help here giving a fable or anecdote which is exactly to the point.
('1', 27, 1, 4, 66578) A king fell in love with a female tooth brush seller, who was a very Venus in beauty.
('1', 27, 1, 5, 66664) As might naturally be expected she was ordered to be placed in the king's palace.
('1', 27, 1, 6, 66746) She was, in fact, placed in the lap of luxury.
('1', 27, 1, 7, 66793) She had the best food, the best clothes, in short, everything of the best.
('1', 27, 1, 8, 66868) And lo!

('1', 27, 1, 14, 67291) They were to disappear in as many days as there were rooms, and with them, he said, the illness would disappear.

('1', 27, 1, 16, 67419) Of course the cakes were consumed by the poor queen.
('1', 27, 1, 17, 67472) Now this shows the mastery that habit gets over men.
('1', 27, 1, 18, 67525) So I think the paucity of baths does not greatly harm the shepherd.
('1', 27, 1, 19, 67593) The result of this mode of living was partially noticed in the last article, viz., the vegetarian shepherd is physically strong.
('1', 27, 1, 20, 67722) He is also long lived.
('1', 27, 1, 21, 67745) I know a shepherdess who was more than one hundred yeas old in 1888. When I last saw her, her eyesight was very good.
('1', 27, 1, 22, 67863) Her memory was fresh.

('1', 27, 1, 26, 68020) Besides, the shepherd's figure is symmetrical.
('1', 27, 1, 27, 68067) It is very rare to see any deformity in him.
('1', 27, 1, 28, 68112) Without being fierce like a tiger, he is yet strong and brave and as docile as a lamb.
('1', 27, 1, 29, 68199) Without being awe inspiring, his stature is commanding.
('1', 27, 1, 30, 68255) Altogether, the Indian shepherd is a very fine specimen of a vegetarian, and will compare very favourably with any meat eater so far as bodily strength goes.
('1', 27, 1, 31, 68413) The Vegetarian, 14 3 1891
('1', 27, 2, 32, 68439) 13. SOME INDIAN FESTIVALS I
('1', 27, 3, 33, 68467) At this Easter time I should have liked to write something on the holidays which correspond to the Easter in point of time; but these holidays with their painful associations not being the greatest Hindu festival may very properly give way to the Diwali holidays which are far superior in importance and grandeur to the former.
('1', 28, 0, 1, 68795) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 29
('1', 28, 1, 2, 68828) Diwali, which may be termed the Hindu Christmas, occurs at the end of the Hindu year, i.e., during the month of November.
('1', 28, 1, 3, 68950) It is both a social and religious holiday.
('1', 28, 1, 4, 68993) It spreads over nearly a month.
('1', 28, 1, 5, 69025) The first day of the month of Ashwin (the twelfth month of the Hindu year) heralds the approach of the grand festival when the children let off their first fire works.
('1', 28, 1, 6, 69193) The first nine days are called Nava Ratri (nine nights).
('1', 28, 1, 7, 69250) These days are chiefly marked by garbis.
('1', 28, 1, 8, 69291) Some twenty or thirty, and even more people form themselves into a large circle, in the centre is placed a huge lamp post tastefully constructed and illuminated all round, in the centre also sits a man with his tabors reciting some popular verses.
('1', 28, 1, 9, 69539) The people forming the circle repeat the verses, keeping time to them with claps of hands.
('1', 28, 1, 10, 69630) While repeating the verses, they move round the lamp post, at the same time stooping down in a half bending posture.
('1', 28, 1, 11, 69747) It is very often a great treat to hear these garbis.
('1', 28, 1, 12, 69800) It may be remarked that girls—much less women—never take part in them.
('1', 28, 1, 13, 69871) Of course they may have their own garbis where men would be excluded.
('1', 28, 1, 14, 69941) In some families the custom of half fasting prevails.
('1', 28, 1, 15, 69995) It is sufficient if only one member of the family fasts.
('1', 28, 1, 16, 70052) The fasting man has only one meal a day, and that, too, in the evening.
('1', 28, 1, 17, 70124) Moreover, he is not allowed any corn or pulse, but is restricted to fruit, milk and root vegetables such as potatoes, etc.
('1', 28, 1, 18, 70247) The tenth day of the month is called Dashara, when friends meet and feast one another.
('1', 28, 1, 19, 70334) It is also customary to make presents of sweets to one's friends and especially patrons or superiors.
('1', 28, 1, 20, 70436) Except on the Dashara holiday all the amusements are carried on at night, while the ordinary daily pursuits are attended to in the daytime.
('1', 28, 1, 21, 70576) After Dashara everything is comparatively quiet for about a fortnight, except that the ladies are making preparations for the approaching grand day, by cooking and baking sweets, cakes, etc., for, in India, women of the highest class would not mind cooking.
('1', 28, 1, 22, 70834) In fact, it is an accomplishment which every lady is supposed to possess.
('1', 28, 1, 23, 70908) Thus, spending the evenings in feasting and singing, we reach the thirteenth day of the dark half of the month Ashwin.
('1', 28, 1, 24, 71027) (In India every month is divided into two parts, the dark half and the bright half, the full moon day and the new moon day being starting points; thus, the day following the full moon day is the first day of the dark half of a month, and so on).
('1', 28, 1, 25, 71273) The thirteenth day and the three following days are wholly devoted to amusements and enjoyment.
('1', 29, 0, 1, 71369) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 30
('1', 29, 1, 2, 71410) The thirteenth day is called Dhanteras, i.e., the thirteenth day set apart for the worship of “Lakshmi”, the goddess of wealth.
('1', 29, 1, 3, 71538) Rich people collect different kinds of jewels, precious stones, coins, etc., and put them carefully into a box.
('1', 29, 1, 4, 71650) These they never use for any other purpose than that of worship.
('1', 29, 1, 5, 71715) Each year an addition is made to this collection.
('1', 29, 1, 6, 71765) The worship, i.e., the external worship—for who, save a select few, is there who does not at heart covet, or in other words, worship money?—consists in washing the money with water and milk, and then decorating it with flowers and kumkum, i.e., red ochre.
('1', 29, 1, 7, 72021) The fourteenth day is called Kali Chaudash; but this day people get up before the break of day, and even the laziest person is required to take a good bath; the mother even compels her little children to take a bath, though it is the winter season.
('1', 29, 1, 8, 72270) On the night of Kali Chaudash, cemeteries are supposed to be visited by a procession of ghosts.
('1', 29, 1, 9, 72366) Persons affecting to believe in ghosts would go to these places to see their ghost friends.
('1', 29, 1, 10, 72458) Timid ones would not stir out of their houses lest they should see a ghost.
('1', 29, 1, 11, 72534) The Vegetarian, 28 3 1891
('1', 29, 2, 12, 72560) 14. SOME INDIAN FESTIVALS II
('1', 29, 3, 13, 72589) But lo!
('1', 29, 3, 14, 72597) now is the morning of the fifteenth day, Divali proper.
('1', 29, 3, 15, 72653) The greatest fireworks are let off on the Divali day.
('1', 29, 3, 16, 72707) No one is willing to part with his money on this day.
('1', 29, 3, 17, 72761) He will neither borrow nor lend.
('1', 29, 3, 18, 72794) All the purchases are supposed to have been finished the previous day.
('1', 29, 3, 19, 72865) You are standing near the corner of a public road.
('1', 29, 3, 20, 72916) Mark the shepherd trotting onward in his milk white suit, worn for the first time, with his long beard turned up beside his face and fastened under his turban, singing some broken verses.
('1', 29, 3, 21, 73104) A herd of cows, with their horns painted red and green and mounted with silver, follows him.
('1', 29, 3, 22, 73197) Soon after you see a crowd of little maids, with small earthen vessels resting on cushions placed on their heads.
('1', 29, 3, 23, 73311) You wonder what those vessels contain.
('1', 29, 3, 24, 73350) Your doubt is soon solved by that careless maid spilling some milk from her vessel.
('1', 29, 3, 25, 73434) Then observe that big man with white whiskers and a big white turban, with a long reed pen thrust into his turban.
('1', 29, 3, 26, 73549) He has a long scarf wound round his waist with a silver inkstand adjusted in the scarf.
('1', 29, 3, 27, 73637) He, you must know, is a great banker.
('1', 29, 3, 28, 73675) Thus you see different sorts of persons leisurely going along, full of joy and mirth.
('1', 30, 0, 1, 73761) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 31
('1', 30, 1, 2, 73794) The night comes.
('1', 30, 1, 3, 73811) The streets are resplendent with dazzling illumination; dazzling indeed to a person who has never seen Regent Street or Oxford Street, but by no means to be compared with the scale on which illuminations are carried out at the Crystal Palace, except in large towns like Bombay.
('1', 30, 1, 4, 74089) Men, women and children wear their best costumes, almost all of various colours, and so form a wonderfully bizarre effect, which harmonizes into kaleidoscopic beauty.
('1', 30, 1, 5, 74256) This is also the night for worshipping Saraswati, the goddess of learning.
('1', 30, 1, 6, 74331) Merchants start their new ledgers, by making the first entry.
('1', 30, 1, 7, 74393) The officiating priest, the ubiquitous Brahmin, mutters some prayers and invokes the goddess.
('1', 30, 1, 8, 74487) At the end of the worship, the children, who are only too impatient, set the fireworks ablaze; and as this worship generally takes place at a fixed time, the streets resound with the popping and fizzing and cracking of fireworks.
('1', 30, 1, 9, 74717) Pious people then go to the temples, but here too there is nothing to be seen but mirth and glee, dazzling light and splendour.
('1', 30, 1, 10, 74845) The following day, i.e., the new year's day, is the day of paying and receiving visits.
('1', 30, 1, 11, 74933) Kitchen fires are put out on this day, so that people eat the cold food which has been previously prepared.
('1', 30, 1, 12, 75041) But the glutton by no means starves, for there is such profusion that though he eats and eats again there is yet plenty and to spare.
('1', 30, 1, 13, 75175) Well to do classes buy and cook every sort of vegetables, corn and pulse, and taste them all on the new year's day.
('1', 30, 1, 14, 75291) The second day of the new year is comparatively a quiet day.
('1', 30, 1, 15, 75352) Kitchen fires are now re lighted.
('1', 30, 1, 16, 75386) Light food is generally taken after the heavy meals of the previous days.
('1', 30, 1, 17, 75460) There is no display of fireworks except by some mischievous children.
('1', 30, 1, 18, 75530) Illumination, too, is on a smaller scale.
('1', 30, 1, 19, 75572) With the second day the Divali holidays are practically over.
('1', 30, 1, 20, 75634) Let us see how these holidays affect society, and how many desirable things people do unwittingly.
('1', 30, 1, 21, 75733) Generally, all the family members try to meet together for the holidays at their chief place of residence.
('1', 30, 1, 22, 75840) The husband always tries to get home to his wife again, even though his business may have taken him away the whole of the previous year.
('1', 30, 1, 23, 75977) The father travels a great distance to meet his children.
('1', 30, 1, 24, 76035) The son, if abroad, comes back from his school and so a general reunion always takes place.
('1', 30, 1, 25, 76127) Then all who can afford it have new sets of clothes.
('1', 30, 1, 26, 76180) Among the richer classes ornaments, too, are ordered especially for the occasion.
('1', 30, 1, 27, 76262) Even old family quarrels are patched up.
('1', 31, 0, 1, 76303) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 32
('1', 31, 1, 2, 76344) At any rate a serious attempt is made to do so.
('1', 31, 1, 3, 76392) Houses are repaired and whitewashed.
('1', 31, 1, 4, 76429) Old furniture, which was lying packed up in a wooden case, is taken out, cleaned, and used for decorating the rooms for the time being.
('1', 31, 1, 5, 76565) Old debts, if any, are paid up wherever possible.
('1', 31, 1, 6, 76615) Everyone is supposed to buy some new thing, which almost always takes the form of a metallic vessel, or some such thing, for the new year's day.
('1', 31, 1, 7, 76760) Alms are freely given.
('1', 31, 1, 8, 76783) Persons not very careful about offering prayers or visiting temples are now doing both.
('1', 31, 1, 9, 76871) On holidays no one is to quarrel with or swear at any other—a pernicious habit very much in vogue, particularly among the lower classes.
('1', 31, 1, 10, 77008) In a word, everything is quiet and joyful.
('1', 31, 1, 11, 77051) Life, instead of being burdensome, is perfectly enjoyable.
('1', 31, 1, 12, 77110) It will be easily seen that good and far reaching consequences cannot fail to flow from such holidays, which some cry down as a relic of superstition and tomfoolery, though in reality they are a boon to mankind, and tend to relieve a great deal the dull monotony of life among the toiling millions.
('1', 31, 1, 13, 77409) Though the Divali holidays are common to the whole of India, the mode of observing them varies in point of details in different parts.
('1', 31, 1, 14, 77544) Moreover, this is but an imperfect description of the greatest festival of the Hindus.
('1', 31, 1, 15, 77631) And it must not be supposed that there is no abusing of the holidays.
('1', 31, 1, 16, 77701) Like every other thing, this festival, too, may have, and probably has, its black side, but that had better be left alone.
('1', 31, 1, 17, 77824) Certainly the good that it does far outweighs the evil.
('1', 31, 1, 18, 77880) The Vegetarian, 4 4 1891
('1', 31, 2, 19, 77905) 15. SOME INDIAN FESTIVALS III
('1', 31, 3, 20, 77935) Next in importance to the Divali holidays are the Holi holidays, which were alluded to in The Vegetarian of the 28th March.
('1', 31, 3, 21, 78059) Holi holidays, as will be remembered, correspond to Easter in point of time.
('1', 31, 3, 22, 78136) Holi takes place on the full moon day of the fifth month, Falgun, of the Hindu year.
('1', 31, 3, 23, 78221) This is just the springtime.
('1', 31, 3, 24, 78250) Trees are budding forth.
('1', 31, 3, 25, 78275) Warm clothes are put off.
('1', 31, 3, 26, 78301) Light clothes are the fashion.
('1', 31, 3, 27, 78332) That the spring has come is even more manifest when we have a peep at one of the temples.
('1', 31, 3, 28, 78422) The moment you enter a temple (and you must be a Hindu in order to gain admittance thereinto), you smell nothing but sweet flowers.
('1', 31, 3, 29, 78554) Pious persons are sitting on the steps, making garlands for Thakorji (God).
('1', 31, 3, 30, 78630) Among the flowers you see beautiful roses, chameli, moghra, etc.
('1', 31, 3, 31, 78695) When the doors are flung open
('1', 32, 0, 1, 78725) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 33
('1', 32, 1, 2, 78758) for darshan (literally, seeing), you observe the fountains in full play.
('1', 32, 1, 3, 78831) You enjoy soft and fragrant breezes.
('1', 32, 1, 4, 78868) Thakorji has worn light costumes of delicate shades.
('1', 32, 1, 5, 78921) Piles of flowers before him, and garlands round his neck, almost hide him from your view.
('1', 32, 1, 6, 79011) He is swung to and fro.
('1', 32, 1, 7, 79035) The swing, too, is covered with green leaves sprinkled with fragrant waters.
('1', 32, 1, 8, 79112) Outside the temple the sight is not edifying.
('1', 32, 1, 9, 79158) You here meet with nothing but obscene language during the fortnight preceding the Holi.
('1', 32, 1, 10, 79247) In small villages, it is difficult for ladies to appear without being bespattered with mud.
('1', 32, 1, 11, 79339) They are the subject of obscene remarks.
('1', 32, 1, 12, 79380) The same treatment is meted out to men without distinction.
('1', 32, 1, 13, 79440) People form themselves into small parties.
('1', 32, 1, 14, 79483) Then one party competes with another in using obscene language and singing obscene songs.
('1', 32, 1, 15, 79573) All persons— men and children, but not women—take part in these revolting contests.
('1', 32, 1, 16, 79657) Indeed, it is not considered bad taste to use obscene words during this season.
('1', 32, 1, 17, 79737) In places where people are steeped in ignorance they even pelt one another.
('1', 32, 1, 18, 79813) They paint obscene words on your clothes, and if you wear a white garment and go out, you are sure to return home with plenty of mud about you.
('1', 32, 1, 19, 79957) This reaches its climax on the Holi day.
('1', 32, 1, 20, 79998) Whether you are in the house or out of it, obscene words are jarring on your ears.
('1', 32, 1, 21, 80081) If you happen to visit a friend, you are sure to be bathed in foul water, or in fragrant water, as the case may be.
('1', 32, 1, 22, 80197) In the evening, a big pile of wood or dried cow dung is made and set on fire.
('1', 32, 1, 23, 80275) These piles are often as high as twenty feet or more.
('1', 32, 1, 24, 80329) And the pieces of wood used are so thick that the fire is not extinguished for seven or eight days.
('1', 32, 1, 25, 80429) On the day following, people heat water on these fires and bathe with it.
('1', 32, 1, 26, 80503) So far I have spoken of the way in which the Holi holidays are abused.
('1', 32, 1, 27, 80574) It is a relief to be able to say that with the progress of education and civilization such scenes are slowly, though surely, dying out.
('1', 32, 1, 28, 80710) But the richer and refined classes use these holidays in a very decent way.
('1', 32, 1, 29, 80786) Coloured water and fragrant waters take the place of mud.
('1', 32, 1, 30, 80844) Throwing pails of water is replaced here by a little sprinkling only.
('1', 32, 1, 31, 80914) Orange coloured water is most used during these days.
('1', 32, 1, 32, 80968) It is made by boiling dried flowers, called kesuda, which have the colour of an orange.
('1', 32, 1, 33, 81056) Rose water, too, is used where people can afford it.
('1', 32, 1, 34, 81109) Friends and relations meet and feast one another, and thus enjoy the spring in merriment.
('1', 32, 1, 35, 81199) In many respects, the Divali holidays present a beautiful contrast
('1', 33, 0, 1, 81266) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 34
('1', 33, 1, 2, 81307) to the, for the most part, unholy Holi holidays.
('1', 33, 1, 3, 81356) Divali holidays begin soon after the monsoon season which is also the time of fasting.
('1', 33, 1, 4, 81443) So the feasting during the Divali holidays is all the more enjoyable.
('1', 33, 1, 5, 81513) While the Holi holiday follow the winter which is the time for taking concentrated foods of all sorts, such foods are left off during the Holi holidays.
('1', 33, 1, 6, 81666) Obscene language of Holi follows the most sacred songs of the Divali.
('1', 33, 1, 7, 81736) Then again people begin to wear winter clothes in the Divali, while they put these off in the Holi.
('1', 33, 1, 8, 81836) The Divali proper takes place on the fifteenth day of the dark half of the month Ashwin and consequently there is much illumination; while on account of the Holi taking place on the full moon day, illumination would be out of place.

('1', 33, 2, 10, 82095) 16. THE FOODS OF INDIA 1
('1', 33, 3, 11, 82120) Before I proceed to the subject of my address I should like to tell you what are my qualifications for undertaking the task.
('1', 33, 3, 12, 82245) When Mill wrote the History of India, he, in his most interesting preface, pointed out how he was qualified to write the book, though he had never been to India, and was ignorant of the Indian languages.
('1', 33, 3, 13, 82449) So I think that in following his example, I shall be doing just what I ought to do.
('1', 33, 3, 14, 82533) Of course, the very idea of referring to one's qualifications for any task argues some sort of unfitness on the part of the speaker or writer, and I confess that I am not the person to speak upon the “Foods of India”.
('1', 33, 3, 15, 82751) I have undertaken the task not because I am thoroughly competent to speak on the subject but because I thought I would thereby be doing a service to the cause that both you and I have at heart.
('1', 33, 3, 16, 82945) My remarks are chiefly derived from my experience of the Bombay Presidency.
('1', 33, 3, 17, 83021) Now, as you know, India is a vast peninsula populated by two hundred and eighty five million souls.
('1', 33, 3, 18, 83121) It is as large as Europe less Russia.
('1', 33, 3, 19, 83159) In such a country, the customs and manners in different parts must be necessarily different.
('1', 33, 3, 20, 83252) So, if in future you hear anything different from what I am going to say, I request you to bear in mind the above fact.
('1', 33, 3, 21, 83372) As a general rule, my remarks will apply to the whole of India.
('1', 33, 3, 22, 83436) I shall divide the subject into three parts.
('1', 33, 3, 23, 83481) In the first place I shall say something, by way of preliminary, about the people who live upon the foods; secondly, I shall describe the foods; and thirdly, their uses, etc.
('1', 34, 0, 1, 83656) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 35
('1', 34, 1, 2, 83689) It is commonly believed that all the inhabitants of India are vegetarians, but this is not true; and for that matter even all the Hindus are not vegetarians.
('1', 34, 1, 3, 83847) But it is quite true to say that the great majority of the inhabitants of India are vegetarians 1. Some of them are so because of their religion, while others are compelled to live on vegetable foods because they cannot afford to pay for meat.
('1', 34, 1, 4, 84091) This will be quite clear to you when I tell you that there are millions in India who live upon one pice i.e., one third of a penny a day, and even in a poverty stricken country like India you cannot get eatable meat for that sum.
('1', 34, 1, 5, 84321) These poor people have only one meal per day, and that consists of stale bread and salt, a heavily taxed article.
('1', 34, 1, 6, 84435) But Indian vegetarians and meat eaters are quite different from English vegetarians and meat eaters.
('1', 34, 1, 7, 84536) Indian meat eaters, unlike English meat eaters, do not believe that they will die without meat.
('1', 34, 1, 8, 84632) So far as my knowledge goes, they (the Indian meat eaters) do not consider meat a necessity of life but a mere luxury.
('1', 34, 1, 9, 84751) If they can get their roti, as bread is generally called there, they get on very well without their meat.
('1', 34, 1, 10, 84857) But look at our English meat eater; he thinks that he must have his meat.
('1', 34, 1, 11, 84931) Bread simply helps him to eat meat, while the Indian meat eater thinks that meat will help him to eat his bread.
('1', 34, 1, 12, 85044) I was talking the other day to an English lady on the ethics of diet, and she exclaimed, while I was telling her how even she could easily become a vegetarian, “Say what you will, I must have my meat, I am so fond of it, and am positively sure I cannot live without it.” “But, madam,” I said, “suppose that you were compelled to live on a strictly vegetable diet, how would you manage then?” “Oh,” she said, “don't talk of that.
('1', 34, 1, 13, 85473) I know I could not be compelled to do so, and if I were I should feel very uncomfortable.” Of course, no one can blame the lady for so saying.
('1', 34, 1, 14, 85616) Society is in such a position for the present that it is impossible for any meat eater to leave off eating meat without much difficulty.
('1', 34, 1, 15, 85753) In the same manner, an Indian vegetarian is quite different from an English one.
('1', 34, 1, 16, 85834) The former simply abstains from anything that

('1', 35, 1, 8, 87054) I must say that I shall not dwell upon the flesh foods at all, as these, even where they are used, do not form the staple article of food.

('1', 36, 1, 16, 90505) The soil of India is so rich that it can produce any vegetable you like.

('1', 37, 1, 13, 92895) Now, before I come to the last division of my subject, I should request you to bear in mind the following divisions that I have made: first, corn for bread making, e.g., wheat, millet, etc.; second, pulse, for dal or soup making; third, green vegetables; fourth, fruits; and, fifth and last, nuts.

('1', 37, 1, 17, 93389) Diet cure or hygiene is a comparatively recent discovery in England.

('1', 37, 1, 24, 94100) These cakes are always fresh made, and generally eaten hot with clarified butter.

('1', 38, 1, 2, 94590) Pulse for soup making, e.g., peas, lentils, etc., is prepared by simply boiling it in water.

('1', 39, 1, 2, 97131) giving, and therefore in winter, when we take concentrated foods, we prepare them with milk and various other things too numerous to be mentioned, and eat an ounce every day.

('1', 48, 6, 14, 120118) 22. ON WAY HOME TO INDIA I
('1', 48, 7, 15, 120145) It was on the 12th June, 1891, that I left for Bombay after three years' stay in England.
('1', 48, 7, 16, 120235) A beautiful day it was: the sun shone brilliantly; no overcoat was needed to keep off the cold breezes.
('1', 48, 7, 17, 120339) It was at 11.45 that an express train carrying the passengers left the Liverpool Street Station for the docks.
('1', 49, 0, 1, 120450) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 50
('1', 49, 1, 2, 120491) I could not make myself believe that I was going to India until I stepped into the steamship Oceana, of the P. & O. Company.
('1', 49, 1, 3, 120616) So much attached was I to London and its environments for who would not be?
('1', 49, 1, 4, 120692) London with its teaching institutions, public galleries, museums, theatres, vast commerce, public parks and vegetarian restaurants, is a fit place for a student and a traveller, a trader and a “addist”—as a vegetarian would be called by his opponents.
('1', 49, 1, 5, 120944) Thus, it was not without deep regret that I left dear London.
('1', 49, 1, 6, 121006) At the same time I was glad because I was to see my friends and relations in India after such a long time.
('1', 49, 1, 7, 121113) Oceana is an Australian steamer, one of the largest boats of the Company.
('1', 49, 1, 8, 121187) She weighs 6,188 tons and her horse power is 1,200. When we stepped into this vast floating island, we were treated to a good refreshing tea, to which all (passengers and friends alike) did justice.
('1', 49, 1, 9, 121386) I must not omit to say that the tea was served gratis.
('1', 49, 1, 10, 121441) At this time, a stranger would have taken them all for passengers (and they were a goodly number), from the ease with which they were taking their tea; but, when the bell rang to inform the friends of the passengers that the ship was going to weigh anchor, the number appreciably melted away.
('1', 49, 1, 11, 121734) There was much cheering and waving of handkerchiefs when the ship steamed off the harbour.
('1', 49, 1, 12, 121825) It may be well here to contrast the Oceana with the Assam into which the Bombay bound passengers had to transship at Aden.
('1', 49, 1, 13, 121948) There were English waiters on the Oceana, always neat, clean and obliging.
('1', 49, 1, 14, 122023) On the other hand, there were Portuguese waiters on board the Assam, who murdered the Queen's English, and who were always the reverse of clean, and also sulky and slow.
('1', 49, 1, 15, 122193) There was, moreover, a difference of quality in the food supplied in the two steamers.
('1', 49, 1, 16, 122280) This was evident from the way in which the passengers were grumbling in the Assam.
('1', 49, 1, 17, 122363) Nor was this all.
('1', 49, 1, 18, 122381) The accommodation in the Oceana far outdid that in the Assam; this, however, the company could not help; they could not throw away the latter because the former was better.
('1', 49, 1, 19, 122554) How did the vegetarians manage in the ship?
('1', 49, 1, 20, 122598) This would be an apt question.
('1', 49, 1, 21, 122629) Well, there were only two vegetarians, including myself.
('1', 49, 1, 22, 122686) Both of us were prepared, in case we did not get anything better, to manage with boiled potatoes, cabbage and butter.
('1', 49, 1, 23, 122804) But we had no reason to go to that extreme.
('1', 49, 1, 24, 122848) The obliging steward gave us some vegetable curry,
('1', 50, 0, 1, 122899) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 51
('1', 50, 1, 2, 122932) rice, stewed and fresh fruit from the first saloon, and last, but not least, brown bread; so we had all we wanted.
('1', 50, 1, 3, 123047) Undoubtedly, they are very liberal in giving good and sufficient food to the passengers.
('1', 50, 1, 4, 123136) Only, they go too far; so at least it seems to me.
('1', 50, 1, 5, 123187) It would not be amiss to describe what the second saloon menus contained, and how many meals the passengers had.
('1', 50, 1, 6, 123300) To begin with, the first thing in the morning, an average passenger would have a cup or two of tea and a few biscuits.
('1', 50, 1, 7, 123419) At 8.30 a.m.
('1', 50, 1, 8, 123432) the breakfast bell would bring down the passengers to the dining room.
('1', 50, 1, 9, 123503) They were punctual to the minute, at their meals, at any rate.
('1', 50, 1, 10, 123566) The breakfast menu generally contained oatmeal porridge, some fish, chop, curry, jam, bread and butter, tea or coffee, etc., everything ad libitum.
('1', 50, 1, 11, 123714) I have often seen passengers take porridge, fish and curry, bread and butter, and wash down with two or three cups of tea.
('1', 50, 1, 12, 123837) Hardly had we time to digest the breakfast, when, bang, it was the dinner bell at 1.30 p.m.
('1', 50, 1, 13, 123929) The dinner was as good as breakfast: plenty of mutton and vegetables, rice and curry, pastry, and what not.
('1', 50, 1, 14, 124037) Two days of the week, all the second saloon passengers were served with fruit and nuts in addition to the ordinary dinner.
('1', 50, 1, 15, 124160) But this, too, was not sufficient.
('1', 50, 1, 16, 124195) The dinner fare was so easily digestible that we wanted a “refreshing” cup of tea and biscuits at 4 p.m.
('1', 50, 1, 17, 124300) Well, but the evening breezes seemed so soon to take away all the effect of “that little” cup of tea that we were served a “high tea” at 6.30 p.m.: bread and butter, jam or marmalade, or both, salad, chops, tea, coffee, etc.
('1', 50, 1, 18, 124525) The sea air seemed to be so very salubrious that the passengers could not retire to bed before taking a few, a very few—only eight or ten, fifteen at the most—biscuits, a little cheese and some wine or beer.
('1', 50, 1, 19, 124733) In the light of the above, are not the following lines too true:
('1', 50, 2, 20, 124798) Your belly is your God, your stomach is your temple, your paunch is your altar, your cook is your priest.
('1', 50, 2, 21, 124904) It is in the cooking pots that your love is inflamed, it is in the kitchen that your faith grows fervid, it is in the flesh dishes that all hope lies hid.
('1', 50, 2, 22, 125059) Who is held in so much esteem with you as the frequent giver of dinners, as the sumptuous entertainer, as the practised toaster of health?
('1', 50, 2, 23, 125198) The second saloon was pretty full of passengers of all sorts.
('1', 50, 2, 24, 125260) There were soldiers, clergymen, barbers, sailors, students, officials and, maybe, adventurers.
('1', 50, 2, 25, 125355) There were three or four ladies.
('1', 50, 2, 26, 125388) We beguiled our time chiefly in eating and drinking.
('1', 50, 2, 27, 125441) The rest of the time was either

('1', 51, 1, 2, 125514) dozed away or passed in chatting, at times in discussing, in playing games, etc.
('1', 51, 1, 3, 125595) But after two or three days, the time between the meals seemed to hang heavy in spite of discussions and cards and scandals.
('1', 51, 1, 4, 125720) Some of us really warmed to the work and got up concerts, tugs of war, and running races for prizes.
('1', 51, 1, 5, 125821) One evening was devoted to concerts and speeches.
('1', 51, 1, 6, 125871) Now, I thought it was time for me to poke my nose in.
('1', 51, 1, 7, 125925) I requested the secretary of the committee, who managed those things, to give me a quarter of an hour for a short speech on vegetarianism.
('1', 51, 1, 8, 126064) The secretary obligingly nodded consent to my request.
('1', 51, 1, 9, 126119) Well, I made grand preparations.
('1', 51, 1, 10, 126152) I thought out and then wrote out and re wrote the speech that was to be delivered.
('1', 51, 1, 11, 126235) I well knew that I had to meet a hostile audience, and that I should take care that my speech did not send my audience to sleep.
('1', 51, 1, 12, 126364) The secretary had asked me to be humorous.
('1', 51, 1, 13, 126407) I told him that I might be nervous, but humorous I could not be.
('1', 51, 1, 14, 126472) Now, what do you think became of the speech?
('1', 51, 1, 15, 126517) The second concert never came off, and so the speech was never delivered, to my great mortification.
('1', 51, 1, 16, 126618) I fancy it was because no one seemed to enjoy the first evening, for we had no Pitts and Gladstones in the second saloon.
('1', 51, 1, 17, 126740) However, I succeeded in discussing vegetarianism with two or three passengers, who heard me calmly, and answered in effect, “We grant you the argument; but so long as we feel happy on our present diet (never mind about our being dyspeptic at times), we cannot give it a trial!” One of them, seeing that my vegetarian friend and I got nice fruits every day, did give the V.E.M. diet a trial, but the chop was too great a temptation for him.
('1', 51, 1, 18, 127180) Poor man!

('1', 51, 3, 21, 127243) Moreover, as an instance of affability between passengers and of politeness on the part of the first saloon passengers, the second saloon passengers were often invited to witness the theatricals and dances that they got up from time to time.
('1', 51, 3, 22, 127485) They had some very nice ladies and gentlemen in the first

('1', 52, 1, 2, 127576) saloon.
('1', 52, 1, 3, 127584) But it would not do to have all play and no quarrel, so some of the passengers thought fit to get drunk (beg your pardon, Mr. Editor, they got drunk almost every evening, but this particular evening they got drunk and disorderly).
('1', 52, 1, 4, 127815) They, it seems, were discussing with one another over a glass of whisky, when some of them used improper language.

('1', 52, 1, 6, 127994) The matter was reported to the captain.
('1', 52, 1, 7, 128034) He reproved these pugilistic gentlemen, and ever since then we had no more rows.
('1', 52, 1, 8, 128115) Thus, dividing our time between eating and amusements, we moved onward.
('1', 52, 1, 9, 128187) After two days' voyage, the steamer passed by, but did not touch, Gibraltar.
('1', 52, 1, 10, 128264) This caused much disappointment, mostly among smokers, who wanted to get tobacco, duty free in Gibraltar, as some of us had entertained a hope the steamer would cast anchor.
('1', 52, 1, 11, 128438) The next place reached was Malta.
('1', 52, 1, 12, 128472) It being a coaling station, the steamer stops there for about nine hours.
('1', 52, 1, 13, 128546) Almost all the passengers went ashore.
('1', 52, 1, 14, 128585) Malta is a beautiful island without the London smoke.
('1', 52, 1, 15, 128639) The construction of houses is different.
('1', 52, 1, 16, 128680) We had a look round the Governor's palace.
('1', 52, 1, 17, 128723) The armoury is well worth a visit.
('1', 52, 1, 18, 128758) Napoleon's carriage is on view there.
('1', 52, 1, 19, 128796) You see there some beautiful paintings too.
('1', 52, 1, 20, 128840) The market is not bad.
('1', 52, 1, 21, 128863) The fruit is cheap.
('1', 52, 1, 22, 128883) The cathedral is magnificent.

('1', 52, 1, 24, 128974) There you see some thousands of orange trees and some ponds with gold fish.
('1', 52, 1, 25, 129050) The drive was very cheap, only 2s.
('1', 52, 1, 26, 129085) What a wretched place Malta is for beggars!
('1', 52, 1, 27, 129129) You cannot go along the road quietly without being pestered by a crowd of dirty looking beggars.
('1', 52, 1, 28, 129226) Some would offer to be your guides, others would offer to take you to shops where you could buy cigars or the famous Maltese sweet nougat.
('1', 52, 1, 29, 129365) From Malta we reached Brindisi.
('1', 52, 1, 30, 129397) It is a good harbour and that is all.
('1', 52, 1, 31, 129435) You cannot pass a single day in amusement.
('1', 52, 1, 32, 129478) We had about nine hours or more at our disposal, but we could not utilize even four.
('1', 52, 1, 33, 129563) After Brindisi we reached Port Said.
('1', 52, 1, 34, 129600) There we took final leave of Europe and the Mediterranean.
('1', 52, 1, 35, 129659) Of course, there is nothing to be seen in Port Said, unless you want to see the dregs of society.
('1', 52, 1, 36, 129757) It is full of rogues and rascals.

('1', 53, 1, 2, 129832) From Port Said the steamer moves along very slowly, for we enter the Suez Canal of M. de Lesseps.
('1', 53, 1, 3, 129930) It is a distance of eighty seven miles.
('1', 53, 1, 4, 129970) The steamer took nearly twenty four hours to travel that distance.
('1', 53, 1, 5, 130037) We were close to the land on both sides.
('1', 53, 1, 6, 130078) The strip of water is so narrow that two steamers cannot go abreast except at certain places.
('1', 53, 1, 7, 130172) At night the sight is charming.
('1', 53, 1, 8, 130204) All the ships are required to light electric lights in front and these are very powerful.
('1', 53, 1, 9, 130294) The scene when two ships pass one another is very pleasant.

('1', 53, 1, 25, 131242) The Indian Ocean is generally calm, so during monsoon it is stormy with a vengeance.

('1', 53, 1, 38, 131787) Your forks and spoons are in your lap, even the cruet stand and the soup plate; your napkin is dyed yellow and so on.
('1', 53, 1, 39, 131905) One morning I asked the steward if that was what he would call a real storm, and he said: “No, sir, this is nothing.” and, waving his arm, showed me how the steamer would roll in a real storm.

('1', 53, 1, 41, 132154) It was raining very hard and so it was difficult going ashore.
('1', 53, 1, 42, 132217) However, we reached the shore safely, and bade good bye to the Assam.

('1', 54, 4, 15, 133190) He thinks that I need not despair of getting a decent livelihood in Kathiawar1 and that without directly taking part in the khutput 2. However this may be, since he is so hopeful and is entitled to every consideration from me, I shall follow his advice.
('1', 54, 4, 16, 133444) Here, too, I have been promised some work.
('1', 54, 4, 17, 133487) So I intend to be here for about two months at least.
('1', 54, 4, 18, 133541) I do not think my accepting a literary post will materially interfere with my legal studies.
('1', 54, 4, 19, 133634) On the other hand, such a work will add to my knowledge that cannot but be indirectly useful in practice.

('1', 54, 4, 22, 133869) Of course, I asked for a loan on the strength of the promise you made me while at Rajkot.
('1', 54, 4, 23, 133959) I entirely agree with you that your father should not know of it.

('1', 54, 4, 27, 134165) My brother has been retained in Sachin as Secretary to the Nawab of Sachin.
('1', 54, 4, 28, 134241) He has gone to Rajkot and will return in a few days.

('1', 55, 2, 13, 135369) 25. LETTER TO “THE NATAL ADVERTISER”
('1', 55, 3, 14, 135406) DURBAN, May 26, 1893
('1', 55, 4, 15, 135427) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Advertiser
('1', 55, 5, 16, 135462) SIR, I was startled to read a paragraph in your today's issue referring to myself, under the heading, “An Unwelcome Visitor”.
('1', 55, 5, 17, 135588) 2 I am very
('1', 55, 6, 18, 135600) 1 Administrator.
('1', 55, 6, 19, 135617) 2 The reference was as follows: "An Indian entered the Court House yesterday afternoon and took a seat at the horseshoe.
('1', 55, 6, 20, 135738) He was well dressed and it was understood that he was an English barrister, on his way to Pretoria, where he is reported to be engaged in an Indian case.
('1', 55, 6, 21, 135892) He entered the Court without removing his head covering or salaaming, and the Magistrate looked at him with disapproval.
('1', 55, 6, 22, 136013) The new arrival was courteously asked his business, and he replied that he was an English barrister.
('1', 55, 6, 23, 136114) He did not attempt to present his credentials, and, on returning to the horseshoe was quietly told that the proper course for him to pursue, before taking up his position at the Bar, was to gain admission to the Supreme Court." The incident was reported in The Natal Mercury, 26 5 1893.
('1', 56, 0, 1, 136401) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 57
('1', 56, 1, 2, 136434) sorry if His Worship the Magistrate looked at me with disapproval.
('1', 56, 1, 3, 136501) It is true that on entering the Court I neither removed my head dress nor salaamed, but in so doing I had not the slightest idea that I was offending His Worship, or meaning any disrespect to the Court.
('1', 56, 1, 4, 136704) Just as it is a mark of respect amongst the Europeans to take off their hats, in like manner it is in Indians to retain one's head dress.
('1', 56, 1, 5, 136842) To appear uncovered before a gentleman is not to respect him.
('1', 56, 1, 6, 136904) In England, on attending drawing room meetings and evening parties, Indians always keep the head dress, and the English ladies and gentlemen generally seem to appreciate the regard which we show thereby.
('1', 56, 1, 7, 137108) In High Courts in India those Indian advocates who have not discarded their native head dress invariably keep it on.
('1', 56, 1, 8, 137225) As to bowing, or salaaming as you would call it, I again followed the rule observed in the Bombay High Court.
('1', 56, 1, 9, 137335) If an advocate enters the Court after the judge has taken his seat on the bench he does not bow, but all the advocates rise up when the judge enters the Court, and keep standing until the judge has taken his seat.
('1', 56, 1, 10, 137549) Accordingly, yesterday when His Worship entered the Court I rose up, and took my seat only after His Worship had done so.
('1', 56, 1, 11, 137671) The paragraph seems to convey also that though I was told privately not to keep my seat at the horseshoe, I nevertheless “returned to the horseshoe”.
('1', 56, 1, 12, 137821) The truth is that I was taken by the chief clerk to the interpreters' room, and was asked not to take my seat at the horseshoe the next time I came unless I produced my credentials.
('1', 56, 1, 13, 138003) To make assurance doubly sure I asked the chief clerk if I could retain my seat for the day, and he very kindly said “yes”.
('1', 56, 1, 14, 138127) I was therefore really surprised to be told again in open court that in order to be entitled to the seat I had to produce credentials, etc.
('1', 56, 1, 15, 138267) Lastly, I beg His Worship's pardon if he was offended at what he considered to be my rudeness, which was the result of ignorance and quite unintentional.
('1', 56, 1, 16, 138421) I hope, in fairness, you will extend me the favour of finding the above explanation a space in your paper, as the paragraph, if unexplained, would be likely to do me harm.
('1', 56, 1, 17, 138593) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Natal Advertiser, 29 5 1893
('1', 57, 0, 1, 138650) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 58
('1', 57, 1, 2, 138691) 26. LETTER TO “THE NATAL ADVERTISER”
('1', 57, 2, 3, 138728) PRETORIA, September 16, 1893
('1', 57, 3, 4, 138757) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Advertiser
