('1', 61, 4, 5, 146970) SIR, I have to request your indulgence for inserting the following in your paper: To make an exhaustive reply to the programme set forth by you for the would be anti Asiatic league in your issue of the 19th inst.
('1', 61, 4, 6, 147183) is a Herculean task, and it cannot be undertaken in the compass of a letter to a newspaper.
('1', 61, 4, 7, 147275) I would, however, with your permission, take up only two items.
('1', 61, 4, 8, 147339) viz., the fears about “the coolie vote swamping the European vote”, and the supposed unfitness of the Indians to vote.
('1', 61, 4, 9, 147458) At the outset, I would appeal to your good sense, and the love of fair play which is supposed to be a characteristic of the British nation.
('1', 61, 4, 10, 147598) No amount of facts or arguments would convince you or your readers of the justness of my remarks if you or they are resolved upon looking at one side only of the question.
('1', 61, 4, 11, 147770) Cool judgment and a dispassionate and impartial enquiry are essential to a right view of the whole matter.
('1', 61, 4, 12, 147877) Does it not appear a far fetched view that the Indian vote can ever swamp the European vote?
('1', 61, 4, 13, 147970) A mere superficial observer can see that such a thing can never happen.
('1', 61, 4, 14, 148042) A sufficient number can never command the property qualifications to be able to outdo the European vote.
('1', 61, 4, 15, 148147) They are divided into two classes—the traders and the labourers.
('1', 61, 4, 16, 148212) The latter are by far in the majority, and have no votes as a rule.
('1', 61, 4, 17, 148280) Poverty stricken, they come to Natal on starvation wages.
('1', 61, 4, 18, 148338) Can they ever dream of having enough property to qualify themselves for voting?
('1', 61, 4, 19, 148418) And these are they who live here with any degree of permanence.
('1', 61, 4, 20, 148482) Some only of the former class have the property qualifications; but then they do not live permanently in Natal, and many of those who can legally vote would never care to do so.
('1', 61, 4, 21, 148660) The Indians as a class never, even in their own country, avail themselves of all their political rights.
('1', 61, 4, 22, 148765) They are too much taken up with their
('1', 62, 0, 1, 148803) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 63
('1', 62, 1, 2, 148836) spiritual well being to think of taking an active part in politics.
('1', 62, 1, 3, 148904) They have no great political aspirations.
('1', 62, 1, 4, 148946) They come not to be politicians, but to earn an honest bread, and it is a matter for regret if some do not earn it strictly honestly.
('1', 62, 1, 5, 149080) So, then, it seems that all the fears about the Indian vote assuming portentous proportions are ill grounded.
('1', 62, 1, 6, 149190) And even the few votes that the Indians command cannot in any way affect Natal politics.
('1', 62, 1, 7, 149279) All talk about an Indian party clamouring for Indian representation seems to be chimerical, for the selection would always be between two White men.
('1', 62, 1, 8, 149428) Would it, then, matter much that there are some Indian votes?
('1', 62, 1, 9, 149490) The most the few votes can do will be to secure them a perfectly White gentleman, who would, if he is faithful to his promise, do them good service in the Assembly.
('1', 62, 1, 10, 149655) And fancy one or two such members making up an Indian party!
('1', 62, 1, 11, 149716) Why, they, or rather he, would be a veritable John 1 crying in the wilderness without his electric, and perhaps I should say divine, power of converting.

('1', 62, 1, 17, 150429) It is impossible to enter into a full discussion of all the questions suggested by an enquiry into the matter.
('1', 62, 1, 18, 150540) I may, however, be allowed to point out that they enjoy these privileges in India.
('1', 62, 1, 19, 150623) The Queen’s Proclamation of 1858—which is justly and rightly called the Magna Charta of the Indians—runs :
('1', 62, 2, 20, 150730) We hold ourselves bound to the natives of our Indian territories by the same obligations of duty which bind us to all our other subjects, and these obligations by the blessing of Almighty God, we shall faithfully and conscientiously fulfil.
('1', 62, 2, 21, 150971) It is our further will that, so far as may be, our subjects, of whatever race or creed, be freely and impartially admitted to offices in our service, the duties of which they may be qualified by their education, ability, and integrity, duly to discharge.

('1', 64, 4, 12, 154372) Some of them have published books describing with much effect what is to be seen

('1', 66, 2, 8, 159295) CHAPTER 1
('1', 66, 3, 9, 159305) WHO SHOULD GO TO ENGLAND?
('1', 66, 3, 10, 159331) It may be laid down broadly that all who can afford should go to England.
('1', 66, 3, 11, 159405) Of course, here the meaning of the word ‘afford’ should be understood in its widest sense.
('1', 66, 3, 12, 159496) Thus some cannot go to England because they cannot afford the money, some cannot afford through ill health, others cannot owing to young age and various other objections.
('1', 66, 3, 13, 159667) All these will be briefly discussed in the following paragraphs.
('1', 66, 3, 14, 159732) The first and the foremost question is the question of health.
('1', 66, 3, 15, 159795) No one with a weak chest or a tendency to consumption should ever think of going to England.
('1', 66, 3, 16, 159888) It will simply mean going to England in order to court death away from friends and relations.
('1', 66, 3, 17, 159982) It is true that you can go to the south of Europe not only without injury to the constitution but with benefit to it; thus you can go to the Riviera and be cured of consumption.
('1', 66, 3, 18, 160160) Thousands of consumptive persons annually flock there to be cured of the fell disease.
('1', 66, 3, 19, 160247) It is supposed to be one of the finest places for persons with weak chests; but all this means a great outlay of money.
('1', 66, 3, 20, 160367) And then again the book is not written for invalids so that they may get cured by following the instructions therein contained.
('1', 66, 3, 21, 160495) It is written for those with a good health who want to learn and be useful.
('1', 66, 3, 22, 160571) Moreover it is for those who would go to England.
('1', 66, 3, 23, 160621) It is true also that a person with a generally weak health might take a trip to England during the summer season without coming to much or any harm.
('1', 66, 3, 24, 160770) Still, if I can venture to give an opinion, I should say that those with any chest disease whatever should never think of going to
('1', 67, 0, 1, 160901) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 68
('1', 67, 1, 2, 160942) England except under special circumstances and conditions.
('1', 67, 1, 3, 161001) On the other hand, persons suffering from any disease due to a warm climate can do worse than going to England.
('1', 67, 1, 4, 161113) I used to suffer from headaches and nose bleeding in India.

('1', 77, 1, 13, 184141) It takes nearly 22 days by the P & O boats to reach London and 13 days to reach Brindisi, whence London is reached in 2 days by rail.
('1', 77, 1, 14, 184275) It seems that it is much better to take the sea route throughout.
('1', 77, 1, 15, 184341) Thereby all the inconveniences of removing luggage and having it examined, etc., are avoided and all the comforts to be found in P & O boats are enjoyed for a longer time.

('1', 80, 1, 2, 190946) Having landed in London, where to go seems to present some difficulty.

('1', 81, 1, 2, 193248) most inviting and yet most repulsive.

('1', 81, 1, 4, 193353) Every man would furnish his own estimates, thinking at the same time that no other estimates could be true and, if true, possible for everyone.
('1', 81, 1, 5, 193497) That again is the question which is the most important, especially, to a man of ordinary circumstances.

('1', 81, 1, 7, 193844) It is moreover true that the ordinary estimates quoted are from 10 to 20 pounds per month.
('1', 81, 1, 8, 193935) Living on £10 per month was pronounced to be very economical.
('1', 81, 1, 9, 193997) With such estimates to say that one can live comfortably on £4 a month or £1 a week could be a heresay: Nevertheless, it is a fact beyond doubt, as shall be proved just now, that it is possible to live on one pound a week and that many have lived on less.
('1', 81, 1, 10, 194253) I may say that I have tried the experiment successfully and was never happier than under the £4 living.

('1', 81, 1, 13, 194452) A) how, from £12 per month, I gradually came down to £4 per month.
('1', 81, 1, 14, 194519) First of all, I shall consider the cost of lodgings.
('1', 81, 1, 15, 194572) It is commonly supposed that a student should have two rooms, one bed room and one sitting room.
('1', 81, 1, 16, 194669) Now this is quite useless except to show, that you are very rich and can afford to spend any amount of money.
('1', 81, 1, 17, 194779) This guide is not written for those who would make a show very often false, of their riches.
('1', 81, 1, 18, 194872) It is written for those who would live a regular student's life, as economical as possible.
('1', 81, 1, 19, 194964) There are many professional gentlemen bachelors living in one room only.
('1', 81, 1, 20, 195037) Of course, there are many Indian students and thousands of English students living in one room only.
('1', 81, 1, 21, 195138) Two rooms are more for families than for students.
('1', 81, 1, 22, 195189) Then if you have one room only with the necessary furniture in a good quarter, it can be had for 7s per week and less.

('1', 81, 1, 26, 195547) In such a room you would find a table, three or four chairs, an easy chair, a wash stand with all the requisites, a hearth, a chest of drawers, probably a book case, cupboard, a carpet, a bedstead with bed sheets and blankets, a looking glass, etc.

('1', 82, 1, 4, 196103) It is always best to find out a room in the neighbourhood of a place to be frequented most by you.

('1', 82, 1, 6, 196280) Secondly, as to other expenses, e.g., washing, bathing, etc.
('1', 82, 1, 7, 196341) Your washerman's bill need not amount to more than 11 pence per week, which is as follows: d 1 Flannel shirt 2 1 Drawers 2 1 Vest 2 2 Handkerchiefs 1 1 Sleeping suit 4
('1', 82, 2, 8, 196509) Total 11 d A saving can be effected in the above if you do not use the drawers which you need not, in summer especially.

('1', 82, 2, 18, 197467) You can pour water into your basin, dip a sponge in it and rub hard with the sponge twice or thrice and then rub the body with a dry towel, and you have taken a very nice bath which gives a glow to the body and keeps it clean.

('1', 84, 1, 16, 201833) Passing now from this comparatively incontestable part of the question of the cost of living, we reach the most important and contestable part of the question, viz., the cost of food.
('1', 84, 1, 17, 202017) There is so much to be said on this part of the subject, so much prejudice and misunderstanding to be removed that to treat the subject fully would require a separate and larger book.
('1', 85, 0, 1, 202201) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 86
('1', 85, 1, 2, 202242) How to get good, nutritious, healthy and palatable food for 9s per week is the question before us.
('1', 85, 1, 3, 202341) At the outset I may say that those only can live on that sum who “eat to live”, not “live to eat”.
('1', 85, 1, 4, 202440) If you must have the luxuries, if you cannot sit at the table without company, if you must entertain friends pretty frequently to sumptuous dinners, if you must live like a gourmand, then for you ten times the sum may not be sufficient.

('1', 103, 1, 3, 244401) In Lincoln's Inn, those who have passed public examination only in the British Dominions are exempted from that payment.

('1', 103, 1, 5, 244581) Such information can be had directly by writing to the treasurers of the respective Inns of which there are four, viz., Inner Temple, Middle Temple, Lincoln's Inn and Gray's Inn.
('1', 103, 1, 6, 244760) Perhaps, from an economic point of view, Lincoln's Inn is the best Inn, which boasts also the best library.
('1', 103, 1, 7, 244868) Middle Temple is the most patronized by the Indians.
('1', 103, 1, 8, 244921) From the education point of view, all the Inns are equal because they have a common examination.
('1', 103, 1, 9, 245018) Middle Temple pays the scholarships in cash, the Inner Temple makes you join chambers and pays for them.
('1', 103, 1, 10, 245123) One has to keep twelve terms before being called to the bar.
('1', 103, 1, 11, 245184) There are four terms every year, the 1st in January, the 2nd in April, the 3rd in June and 4th in November.
('1', 103, 1, 12, 245292) The shortest term lasts 20 days and the longest about 31 days.
('1', 103, 1, 13, 245355) Keeping terms means taking dinners in the respective Inns to which you belong; you have not necessarily to take your dinner but you must go to the dining hall punctually at the appointed time and sit there for one hour.
('1', 103, 1, 14, 245575) You are said to have kept one term when you have attended six dinners in the term.
('1', 103, 1, 15, 245658) Those who belong to a university have to attend only three dinners.
('1', 103, 1, 16, 245726) These dinners, whether partaken of or not, have to be paid for Inner Temple charges 31/2s per dinner, Middle Temple 2s.
('1', 103, 1, 17, 245846) Thus you make a saving of 11/2s every dinner by joining the Middle Temple.
('1', 103, 1, 18, 245921) And such dinners have to be taken 12 times in all.
('1', 103, 1, 19, 245972) Lincoln's Inn and Gray's Inn, too, charge most probably 2s.
('1', 103, 1, 20, 246032) If you pay for the dinners and if you have no religious objection, why should you not take your dinner, one may pertinently ask?
('1', 103, 1, 21, 246161) The answer is you ought to dine, but, then, a further question arises as to what a vegetarian should do.
('1', 103, 1, 22, 246266) Well, you can have ordinarily bread and vegetables and cheese, but you can have a better vegetarian dinner specially prepared for you by applying to the chief steward of the Inn or, if need be, the sub treasurer of your Inn.
('1', 103, 1, 23, 246491) A Parsi friend who had turned a vegetarian and I used to get our vegetarian dinners specially prepared.

('1', 104, 1, 3, 246778) To be fit for being called to the Bar at the end of 12 terms, two examinations must be passed, one in Roman Law and the other in the English Laws.
('1', 104, 1, 4, 246925) A student can appear in the Roman Law examination after—but not before—keeping four terms.
('1', 104, 1, 5, 247016) Thus, after reaching England, the student has one year at least to prepare for the examination which is much more than what is required for the purposes of passing the examination; hence, the brilliant results of the examination.
('1', 104, 1, 6, 247246) For Roman Law, Saunder's Justinian is the text book.
('1', 104, 1, 7, 247299) Many students, however, read Hunter's Introduction to Roman Law.
('1', 104, 1, 8, 247364) The other examination called the Bar Final a student can appear in it after—but not before—keeping nine terms, i.e., at the end of two years after admission.
('1', 104, 1, 9, 247522) This time, too, is more than enough for the examination.
('1', 104, 1, 10, 247579) The examination takes place in the Law of Property, Common Law including Criminal Law and Equity, and lasts for four days.
('1', 104, 1, 11, 247702) It used to last only three days, but now there are two Equity papers instead of one.
('1', 104, 1, 12, 247787) For the Law of Property the prescribed books are: William's Real Property “ Personal Property Goodeve's Real Property “ Personal Property Edward’s Compendium of the Law of Property in Land.
('1', 104, 1, 13, 247977) Students, however, generally find it sufficient to read William's and Goodeve's Real Property and Goodeve's Personal Property.
('1', 104, 1, 14, 248104) Very few read William's on personal property.
('1', 104, 1, 15, 248150) They read besides, various guides to the examination.
('1', 104, 1, 16, 248204) In Law the prescribed Common book is Broom's Common Law.
('1', 104, 1, 17, 248261) Indermauer's Common Law is, however, read in addition to or instead of Broom by the students.
('1', 104, 1, 18, 248355) For Equity the prescribed book is Snell's Equity.
('1', 104, 1, 19, 248405) The matter of the examination changes almost every year.
('1', 104, 1, 20, 248462) Thus, while generally a competent knowledge of the English laws is required, special subjects are prescribed every year.
('1', 104, 1, 21, 248583) For instance, for Equity they sometimes prescribe certain portions only (e.g., trusts, mortgages, etc.) from White and Tudor's Leading Cases in Equity.

('1', 105, 1, 2, 248777) Those, however, who are well grounded in the general principles of law do not find it difficult to pass.

('1', 105, 1, 4, 248960) A notion seems to prevail in many quarters that students are called to the bar without any examinations or that the examinations are a farce.
('1', 105, 1, 5, 249102) Both these statements are entirely without foundation and inventions of fertile brains.
('1', 105, 1, 6, 249190) No doubt the examinations are easy or, rather, found to be easy.
('1', 105, 1, 7, 249255) The results are generally good.
('1', 105, 1, 8, 249287) There are two or three reasons for the examinations being found easy.
('1', 105, 1, 9, 249357) In the first place, they take place four times every year.
('1', 105, 1, 10, 249416) So, then, if a student fails, the failure does not shock him so much as it does in India.
('1', 105, 1, 11, 249506) In England he can re appear in three months.
('1', 105, 1, 12, 249551) Secondly, the time at the student's disposal for preparation is ample.
('1', 105, 1, 13, 249622) While both the examinations are a year's work at the rate of 6 hours per day, to ensure success there are clear two years at the student's disposal.
('1', 105, 1, 14, 249771) So, then, the preparation can be made with a light heart and without having to work hard.
('1', 105, 1, 15, 249861) Whether it is good that more than sufficient time should be given for preparation is another question altogether, but let there be only three months for preparing for the examinations and we shall have cutting [sic] results and a different verdict.
('1', 105, 1, 16, 250110) Thirdly, there are many facilities for study in the shape of tutors, etc.
('1', 105, 1, 17, 250184) It is only in rare cases that tutors should be resorted to.
('1', 105, 1, 18, 250244) It is a useless waste of money.
('1', 105, 1, 19, 250276) And a tutored student never goes beyond what is required and forgets what he has learnt soon after the examination.
('1', 105, 1, 20, 250392) Such is the experience of many.
('1', 105, 1, 21, 250424) Nothing like self preparation.

('1', 106, 1, 7, 251548) It may be important here to discuss whether it is desirable that the student should try for scholarship examinations.
('1', 106, 1, 8, 251666) It has been said above that, for the purposes of passing the examinations, the time at the student's disposal is more than enough.
('1', 106, 1, 9, 251797) The question, therefore, is what shall he do with the rest of his time?

('1', 106, 1, 14, 252187) Private study very often gives place to other pursuits, not so study for an examination.

('1', 113, 1, 7, 266391) Although the estimates supplied are not the lowest possible it is supposed that no one would venture to go to England who could not afford £420, i.e., at the present rate of exchange Rs. 6,720. I have, however, a word to say further.

('1', 113, 1, 11, 266957) And mind, Rs. 10,000 would not supply you with luxuries.
('1', 113, 1, 12, 267014) They would simply make you pine for more to vie with your luxurious brothers and thus, in fact, make you more miserable.

('1', 121, 14, 23, 286958) The petition of which this fragment formed part was presumably submitted in that year to someone in authority, who cannot be identified.

('1', 121, 14, 27, 287367) These have been spelt out.

('1', 135, 3, 7, 310511) From the original: S.N. 32320
('1', 135, 4, 8, 310541) 34. AN EXPERIMENT IN VITAL FOOD
('1', 135, 5, 9, 310573) Before describing the experiment, if it may be called one, I would mention that I gave the vital food a trial in Bombay for a week; that I left it off only because at the time I had to entertain many friends, and because there were some other social considerations; that the vital food agreed with me very well than; and that, had I been able to continue it, very likely it would have suited me.
('1', 135, 5, 10, 310969) I give the notes as I took them while I was conducting the experiment.
('1', 135, 5, 11, 311040) August 22nd, 1893. Began the vital food experiment.
('1', 135, 5, 12, 311092) I have been having a cold for the last two days, with a slight cold in the ears too.
('1', 135, 5, 13, 311177) Had two tablespoonfuls of wheat, one of peas, one of rice, two of sultanas, about twenty small nuts, two oranges, and a cup of cocoa for breakfast.
('1', 135, 5, 14, 311325) The pulses and cereals were soaked overnight.
('1', 135, 5, 15, 311371) I finished the meal in 45 minutes.
('1', 135, 5, 16, 311406) Was very bright in the morning, depression came on in the evening, with a slight headache.
('1', 135, 5, 17, 311497) For dinner had the usual things —bread, vegetables, etc.
('1', 135, 5, 18, 311554) August 23rd.
('1', 135, 5, 19, 311567) Feeling hungry, had some peas last evening.
('1', 135, 5, 20, 311611) Owing to that I did not sleep well, and woke up with a bad taste in the mouth in the morning.
('1', 135, 5, 21, 311705) Had the same breakfast and dinner as yesterday.
('1', 135, 5, 22, 311753) Though the day was very dull and it rained a little, I had no headache or cold.
('1', 135, 5, 23, 311833) Had tea with Baker 1. This did not agree at all.
('1', 135, 5, 24, 311882) Felt pains in the stomach.
('1', 135, 5, 25, 311909) August 24th.
('1', 135, 5, 26, 311922) In the morning woke up uneasy, with a heavy stomach.
('1', 135, 5, 27, 311975) Had the same breakfast, except that the one spoonful of peas was reduced to half.
('1', 135, 5, 28, 312057) The usual dinner.
('1', 135, 5, 29, 312075) Did not feel well.
('1', 135, 5, 30, 312094) Had feeling of indigestion the whole day.
('1', 135, 5, 31, 312136) August 25th.
('1', 135, 5, 32, 312149) Felt a heaviness in the stomach when I got up.
('1', 135, 6, 33, 312196) 1 A. W. Baker, attorney and preacher, who discussed Christianity with Gan dhiji and introduced him to Christian friends in Pretoria
('1', 136, 0, 1, 312328) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 137
('1', 136, 1, 2, 312362) During the day, too, did not feel well.
('1', 136, 1, 3, 312402) Had no appetite for dinner.
('1', 136, 1, 4, 312430) Still I had it.
('1', 136, 1, 5, 312446) There were undercooked peas for dinner yesterday.
('1', 136, 1, 6, 312496) That may have to do with the heaviness.

('1', 137, 1, 2, 314874) with much difficulty.

('1', 137, 1, 4, 314953) September 1st.
('1', 137, 1, 5, 314968) Got up in the morning quite tired.

('1', 137, 1, 13, 315274) Had the old food (porridge, bread, butter, jam and cocoa).
('1', 137, 1, 14, 315333) Felt ever so much better.
('1', 137, 1, 15, 315359) Thus ended the vital food experiment.
('1', 137, 1, 16, 315397) Under more favourable circumstances it might not have failed.
('1', 137, 1, 17, 315459) A boarding house, where one cannot control everything, where it is not possible to make frequent changes in the diet, is hardly a place where food experiments can be conducted successfully.
('1', 137, 1, 18, 315649) Again, it will have been noticed that the only fresh fruit that I could get was oranges.
('1', 137, 1, 19, 315738) No other fruits were to be had in the Transvaal then.
('1', 137, 1, 20, 315792) It is a matter of great regret that, although the Transvaal soil is very fruitful, the fruit cultivation is very much neglected.
('1', 137, 1, 21, 315921) Again, I could not get any milk, which is a very dear commodity here.
('1', 137, 1, 22, 315991) People generally use condensed milk in South Africa.
('1', 137, 1, 23, 316044) It must, therefore, be admitted that the experiment is entirely useless to prove the value of vital food.
('1', 137, 1, 24, 316150) It were sheer audacity to venture any opinion on the vital food after an eleven days' trial under adverse circumstances.
('1', 137, 1, 25, 316271) To expect the stomach, used for twenty years and upwards to cooked food, to assimilate, at a stroke, uncooked food, is too much, and yet I think the experiment has its value.
('1', 137, 1, 26, 316446) It should serve as a guide to others, who would embark upon such experiments, attracted to them by some of their charms, but have not the ability, or the means, or the circumstances, or the patience, or the knowledge to carry them to a successful issue.
('1', 137, 1, 27, 316700) I confess I had none of the above qualifications.
('1', 137, 1, 28, 316750) Having no patience to watch the results slowly, I violently changed my diet.
('1', 137, 1, 29, 316827) From the very start, the breakfast consisted of the vital food, while four or five days had hardly passed when the dinner, too, consisted of vital food.
('1', 137, 1, 30, 316980) My acquaintance with the vital food theory was very superficial indeed.
('1', 137, 1, 31, 317052) A little pamphlet by Mr. Hills, and one or two articles that recently appeared from his pen in The Vegetarian were all I knew about it.
('1', 137, 1, 32, 317188) Anyone, therefore, not possessing the necessary qualifications, is, I believe, doomed to failure, and will hurt both himself and the cause he is trying to investigate into and
('1', 138, 0, 1, 317364) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 139
('1', 138, 1, 2, 317398) advance.
('1', 138, 1, 3, 317407) And after all, is it worth while for an ordinary vegetarian to devote his attention to such pursuits—a vegetarian who enjoys good health and is satisfied with his diet?
('1', 138, 1, 4, 317576) Would it not be better to leave it to the adepts who devote their lives to such researches?
('1', 138, 1, 5, 317668) These remarks apply especially to those vegetarians who base their creed on the grand basis of humanitarianism—who are vegetarians because they consider it wrong, nay, even sinful, to kill animals for their food.
('1', 138, 1, 6, 317881) That the ordinary vegetarianism is possible, is conducive to health, he who runs may see.
('1', 138, 1, 7, 317971) What more, then, do we want?
('1', 138, 1, 8, 318000) Vital food may have its grand possibilities in store; but it will surely not make our perishable bodies immortal.
('1', 138, 1, 9, 318114) That any considerable majority of human beings would ever do away with cooking does not seem feasible.
('1', 138, 1, 10, 318217) The vital food will not, cannot, as such, minister to the wants of the soul.
('1', 138, 1, 11, 318294) And if the highest aim, indeed, the only aim of this life, be to know the soul, then, it is humbly submitted, anything that takes away from our opportunities of knowing the soul, and therefore, also playing with the vital food and other such experiments, is playing away, to that extent, the only desirable aim in life.
('1', 138, 1, 12, 318614) If we are to eat that we may live to the glory of Him, of whom we are, then, is it not sufficient that we eat nothing that, to Nature, is repulsive, that requires the unnecessary spilling of blood?
('1', 138, 1, 13, 318812) No more, however, of this while I am yet on the threshold of my studies in that direction.
('1', 138, 1, 14, 318903) I simply throw out these thoughts, which were passing through the mind while I was conducting the experiment, so that some dear brother or sister may find, perchance, an echo of their own in this.
('1', 138, 1, 15, 319100) The reasons which led me to try the vital food were its extreme simplicity.
('1', 138, 1, 16, 319176) That I could dispense with cooking, that I could carry about my own food wherever I went, that I should not have to put up with any uncleanness of the landlady or those who supplied me with food, that, in travelling in such countries as South Africa, the vital food would be an ideal food, were charms too irresistible for me.
('1', 138, 1, 17, 319503) But what a sacrifice of time and trouble to achieve what is after all a selfish end, which falls short of the highest!
('1', 138, 1, 18, 319622) Life seems too short for these things.
('1', 138, 1, 19, 319661) The Vegetarian, 24 3 1894

('1', 139, 1, 2, 319729) 35. LETTER TO “THE VEGETARIAN” 1
('1', 139, 2, 3, 319762) [PRETORIA] TO THE EDITOR The Vegetarian
('1', 139, 3, 4, 319802) MY DEAR BROTHER, If you are a vegetarian, I think it is your duty to join the London Vegetarian Society, and to subscribe to The Vegetarian if you have not done so already.
('1', 139, 3, 5, 319975) It is your duty because — (1) You will thereby encourage and aid the creed you profess.
('1', 139, 3, 6, 320063) (2) That will be an expression of the bond of sympathy that should exist between a vegetarian and a vegetarian in a land where there are so few of them.
('1', 139, 3, 7, 320216) (3) The vegetarian movement will indirectly aid India politically also, inasmuch as the English vegetarians will more readily sympathize with the Indian aspirations (that is my personal experience).
('1', 139, 3, 8, 320415) (4) Looking at the question even from a purely selfish point of view, you will thereby be able to have a large circle of vegetarian friends who ought to be more acceptable than others.
('1', 139, 3, 9, 320600) (5) Your knowledge of the vegetarian literature will enable you to remain firm in your principles in a land where you are exposed to so many temptations, which have in very many cases proved irresistible, and you will, in case of illness, be able to get the aid of vegetarian doctors and drugs, whom and which you will know very easily, having joined the Society and subscribed to its paper.
('1', 139, 3, 10, 320992) (6) That will help your fellow brothers in India a great deal, and be also a means of dispelling the doubt that still lingers in the minds of our parents as to the possibility of existence under a vegetarian diet,
('1', 139, 4, 11, 321206) 1 This was published along with the note reading: “Mr. M. K. Gandhi has sent round the following letter to the Indians in England and we reproduce it here to show what active work is still being done in our midst by Mr. Gandhi, in spite of the distance which separates him from us.
('1', 139, 4, 12, 321488) And yet our opponents say that vegetarian Indians have no persistence of purpose like the sons of “Honest John Bull"!
('1', 139, 4, 13, 321606) Ed., Veg.”
('1', 140, 0, 1, 321617) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 141
('1', 140, 1, 2, 321651) and thus facilitate the way of other Indians to visit England a great deal.
('1', 140, 1, 3, 321727) (7) If there were a sufficient number of Indian subscribers, the Editor of The Vegetarian may be induced to devote a page or a column to India, which, you will admit, cannot but result in benefit to India.
('1', 140, 1, 4, 321933) Many more reasons can be given to show why you should join the Society and subscribe to The Vegetarian, but I hope these will be sufficient to induce you to view my proposal with favour.
('1', 140, 1, 5, 322120) Even if you are not a vegetarian, you will find that many of the above reasons will apply to you also, and you can subscribe to The Vegetarian, and who knows but you may, in the end, consider it a privilege to join the rank of those who never depend for their existence on the blood of their fellow creatures.
('1', 140, 1, 6, 322430) Of course, there is also the Manchester Vegetarian Society and its organ The Vegetarian Messenger.
('1', 140, 1, 7, 322529) I have pleaded for the L.V.S. and its organ simply because it is so very handy, being in London, and because its organ is weekly.
('1', 140, 1, 8, 322659) I do trust that you will not excuse yourself from joining and subscribing on the score of economy, for the subscription is so small, and it is sure to more than repay your money.
('1', 140, 1, 9, 322838) Hoping you will not consider this an impertinence on my part.
('1', 140, 2, 10, 322900) Yours in brotherly love, M. K. GANDHI The Vegetarian, 28 4 1894
('1', 140, 3, 11, 322964) 36. VEGETARIANISM AND CHILDREN
('1', 140, 4, 12, 322995) Mr. M. K. Gandhi, in a private letter, writes: Recently a grand convention of Keswick Christians was held in Wellington, under the presidency of Rev.
('1', 140, 4, 13, 323145) Andrew Murray.
('1', 140, 4, 14, 323160) I attended it in the company of some dear Christians; they have a boy six or seven years old.
('1', 140, 4, 15, 323254) He came out with me for a walk one day during the time.
('1', 140, 4, 16, 323310) I was simply talking to him about kindness to animals.
('1', 140, 4, 17, 323365) During the talk we discussed vegetarianism.
('1', 140, 4, 18, 323409) Ever since that time, I am told, the boy has not taken meat.
('1', 140, 4, 19, 323470) He did watch me, before the above conversation, taking only vegetables at the dinner table, and questioned me why I would not take meat.
('1', 140, 4, 20, 323607) His parents, though not
('1', 141, 0, 1, 323631) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 142
('1', 141, 1, 2, 323673) themselves vegetarians, are believers in the virtue of vegetarianism, and did not mind my talking to their boy about it.
('1', 141, 1, 3, 323794) I write this to show how easily you can convince children of the grand truth, and induce them to avoid meat if their parents are not against the change.
('1', 141, 1, 4, 323947) The boy and I are thick friends now.
('1', 141, 1, 5, 323984) He seems to like me very much.
('1', 141, 1, 6, 324015) Another boy, about 15, I was talking to, said he could not himself kill or see a fowl killed, but did not object to eating it.

('1', 143, 1, 2, 326699) 38. PETITION TO NATAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY 1
('1', 143, 2, 3, 326744) DURBAN, June 28, 1894
('1', 143, 3, 4, 326766) TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE COLONY OF NATAL THE PETITION OF THE INDIANS RESIDENT IN THE COLONY OF NATAL
('1', 143, 4, 5, 326919) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT : 1. Your Petitioners are British subjects, who have come from India and settled in the Colony.
('1', 143, 4, 6, 327035) 2. Your Petitioners are many of them registered as electors duly qualified to vote at the election of members to your Honourable Council and Assembly.
('1', 143, 4, 7, 327186) 3. Your Petitioners have read with feelings of unfeigned regret and alarm the debate as reported in the newspapers on the second reading of the Franchise Law Amendment Bill.
('1', 143, 4, 8, 327360) 4. Your Petitioners, with the greatest deference to your Honourable House, beg to dissent entirely from the views of the various speakers, and feel constrained to say that the real facts fail to support the reasons adduced in justification of the passing of the unfortunate measure.
('1', 143, 4, 9, 327643) 5. The reasons, as reported in the newspapers, brought forward in support of the measure, your Petitioners understand, are: (a) that the Indians have never exercised the franchise in the land they come from; (b) that they are not fit for the exercise of the franchise.
('1', 143, 4, 10, 327912) 6. Your Petitioners respectfully beg to press on the notice of the Honourable Members that all the facts and history point the other way.
('1', 143, 4, 11, 328050) 7. The Indian nation has known, and has exercised, the power of election from times far prior to the time when the Anglo Saxon races first became acquainted with the principles of representation.
('1', 143, 5, 12, 328246) 1 First it was addressed to both the Council and the Assembly, Then it was amended and addressed only to the Assembly, and a separate petition was addressed to the Council; vide “Petition to Natal Legislative Council”, 4 7 1894.
('1', 144, 0, 1, 328475) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 145
('1', 144, 1, 2, 328509) 8. In support of the above, your Petitioners beg to draw the attention of your Honourable Assembly to Sir Henry Sumner Maine's 1
('1', 144, 2, 3, 328638) Village Communities, where he has most clearly pointed out that the Indian races have been familiar with representative institutions almost from time immemorial.
('1', 144, 2, 4, 328800) That eminent lawyer and writer has shown that the Teutonic Mark was hardly so well organized or so essentially representative as an Indian village community until the precise technical Roman form was engrafted upon it.
('1', 144, 2, 5, 329019) 9. Mr. Chisolm Anstey 2, in a speech delivered before the East India Association in London, said:
('1', 144, 3, 6, 329117) We are apt to forget in this country, when we talk of preparing people in the East by education and all that sort of thing for Municipal Government and Parliamentary Government, that the East is the parent of Municipalities.
('1', 144, 3, 7, 329342) Local Self government, in the widest acceptation of the term, is as old as the East itself.
('1', 144, 3, 8, 329434) No matter what may be the religion of the people who inhabit what we call the East, there is not a portion of the country from East to West, from North to South, which is not swarming with municipalities; and not only so, but, like to our municipalities of old, they are all bound together as in a species of network, so that you have, ready made to your hand, the framework of the great system of representation.
('1', 144, 3, 9, 329848) Every caste in every village or town has its own rules or regulations, and elects representatives, and furnishes an exact prototype of the Saxon Witans, from which have sprung the present Parliamentary institutions.
('1', 144, 3, 10, 330064) 10. The word Panchayat is a household word throughout the length and breadth of India, and it means, as the Honourable Members may be well aware, a Council of Five elected by the class of the people to whom the five belong, for the purpose of managing and controlling the social affairs of the particular caste.
('1', 144, 3, 11, 330376) 11. The State of Mysore has at the present moment a representative parliament, called the Mysore Assembly, on the exact model of the British Parliament.
('1', 144, 3, 12, 330529) 12. The trading Indian community now residing in Durban have their Panchayat, or Council of Five, and in case of matters of pressing importance their deliberations are controlled by the community at large, who can, according to the constitution of the body, overrule
('1', 144, 4, 13, 330796) 1 1822 88; eminent jurist whose works include Ancient Law and Early History of Institutions.
('1', 144, 4, 14, 330889) He was a member of the Indian Council, 1862 69 and 1871.
('1', 144, 5, 15, 330946) 2 1816 73; lawyer and politician; Member of Parliament, 1847 52
('1', 145, 0, 1, 331010) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 146
('1', 145, 1, 2, 331052) their decisions by a sufficient majority.
('1', 145, 1, 3, 331094) Here is, your Memorialists submit, a proof of their capabilities as regards representation.
('1', 145, 1, 4, 331186) 13. Indeed, so much has the Indians' ability to understand representative institutions been recognized by Her Majesty's Government that India enjoys municipal local self government in the truest sense of the term.
('1', 145, 1, 5, 331400) 14. There were, in 1891, 755 municipalities and 892 local boards in India, with 20,000 Indian members.
('1', 145, 1, 6, 331503) This would give some idea of the magnitude of the municipalities and the electorate.
('1', 145, 1, 7, 331588) 15. If further proof be needed on this head, your Petitioners draw the Honourable Members' attention to the recently passed India Councils Bill, whereby the system of representation has been introduced even into the Legislative Councils of the various Presidencies of India.
('1', 145, 1, 8, 331863) 16. Your Honourable Assembly will, your Petitioners trust, see, therefore, that the exercise of the franchise by them is no extension of a new privilege they have never before known or enjoyed, but on the contrary, the disqualification to exercise it would be an unjust restric tion which, under similar circumstances, would never be put on them in the land of their birth.
('1', 145, 1, 9, 332237) 17. Hence, also, your Petitioners submit that the fear that they may, if they were allowed to exercise the privilege of franchise, “become propagandists of agitation and instruments of sedition in that great country they come from”, is, to say the least of it, without ground.
('1', 145, 1, 10, 332514) 18. Your Petitioners deem it unnecessary to dwell upon the minor points and the needlessly harsh remarks made in the course of the debate on the second reading.
('1', 145, 1, 11, 332675) They would, however, crave leave to give some extracts which bear on the subject under consideration.
('1', 145, 1, 12, 332777) Your Petitioners would rather have been judged by their works than have sought to justify themselves by quoting what others have thought of their race; but, under the present circumstances, they have no other course left open to them, since, owing to want of free intercourse, there seems to prevail much misunderstanding about their capabilities.
('1', 145, 1, 13, 333125) 19. Speaking at a meeting at the Assembly Rooms, Kennington, Mr. F. Pincott said:
('1', 145, 2, 14, 333207) We have heard a great deal in this country about the ignorance of the Indian people and their unfitness for appreciating the great advantages of representative government.
('1', 145, 2, 15, 333379) All that is really very foolish, because
('1', 146, 0, 1, 333420) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 147
('1', 146, 1, 2, 333454) representative government has nothing to do with education.
('1', 146, 1, 3, 333514) It has a great deal to do with common sense, and the people of India are gifted with as much common sense, as we have; we exercised the right of election and we had representative institutions many hundreds of years before we possessed any education whatever.
('1', 146, 1, 4, 333774) Therefore, the educational test goes simply for naught.
('1', 146, 1, 5, 333830) Those who know the history of our country know very well that two hundred years ago the grossest superstition and ignorance prevailed, and yet we had our representative institutions.
('1', 146, 1, 6, 334013) 20. Sir George Birdwood 1, writing on the general character of the people of India, thus sums up:
('1', 146, 2, 7, 334111) The people of India are in no intrinsic sense our inferiors, while in things measured by some of the false standards, false to ourselves, we pretend to believe in, they are our superiors.
('1', 146, 2, 8, 334299) 21. Says Sir Thomas Munro, one of the Governors of Madras:
('1', 146, 3, 9, 334358) I do not know what is meant by civilizing the people of India.
('1', 146, 3, 10, 334421) In the theory and practice of good government they may be deficient; but if a good system of agriculture, if unrivalled manufacture .
('1', 146, 3, 11, 334555) if the establishment of schools for reading and writing, if the general practice of kindness and hospitality .
('1', 146, 3, 12, 334666) are amongst the points that denote a civilized people, then they are not inferior in civilization to the people of Europe.
('1', 146, 3, 13, 334789) 22. Professor Max Muller thus speaks of the much abused and more misunderstood Indian :
('1', 146, 4, 14, 334877) If I were asked under what sky the human mind has most fully developed some of its choicest gifts, has most deeply pondered on the greatest problem of life, and has found solutions of some of them which well deserve the attention even of those who have studied Plato and Kant, I should point to India.
('1', 146, 4, 15, 335179) 23. To appeal to the finer feelings, your Petitioners respectfully venture to point out that the Franchise Law Amendment Bill, if passed, would have a tendency to retard, instead of hastening, the process of unification the flower of the British and the Indian nations are earnestly striving for.
('1', 146, 4, 16, 335476) 24. Your petitioners have purposely let the English authorities speak on their behalf, without any comments to amplify the above extracts.
('1', 146, 4, 17, 335615) It is yet possible to multiply such extracts, but your Petitioners confidently trust that the above will prove sufficient to convince your Honourable Assembly of the justice of their prayer, and they earnestly beseech your Honourable Assembly to reconsider

('1', 147, 3, 6, 336542) 39. DEPUTATION TO NATAL PREMIER11
('1', 147, 4, 7, 336576) DURBAN, June 29, 1894
('1', 147, 5, 8, 336598) TO SIR JOHN ROBINSON, K.C.M.G. PREMIER AND COLONIAL SECRETARY COLONY OF NATAL
('1', 147, 6, 9, 336676) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR HONOUR, We have to thank Your Honour very much for sparing some of Your Honour's valuable time to receive this deputation.
('1', 147, 6, 10, 336818) We beg to present this petition of the Indians residing in the Colony to Your Honour and beg you to give it Your Honour's earnest attention.
('1', 147, 6, 11, 336959) We would not trespass longer on Your Honour’s courtesy than is absolutely necessary.
('1', 147, 6, 12, 337044) We, however, regret that we have not at our disposal time enough to lay our case as thoroughly as possible before Your Honour.
('1', 147, 6, 13, 337171) Sir, we have been taunted with having woken up almost too late.
('1', 147, 6, 14, 337235) It is only necessary to put before you the peculiar circumstances to convince Your Honour that we could not possibly have approached the honourable Houses earlier.
('1', 147, 6, 15, 337399) The two chief leading members of the community were away from the Colony on urgent business and were shut out from all communication with people in the Colony.
('1', 147, 6, 16, 337559) Our very imperfect knowledge of the English language materially prevents us from keeping ourselves in touch with important matters as we should like to be.
('1', 147, 7, 17, 337715) 1 Enclosure No.
('1', 147, 7, 18, 337731) 1 in Schedule of Correspondence published by order of the Legislative Assembly of Natal on April 21, 1896
('1', 148, 0, 1, 337837) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 149
('1', 148, 1, 2, 337871) With greatest respect to Your Honour, we beg to point out that both the Anglo Saxon and the Indian races belong to the same stock.
('1', 148, 1, 3, 338002) We read Your Honour's eloquent speech at the time of the second reading of the Bill with rapt attention and took great pains to ascertain if any writer of authority gave countenance to the view expressed by Your Honour about the difference of the stocks from which both the races have sprung up.
('1', 148, 1, 4, 338298) Max Muller, Morris, Greene and a host of other writers with one voice seem to show very clearly that both the races have sprung from the same Aryan stock, or rather the Indo European as many call it.
('1', 148, 1, 5, 338498) We have no wish whatever to thrust ourselves as members of a brother nation on a nation that would be unwilling to receive us as such, but we may be pardoned if we state the real facts, the alleged absence of which has been put forward as an argument to pronounce us as unfit for the exercise of the franchise.
('1', 148, 1, 6, 338809) Your Honour has, moreover, been reported to have said that it would be cruel to expect Indians to exercise the privilege of franchise.
('1', 148, 1, 7, 338944) We humbly submit that our petition is a sufficient answer to this.
('1', 148, 1, 8, 339011) It has given us no small satisfaction to know that, however unjust Your Honour's speech may have appeared to us from our point of view, it breathed truest sentiments of justice, morality and, what is more, Christianity.
('1', 148, 1, 9, 339231) So long as such a spirit is noticeable among the chosen of the land, we would never despair of right being done in every case.
('1', 148, 1, 10, 339358) It is therefore that we have ventured to approach Your Honour, fully believing that, in the light of the new facts disclosed by our humble petition, a display of the same sentiments will result in substantial justice being done to the Indians in the Colony.
('1', 148, 1, 11, 339616) We believe that the prayer of the petitioners is very modest.
('1', 148, 1, 12, 339678) If the newspaper reports are trustworthy, Your Honour was pleased to acknowledge that there were some respectable Indians who were intelligent enough to exercise the precious privilege.
('1', 148, 1, 13, 339864) That alone, in our humble opinion, is a sufficient reason for granting a Commission of enquiry into the momentous question.
('1', 148, 1, 14, 339988) We are willing to face, nay, we court such a Commission, and, will it be asking too much if we ask that the Indians should be allowed to exercise the privilege, if the impartial judgment of an impartial Commission pronounced the Indians fit for such an exercise?
('1', 148, 1, 15, 340251) If we have understood the Bill rightly, the Indians would, in the event of its becoming law, rank lower than the lowest native.
('1', 148, 1, 16, 340379) For, while the latter can educate himself into fitness
('1', 149, 0, 1, 340434) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 150
('1', 149, 1, 2, 340476) for the power of election, the former never can.
('1', 149, 1, 3, 340525) The Bill seems to be so sweeping that even the Indian Member of the British House of Commons, did he come here, would not be fit for becoming a voter.
('1', 149, 1, 4, 340676) Did we not know that other matters of equal importance seriously engage Your Honour's attention, we could go on showing the injurious consequences that would flow from the interpretation of the Bill, consequences perhaps never contemplated by its illustrious authors.
('1', 149, 1, 5, 340944) If we were given a week's time we could put our case more exhaustively before the House of Assembly.
('1', 149, 1, 6, 341045) We would then leave our cause in Your Honour's hands, imploring Your Honour with all the earnestness at our command to use Your Honour's powerful influence and to see that full justice is done to the Indians.
('1', 149, 1, 7, 341254) For it is justice we want and that only.
('1', 149, 1, 8, 341295) We thank your Honour for receiving this deputation and the patience and courtesy shown to us.
('1', 149, 1, 9, 341389) We beg to subscribe ourselves on behalf of the Indian community,
('1', 149, 2, 10, 341454) Your Honour’s obedient servants, M. K. GANDHI AND THREE OTHERS Colonial Office Records No.

('1', 151, 8, 8, 343621) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY, At a meeting held on the 1st July, 1894, of leading Indians in Durban, we were requested to await Your Excellency’s pleasure with regard to the Franchise Law Amendment Bill, which was read a third time last evening in the Honourable the Legislative Assembly of the Colony of Natal.
('1', 151, 8, 9, 343934) The Bill as it stands, disqualifies every Indian, whether a British subject or not, not already on the Voters' List, from becoming a voter.
('1', 151, 8, 10, 344074) We venture to say that, without any further qualification, the Bill is manifestly unjust, and would work very harshly at any rate upon some Indians.
('1', 151, 8, 11, 344223) Even in England, any British subject having the proper qualifications is entitled to vote, irrespective of caste, colour, or creed.

('1', 151, 8, 14, 344733) We trust that Your Excellency, representing Her Most Gracious Majesty the Queen Empress, will not sanction a measure that would seem to lay down that an Indian British subject of Her Majesty can never become fit to exercise the franchise.

('1', 154, 1, 2, 349596) 43. EXTRACT FORM LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI 1
('1', 154, 2, 3, 349642) DURBAN, July 5, 1894 The first Parliament of Natal under Responsible Government has been pre eminently an Indian Parliament.
('1', 154, 2, 4, 349767) It has for the most part occupied itself with legislation affecting Indians, by no means favourably.
('1', 154, 2, 5, 349868) The Governor, in opening the Legislative Council and Assembly, remarked that his Ministers would deal with the Franchise which was exercised by Indians in Natal, although they never exercised it in India.
('1', 154, 2, 6, 350073) The reasons given for the sweeping measure to disfranchise Indians were that they had never exercised the Franchise before, and that they were not fit for it.
('1', 154, 2, 7, 350232) The petition of the Indians seemed to prove a sufficient answer to this.
('1', 154, 2, 8, 350305) Hence they have now turned round and given out the real object of the Bill, which is simply this: “We do not want the Indians any more here.
('1', 154, 2, 9, 350446) We want the coolies, but they shall remain slaves here and go back to India as soon as they are free.” I earnestly request your undivided attention to the cause and appeal to you to use your influence that always has been and is being used on behalf of the Indians, no matter where situated.
('1', 154, 2, 10, 350738) The Indians look up to you as children to the father.
('1', 154, 2, 11, 350792) Such is really the feeling here.
('1', 154, 2, 12, 350825) A word for myself and what I have done.
('1', 154, 2, 13, 350865) I am yet inexperienced and young and, therefore, quite liable to make mistakes.
('1', 154, 2, 14, 350945) The responsibility undertaken is quite out of proportion to my ability.
('1', 154, 2, 15, 351017) I may mention that I am doing this without any remuneration.
('1', 154, 2, 16, 351078) So you will see that I have not taken the matter up, which is beyond my ability, in order to enrich myself at the expense of the Indians.
('1', 154, 2, 17, 351216) I am the only available person who can handle the question.
('1', 154, 2, 18, 351276) You will, therefore, oblige me very greatly if you will kindly direct and guide me and make necessary suggestions which shall be received as from a father to his child.
('1', 154, 3, 19, 351445) Dadabhai Naoroji : The Grand Old Man of India, pp.
('1', 154, 4, 20, 351496) 1 Dadabhai Naoroji (1825 1917); statesman, often called.
('1', 154, 4, 21, 351553) “the Grand Old Man of India”.
('1', 154, 4, 22, 351583) Thrice presided over the Congress session, in 1886, 1893 and 1906. Enuniciated, for the first time, Congress goal as one of swaraj or independence.
('1', 154, 4, 23, 351731) Member of the British Committee of the Congress in London.

('1', 155, 1, 2, 351832) 44. PETITION TO NATAL LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL 1
('1', 155, 2, 3, 351876) DURBAN, July 6, 1894
('1', 155, 3, 4, 351897) TO THE HONOURABLE THE PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF HONOURABLE THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL OF THE COLONY OF NATAL
('1', 155, 4, 5, 352002) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED INDIANS RESIDENT IN THE COLONY OF NATAL
('1', 155, 5, 6, 352074) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT : (1) Your Petitioners have been appointed by the Indian community resident in this Colony to approach your Honourable Council with regard to the “Franchise Law Amendment Bill”.
('1', 155, 5, 7, 352272) (2) Your Petitioners regret sincerely that their petition presented on 4th July, 1894, through the Honourable Mr. Campbell, being notin order, they have again to trespass on your Honourable Council's valuable time.
('1', 155, 5, 8, 352487) (3) Your Petitioners, as trusted and responsible members of the Indian community, beg to draw your Honourable Council's attention to the fact that the Bill under discussion has created a widespread feeling of dissatisfaction and disappointment among the Indian community.
('1', 155, 5, 9, 352759) The more the provisions of the Bill become known among the Indians, the more your Petitioners hear the following expressions of opinion : “ Sarkar Mabap 2 is going to kill us, what shall we do?” (4) With the greatest respect to your Honourable Council, your Petitioners submit that this is no mere idle expression of opinion, but a sincere one, which is worthy of the most serious consideration by the Honourable Council.
('1', 155, 5, 10, 353181) (5) It is not, your Petitioners venture respectfully to submit, a fact that the Indians do not know what voting means, as was attempted to be shown during the debate on the second reading of the Bill in your Honourable Council.
('1', 155, 5, 11, 353409) They know very well what privilege a right
('1', 155, 6, 12, 353452) 1 This was presented by the Hon.
('1', 155, 6, 13, 353485) Mr. Campbell to the Legislative Council of the Natal Parliament on July 6, 1894, on behalf of Hajee Mahomed Hajee Dada and seven other Indians.
('1', 155, 7, 14, 353629) 2 Government considered as “mother father”
('1', 156, 0, 1, 353672) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 157
('1', 156, 1, 2, 353706) of voting confers, and feel also the responsibility such a privilege carries with it.
('1', 156, 1, 3, 353792) Your Petitioners only wish that your Honourable Council could personally witness the excitement and the anxiety with which every stage in the progress of the Bill is watched by the Indian Community.
('1', 156, 1, 4, 353991) (6) Your Petitioners would not, for one moment, say that every member of the community has such a knowledge and, therefore such a feeling, but they may be permitted to say that it is general.
('1', 156, 1, 5, 354183) Nor would your Petitioners hold that there are not Indians who should have no right to vote, but your Petitioners submit that that is no reason why the Indians should be excluded wholesale from the privilege.
('1', 156, 1, 6, 354392) (7) Your Petitioners venture to submit for your Honourable Council's consideration some of the anomalous results that would follow the operation of the Bill : (a) The Bills arbitrarily keeps on the Voters' List those who are already there, while it forever shuts the door against any new addition of a person who has not chosen to exercise the privilege hitherto.
('1', 156, 1, 7, 354756) (b) While some Indian fathers will be able to vote, their children never can, although the latter may surpass the former in every respect.
('1', 156, 1, 8, 354895) (c) It practically puts the free and indentured Indians in the same scale.
('1', 156, 1, 9, 354970) (d) Taking out for a moment the question of policy as the principle of the Bill, which seems to have developed but lately, the Bill seems to lay down that India has not at the present moment any Indian who is fit to exercise the privilege of franchise and that there is such a wide difference between a European and an Indian that contact with the former, even for any length of time, does not fit him for the exercise of the precious privilege.
('1', 156, 1, 10, 355416) (8) Is it fair, your Petitioners humbly ask, that, while the father is a voter, he has to see his son, on whom he has lavished enormous sums of money to educate him so that he may become a public man, unable to possess a right that is now recognized as the birthright of all really educated persons born in civilized countries where representative institutions prevail?
('1', 156, 1, 11, 355786) (9) Your Petitioners would very much like to have dwelt upon the fear that the permission to allow the Asiatic to vote would ultimately result in a Government of Natives by coloured people, the Indians.
('1', 156, 1, 12, 355989) But your Petitioners are afraid that this is not the occasion on
('1', 157, 0, 1, 356054) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 158
('1', 157, 1, 2, 356096) which your Petitioners may lay their humble views before your Honourable Council on the question.
('1', 157, 1, 3, 356194) They would rest content with saying that, in their opinion, such a contingency can never happen, and certainly the time is not ripe to provide against it, were it even possible in the remote future.
('1', 157, 1, 4, 356393) (10) Your Petitioners beg respectfully to submit that the Bill makes an invidious distinction between one class of British subjects and another.
('1', 157, 1, 5, 356538) But it has been said that, if Indian British subjects are to be treated equally with the Europeans, the same treatment should be accorded to other British subjects, e.g., the Natives of the Colony.
('1', 157, 1, 6, 356736) Without entering into odious comparisons, your Petitioners would venture to quote from the Royal Proclamation of 1858, which would show on what principles the British Indian subjects have been and should be treated :
('1', 157, 2, 7, 356953) We hold ourselves bound to the Natives of our Indian territories by the same obligations of duty which bind us to all our other subjects, and those obligations, by the blessing of Almighty God, we shall faithfully and conscientiously fulfil.
('1', 157, 2, 8, 357195) And it is our further will that, so far as may be, our subjects, of whatever race or creed, be freely and impartially admitted to offices in our services, the duties of which they may be qualified by their education, ability and integrity, duly to discharge.
('1', 157, 2, 9, 357454) In their prosperity will be our strength, in their contentment our security and in their gratitude our best reward.
('1', 157, 2, 10, 357570) (11) On the lines laid down in the above extract, and also the Charter of 1833 1, the Indians have been admitted to the most responsible posts in India, e.g., that of Chief Justice.
('1', 157, 2, 11, 357752) And yet here, in a British Colony, an attempt is being made to deprive your Petitioners or their brethren or their children of the commonest right of an ordinary citizen.
('1', 157, 2, 12, 357923) (12) It has now been said that the Indians know the Municipal Self government but not the Political.
('1', 157, 2, 13, 358024) Your Petitioners submit that this, too, is not now strictly true.
('1', 157, 2, 14, 358090) But granting that it is strictly so, should that be any reason for barring the door to Political Franchise to Indians in a country where a Parliamentary Government prevails?
('1', 157, 3, 15, 358264) 1 Based on the findings of a Parliamentary Commission of Enquiry, the Act abolished the East India Company's trading rights in India and confined its function to ruling its possessions.
('1', 157, 3, 16, 358450) Reaffirmed in 1853, the Charter Act provided that no Indian shall be disabled from holding any place, office or employment under the East India Company by reason of his religion, place of birth, descent or colour.
('1', 158, 0, 1, 358664) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 159
('1', 158, 1, 2, 358698) Your Petitioners submit that the real and only test should be whether your Petitioners, and those on whose behalf they plead, are capable or not.
('1', 158, 1, 3, 358844) A person coming from under Monarchical Government, e.g., Russian, may not have been able to show his capabilities to understand or appreciate Representative Government, and yet your Petitioners venture to believe your Honourable Council will not condemn such a one as unfit, if he is otherwise capable and fit.
('1', 158, 1, 4, 359155) (13) Before concluding, your Petitioners beg to draw your Honourable Council's attention to the following memorable words of Lord Macaulay : “Free and civilized as we are, it is to little purpose, if we grudge to any portion of the human race an equal portion of freedom and civilization.” (14) Your Petitioners fervently trust that the above facts and arguments, if they prove nothing else, will prove to the satisfaction of your Honourable Council that a real necessity exists for a Commission of enquiry as to the fitness or the unfitness of the Indians to exercise the Franchise, as also to ascertain whether there is any ground for the fear that, in case of the Indian being allowed to exercise the privilege of Franchise as heretofore, their vote will swamp the European vote, and that they will have the reins of Government in their hands, and also to report upon such other important questions.
('1', 158, 1, 5, 360058) Your Petitioners pray, therefore, that your Honourable Council will send the Bill back for reconsideration by the Honourable the Legislative Assembly, with such just andequitable recommendations as your Honourable Council may think fit.
('1', 158, 1, 6, 360295) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioners, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, etc., etc.

('1', 159, 2, 3, 360520) DURBAN, July 7, 1894
('1', 159, 3, 4, 360541) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Mercury
('1', 159, 4, 5, 360573) SIR, It was a treat to read your learned and able leader in today's issue.
('1', 159, 4, 6, 360648) It was not expected that there would be nothing to be said against the franchise petition.
('1', 159, 4, 7, 360739) That would be a wondrous—I was almost going to say, superhuman—thing that would not have its two sides, in these modern times.
('1', 159, 4, 8, 360866) On the same principle, Sir George Chesney is not the only writer who would serve your purpose.
('1', 159, 4, 9, 360961) Sir Henry Sumner Maine was also, after all, a mortal.
('1', 159, 4, 10, 361015) It is, therefore, only natural that his theories and conclusions should be contested.
('1', 159, 4, 11, 361101) There seems to be no escape for a mortal from “the pairs of opposites”.
('1', 159, 4, 12, 361173) I would, however, without for the present presenting the other aspect of the case, beg leave to revert to the matter on some future occasion.
('1', 159, 4, 13, 361315) The object of writing this letter is to “surprise” you.
('1', 159, 4, 14, 361371) The State of Mysore, I am glad to say, has given the political franchise rights to its subjects.
('1', 159, 4, 15, 361468) I take the following from a newspaper report :
('1', 159, 5, 16, 361515) Under the system now expounded by the Dewan, all landholders paying a
('1', 159, 6, 17, 361585) 1 This was in reply to an article entitled "Indian Village Communities" in The Natal Mercury, 7 7 1894, commenting on the petition presented to the Natal Legis lative Council by the Indian community in connection with the Franchise Law Ame ndment Bill.
('1', 159, 6, 18, 361838) It was argued that Parliamentary Government was very different from any form of representation known to the village communities of India.
('1', 159, 6, 19, 361976) The Bill excluded Indians from the franchise on the ground that they had not exercised the franchise in their own country.
('1', 159, 6, 20, 362099) The Indians pleaded that they had done so from ancient times in their village communities.
('1', 159, 6, 21, 362190) But The Natal Mercury contested this view, and that of Sir Henry Sumner Maine, in his Village Communities in the East and West, that Indian had been familiar with representative institutions almost from time immemorial.
('1', 159, 6, 22, 362410) It maintained that Indian village communities had nothing to do with political repre sentation but only with the legal question of land tenure.
('1', 159, 6, 23, 362554) It argued that village community life was common to all primitive peoples and, if anything, proved the backwardness of a people, and quoted General Sir George Chesney's views in The Nineteenth Century to the effect that Indians were still in their political infancy.
('1', 160, 0, 1, 362821) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 161
('1', 160, 1, 2, 362855) revenue of Rs. 100 or more, or mohatarfa 1 of Rs. 13 and upwards, are entitled to vote for members of the Representative Assembly, and are eligible to become members themselves.
('1', 160, 1, 3, 363033) Besides, all non official graduates of any Indian University, ordinarily residing in the taluk, have been given the privilege of electing, as well as of being elected.
('1', 160, 1, 4, 363201) Thus property as well as intelligence will be represented in the Assembly.
('1', 160, 1, 5, 363276) Further, it has also been specified that public associations, municipalities and the local boards may also elect members.
('1', 160, 1, 6, 363398) The total number of members fixed is 347, and these members are elected by nearly 4,000 electors.
('1', 160, 1, 7, 363496) Sir, I appeal to your good sense, and ask you, will you not better serve humanity by collecting and pointing our points of resemblances between the two peoples than by holding out to the public gaze points of contrasts, often far fetched or merely imaginary, that can but arouse the worst feeling of a man, while they can do nobody any real good?
('1', 160, 1, 8, 363843) I hardly think it can be to your interest to sow the seeds of jealousy and animosity between the two nations.
('1', 160, 1, 9, 363953) That, I doubt not, is in your power, as it is in anybody's, more or less.
('1', 160, 1, 10, 364027) But a thing far higher and far nobler, too, lies within your reach—a thing that would bring you not only greatness, but goodness, and what is more, the gratitude of a nation that has not been crushed under 1,200 years' tyranny and oppression, a fact by itself a miracle,—and that thing is to educate rightly the Colony about India and its people.
('1', 160, 2, 11, 364374) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Natal Mercury, 11 7 1894
