('1', 162, 1, 2, 366023) 47. PETITION TO LORD RIPON 1
('1', 162, 2, 3, 366052) [DURBAN, Before July 14, 1894] 2
('1', 162, 3, 4, 366085) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE RIGHT HONOURABLE MARQUIS OF RIPON, HER MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES THE PETITION OF THE UNDER SIGNED INDIANS NOW RESIDING IN THE COLONY OF NATAL
('1', 162, 4, 5, 366279) MOST HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT : 1. Your Lordship's Petitioners are Indian British subjects, residing in the various districts of the Colony of Natal.
('1', 162, 4, 6, 366424) 2. Some of Your Lordship's Petitioners are traders, who have come to the Colony and settled therein.
('1', 162, 4, 7, 366525) Some again are those who, in the first instance, came from India under indenture, and have now, for some time (even thirty years), become free.
('1', 162, 4, 8, 366669) Some are Indians under indenture, and some are born and educated in the Colony, and engaged in various pursuits of life as attorneys’ clerks, compounders, compositors, photographers, schoolmasters, etc.
('1', 162, 4, 9, 366872) Again, some of Your Lordship's Petitioners have considerable landed property in the Colony, and are duly qualified to vote at the election of Members for the Honourable the Legislative Assembly.
('1', 162, 4, 10, 367067) And a few have got sufficient property qualifications, but have not been able to get their names on the Voters’ Roll for some cause or other.
('1', 162, 4, 11, 367209) 3. Your Lordship’s Petitioners hereby approach Your Lordship with regard to the Franchise Law Amendment Bill, which was introduced last session by the Honourable Sir John Robinson, the Prime Minister of the Colony, and which has passed the third reading in the Honourable Legislative Council, and received the assent of His Excellency the Governor, subject to its being disallowed by Her Majesty.
('1', 162, 5, 12, 367606) 1 Enclosure No.
('1', 162, 5, 13, 367622) 1 in Despatch No.
('1', 162, 5, 14, 367640) 66 dated July 31, 1894, from Sir Walter Hely Hutchinson, Governor of Natal, to Lord Ripon, Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('1', 162, 5, 15, 367768) In An Autobiography, Pt. II, Ch. XVII, Gandhiji says he took great pains over this petition and obtained over 10, 000 signatures for it in the course of a fortnight.
('1', 162, 5, 16, 367934) The Prime Minister of Natal in his forwarding letter to the Governor set out reasons for recommending rejection of the petition.
('1', 162, 6, 17, 368063) 2 Vide the succeeding item.
('1', 163, 0, 1, 368091) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 164
('1', 163, 1, 2, 368133) 4. The Bill above referred to has for its object the disqualification of all the persons of Asiatic extraction, who have settled in the Colony, to vote at the Parliamentary elections.
('1', 163, 1, 3, 368317) It, however, excepts those who are already rightly placed on the Voters' Lists.
('1', 163, 1, 4, 368397) 5. Your Lordship's Petitioners crave leave to give a short history of the movement carried on to obtain redress through the constituted authorities in the Colony.
('1', 163, 1, 5, 368560) 6. It was when the Franchise Law Amendment Bill had passed the second reading that Your Lordship's Petitioners first approached the Honourable the Legislative Assembly.
('1', 163, 1, 6, 368729) When Your Lordship's Petitioners became aware that two days after the second reading, the Bill had passed the committee stage, and a day after, it would pass the third reading it was impossible to present a petition to the Hon.
('1', 163, 1, 7, 368957) the Legislative Aeeembly unless the third reading was postponed.
('1', 163, 1, 8, 369022) Your Lordship's Petitioners, therefore, sent a telegraphic petition 1 to the Honourable the Legislative Assembly, requesting that a postponement should be granted.
('1', 163, 1, 9, 369186) The postponement was very graciously granted for one day.
('1', 163, 1, 10, 369244) In that one day, about 500 Indians signed a petition which was next day presented to the Honourable the Legislative Assembly.
('1', 163, 1, 11, 369370) In Maritzburg, a deputation waited upon some Honourable Members of the Honourable House, including the Premier and the Attorney General.
('1', 163, 1, 12, 369507) The deputation was very courteously received and given a patient hearing.
('1', 163, 1, 13, 369581) Most of the Honourable Members waited upon more or less admitted the justice of the prayer contained in the said petition, though all said that it was presented too late.
('1', 163, 1, 14, 369752) The Honourable Prime Minister, in order that it might be studied, asked leave to postpone the third reading for four days.
('1', 163, 1, 15, 369875) It might be mentioned also that telegraphic petitions were sent to the Honourable the Legislative Council from Verulam, Richmond Road and other places, endorsing the said petition.
('1', 163, 1, 16, 370056) But they were ruled out of order on the ground they were not presented through a Member of the House.
('1', 163, 1, 17, 370158) Your Lordship's Petitioners have not annexed hereto the various petitions referred to, as these will no doubt be sent to Your Lordship by the Government.
('1', 163, 1, 18, 370312) 7. Four days, after the presentation of the petition, i.e., on the 2nd July, 1894, Monday, the Bill was, contrary to your Petitioners' expectations and much to their regret, read a third time.
('1', 163, 2, 19, 370505) 1 This is not available.
('1', 164, 0, 1, 370530) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 165
('1', 164, 1, 2, 370564) 8. On the Tuesday following, Your Lordship's Petitioners there upon sent a petition to the Honourable the Legislative Council, which was presented through the Honourable Mr. Campbell, but the petition was ruled not in order, because it contained references to the Honourable the Legislative Assembly, and the Bill was read a second time.
('1', 164, 1, 3, 370902) Your Lordship's Petitioners, as soon as they knew this, lost no time in addressing another petition to the Honourable Council, which was sent on the Thursday following, and was presented on Friday through the same Honourable Member.
('1', 164, 1, 4, 371135) In the meanwhile, i.e., within one day after the second reading, the Bill had passed the committee stage.
('1', 164, 1, 5, 371241) The Honourable Mr. Campbell moved the postponement of the third reading of the Bill, in order that the petition last mentioned might be considered.
('1', 164, 1, 6, 371389) The motion, however, was not carried on the ground that the petition was presented too late.
('1', 164, 1, 7, 371482) The Bill had been hardly four days before the Honourable Council, as Your Lordship will notice.
('1', 164, 1, 8, 371578) Your Lordship's Petitioners may also mention that a deputation was appointed by the leading members of the Indian community to wait upon His Excellency the Honourable Sir Walter F. Hely Hutchinson, who very kindly and courteously received the deputation.
('1', 164, 1, 9, 371833) In order to know the individual opinions of the Honourable Members of the two Houses, a Committee of Indians sent a printed circular 1to the Honourable Members requesting them to answer certain questions.
('1', 164, 1, 10, 372038) Your Petitioners append hereto the Circular and the Memorandum containing the questions.
('1', 164, 1, 11, 372127) So far, only one Honourable Member has been good enough to send a reply, but he, too, has not answered the questions.
('1', 164, 1, 12, 372245) 9. Before proceeding to criticize the Franchise Bill, Your Lordship's Petitioners would beg to dispose of one point that has been used against Your Lordship's Petitioners, namely, that they approached the Honourable Assembly too late.
('1', 164, 1, 13, 372480) As to this, your Petitioners would simply state that they were not technically too late, and that the issues involved were, and are, so important, and the Bill so vitally affected and affects Her Majesty’s Indian subjects that the Government, or the Honourable the Legislative Council and the Legislative Assembly might well have reconsidered their decision and thoroughly investigated Your Lordship’s Petitioners’ case before allowing the Bill to pass the third reading.
('1', 164, 2, 14, 372952) 1Vide “A Circular Letter to Legislators”, 1 7 1894.
('1', 165, 0, 1, 373004) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 166
('1', 165, 1, 2, 373046) 10. During the debate it was stated, as also it is stated in the preamble of the Bill, that the Asiatic communities have never exercised the privilege of Franchise, and it was stated further, during the debate, that the Asiatics were not fit to exercise the Franchise.
('1', 165, 1, 3, 373315) These were, then, the two chief reasons alleged for the exclusion of the Indians from the privilege of the Franchise.
('1', 165, 1, 4, 373433) Your Petitioners venture to believe that the petition to the Honourable Assembly sufficiently disposes of the two contentions above mentioned.
('1', 165, 1, 5, 373576) 11. Although it was not openly acknowledged that the two objections to the Asiatics exercising the Franchise privilege had fallen through, it seemed to be tacitly recognized that such was the case, for it was more openly declared in the third reading of the Bill in the Honourable Assembly, that the exclusion was to be justified, not on moral and equitable grounds, as was contended at the time of the second reading, but on purely political grounds.
('1', 165, 1, 6, 374028) It was said that, if the Indians were allowed to vote, their vote would swamp the European vote, and that there would be a Government by the Asiatics instead of by the Europeans.
('1', 165, 1, 7, 374207) 12. Your Lordship's Petitioners venture [to submit], with the greatest deference to both the Honourable Houses, that the above fears are entirely groundless.
('1', 165, 1, 8, 374365) Even at the present moment there are very few Indian electors as compared with European electors.
('1', 165, 1, 9, 374463) The Indians who come under indenture cannot possibly have the sufficient property qualifications to be qualified for voting during their term of indenture, and for many more years afterwards.
('1', 165, 1, 10, 374655) It is, moreover, a notorious fact that those who come on their own means do not remain for good in the Colony, but after a certain number of years, return home and are replaced by other Indians.
('1', 165, 1, 11, 374850) Thus, so far as the trading community is concerned, the number of votes would, as a rule, always remain unchanged.
('1', 165, 1, 12, 374965) Another fact, too, cannot be lost sight of, viz., that the Indians do not take such an active interest in the political affairs of the Colony as the European section of the community.
('1', 165, 1, 13, 375149) It seems that there are 45,000 Europeans, and the same number of Indians; that fact alone shows how material is the difference between the European and the Indian vote.
('1', 165, 1, 14, 375318) And Your Lordship’s Petitioners submit that it is well nigh impossible that any Indian can hope to enter into the Natal Parliament for generations to come.
('1', 165, 1, 15, 375474) This, Your Lordship's Petitioners humbly submit, hardly needs any proof to support it.
('1', 165, 1, 16, 375561) 13. And if Your Lordship's Petitioners are not unfit to exercise
('1', 166, 0, 1, 375626) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 167
('1', 166, 1, 2, 375660) the privilege, should it matter that they have some voice in the government of the Colony, and more especially the government of themselves?
('1', 166, 1, 3, 375801) 14. Your Lordship’s Petitioners venture to submit that the Bill is admittedly retrograde in character and that it is manifestly unjust.
('1', 166, 1, 4, 375937) 15. The very fact that those who are rightly on the Voters' List are to be allowed to remain there, at once, in your Petitioners' humble opinion, recognizes the ability of your Petitioners to understand the privilege and the responsibility attached to the exercise of the Franchise.
('1', 166, 1, 5, 376220) Your Lordship's Petitioners cannot believe that they are allowed to remain on the List even though they are not fit to vote, as was attempted to be shown in the course of the debate.
('1', 166, 1, 6, 376403) 16. It has also been said that Clause II of the Bill fully meets the ends of justice.
('1', 166, 1, 7, 376489) Your Petitioners submit that it does not.
('1', 166, 1, 8, 376531) On the contrary, it injures the feelings of both those who are on the List and those who are not.
('1', 166, 1, 9, 376629) 17. It is little comfort to those who are already on the List to know that they may vote, while their children never can, no matter how well educated and well qualified they may be.
('1', 166, 1, 10, 376811) Indian parents who settle in the Colony will have, if the Bill becomes law, the best stimulus to give higher education to their children taken away from them.
('1', 166, 1, 11, 376970) They would hardly like to see their sons pariahs of society, without a status or without any ambition in life.
('1', 166, 1, 12, 377081) Even wealth becomes useless if it gives a man no place in society.
('1', 166, 1, 13, 377148) The very aim with which men collect wealth is thus nipped in the bud.
('1', 166, 1, 14, 377218) 18. And the Second Clause vexes those who have been in the Colony already to know that, while their brethren, who are in no way superior to them, by a chance retain the right to vote, they themselves cannot vote simply because, perhaps, owing to circumstances entirely beyond their control, they have not been able to get their names on the Voters' List.
('1', 166, 1, 15, 377573) The Bill thus makes between Indian British subjects of the same class an invidious distinction based on accidental circumstances.
('1', 166, 1, 16, 377703) 19. It has also been hinted that the justice done by the Second Clause is not gratefully acknowledged by your Petitioners.
('1', 166, 1, 17, 377826) But, with the greatest respect to the just intentions of the Government in introducing the Second Clause, Your Lordship's Petitioners have failed to see the justice thereof.
('1', 166, 1, 18, 378000) This was even admitted by some Honourable Members themselves, who did not care whether the Second Clause was
('1', 167, 0, 1, 378109) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 168
('1', 167, 1, 2, 378151) “in” or “out”, as those votes were bound to drop off before long.
('1', 167, 1, 3, 378217) This seems to be self evident.
('1', 167, 1, 4, 378248) 20. Your Lordship's Petitioners have noticed with shame and sorrow the zealous attempt made to compare your Petitioners with the Natives of South Africa.
('1', 167, 1, 5, 378402) Very often it was said the Natives had a better claim to vote, if the Indians had any, simply because they were British subjects.
('1', 167, 1, 6, 378532) Your Lordship's Petitioners would not enter into a discussion of the comparison, but would draw Your Lordship's attention to the Royal Proclamation of 1858, as also to Your Lordship's own personal experience of the Indian nation.
('1', 167, 1, 7, 378762) Your Petitioners need hardly point out the marked difference that exists between the Governments of Indian British subjects and Native British subjects.
('1', 167, 1, 8, 378915) 21. There are, at the present moment, hundreds of educated Indians, signatures of some of whom appear in the petition, who would not be able to vote at the Parliamentary elections if the Bill became law.
('1', 167, 1, 9, 379119) Your Petitioners fully trust that Your Lordship will never advise Her Most Gracious Majesty to sanction a Bill that would cause such a grave injustice to any section of British subjects.
('1', 167, 1, 10, 379306) 22. In the Natal Government Gazette of March 27, 1894, Your Lordship's Petitioners find, from the Indian Immigrants School Board Report for 1893, that there were 26 schools and 2,589 scholars studying in the schools that year.
('1', 167, 1, 11, 379533) Your Petitioners respectfully submit that these boys, who are many of them born in the Colony, are entirely brought up after the European style.
('1', 167, 1, 12, 379678) They, in later life, come in contact chiefly with the European community, and therefore, in every respect, become as fit for the Franchise privilege as any European, unless there is something radically wanting in them to compete with the Europeans in educational ability.
('1', 167, 1, 13, 379950) That they are not incompetent, Your Lordship's Petitioners submit, has been proved beyond doubt by the best authorities on such subjects.
('1', 167, 1, 14, 380088) The results, alike in India as in England, of the competition between English and Indian students, furnish ample proof of the Indian's ability to successfully compete with the European.
('1', 167, 1, 15, 380274) Your Lordship's Petitioners purposely refrain from quoting extracts from the evidence given before the Parliamentary committees, or from great writers on the above head, because that would almost look like carrying coals to Newcastle.
('1', 167, 1, 16, 380509) If, then, your Petitioners humbly venture to claim a vote for these boys when they come of age, is it not merely asking what any person in a civilized country would consider as his birthright and
('1', 168, 0, 1, 380705) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 169
('1', 168, 1, 2, 380739) would very properly resent any interference with?
('1', 168, 1, 3, 380789) Your Petitioners confidently trust that Your Lordship will not let these boys be subjected to the indignity of being deprived of the commonest right of a citizen in a country governed by Parliamentary institutions.
('1', 168, 1, 4, 381004) 23. Your Lordship's Petitioners here have to note with gratitude that the Hon.
('1', 168, 1, 5, 381083) Mr. Campbell and the Hon.
('1', 168, 1, 6, 381109) Mr. Don saw and remarked about the injustice that would be done to those Indians who come to the Colony on their own means, but they, too, seem to think, with the other Honourable Members, that those who come under indenture should never get the vote.
('1', 168, 1, 7, 381361) Your Lordship's Petitioners, while they admit (although they cannot help remarking that poverty should be no crime if a man is otherwise fit) that the indentured Indians, while under indenture, may not have the right to vote, they respectfully submit that even these men should not for ever be deprived from voting if they acquire the sufficient qualifications in later life.
('1', 168, 1, 8, 381737) Such men who come here are, as a rule, ablebodied and young; they come under European influences, and while they are under indenture, and especially after they become free, rapidly begin to assimilate themselves to the European civilization, and develop into full Colonists.
('1', 168, 1, 9, 382012) They are admitted to be very useful, in fact, invaluable people, who live quietly and peacefully.
('1', 168, 1, 10, 382110) It may be remarked that most of the educated Indian youths, who are now in the Civil Service as clerks and interpreters, or outside it as schoolmasters, teachers or attorneys' clerks, have come to the Colony under indenture.
('1', 168, 1, 11, 382335) It is submitted that it would be cruel not to allow them, or their children, to vote and to have a voice in their own government at any rate.
('1', 168, 1, 12, 382477) Your Petitioners submit that the fact alone that a person is of Asiatic extraction or has once been under indenture, should not be a bar to political freedom and political privileges, if he is or becomes otherwise duly fit and qualified.
('1', 168, 1, 13, 382715) 24. Your Lordship's Petitioners beg to draw Your Lordship's attention to the anomaly that the Bill would rank the Indian lower than the rawest Native.
('1', 168, 1, 14, 382866) For while the rawest Native can become emancipated if he acquires the proper qualifications, the Indian British subject who is now entitled to vote would be so disenfranchised that he can never again become emancipated, no matter how capable he becomes in after life, or how capable he is at the time of disenfranchisement.
('1', 168, 1, 15, 383190) 25. The measure is so sweeping and so drastic that, Your
('1', 169, 0, 1, 383247) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 170
('1', 169, 1, 2, 383289) Lordship's Petitioners humbly submit, it is an insult to the whole Indian nation, inasmuch as, if the most distinguished son of India came to Natal and settled, he would not be able to have the right to vote because, presumably, according to the Colonial view, he is unfit for the privilege.
('1', 169, 1, 3, 383581) This hardship was recognized by the Honourable Members in both the Houses, and the Honourable the Treasurer went so far as to say that special cases of hardship may in future be dealt with by the Parliament.
('1', 169, 1, 4, 383789) 26. To illustrate the above argument more fully, your Petitioners would draw Your Lordship's attention to the papers and Government Gazettes in connection with the Indian vote question that was raised and discussed in the late Honourable the Legislative Council of Natal.
('1', 169, 1, 5, 384061) From a Blue book containing the correspondence relating to the affairs of Natal (C 3796, 1883), your Petitioners take the following from Mr. Saunders's letter to the Colonial Office (page 3) :
('1', 169, 2, 6, 384254) The mere definition that these signatures must be in full, and in the elector's own handwriting, and written in European characters, would go a long way to check the extreme risk of the Asiatic mind swamping the English.
('1', 169, 2, 7, 384475) Thus Mr. Saunders, zealous advocate as he was of anti Asiatic policy, could not go further than this.
('1', 169, 2, 8, 384577) In the same letter, the honourable gentleman says further:
('1', 169, 3, 9, 384636) The better class Indians feel and see there is a difference between the raw coolie and themselves.
('1', 169, 3, 10, 384735) Therefore, it seems that the Government of the day was quite willing to distinguish between Indians and Indians.
('1', 169, 3, 11, 384848) Now, unfortunately, under free institutions, all Indians, indentured, and freed, and free, are attempted to be put in the same scale.
('1', 169, 3, 12, 384982) Your Petitioners cannot help respectfully expressing that Mr. Saunder's measure was comparatively very mild compared to the Bill under discussion.
('1', 169, 3, 13, 385129) But that measure, too, did not receive support from Her Majesty's benign Government; much less, therefore, your Petitioners submit, should the Franchise Law Amendment Bill.
('1', 169, 3, 14, 385302) In the same book above referred to, the then Protector of Immigrants, Mr. Graves, says, at page 7 :
('1', 169, 4, 15, 385402) I am of the opinion that only those Indians who have abandoned all claim for themselves and their families for a free return passage to India are justly entitled to the Franchise.
('1', 169, 4, 16, 385582) He very justly pointed out also, that the signature test suggested by Mr. Saunders was not applied in practice to the European electors.
('1', 170, 0, 1, 385719) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 171
('1', 170, 1, 2, 385753) At the same page, the then Attorney General says in his report :
('1', 170, 2, 3, 385818) It will be noticed that the measure drafted by me contains certain clauses which have been adopted from the recommendations of the Select Committee, providing for the carrying out of the alternative plan mentioned in Mr. Saunders's letter, while the proposal for the specific disqualification of aliens has not been considered advisable of adoption.
('1', 170, 2, 4, 386168) Your Lordship's Memorialists would beg to draw Your Lordship's attention to the same learned gentleman's report at page 91 of the same Blue book.
('1', 170, 2, 5, 386314) The temptation to quote again from another report by the same learned Attorney General is irresistible.
('1', 170, 2, 6, 386418) At page 14 (ibid.) he says:
('1', 170, 3, 7, 386446) As regards the proposal to exclude from the exercise of the Franchise all persons of every nationality or race which is not in every respect under the common law of the Colony, this is a provision evidently aimed at the electoral rights at present enjoyed by the Indian and Creole population of this Colony.
('1', 170, 3, 8, 386754) As I have already stated in my report on Bill No.
('1', 170, 3, 9, 386804) 12, I cannot recognize the justice or expediency of such a measure.
('1', 170, 3, 10, 386872) 27. Thus is happens that, under a freer constitution in the Colony, that should include Your Lordship's Petitioners also, the First Responsible Ministry, your Petitioners regret to say, have attempted to make your Petitioners less free, to disenfranchise them wholesale.
('1', 170, 3, 11, 387143) In the face of the fact that, under the old regime, a far less bold attempt to restrict the rights of your Petitioners did not receive countenance from the Home Government, your Petitioners have every hope that the present attempt will meet with the same fate, and justice done to Your Lordship's Petitioners.
('1', 170, 3, 12, 387453) 28. The other pernicious consequences indirectly connected with the Franchise Bill are too numerous to mention; your Petitioners would, however, crave leave to discuss a few.
('1', 170, 3, 13, 387628) 29. It is a known fact that there is, in the Colony, a wide gulf between the European section of the community and the Indian.
('1', 170, 3, 14, 387755) The Indian is hated and shunned by the European.
('1', 170, 3, 15, 387804) He is often needlessly vexed and harassed.
('1', 170, 3, 16, 387847) The Franchise Bill, your Petitioners submit, will only accentuate such a feeling.
('1', 170, 3, 17, 387929) The signs have already begun to appear.
('1', 170, 3, 18, 387969) To verify this, your Petitioners commend the newspapers of the current dates to Your Lordship's attention, and also the debates in both the Honourable Houses.
('1', 170, 3, 19, 388128) 30. It was said, in the course of the debate on the second reading, that the disqualification put upon the Indians would put a
('1', 171, 0, 1, 388255) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 172
('1', 171, 1, 2, 388297) greater responsibility upon the legislators of the Colony and that the Indian interests would be better protected than if they were represented.
('1', 171, 1, 3, 388442) This, Your Lordship's Petitioners beg to submit, is contrary to all experience up to the present time.
('1', 171, 1, 4, 388545) 31. Some Honourable Members thought that the Indians should not be allowed to vote at the Municipal elections also.
('1', 171, 1, 5, 388661) It was whispered, during the debate, among the responsible quarters, that that question would receive attention on a future, but early, date.
('1', 171, 1, 6, 388803) The Franchise Bill is only the proverbial thin end of the wedge.
('1', 171, 1, 7, 388868) Once driven a little, it would not be difficult to drive it through.
('1', 171, 1, 8, 388937) That seemed to be the feeling.
('1', 171, 1, 9, 388968) 32. Your Lordship is aware that it is intended to levy a residential tax on the Indians coming under indenture, should they choose to settle in the Colony.
('1', 171, 1, 10, 389124) The tax, it was said, should be sufficiently heavy not to make it worth their while to stop in the Colony or to make it possible for them to compete with the Colonists.
('1', 171, 1, 11, 389293) That is another indication of how your Petitioners' interests would be better protected if they were disenfranchised!
('1', 171, 1, 12, 389411) 33. During the debate on the Civil Service Bill, it was contended by some Honourable Members that, since the Franchise was to be taken away from the Indians, it was as well that the Indians should be debarred from entering the Civil Service also.
('1', 171, 1, 13, 389658) An amendment was moved to this effect, and was rejected only by the casting vote of the Honourable the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, thanks to the forethought and tact of the Government who requested that the House should be divided.
('1', 171, 1, 14, 389899) Your Petitioners fully recognize that, in this case, the Government took up a very sympathetic attitude towards the Indians; but still, the tendency and portents of these events are unmistakable.
('1', 171, 1, 15, 390095) The Franchise Bill gave the opportunity for the amendment.
('1', 171, 1, 16, 390154) 34. Your Lordship's Petitioners understand that in the Cape Colony no such colour or race distinctions are made.
('1', 171, 1, 17, 390267) 35. Your Lordship's Petitioners respectfully venture to point out that the effect of the Bill, if it became law, will be simply disastrous to the interests of the British Indian subjects in the other parts of South Africa.
('1', 171, 1, 18, 390490) Down trodden and hated as they already are in the Transvaal, things will be simply unbearable for them.
('1', 171, 1, 19, 390594) If Indian British subjects in a British Colony are allowed to be treated at all on an unequal footing, your Petitioners humbly submit that a time will soon come when it will
('1', 172, 0, 1, 390768) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 173
('1', 172, 1, 2, 390802) be impossible for Indians, having any idea whatever of self respect, to remain in the Colony and that such a thing would materially interfere with their business, and throw hundreds of Her Majesty's Indian subjects out of work.
('1', 172, 1, 3, 391030) 36. In conclusion, your Petitioners hope that above facts and arguments will convince Your Lordship of the injustice of the Franchise Law Amendment Bill, and that Your Lordship will not allow an unwarranted interference with the rights of one section of Her Majesty's subjects by another.
('1', 172, 1, 4, 391319) And for this act of justice and mercy, Your Lordship's Petitioners, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, etc., etc.

('1', 172, 5, 9, 391525) 48. LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI C/O MESSRS DADA ABDOOLA & CO., DURBAN, July 14, 1894
('1', 172, 6, 10, 391609) TO THE HON.
('1', 172, 6, 11, 391621) MR. DADABHAI NAOROJI M.P.
('1', 172, 7, 12, 391647) SIR, In continuation of my letter 2 dated the 7th instant, I have to inform you of the progress of the movement against the Franchise Law Amendment Bill as follows : The Bill passed the 3rd reading in the Legislative Council on the 7th instant.
('1', 172, 7, 13, 391892) The other petition to the Council was accepted.
('1', 172, 7, 14, 391940) One Hon.
('1', 172, 7, 15, 391949) Member moved the postponement of the 3rd reading till the petition was considered by the House.
('1', 172, 7, 16, 392045) The motion was rejected.
('1', 172, 7, 17, 392070) The Governor has given his assent to the Bill subject to its being disallowed by Her Majesty.
('1', 172, 7, 18, 392164) The Bill has a proviso in it that it shall not become law until, by a proclamation or otherwise, the Governor signifies that it is not Her Majesty's wish to disallow the Bill.
('1', 172, 8, 19, 392340) 1 Vice President of the Natal Indian Congress, 1894 99
('1', 172, 9, 20, 392395) 2 This letter is not available.
('1', 173, 0, 1, 392427) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 174
('1', 173, 1, 2, 392469) I send you herewith a copy of the petition 1 to the Home Government that will be sent to the Governor here probably on the 17th instant.
('1', 173, 1, 3, 392606) It will be signed by nearly 10,000 Indians.
('1', 173, 1, 4, 392650) Nearly 5,000 signatures have already been received.
('1', 173, 1, 5, 392702) I regret to say that I am unable to send you a copy of the petition 2 to the Council.
('1', 173, 1, 6, 392788) I however beg to send a newspaper cutting which gives a fairly good report.
('1', 173, 1, 7, 392864) I do not think there remains anything more to be added.
('1', 173, 1, 8, 392920) The situation is so critical that if the Franchise Bill becomes law, the position of the Indians 10 years hence will be simply intolerable in the Colony.
('1', 173, 1, 9, 393074) I remain, Your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI

('1', 173, 3, 11, 393166) 49. LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI P. O. B. 253, Confidential DURBAN, July 27, 1894
('1', 173, 4, 12, 393246) TO THE HON.
('1', 173, 4, 13, 393258) MR. DADABHAI NAOROJI, M.P.
('1', 173, 5, 14, 393285) SIR, In continuation of my letter of the 14th instant I have to inform you as follows : The petition to the Home Government, a copy of which has already been sent to you, was sent, I hear, last week.
('1', 173, 5, 15, 393485) Mr. Escombe 3, the Attorney General, has made a report to the effect—f the informant is right—that the only reason for passing the Bill is to prevent the Asiatics from controlling the government of the Natives.
('1', 173, 5, 16, 393696) The real reason, however, is simply this.
('1', 173, 5, 17, 393738) They want to put the Indians under such disabilities and subject them to such insults that it may not be worth their while to stop in the Colony.
('1', 173, 5, 18, 393884) Yet, they do not
('1', 173, 6, 19, 393901) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('1', 173, 7, 20, 393928) 2 Vide "Petition to Natal Legislative Council", 6 7 1894.
('1', 173, 8, 21, 393986) 3 Sir Harry Escombe (1838 99); Premier of Natal in 1897. He pleaded for Gandhiji's admission to the Bar of the Natal Supreme Court.
('1', 174, 0, 1, 394118) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 175
('1', 174, 1, 2, 394152) want to dispense with the Indians altogether.
('1', 174, 1, 3, 394198) They certainly do not want those Indians who come on their own means and they want the indentured Indians very badly; but they would require, if they could, the indentured Indian to return to India after his term of indenture.
('1', 174, 1, 4, 394425) A perfect leonine partnership!
('1', 174, 1, 5, 394456) They know very well that they cannot do this at once—so they have begun with the Franchise Bill.
('1', 174, 1, 6, 394553) They want to feel the pulse of the Home Government on the question.
('1', 174, 1, 7, 394621) One member of the Assembly writes to me that he does not believe that the HomeGovernment would sanction the Bill.
('1', 174, 1, 8, 394735) I need hardly say how important it is for the Indian community that the Bill should not receive the sanction.
('1', 174, 1, 9, 394845) Natal is not a bad place for the Indians.
('1', 174, 1, 10, 394887) Good many Indian traders earn a respectable living here.
('1', 174, 1, 11, 394944) The Bill, if it became law, would be a very great blow to further Indian enterprise.
('1', 174, 1, 12, 395029) Of course, I may state again, as I have done once, that there is not the slightest probability of the government of the Natives passing from the Europeans to the Indians.
('1', 174, 1, 13, 395200) This is simply meant to frighten the Home Government.
('1', 174, 1, 14, 395254) Those who live here—including the Government—know very well that such a thing will never happen.
('1', 174, 1, 15, 395351) They do not want the Indians to elect white members—2 or 3—who may look after their interests in the Parliament, so that the Government may work their way towards the destruction of the Indians without any opposition whatever.
('1', 174, 1, 16, 395578) I have sent copies of the petition to Sir W. Wedderburn 1 and others there and also some copies to Indian newspapers.
('1', 174, 1, 17, 395696) Please excuse the length of my letters.
('1', 174, 1, 18, 395736) You will very much oblige me by giving hints as to the way of working.
('1', 174, 2, 19, 395807) I beg to remain, Sir Your faithful servant M. K. GANDHI

('1', 175, 3, 6, 396238) LEWIS 1, I thank you for your kind letter of the 27th June.
('1', 175, 3, 7, 396298) After I wrote to you last, 2 I had occasion to come in contact with a doctor in Pretoria.
('1', 175, 3, 8, 396388) He seemed to be the only gentleman in addition to another who took interest in theosophical subjects.
('1', 175, 3, 9, 396490) I gave him The Perfect Way to read.
('1', 175, 3, 10, 396526) He liked it so much that he wished me to get another copy for him.
('1', 175, 3, 11, 396593) I made him a present of my copy.
('1', 175, 3, 12, 396626) I would therefore thank you if you will kindly send me a copy of The Perfect Way.
('1', 175, 3, 13, 396708) I would send you the money next time.
('1', 175, 3, 14, 396746) I have no time to do so this time.
('1', 175, 3, 15, 396781) I have settled in Durban for practice as an advocate.
('1', 175, 3, 16, 396835) More of this you will know from Mr. Oldfield.
('1', 175, 3, 17, 396881) During my stay here I intend to spread as much as possible information about theosophy.
('1', 175, 3, 18, 396969) (To me there is little difference between Theosophy and Esoteric Christianity).
('1', 175, 3, 19, 397049) I have therefore sent out letters 3
('1', 175, 4, 20, 397085) to the President of the Vegetarian Society and Mrs. Besant 4. I propose that the E.C.U. 5 should send me a selection of books to be sold here.
('1', 175, 4, 21, 397228) I would sell the books at cost price plus the postage and 5% commission to be kept by me.
('1', 175, 4, 22, 397318) As to the price, however, I should be left free to use my discretion.
('1', 175, 4, 23, 397388) I would send up the 6 sale proceeds of the books every three months.
('1', 175, 4, 24, 397457) The advertisement charges will be borne by me.
('1', 175, 4, 25, 397504) If at the end of one year nothing is sold, I would
('1', 175, 5, 26, 397555) 1 An admirer of Anna Kingsford, author of The Perfect Way, etc., and friend of Edward Maitland, President of the Esoteric Christian Union; she was a founder of the Union.
('1', 175, 5, 27, 397726) Gandhiji appears to have come into close contact with her while studying for the Bar in England.
('1', 175, 6, 28, 397823) 2 The letter is not available.
('1', 175, 7, 29, 397854) 3 These are not available.
('1', 175, 8, 30, 397881) 4 Dr. Annie Besant, the theosophist leader
('1', 175, 9, 31, 397924) 5 Esoteric Christian Union.

('1', 176, 1, 2, 398071) return the books at my cost.

('1', 176, 1, 4, 398186) 5 copies of The Perfect Way, 5 of Clothed with the Sun and 10 of The New Gospel of Interpretation and other books may be sent to me.
('1', 176, 1, 5, 398319) If sufficient interest is evoked, I would add on the advertising charges also to the cost price.
('1', 176, 1, 6, 398416) The cost price of the books should be stated in each case in the letter of instruction.

('1', 176, 1, 8, 398593) I hope you will be able to persuade the Union or those in authority to accede to the above proposal.
('1', 176, 1, 9, 398694) If you do not think much of the Souls, what position is the book to occupy in respectable literature?
('1', 176, 1, 10, 398796) If the author has written what is absolutely true from personal observation, the book cannot be lightly treated.
('1', 176, 1, 11, 398909) If it is an attempt to delude the people into a belief in real truths by fascinating falsehoods, the book deserves the highest condemnation possible.
('1', 176, 1, 12, 399059) For we will not learn truth by means of falsehoods.
('1', 176, 1, 13, 399111) Of course I write this without meaning the slightest disrespect for the author of whom I know nothing.
('1', 176, 1, 14, 399214) She may be a lady of the highest probity and truth.
('1', 176, 1, 15, 399266) I only repeat that to appreciate the Souls, acquaintance with the author's character is absolutely necessary.
('1', 176, 1, 16, 399376) I could get many signatures to the petition you enclosed.
('1', 176, 1, 17, 399434) But I am afraid the Natal signatures would be quite useless.
('1', 176, 1, 18, 399495) Is it not a sad commentary on the morality of the age that a most important, and yet most harmless and elevating, movement should not receive good support?
('1', 176, 1, 19, 399651) At times when I think of these things, I thoroughly despair of fruits of works.
('1', 176, 1, 20, 399731) A verse from the Bhagavad Gita saves me from utter despair and consequent inaction—a verse which enjoins freedom from attachment to fruits of works.
('1', 176, 1, 21, 399880) With respects,

('1', 177, 11, 13, 401401) CONDITIONS OF MEMBERSHIP
('1', 177, 12, 14, 401426) Any person approving of the work of the Congress can become its member by paying the subscription and signing the membership form.
('1', 177, 12, 15, 401557) The monthly subscription is 5/ minimum and yearly £3.
('1', 178, 0, 1, 401611) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 179
('1', 178, 1, 2, 401645) THE OBJECTS OF THE NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS 1
('1', 178, 2, 3, 401688) 1. To promote concord and harmony among the Indians and the Europeans residing in the Colony.
('1', 178, 2, 4, 401782) 2. To inform the people in India by writing to the newspapers, publishing pamphlets, and delivering lectures.
('1', 178, 2, 5, 401892) 3. To induce Hindustanis—particularly Colonial born Indians— to study Indian history and literature relating to India.
('1', 178, 2, 6, 402011) 4. To inquire into the conditions of the Indians and to take proper steps to remove their hardships.
('1', 178, 2, 7, 402112) 5. To inquire into the conditions of the indentured Indians and to take proper steps to alleviate their sufferings.
('1', 178, 2, 8, 402228) 6. To help the poor and helpless in every reasonable way.
('1', 178, 2, 9, 402286) 7. To do such work as would tend to improve the moral, social and political conditions of the Indians.
('1', 178, 3, 10, 402389) RULES AMENDED OR CANCELLED BY THE COMMITTEE AND
('1', 178, 4, 11, 402437) RATIFIED BY THE CONGRESS
('1', 178, 5, 12, 402462) 1. Authority is given to rent a hall for meetings for a sum not exceeding £10 monthly.
('1', 178, 5, 13, 402549) 2. The Committee shall meet at least once every month.
('1', 178, 5, 14, 402604) 3. The General Meeting of the Congress shall be held at least once every year—not necessarily in Durban.
('1', 178, 5, 15, 402709) 4. The Hon.
('1', 178, 5, 16, 402721) Secretary shall invite members from other parts of the Colony.
('1', 178, 5, 17, 402784) 5. The Committee shall have the power to frame and pass rules and shall have all other powers of ordinary transaction.
('1', 178, 5, 18, 402903) 6. The Committee shall have the power to appoint a paid Secretary at a reasonable salary.
('1', 178, 5, 19, 402993) 7. The Hon.
('1', 178, 5, 20, 403005) Secretary shall, if he chooses, invite a European who takes interest in the welfare of the Congress to be a Vice President.
('1', 178, 5, 21, 403129) 8. The Hon.
('1', 178, 5, 22, 403141) Secretary shall, if he chooses, subscribe for the newspapers and books for the Congress Library out of the Congress Fund.

('1', 179, 1, 2, 403405) 9. The Hon.
('1', 179, 1, 3, 403417) Secretary shall record in the Account Book whether a cheque is signed by himself or jointly with the signature of another.
('1', 179, 2, 4, 403540) RULES PASSED BY THE COMMITTEE
('1', 179, 3, 5, 403570) 1. The Chairman shall preside at every meeting; in his absence, the first member of the Committee; if he too be absent, then the second member and so on.
('1', 179, 3, 6, 403724) 2. The Hon.
('1', 179, 3, 7, 403736) Secretary shall, at the commencement of a meeting, read out the minutes of the last meeting after which the President shall sign it.
('1', 179, 3, 8, 403869) 3. The Committee may not recognize a proposal or a resolution for which no notice had been given in advance to the Secretary for its introduction.
('1', 179, 3, 9, 404016) 4. The Hon.
('1', 179, 3, 10, 404028) Secretary shall read out a detailed account of moneys received or spent by the Committee or the Congress.
('1', 179, 3, 11, 404134) 5. The Committee may not attend to a proposal unless such is proposed by a Committee member and seconded by another.
('1', 179, 3, 12, 404251) 6. The Chairman and the Secretary shall be counted by virtue of their offices as Committee members.
('1', 179, 3, 13, 404351) In case of equal voting, the Chairman shall have a casting vote.
('1', 179, 3, 14, 404416) 7. Every member shall face the Chairman when addressing a meeting.
('1', 179, 3, 15, 404483) 8. Every member shall use the word Mr. in addressing another member at a Committee meeting.
('1', 179, 3, 16, 404575) 9. The proceedings of a Committee meeting shall be carried on in one or all of the following languages: Gujarati, Tamil, Hindustani and English.
('1', 179, 3, 17, 404720) 10. If it be deemed necessary, the Chairman shall order a member to translate the speech of another member.
('1', 179, 3, 18, 404828) 11. Every proposal or resolution shall pass by a majority of votes.
('1', 179, 3, 19, 404896) 12. When the Congress has £50 minimum in hand, the Hon.
('1', 179, 3, 20, 404952) Secretary shall deposit such amount in any bank he chooses in the name of the Natal Indian Congress.
('1', 179, 3, 21, 405053) 13. The Hon.
('1', 179, 3, 22, 405066) Secretary shall be held responsible for any moneys he has not deposited in the Bank.
('1', 179, 3, 23, 405151) 14. An authority shall be first obtained from the Committee for any irregular expenditure exceeding the sum of £5. If any expenses
('1', 180, 0, 1, 405282) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 181
('1', 180, 1, 2, 405316) are incurred exceeding the above sum by the Chairman or the Secretary without the sanction and approval of the Committee, it shall be held that he did it at his own responsibility.
('1', 180, 1, 3, 405497) The Hon.
('1', 180, 1, 4, 405506) Secretary shall sign cheques up to the sum of £5, and for any amount exceeding the said sum [they] shall be signed jointly with any of the following members : Messrs Abdoola Hajee Adam, Moosa Hajee Cassim, Abdo ol Kadar, Colundaveloo Pillay, P. Dawjee Mahomed, Hoosen Cassim.
('1', 180, 1, 5, 405782) 15. A quorum shall be formed of ten members, in addition to the Chairman and the Secretary, to carry on the work of the meeting.
('1', 180, 1, 6, 405911) 16. The Hon.
('1', 180, 1, 7, 405924) Secretary shall issue notice of a proposed meeting not less than two days in advance.
('1', 180, 1, 8, 406010) 17. It shall be held that the 16th rule was observed provided a written notification was given through the post or a messenger.
('1', 180, 1, 9, 406138) 18. Any Committee member who is absent from six consecutive meetings shall be liable to have his name struck off the list (after having been notified by the Committee of such intention).
('1', 180, 1, 10, 406325) A member who is absent from a meeting shall show the cause of his absence at the next meeting.
('1', 180, 1, 11, 406420) 19. Any member who fails to pay his subscription for three consecutive months without showing any reasonable ground shall cease to be a member.
('1', 180, 1, 12, 406564) 20. No smoking shall be allowed at any Committee meeting.
('1', 180, 1, 13, 406622) 21. If two members get up simultaneously to speak, the chairman shall decide who is to speak first.
('1', 180, 1, 14, 406722) 22. If a sufficient number of members is present the Committee meeting shall proceed at its appointed hour.
('1', 180, 1, 15, 406830) However, if the sufficient number is deficient at the appointed time or half an hour after it, the meeting shall terminate without any transaction.
('1', 180, 1, 16, 406978) 23. The Natal Indian Association may use the Hall and the Library free of charge, and they, in return, shall give their reasonable services such as doing writing work, etc.
('1', 180, 1, 17, 407151) 24. All the members of the Congress shall be entitled to use the Congress Library.
('1', 180, 1, 18, 407234) 25. The Committee members shall sit in an enclosure and the onlookers outside.
('1', 180, 1, 19, 407313) The onlookers must not take any part in the proceedings.
('1', 180, 1, 20, 407370) Should they create any disturbance by shouting, etc., they shall be liable to be expelled from the Hall.

('1', 181, 3, 4, 407616) 52. LETTER TO “THE TIMES OF NATAL” 2
('1', 181, 4, 5, 407653) DURBAN, October 25, 1894
('1', 181, 5, 6, 407678) TO THE EDITOR The Times of Natal
('1', 181, 6, 7, 407711) SIR, I would, with your permission, venture to make a few remarks on your leader, entitled “Rammysammy”, in your issue of the 22nd instant.
('1', 181, 6, 8, 407851) I have no wish to defend the article in The Times of India noticed by you; but is not your very leader its sufficient defence?

('1', 184, 1, 2, 413057) 54. LETTER TO “THE NATAL MERCURY”
('1', 184, 2, 3, 413091) DURBAN, November 26, 1894
('1', 184, 3, 4, 413117) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Mercury
('1', 184, 4, 5, 413149) SIR, You will greatly oblige me by allowing me to draw the attention of your readers to an advertisement that appears in your advertisement columns with regard to the Esoteric Christian Union.
('1', 184, 4, 6, 413342) The system of thought expounded by the books advertised is not, by any means, a new system but a recovery of the old, presented in a form acceptable to the modern mind.
('1', 184, 4, 7, 413511) It is, moreover, a system of religion which teaches universality, and is based on eternal verities and not on phenomena or historical facts merely.
('1', 184, 4, 8, 413659) In that system, there is no reviling Mahomed or Buddha in order to prove the superiority of Jesus.
('1', 184, 4, 9, 413758) On the other hand, it reconciles the other religions with Christianity which, in the opinion of the authors, is nothing but one mode (among many) of presentation of the same eternal truth.
('1', 184, 4, 10, 413947) The many puzzles of the Old Testament find herein a solution at once complete and satisfactory.
('1', 184, 4, 11, 414043) If there is anyone of your readers who has found the presentday materialism and all its splendour to be insufficient for the needs of his soul, if he has a craving for a better life, and if, under the dazzling and bright surface of modern civilization, he finds that there is much that is contrary to what one would expect under such a surface, and above all, if the modern luxuries and the ceaseless feverish activity afford no relief, to such a one I beg to recommend the books referred to.
('1', 184, 4, 12, 414536) And I promise that, after a perusal, he will find himself a better man, even though he may not thoroughly identify himself with the teaching.
('1', 184, 4, 13, 414678) If there is anyone who would like to have a chat on the subject, it would afford me the greatest pleasure to have a quiet interchange of views.
('1', 184, 4, 14, 414822) In such a case, I would thank any such gentleman to correspond with me personally.
('1', 184, 4, 15, 414905) I need hardly mention that the sale of the books is not a pecuniary concern.
('1', 184, 4, 16, 414982) Could Mr. Maitland, the President of the Union, or its agent here, afford to give them away, they would gladly do so.
('1', 184, 4, 17, 415100) In many cases, the books have been sold at
('1', 185, 0, 1, 415143) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 186
('1', 185, 1, 2, 415185) less than cost price.
('1', 185, 1, 3, 415207) In a few, t hey have even been given away.
('1', 185, 1, 4, 415250) A systematic distribution for nothing has been found impossible.
('1', 185, 1, 5, 415315) The books will be gladly lent in some cases.
('1', 185, 1, 6, 415360) I would try to conclude with a quotation from a letter of the late Abbe Constant to the authors : “Humanity has always and everywhere asked itself these three supreme questions: Whence come we?
('1', 185, 1, 7, 415554) What are we?
('1', 185, 1, 8, 415567) Whither go we?
('1', 185, 1, 9, 415582) Now these questions at length find an answer complete, satisfactory, and consolatory in The Perfect Way.”
('1', 185, 2, 10, 415688) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Natal Mercury, 3 12 1894

('1', 185, 7, 18, 415889) SIRS, Were it possible to write to you anonymously, nothing would have been more pleasing to me.
('1', 185, 7, 19, 415986) But the statements I shall have to make in this letter will be so grave and important that it would be considered a sheer act of cowardice not to disclose my name.
('1', 185, 7, 20, 416150) I beg, however, to assure you that I write not from selfish motives, nor yet from those of self aggrandisement or of seeking notoriety.
('1', 185, 7, 21, 416286) The one and only object is to serve India, which is by accident of birth called my native country, and to bring about better understanding between the European section of the community and the Indian in this Colony.
('1', 185, 7, 22, 416502) The only way this can be done is to appeal to those who represent and, at the same time, mould public opinion.
('1', 185, 7, 23, 416613) Hence, if the Europeans and the Indians live in a perpetual state of quarrel, the blame would lie on your shoulders.
('1', 185, 7, 24, 416730) If both can walk together and live together quietly and without friction, you will receive

('1', 186, 1, 4, 417077) Gladstone's opinions are the opinions of half England, and Salisbury's are those of the other half.

('1', 186, 2, 21, 418728) The question what use the Colony will make of the 40,000 Indians is, I submit, worthy of the most serious consideration by the Colonists, and especially those who have the reins of Government in

('1', 187, 1, 4, 419383) Most of them have settled here with their families.

('1', 187, 1, 8, 419830) It is for you to say whether you will lower them or raise them in the scale of civilization, whether you will bring them down to a level lower than what they should occupy on account of heredity, whether you will alienate their hearts from you, or whether you will draw them closer to you—whether, in short, you would govern them despotically or sympathetically.
('1', 187, 1, 9, 420193) You can educate public opinion in such a way that the hatred will be increased day by day; and you can, if you chose so to do, educate it in such a way that the hatred would begin to subside.

('1', 187, 1, 11, 420506) 2. What are they?

('1', 187, 1, 14, 420858) I In discussing the first question, I will deal, first of all, with the Indians employed as labourers, most of whom have come to the Colony under indenture.
('1', 187, 1, 15, 421015) It seems to have been acknowledged by those who are supposed to know, that the indentured Indians are indispensable for the welfare of the Colony; whether as menials or waiters, whether as railway servants or gardeners, they are a useful addition to the Colony.

('1', 188, 3, 21, 423784) One seeks the solution in the introduction of a yellow race, able to stand a tropical climate and intelligent enough to undertake those special avocations which in temperate climates would be filled by Europeans.

('1', 189, 1, 3, 424699) The Indian, liked by both black and white, will serve as a link between these two divergent races.
('1', 189, 1, 4, 424798) As to the Indian traders, who are miscalled Arabs, it would appear best to consider the objections raised to their coming to the Colony.
('1', 189, 1, 5, 424935) From the papers, especially The Natal Mercury of 6 7 '94, and The Natal Advertiser of 15 9 '93, the objections appear to be that they are successful traders, and that, their mode of living being very simple, they compete with the European trader in petty trades.

('1', 189, 1, 13, 425803) He who runs may see that it is nothing but their habits, which are extremely simple, though not barbarous, as The Natal Advertiser would have it.
('1', 189, 1, 14, 425949) The chiefest element of their success, in my humble opinion, is their total abstinence from drink and its attendant evils.
('1', 189, 1, 15, 426072) That habit at once causes an enormous saving of money.
('1', 189, 1, 16, 426127) Moreover, their tastes are simple, and they are satisfied with comparatively small profits, because they do not keep uselessly large establishments.

('1', 189, 1, 18, 426336) It is difficult to see how these facts can be urged as an objection to their stopping in the Colony.
('1', 189, 1, 19, 426437) Of course, they do not gamble, as a rule do not smoke, and can put up with little inconveniences; work more than eight hours a day.
('1', 189, 1, 20, 426569) Should they be expected to, is it desirable that they should, abandon these virtues, and contract the terrible vices under which the Western nations are groaning, so that they may be permitted to live in the Colony without molestation?

('1', 190, 1, 2, 427039) much that is said against their insanitary habits proceeds merely out of spite and hatred, there is no denying that in this respect they are not everything that could be desired.

('1', 190, 1, 8, 427693) I may be allowed to say, from personal experience, that the trading community are compelled by their religion to bathe once a week at least, and have to perform ablutions, i.e., wash their faces and hands up to the elbows, and their feet, every time they offer prayers.
('1', 190, 1, 9, 427963) They are supposed to offer prayers four times a day, and there are very few who fail to do so at least twice a day.
('1', 190, 1, 10, 428079) It will, I hope, be readily admitted that they are exceptionally free from those vices which render a community a danger to society.
('1', 190, 1, 11, 428212) They yield to no one in their obedience to constitutional authority.

('1', 190, 1, 13, 428316) And except the ruffians who are sometimes picked out, of course unknowingly, by the immigration agents at Calcutta and Madras, they seem to be free from the highly grievous offences.
('1', 190, 1, 14, 428499) I regret that my inability to compare the Criminal Court statistics prevents me from making any further observations on this point.
('1', 190, 1, 15, 428631) I will, however, beg leave to quote from the Natal Almanac: “It must be said for the Indian population that it is on the whole orderly and law abiding.” I submit that the above facts show that the Indian labourers are not only desirable but useful citizens of the Colony, and also absolutely essential to its well being, and that the traders have nothing in them that should render them undesirable in the Colony.
('1', 190, 1, 16, 429045) As to these latter, before quitting the subject, I would further add that they are a veritable blessing to the poor portion of the European community, in so far as by their keen competition they keep down the prices of necessities of life; and knowing their language and under standing their customs, are indispensable to the Indian labourers, whose wants they study and supply, and whom they can deal with on better terms than the Europeans.
('1', 190, 3, 17, 429488) The second head of the enquiry is the most important, viz., what
('1', 191, 0, 1, 429553) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 192
('1', 191, 1, 2, 429595) are they, and I request you to peruse it carefully.
('1', 191, 1, 3, 429647) My purpose in writing on this subject will have been served if only it stimulates a study of India and its people; for, I thoroughly believe that one half, or even three fourths, of the hardships entailed upon the Indians in South Africa result from want of information about India.
('1', 191, 1, 4, 429930) No one can be more conscious than myself of whom I am addressing this letter to.
('1', 191, 1, 5, 430011) Some Honourable Members may resent this portion of my letter as an insult.
('1', 191, 1, 6, 430086) To such I say with the greatest deference: “I am aware that you know a great deal about India.
('1', 191, 1, 7, 430181) But is it not a cruel fact that the Colony is not the better for your knowledge?
('1', 191, 1, 8, 430262) Certainly the Indians are not, unless the knowledge acquired by you is entirely different from and opposed to that acquired by others who have worked in the same field.
('1', 191, 1, 9, 430431) Again, although this humble effort is directly addressed to you, it is supposed to reach many others, in fact all who have an interest in the future of the Colony with its present inhabitants.” In spite of the Premier's opinion to the contrary, as expressed in his speech at the second reading of the Franchise Bill, with the utmost deference to His Honour, I venture to point out that both the English and the Indians spring from a common stock, called the Indo Aryan.
('1', 191, 1, 10, 430901) I would not be able, in support of the above, to give extracts from many authors, as the books of reference at my disposal are unfortunately very few.
('1', 191, 1, 11, 431052) I, however, quote as follows from Sir W. W. Hunter's Indian Empire:
('1', 191, 2, 12, 431120) This nobler race (meaning the early Aryans) belonged to the Aryan or Indo Germanic stock, from which the Brahman, the Rajput, and the Englishman alike descend.
('1', 191, 2, 13, 431280) Its earliest home visible to history was in Central Asia.
('1', 191, 2, 14, 431338) From that common camping ground certain branches of the race started for the East, others for the West.
('1', 191, 2, 15, 431442) One of the Western offshoots founded the Persian Kingdom; another built Athens and Lacedaemon, and became the Hellenic nation; a third went on to Italy and reared the city on the seven hills, which grew into Imperial Rome.
('1', 191, 2, 16, 431665) A distant colony of the same race excavated the silver ores of prehistoric Spain; and when we first catch a sight of ancient England, we see an Aryan settlement, fishing in wattle canoes and working the tin mines of Cornwall.
('1', 191, 3, 17, 431891) The forefathers of the Greek and the Roman, of the Englishman and the Hindoo, dwelt together in Asia, spoke the same tongue and worshipped the same gods.
('1', 191, 4, 18, 432045) The ancient religions of Europe and India had a similar origin.
('1', 192, 0, 1, 432109) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 193
('1', 192, 1, 2, 432143) Thus, it will be seen that the learned historian, who must be supposed to have consulted all the authorities, without a shadow of doubt makes the above unqualified assertion.
('1', 192, 1, 3, 432318) If then I err, I err in good company.
('1', 192, 1, 4, 432356) And the belief, whether mistaken or well founded, serves as the basis of operations of those who are trying to unify the hearts of the two races, which are, legally and outwardly, bound together under a common flag.
('1', 192, 1, 5, 432572) A general belief seems to prevail in the Colony that the Indians are little better, if at all, than savages or the Natives of Africa.
('1', 192, 1, 6, 432706) Even the children are taught to believe in that manner, with the result that the Indian is being dragged down to the position of a raw Kaffir 1. Such a state of things, which the Christian legislators of the Colony would not, I firmly believe, wittingly allow to exist and remain, must be my excuse for the following copious extracts, which will show at once that the Indians were, and are, in no way inferior to their Anglo Saxon brethren, if I may venture to use the word, in the various departments of life—industrial, intellectual, political, etc.
('1', 192, 1, 7, 433258) As to Indian philosophy and religion, the learned author of the Indian Empire thus sums up :
('1', 192, 2, 8, 433351) The Brahmin solutions to the problems of practical religion were self discipline, alms, sacrifice to and contemplation of the Deity.
('1', 192, 2, 9, 433484) But, besides the practical questions of the spiritual life, religion has also intellectual problems, such as the compatibility of evil with the goodness of God, and the unequal distribution of happiness and misery in this life.
('1', 192, 2, 10, 433712) Brahmin philosophy has exhausted the possible solutions of these difficulties, and of most of the other great problems which have since perplexed the Greek and Roman sage, mediaeval schoolman and modern man of science (the italics are mine).
('1', 192, 2, 11, 433954) The various hypotheses of creation, arrangement and development were each elaborated and the views of physiologists at the present day are a return with new lights to the evolution theory of Kapila 2 (the italics are mine).
('1', 192, 2, 12, 434178) The works on religion published in the native language in India in 1877 numbered 1192, besides 56 on mental and moral philosophy.
('1', 192, 2, 13, 434308) In 1882 the total had risen to 1545 on religion and 153 on mental and moral philosophy.

('1', 200, 3, 18, 454456) Here are a few samples : “The real canker that is eating into the very vitals of the community”; “these parasites”; “Wily, wretched, semi barbarous Asiatics”; “a thing black and lean and a long way from clean, which they call the accursed Hindoo”; “he is chock full of vice, and he lives upon rice....

('1', 200, 3, 20, 454845) The Press almost unanimously refuses to call the Indian by his proper name.
('1', 200, 3, 21, 454921) He is “Ramsamy”; he is “Mr. Sammy”; he is “Mr. Coolie”; he is “he black man”.
('1', 200, 3, 22, 454999) And these offensive epithets have become so common that they (at any rate one of them, “coolie) are used even in the sacred precincts of the
('1', 201, 0, 1, 455140) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 202
('1', 201, 1, 2, 455182) Courts, as if “the coolie” were the legal and proper name to give to any and every Indian.
('1', 201, 1, 3, 455273) The public men, too, seem to use the word freely.
('1', 201, 1, 4, 455323) I have often heard the painful expressio “coolie clerk” from the mouths of men who ought to know better.
('1', 201, 1, 5, 455428) The expression is a contradiction in terms and is extremely offensive to those to whom it is applied.
('1', 201, 1, 6, 455530) But then, in this Colony the Indian is a creature without feelings!
('1', 201, 1, 7, 455598) The tramcars are not for the Indians.
('1', 201, 1, 8, 455636) The railway officialsmay treat the Indians as beasts.
('1', 201, 1, 9, 455690) No matter how clean, his very sight is such an offence to every white man in the Colony that he would object to sit, even for a short time, in the same compartment with the Indian.
('1', 201, 1, 10, 455871) The hotels shut their doors against them.
('1', 201, 1, 11, 455913) I know instances of respectable Indians having been denied a night's lodging in an hotel.
('1', 201, 1, 12, 456003) Even the public baths are not for the Indians, no matter who they are.
('1', 201, 1, 13, 456074) If I am to depend upon one tenth of the reports that I have received with regard to the treatment of the indentured Indians on the various estates, it would form a terrible indictment against the humanity of the masters on the estates and the care taken by the Protector of Indian immigrants.
('1', 201, 1, 14, 456367) This, however, is a subject which my extremely limited experience of it precludes me from making further remarks upon.
('1', 201, 1, 15, 456486) The Vagrant Law is needlessly oppressive, and often puts respectable Indians in a very awkward position.
('1', 201, 1, 16, 456591) Add to this the rumours that are rife in the air, to the effect that they should be made, or induced, to live in Locations.
('1', 201, 1, 17, 456715) It may be merely an intention; none the less, it is an index of the feeling of the European Colonists against the Indians.
('1', 201, 1, 18, 456838) I beseech you to picture to yourself the state the Indian would be in in Natal if it were possible to carry out all suchintentions.
('1', 201, 1, 19, 456970) Now, is this treatment in consonance with the British traditions of justice, or morality, or Christianity?
('1', 201, 1, 20, 457077) I would, with your permission, quote an extract from Macaulay, and leave it to you to answer the question as to whether the present treatment would have met with his approval.
('1', 201, 1, 21, 457253) Speaking on the subject of the treatment of the Indians, he expressed the following sentiments:
('1', 201, 2, 22, 457349) We shall never consent to administer the pousta 1 to a whole community, to stupefy and paralyse a great people whom God has committed to our charge, for the
('1', 201, 3, 23, 457506) 1 Seed of opium poppy
('1', 202, 0, 1, 457528) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 203
('1', 202, 1, 2, 457562) wretched purpose of rendering them more amenable to our control.
('1', 202, 1, 3, 457627) What is that power worth which is founded on vice, on ignorance, and on misery, which we can hold by violating the most sacred duties which as governors we owe to the governed, which as a people blessed with far more than an ordinary measure of political liberty and of intellectual light we owe to a race debased by three thousand years of despotism and priestcraft?
('1', 202, 1, 4, 457995) We are free, we are civilized, to little purpose, if we grudge to any portion of the human race an equal measure of freedom and civilization.
('1', 202, 1, 5, 458137) I have but to refer you to writers like Mill, Burke, Bright, and Fawcett 1, to further show that they, at any rate, would not give countence to the treatment accorded to the Indians in the Colony.
('1', 202, 1, 6, 458334) To bring a man here on starvation wages, to hold him under bondage, and when he shows the least signs of liberty, or, is in a position to live less miserably, to wish to send him back to his home where he would become comparatively a stranger and perhaps unable to earn a living, is hardly a mark of fair play or justice characteristic of the British nation.
('1', 202, 1, 7, 458693) That the treatment of the Indians is contrary to the teaching of Christianity needs hardly any argument.
('1', 202, 1, 8, 458798) The Man, who taught us to love our enemies and to give our clock to the one who wanted the coat, and to hold out the right cheek when the left was smitten, and who swept away the distinction between the Jew and the Gentile, would never brook a disposition that causes a man to be so proud of himself as to consider himself polluted even by the touch of a fellow being.
('1', 202, 3, 9, 459167) The last head of the enquiry has, I believe, been sufficiently discussed in discussing the first.
('1', 202, 3, 10, 459265) And I for one would not be much grieved in an experiment were tried to drive out each and every Indian from the Colony.
('1', 202, 3, 11, 459385) In that case, I have not the slightest doubt that the Colonists would soon rue the day when they took the step and would wish they had not done it.
('1', 202, 3, 12, 459533) The petty trades and the petty avocations of life would be left alone.
('1', 202, 3, 13, 459604) The work for which they are specially suited would not be taken up by the Europeans, and the Colony would lose an immense amount of revenue now derived from the Indians.
('1', 202, 3, 14, 459774) The climate of South Africa is not such as would enable the Europeans to do the work that they can easily do in Europe.
('1', 202, 3, 15, 459894) What, however, I do submit with the greatest deference is this, that if the Indians must be kept in the Colony, then let them receive such treatment as by their
('1', 202, 4, 16, 460055) 1 Henry Fawcett (1833 84); statesman and professor of Political Economy at Cambridge
('1', 203, 0, 1, 460140) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 204
('1', 203, 1, 2, 460182) ability and integrity they may be fit to receive, that is to say, give them what is their due, and what is the least that a sense of justice, unalloyed by partiality or prejudice, should prompt you to give them.
('1', 203, 1, 3, 460394) It now remains for me only to implore you to give this matter your earnest consideration, and to remind you (here I mean especially the English) that Providence has put the English and the Indians together, and has placed in the hands of the former the destinies of the latter, and it will largely depend upon what every Englishman does with respect to the Indian and how he treats him, whether the putting together will result in an ever lasting union brought about by broad sympathy, love, free mutual intercourse, and also a right knowledge of the Indian character, or whether the putting together will simply last so long as the English have sufficient resources to keep the Indians under check, and the naturally mild Indians have not been vexed into active opposition to the foreign yoke.
('1', 203, 1, 4, 461189) I have, further, to remind you that the English in England have shown by their writings, speeches and deeds that they mean to unify the hearts of the two peoples, that they do not believe in colour distinctions, and that they will raise India with them rather than rise upon its ruins.
('1', 203, 1, 5, 461475) In support of this I beg to refer you to Bright, Fawcett, Bradlaugh, Gladstone, Wedderburn, Pincott, Ripon, Reay, Northbrooke, Dufferin, and a host of other eminent Englishmen who represent public opinion.
('1', 203, 1, 6, 461681) The very fact of an English constituency returning an Indian to the British Ho 1use of Commons, in spite of the expressed wish to the contrary of the then Prime Minister, and almost the whole British Press, both Conservative and Liberal, congratulating the Indian member on the success, and expressing its approval of the unique event, and the whole House again, both Conservative and Liberal, according him a warm welcome—this fact alone, I submit, supports my statement.
('1', 203, 1, 7, 462154) Will you, then, follow them, or will you strike out a new path?
('1', 203, 1, 8, 462218) Will you promote unity, “which is the condition of progress”, or will you promote discord, “which is the condition of degradation”?
('1', 203, 1, 9, 462350) In conclusion, I beg of you to receive the above in the same spirit in which it has been written.
('1', 203, 1, 10, 462448) I have the honour to remain, Your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI

('1', 204, 1, 2, 462644) 56. LETTER TO EUROPEANS 1
('1', 204, 2, 3, 462670) BEACH GROVE, DURBAN, December 19, 1894
('1', 204, 3, 4, 462709) SIR I venture to send you the enclosed for perusal, and solicit your opinion on the subject matter of the Open Letter.
('1', 204, 3, 5, 462828) Whether you be a clergyman, editor, public man, merchant or lawyer, the subject cannot but demand your attention.
('1', 204, 3, 6, 462942) If you are a clergyman, inasmuch as you represent the teaching of Jesus, it must be your duty to see that you are in no way, directly or indirectly, countenancing a treatment of your fellow beings that would not be pleasing to Jesus.
('1', 204, 3, 7, 463176) If you are an editor of a news paper, the responsibility is equally great.
('1', 204, 3, 8, 463251) Whether you are using your influence as a journalist to the evolution or degradation of humanity will depend upon whether you are encouraging division among class and class or striving after union.
('1', 204, 3, 9, 463449) The same remarks will apply to you as a public man.
('1', 204, 3, 10, 463501) If you are a merchant or lawyer, you have then too, a duty to discharge towards your customers and clients from whom you derive a considerable pecuniary advantage.
('1', 204, 3, 11, 463665) It is for you to treat them as dogs or fellow beings demanding your symapathy in the cruel persecution that they are put to owing to the prevalent ignorance about the Indians in the Colony.
('1', 204, 3, 12, 463855) Coming as you do in comparatively close contact with them, you have, no doubt, the opportunity and incentive to study them.
('1', 204, 3, 13, 463979) Looked at from a sympathetic standpoint, they would perhaps show themselves to you as they have been seen by scores and hundreds of Europeans who had the opportunity to study them, and who used it alright.
('1', 204, 3, 14, 464185) Your opinion is solicited with a view to ascertaining if there are many Europeans in the Colony who would actively sympathize with and feel for the Indians in the Colony, assuming that their treatment is not all that could be desired.
