('1', 238, 3, 10, 540154) 66. A BAND OF VEGETARIAN MISSIONARIES
('1', 238, 4, 11, 540192) It was in England that I read in Mrs. Anna Kingsford's Perfect Way in Diet that there was a colony of Trappists 2 in South Africa who were vegetarians.
('1', 238, 4, 12, 540344) Ever since that I had wished to see these vegetarians.
('1', 238, 4, 13, 540399) The wish has at last been realized.
('1', 238, 4, 14, 540435) At the outset, I may remark that South Africa, and particularly Natal, is especially adapted for vegetarians.
('1', 238, 4, 15, 540545) The Indians have made Natal the Garden Colony of South Africa.
('1', 238, 4, 16, 540608) One can grow almost anything on the South African soil, and that in abundance.
('1', 238, 4, 17, 540687) The supply of bananas, pineapples and oranges is almost inexhaustible, and far greater than the demand.
('1', 238, 4, 18, 540791) There is no wonder that the vegetarians can thrive very well in Natal.
('1', 238, 4, 19, 540862) The only wonder is, that in spite of such facilities and the warm climate, there should be so few vegetarians.
('1', 238, 4, 20, 540973) The result is that large tracts of land still remain neglected and uncultivated.
('1', 238, 4, 21, 541054) The staple articles of food are imported when it is perfectly possible to grow all of them in South Africa; and in a vast territory like Natal, there is much distress among a small population of 40,000 whites.
('1', 238, 4, 22, 541264) All this, because they will not take to agricultural pursuits.
('1', 238, 4, 23, 541327) Another curious but painful result of the unnatural mode of living is that there is a very strong prejudice against the Indian population who also number 40,000. The Indians, being vegetarians, take to agriculture without any difficulty whatsoever.
('1', 238, 4, 24, 541576) Naturally,
('1', 238, 5, 25, 541587) 1 On May 8, Camroodeen wrote back (S.N. 39) reporting that he had not been able to collect a single signature to the petition to be presented to Lord Ripon.
('1', 238, 5, 26, 541744) 2 Monks of the Cistercian order founded in 1140 a.d.
('1', 238, 5, 27, 541797) at Soligny la Trappe and noted for silence and other austerities
('1', 239, 0, 1, 541862) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 240
('1', 239, 1, 2, 541904) therefore, all over the Colony, the small farms are owned by Indians, whose keen competition gives offence to the white population.
('1', 239, 1, 3, 542036) They are following a dog in the manager and suicidal policy in so behaving.
('1', 239, 1, 4, 542112) They would rather leave the vast agricultural resources in the country undeveloped, than have the Indians to develop them.
('1', 239, 1, 5, 542235) Owing to such stolidity and shortsightedness, a Colony that can easily support double, or even treble, the number of European and Indian inhabitants, with difficulty supports 80,000 Europeans and Indians.
('1', 239, 1, 6, 542440) The Transvaal Government have gone so far in their prejudice, that the whole of the Republic, although the soil is very fruitful, remains a desert of dust.
('1', 239, 1, 7, 542596) And if the gold mines could not be worked from any cause, thousands of men would be thrown out of employment and literally starved to death.
('1', 239, 1, 8, 542737) Is there not here a great lesson to be learnt?
('1', 239, 1, 9, 542784) The flesheating habits have really tended to retard the progress of the community, and, indirectly, to create division among the two great communities which ought to be united and work hand in hand.
('1', 239, 1, 10, 542983) There is also this striking fact to be noticed that the Indians enjoy as good a health as the Europeans in the Colony, and I know that many doctors would be simply starving if there were no Europeans, or their flesh pots, and that by their thrifty and temperate habits, both attributable to vegetarianism, Indians can successfully compete with Europeans.
('1', 239, 1, 11, 543338) Of course, it should be understood that the Indians in the Colony are not pure vegetarians.
('1', 239, 1, 12, 543430) They are practically so.
('1', 239, 1, 13, 543455) We shall see presently how the Trappists of Mariann Hill, near Pinetown, are a standing testimony to the truth of the above remarks.
('1', 239, 1, 14, 543588) Pinetown is a little village, situated at a distance of 16 miles by rail from Durban.
('1', 239, 1, 15, 543674) It is about 1,100 feet above the sea leavel, and enjoys a beautiful climate.
('1', 239, 1, 16, 543751) The Trappist monastery is about three miles distant from Pinetown.
('1', 239, 1, 17, 543818) My companion and I walked to Mariann Hill, as the hill, or rather the cluster of hills, on which the Abbey is situated, is called.
('1', 239, 1, 18, 543949) It is a very pleasant walk through the little hills all covered with green grass.
('1', 239, 1, 19, 544031) On our reaching the settlement, we saw a gentleman with a pipe in his mouth, and we at once knew that he was not one of the brotherhood.
('1', 239, 1, 20, 544168) He, however, took us to the visitors' room, where a visitors' book was kept.
('1', 239, 1, 21, 544245) It appeared from the book that it commenced from 1894, and there were hardly twenty pages filled up.
('1', 239, 1, 22, 544346) Indeed, the mission is not at all known as it ought to be.
('1', 240, 0, 1, 544405) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 241
('1', 240, 1, 2, 544439) One of the brotherhood came up and bowed very low.
('1', 240, 1, 3, 544490) We were offered tamarind water and pineapples.
('1', 240, 1, 4, 544537) After having refreshed ourselves, we accompanied the guide to the various places he took us to.
('1', 240, 1, 5, 544633) The various buildings one saw were all substantial red brick buildings.
('1', 240, 1, 6, 544705) All was quiet; the silence was broken only by the noise of the instruments in the workshops or the native children.
('1', 240, 1, 7, 544821) The settlement is a quiet little model village, owned on the truest republican principles.
('1', 240, 1, 8, 544912) The principle of liberty, equality and fraternity is carried out in its entirety.
('1', 240, 1, 9, 544994) Every man is a brother, every woman a sister.
('1', 240, 1, 10, 545040) The monks number about 120 on the settlement, and the nuns, or the sisters as they are called, number about 60. The sisters' cloister is about half a mile from the brothers'.
('1', 240, 1, 11, 545215) Both the brothers and the sisters observe a strict vow of silence and of chastity.
('1', 240, 1, 12, 545298) No brother or sister may speak except those who are allowed to by the Abbot, who is the head of the Trappists in Natal.
('1', 240, 1, 13, 545418) And those are only allowed to speak who have to go to town to make purchases or to look after visitors.
('1', 240, 1, 14, 545522) The brothers are dressed in long robes with a black piece of cloth in front and on the back.
('1', 240, 1, 15, 545615) The sisters wear red clothing of the simplest style.
('1', 240, 1, 16, 545668) None seemed to wear socks.
('1', 240, 1, 17, 545695) A candidate for the brotherhood has to make a vow for two years and, till then, is called a novice.
('1', 240, 1, 18, 545795) After two years, he may either leave the cloister or make a vow for life.
('1', 240, 1, 19, 545869) A model Trappist gets up at 2 a.m.
('1', 240, 1, 20, 545904) and devotes four hours to prayer and contemplation.
('1', 240, 1, 21, 545956) At six, he has his breakfast, which consists of bread and coffee, or some such simple foods.
('1', 240, 1, 22, 546049) He dines at twelve, and makes a meal of bread and soup, and fruits.
('1', 240, 1, 23, 546117) He sups at six in the evening and goes to bed at 7 or 8 p.m.
('1', 240, 1, 24, 546178) The brothers eat no fish, flesh or fowl.
('1', 240, 1, 25, 546219) They discard even eggs.
('1', 240, 1, 26, 546243) They take milk, but in Natal we were told they could not get it cheap.
('1', 240, 1, 27, 546314) The sisters are allowed meat four days in the week.
('1', 240, 1, 28, 546366) Asked why they put up with such an anomaly, the obliging guide said: “Because the sisters are more delicate than the brothers.” Neither my companion, who is almost a vegetarian, nor I could see the force or logic of the reasoning.
('1', 240, 1, 29, 546597) Certainly, both of us were very much grieved to hear the news which was a surprise to us, for we expected both the brothers and the sister to be vegetarians.
('1', 240, 1, 30, 546755) They take no intoxicating liquors except under medical advice.
('1', 240, 1, 31, 546818) None may keep money for private use.
('1', 240, 1, 32, 546855) All are equally rich or poor.
('1', 240, 1, 33, 546885) We saw no wardrobes, chests of drawers, or portmanteaus,
('1', 241, 0, 1, 546942) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 242
('1', 241, 1, 2, 546984) although we were allowed to see every inch of the place.
('1', 241, 1, 3, 547041) They may not leave the limits of the settlement, except those who are permitted to do so on business.
('1', 241, 1, 4, 547143) They may not read newspapers and books that are not religious.
('1', 241, 1, 5, 547206) They may not read any religious books but only those that are allowed.
('1', 241, 1, 6, 547277) It is this hard austere life that caused our friend with the pipe in his mouth, whom we first met, to remark in reply to a question whether he was a Trappist—”No fear, I am anything but a Trappist.” And yet the good brothers and sisters did not seem to consider their lives to have fallen on hard places.
('1', 241, 1, 7, 547582) A Protestant clergyman said to his audience that the Roman Catholics are weakly, sickly and sad.
('1', 241, 1, 8, 547679) Well, if the Trappists are any criterion of what a Catholic is, they are, on the contrary, healthy and cheerful.
('1', 241, 1, 9, 547792) Wherever we went, a beaming smile and a lowly bow greeted us, whether we saw a brother or a sister.
('1', 241, 1, 10, 547892) Even while the guide was descanting on the system he prized so much, he did not at all seem to consider the self chosen discipline a hard yoke to bear.
('1', 241, 1, 11, 548044) A better instance of undying faith and perfect, implicit obedience could not well be found anywhere else.
('1', 241, 1, 12, 548150) If their repast is the simplest possible, their dining tables and bedrooms are no less so.
('1', 241, 1, 13, 548241) The former are made on the settlement, of wood, without any varnish.
('1', 241, 1, 14, 548310) They use no tablecloths.
('1', 241, 1, 15, 548335) The knives and spoons are the cheapest to be had in Durban.
('1', 241, 1, 16, 548395) Instead of glass ware they use enamelled things.
('1', 241, 1, 17, 548444) For bedrooms they have a large hall (but none too large for the inmates) which contains about 80 beds.
('1', 241, 1, 18, 548547) Every available space is utilized for the beds.
('1', 241, 1, 19, 548595) In the Native quarters they seem to have overdone it in point of beds.
('1', 241, 1, 20, 548666) As soon as we entered the sleeping hall for Natives, we noticed the closeness and the stuffy air.
('1', 241, 1, 21, 548764) The beds are all joined together, sepa rated by only single boards.
('1', 241, 1, 22, 548832) There was hardly space enough to walk.
('1', 241, 1, 23, 548871) They believe in no colour distinctions.
('1', 241, 1, 24, 548911) The Natives are accorded the same treatment as the whites.
('1', 241, 1, 25, 548970) They are mostly children.
('1', 241, 1, 26, 548996) They get the same food as the brothers, and are dressed as well as they themselves are.
('1', 241, 1, 27, 549084) While it is generally said, not without some truth, that the Christian Kaffir is a failure, everyone, even the wildest sceptic, admit that the mission of the Trappists has proved the most successful in point of turning out really good, Christian Natives.
('1', 241, 1, 28, 549339) While the mission schools of other denominations very often enable the Natives
('1', 242, 0, 1, 549418) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 243
('1', 242, 1, 2, 549452) to contract all the terrible vices of the Western civilization, and very rarely produce any moral effect on them, the Natives of the Trappist mission are patterns of simplicity, virtue and gentleness.
('1', 242, 1, 3, 549653) It was a treat to see them saluting passers by in a humble yet dignified manner.
('1', 242, 1, 4, 549734) There are about 1,200 Natives on the mission, including children and adults.
('1', 242, 1, 5, 549811) They have all exchanged a life of sloth, indolence and superstition, for one of industry, usefulness and devotion to one Supreme God.
('1', 242, 1, 6, 549945) On the settlement there are various workshops—blacksmiths’, tinsmith0s’, carpenters’, shoemakers’, tanners’, etc., where the Natives are taught all these useful industries, in addition to the English and the Zulu languages.
('1', 242, 1, 7, 550169) Here it may be remarked that it speaks volumes for the highmindedness of the noble settlers that, although almost all of them are Germans, they never attempt to teach the Natives German; all these Natives work side by side with the whites.
('1', 242, 1, 8, 550409) At the sisters’ cloisters, they have the ironing, sewing, strawhat manufacturing and knitting departments, where one can see the Native girls, dressed in clean costumes, working assiduously.
('1', 242, 1, 9, 550600) About two miles from the Abbey is situated the printing department, and the flour mill worked by a waterfall.
('1', 242, 1, 10, 550710) It is a huge pile of building.
('1', 242, 1, 11, 550741) There is also an oil machine, which is worked for pressing the oil from monkey nuts.
('1', 242, 1, 12, 550826) It is needless to mention that the above mentioned workshops supply the settlers with most of their requirements.
('1', 242, 1, 13, 550940) They grow many kinds of tropical fruits on the farm and the settlement is almost self supporting.
('1', 242, 1, 14, 551038) They love and respect, and are in turn loved and respected by, the Natives living in their neighbourhood who, as a rule, supply them with the converts.
('1', 242, 1, 15, 551190) The most prominent feature of the settlement is that you see religion everywhere.
('1', 242, 1, 16, 551272) Every room has a Cross and, on the entrance, a small receptacle for holy water which every inmate reverently applies to his eyelids, the forehead and the chest.
('1', 242, 1, 17, 551433) Even the quick walk to the flour mill is not without some reminder of the Cross.
('1', 242, 1, 18, 551514) It is a lovely footpath.
('1', 242, 1, 19, 551539) On one side, you have a magnificent valley through which runs a small rivulet which murmurs the sweetest music, and on the other, little rocks whereon are carved the various inscriptions reminding you of the scenes of the Calvary.
('1', 242, 1, 20, 551770) The valley is wholly covered with a green carpet of vegetation, studded with beautiful trees
('1', 243, 0, 1, 551863) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 244
('1', 243, 1, 2, 551905) here and there.
('1', 243, 1, 3, 551921) A lovelier walk, or a lovelier scenery, could not be well imagined.
('1', 243, 1, 4, 551989) The inscriptions carved in such a place cannot fail to produce a grand effect upon the mind.
('1', 243, 1, 5, 552082) They are carved at such regular intervals that no sooner has one completed one’s thoughts on one inscription than another meets one’s gaze.
('1', 243, 1, 6, 552222) The walk thus forms a continuous exercise for calm contemplation, unmarred by any other thoughts, or outside noise and bustle.
('1', 243, 1, 7, 552349) Some of the inscriptions are: “Jesus falls a first time”; “Jesus falls a second time”; “Simon carries the Cross”; “Jesus is nailed to the Cross”; “Jesus is laid in his mother’s lap”, etc., etc..
('1', 243, 1, 8, 552544) Of course, the Natives, too, are chiefly vegetarians.
('1', 243, 1, 9, 552598) Although they are not prohibited from taking flesh or meat, they are not supplied with any on the settlement.
('1', 243, 1, 10, 552708) There are about twelve such settlements in South Africa, most of which are in Natal.
('1', 243, 1, 11, 552793) There are in all about 300 monks and about 120 nuns.
('1', 243, 1, 12, 552846) Such are our vegetarians in Natal.
('1', 243, 1, 13, 552881) Though they do not make of vegetarianism a creed, though they base it simply on the ground that a vegetarian diet helps them to crucify the flesh better, and though, perhaps, they are not even aware of the existence of the vegetarian societies, and would not even care to read any vegetarian literature, where is the vegetarian who would not be proud of this noble band, even a casul intercourse with whom fills one with a spirit of love, charity and self sacrifice, and who are a living testimony to the triumph of vegetarianism from a spiritual point of view?
('1', 243, 1, 14, 553443) I know from personal experience that a visit to the farm is worth a voyage from London to Natal.
('1', 243, 1, 15, 553540) It cannot but produce a lasting holy impression on the mind.
('1', 243, 1, 16, 553601) No matter whether one is a Protestant, a Christian or a Buddhist or what not, one cannot help exclaiming, after a visit to the farm: “If this is Roman Catholicism, everything said against it is a lie.” It proves conclusively, to my mind, that a religion appears divine or devilish, according as its professors choose to make it appear.
('1', 243, 1, 17, 553937) The Vegetarian, 18 5 1895
('1', 244, 0, 1, 553963) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 245

('1', 245, 9, 13, 557690) Your Petitioners respectfully submit that both the clauses
('1', 245, 10, 14, 557749) 1 The report here says that “some further evidence” recapitulated by Gandhiji has been omitted.

('1', 246, 1, 2, 558632) above referred to are entirely unjust and uncalled for.
('1', 246, 1, 3, 558688) Your Petitioners humbly draw the attention of this Honourable House to the following from the report of the delegates, Messrs Binns 1
('1', 246, 2, 4, 558822) and Mason, who were commissioned to go to India in connection with this matter: So far no second term of indenture has been agreed to in the case of any country to which Coolies emigrated, although the consent of the Government of India had frequently been asked for; and in no instance had the condition of compulsory return at the end of the indentures been sanctioned.
('1', 246, 2, 5, 559194) Thus the clauses in the Bill are a total departure, your Petitioners submit, for the worse, from the practice prevalent throughout the British Colonies.
('1', 246, 2, 6, 559347) Assuming that the average age of an indentured Indian at the time of his entering into the contract of indenture is 25, under the clause which expects the Indian to work for 10 years, the best part of the life of the indentured Indian would be simply spent away in a state of bondage.
('1', 246, 2, 7, 559632) For an Indian to return to India after continuous 10 years’ stay in the Colony would be pure fatuity.
('1', 246, 2, 8, 559734) All the old cords and ties will have been broken up.
('1', 246, 2, 9, 559787) Such an Indian will be comparatively a stranger in his motherland.
('1', 246, 2, 10, 559854) To find work in India would be almost impossible.
('1', 246, 2, 11, 559904) The market is already overcrowded, and he will not have amassed sufficient fortune to enable him to live on the interest on his capital.
('1', 246, 2, 12, 560041) The total of the wages for 10 years would amount to £87. If the indentured Indian saves £50, allowing only £37 for clothing and other expenses during the whole 10 years, that capital will not give him interest sufficient to keep body and soul together, even in a poor country like India.
('1', 246, 2, 13, 560329) Such an Indian, therefore, even if he ventured to return to India, would be compelled to return under indenture, and thus his whole life would be spent in bondage.
('1', 246, 2, 14, 560493) Moreover, during the 10 years the indentured Indian would be entirely neglecting his family, should he have any.
('1', 246, 2, 15, 560606) And a family man will not be able to save even £50. Your Petitioners know several instances of indentured Indians with families having saved nothing.

('1', 247, 1, 4, 561178) Your Petitioners most respectfully venture to submit that it is not in accordance with the principles of simple justice and equity to make a man pay heavily for being allowed to remain free in the Colony after he has already lived under bondage for 10 years.

('1', 248, 5, 7, 563095) 70. MEMORIAL TO J. CHAMBERLAIN
('1', 248, 6, 8, 563126) [DURBAN, August 11, 1895]
('1', 248, 7, 9, 563152) TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN, HER MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE
('1', 248, 8, 10, 563239) FOR THE COLONIES, LONDON
('1', 248, 9, 11, 563264) THE MEMORIAL OF THE UNDERSIGNED INDIANS RESIDING IN THE COLONY OF NATAL
('1', 248, 10, 12, 563336) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT:
('1', 248, 11, 13, 563357) Your Memorialists, representing the Indian community in the Colony of Natal, respectfully venture to approach you with respect tothe Indian Immigration Law Amendment Bill recently passed by the Hon.
('1', 248, 11, 14, 563556) Legislative Assembly, and the Hon.
('1', 248, 11, 15, 563591) Legislative Council of Natal, in so far as it affects the existing conditions of indenture and requires a special licence, costing £3 every year, to be taken out by the indentured Indians coming under that Law and wishing to remain in the Colony as free Indians.
('1', 248, 11, 16, 563854) 2. Your Memorialists, with a view to have the Clauses dealing with the above matter left out, presented respectful memorials 1 to both the Honourable Houses, but, your Memorialists regret to mention, without avail.
('1', 248, 11, 17, 564069) The copies of the memorials are annexed hereto, and marked A and B respectively.
('1', 248, 11, 18, 564150) 3. The Clauses that deal with the matter are as follows: Clause 2. From and after the date when this Act shall take effect the indentures to be signed by Indian immigrants as provided by Schedules B and
('1', 248, 12, 19, 564353) 1Vide “Petition to Natal Legislative Assembly”, before 5 5 1895, and the preceding item.
('1', 249, 0, 1, 564442) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 250
('1', 249, 1, 2, 564484) C of the Indian Immigration Law, 1891, referred to in Section 11 of the said Law, shall contain a Covenant by the Indian immigrants, in words as follows:
('1', 249, 2, 3, 564638) And we further agree that after the expiration or other determination we shall either return to India or remain in Natal under indentures to be from time to time entered into; provided that each term of new indentured service shall be for two years, and provided further, that the rate of wages for each year of indentured service after that provided by this Contract shall be 16/ per month for the first year, 17/ per month for the second year, 18/ per month forthe third year, 19/ per month for the fourth year, and 20/ per month for the fifth and each succeeding year.
('1', 249, 2, 4, 565210) Clause 6 runs as follows: Every indentured Indian who shall have entered into the Covenant set out in Section 2 of this Act, and who shall fail, neglect, or refuse to return to India, or become re indentured in Natal, shall take out year by year, a pass or licence to remain in the Colony to be issued by the Magistrate of his district, and shall pay for such pass or licence a yearly sum of £3 sterling, which may be recovered by summary process by any Clerk of the Peace or other officer appointed to get in such licence money.
('1', 249, 2, 5, 565740) The Schedule B referred to in Clause 2, quoted above, so far as it relates to the period of service is as follows:
('1', 249, 3, 6, 565855) We, the undersigned, emigrants from .
('1', 249, 3, 7, 565893) to Natal, hereby engage to serve the employer to whom we may respectively be allotted by the Protector of Indian Immigrants to Natal; provided that we shall receive monthly in money the wages stated hereunder opposite our respective names, and the allowances following.
('1', 249, 3, 8, 566163) 4. From the above it will be seen, that if the Bill under discussion became law, an indentured Indian, in case he desires to settle in the Colony after the first five years of his indentured service, should either have to remain under perpetual indenture, or pay a yearly tax of £3; your Memorialists have used the word tax advisedly, because that was the word used in the original Bill before it passed the Committee stage.
('1', 249, 3, 9, 566588) Your Memorialists submit that the mere change of name from tax to licence does not make it the less offensive but shows the knowledge on the part of the framers that a special poll tax, on a special class of people in the Colony, is entirely repugnant to the British notions of justice.
('1', 249, 3, 10, 566875) 5. Now, your Memorialists humbly, but emphatically, submit, that to raise the term of indenture from five years to a practically indefinite period is extremely unjust, especially because such a
('1', 250, 0, 1, 567069) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 251
('1', 250, 1, 2, 567103) measure is absolutely uncalled for so far as the industries protected, or affected by, the indentured Indians are concerned.
('1', 250, 1, 3, 567228) 6. The clauses owe their origin to the Commission that was sent out to India in the year 1894 by the Natal Government, and the report made by the Delegates, Messrs Binns and Mason, who formed the Commission.
('1', 250, 1, 4, 567436) The reasons given in that report for such legislation are given at pp.
('1', 250, 1, 5, 567507) 20 and 21 of the Annual Report of the Protector of Immigrants for 1894. Your Memorialists venture to quote the following from the report of the Delegates:
('1', 250, 2, 6, 567662) In a country where the Native population is in number so far in excess of the European, the unlimited settlement of Indians is not considered desirable, and there is a general wish that when they have completed their last period of indenture they should return to India.
('1', 250, 2, 7, 567933) There are already about 25,000 free Indians settled in the Colony, many of whom have allowed their right to a return passage to lapse; this is exclusive of a very considerable Banya trading population!
('1', 250, 2, 8, 568135) 7. Thus the reasons for the special arrangement are political merely.
('1', 250, 2, 9, 568205) Properly speaking, there is no question of overcrowding at all.
('1', 250, 2, 10, 568269) There can be none in a newly opened up country where there are yet vast tracts of land entirely uninhabited and uncultivated.
('1', 250, 2, 11, 568395) 8. Again, in the same report, the Delegates state as follows:
('1', 250, 3, 12, 568457) There is a strong feeling amongst the merchants and shopkeepers
('1', 250, 4, 13, 568521) with regard to the Arabs, who are all traders and not workers; but as they are
('1', 250, 5, 14, 568600) mostly British subjects and do not go to the Colony under any form of
('1', 250, 6, 15, 568670) agreement, it is recognized that they cannot be interfered with.
('1', 250, 8, 16, 568735) The Coolie does not come into competition to any considerable
('1', 250, 9, 17, 568797) extent with the European.
('1', 250, 9, 18, 568823) Field work for Europeans is impossible on the
('1', 250, 10, 19, 568869) coast, where all the plantations are situated, and the number of servants other
('1', 250, 11, 20, 568949) than Coolies and Natives has always been very small.
('1', 250, 13, 21, 569002) Althouth we are decidedly of opinion that up to the present the
('1', 250, 14, 22, 569066) working Indians who have settled down (the italics are your Memorialists')
('1', 250, 15, 23, 569141) have been of great benefit to the Colony, we cannot avoid, having regard to
('1', 250, 16, 24, 569217) the future, and, in the face of the great Native problem yet to be solved in
('1', 250, 17, 25, 569294) South Africa, sharing in the concern which is now felt.
('1', 250, 17, 26, 569350) If a large proportion of
('1', 251, 0, 1, 569375) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 252
('1', 251, 1, 2, 569417) the Coolies had taken advantage of the return passage provided for them, there
('1', 251, 2, 3, 569496) would have been less cause for alarm.
('1', 251, 2, 4, 569534) 9. Your Memorialists most respectfully submit that the above extracts, which form part of the reasons given for measures restrictive of the settlement of freed Indians in the Colony, go to prove the exact opposite; for if the Indian traders, to which class most of your Memorialists belong, who “do not go to the Colony under any form of agreement”, could not be interfered with, much less the indentured Indians, who are also equally British subjects and who are, so to speak, invited to go to the Colony, and whose settlement (in the Delegates' own words) “has been of great benefit to the Colony”, and who have therefore a special claim on the goodwill and attention of the Colonists.
('1', 251, 2, 5, 570222) 10. And, if the 'Coolie' “does not come into competition to any considerable extent with the Europeans”, where is the justification, your Memorialists humbly ask, for adopting measures that would make it difficult for the indentured Indians to earn honest bread in peace and freedom?
('1', 251, 2, 6, 570506) It does not certainly lie in any qualities special to the indentured Indians which render them dangerous members of society.
('1', 251, 2, 7, 570631) The peace loving disposition and the mildness of the Indian nation are proverbial.
('1', 251, 2, 8, 570714) Their obedience to authorities over them is no less prominent a trait of their character, and it would not lie in the mouth of the Delegates to say otherwise; for the Protector, who was one of the Delegates, in his report, at p.
('1', 251, 2, 9, 570943) 15 of the same book, says:
('1', 251, 3, 10, 570970) Many persons, I am aware, condemn the Indians as a race, yet these
('1', 251, 4, 11, 571037) persons cannot fail, if they look around them, to see hundreds of these Indians
('1', 251, 5, 12, 571117) honestly and peaceably pursuing their several useful and desirable
('1', 251, 6, 13, 571184) occupations.
('1', 251, 8, 14, 571197) I am pleased to be able to state that the Indians generally resident in
('1', 251, 9, 15, 571269) the Colony continue to form a prosperous, enterprising and law abiding
('1', 251, 10, 16, 571340) section of the community.
('1', 251, 10, 17, 571366) 11. The Hon.
('1', 251, 10, 18, 571379) the Attorney General, in moving the second reading of the Bill, is reported to have said that:
('1', 251, 11, 19, 571474) There was no intention to interfere with the introduction of labour to
('1', 251, 12, 20, 571545) the injury of any industry, but these Indians were brought here for the purpose
('1', 252, 0, 1, 571625) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 253
('1', 252, 1, 2, 571659) of supplying labour for the development of local industries, and were not
('1', 252, 2, 3, 571733) intended to form portion of the South African nation which was being built up
('1', 252, 3, 4, 571811) in the various States.
('1', 252, 3, 5, 571834) 12. With the greatest deference to the learned Attorney General, your Memorialists humbly submit that the above remarks condemn entirely the clauses under discussion, and venture to believe that Her Majesty's Government will not endorse such remarks by sanctioning the Bill.
('1', 252, 3, 6, 572109) 13.Your Memorialists venture to think that it is against the spirit of the British Constitution to countenance measures that tend to keep men under perpetual bondage.
('1', 252, 3, 7, 572276) That the Bill, if passed, would do so, it is submitted, is self evident.
('1', 252, 3, 8, 572349) 14. The Natal Mercury, the Government organ, of the 11th May, 1895, thus justifies the measure:
('1', 252, 4, 9, 572445) This much, however, the Government cannot accede to, that men who
('1', 252, 5, 10, 572511) contract at fair wages to assist the Colonists, should be allowed to break their
('1', 252, 6, 11, 572592) contract, and remain competitors against the Colonists, those whom, and for
('1', 252, 7, 12, 572668) no other purpose and no other condition, they came to serve.
('1', 252, 7, 13, 572729) To do otherwise
('1', 252, 8, 14, 572745) would be to destroy all distinction between right and wrong and to give tacit
('1', 252, 9, 15, 572823) disavowal of the existence of law and equity.
('1', 252, 9, 16, 572869) There is no desire for, nor is there
('1', 252, 10, 17, 572906) any, harshness of any kind, nor is there anything to which unbiased judgment
('1', 252, 11, 18, 572983) can take exception.
('1', 252, 11, 19, 573003) 15. Your Memorialists have quoted the above to show what feeling exists even amongst responsible quarters against the Indians only because some very few dare to trade in the Colony, after having served as labourers, not only under and during their term of indenture, but a long time after the completion of their term.
('1', 252, 11, 20, 573322) 16. The statement requiring those who are admittedly indispensable to the welfare of the Colony to remain either under perpetual bondage or to “purchase freedom”, as it is put by The Natal Advertiser, 9 5 95, by paying an annual tax of £3, “is neither harsh nor inequitable”, will not, your Memorialists feel sure, be accepted by Her Majesty's Government.
('1', 252, 11, 21, 573678) 17. The injustice of the clauses seems to be so evident and strong, that even The Natal Advertiser, a paper which is by no means favourable towards the Indian, felt it, and expressed it in the following terms on the 16th May, 1895:
('1', 253, 0, 1, 573910) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 254
('1', 253, 1, 2, 573952) The penal clause of the Bill originally was to the effect that the Indians, failing to return to India, should pay “an annual tax to the Government”.
('1', 253, 1, 3, 574102) On Tuesday, the Attorney General moved that this be altered to read: “should take out a pass or licence to remain in the Colony”, for which £3 would be payable.
('1', 253, 1, 4, 574263) This is decidedly an alteration for the better, and effects the same end under less disagreeable terms.
('1', 253, 1, 5, 574367) A broad question, however, is raised by this proposal to establish a special tax on the Coolie settlers.
('1', 253, 1, 6, 574472) If such a disability is to be placed on Coolies coming from another part of the Empire, surely its application should be extended to include members of other non European races, who have no connection with the British Empire, such as Chinese, Arabs, Kaffirs from outside States, and all such visitors.
('1', 253, 1, 7, 574774) To specially select the Coolies coming for attention in this way, and to allow all other aliens to settle with impunity, and without disability, is not an equitable arrangement.
('1', 253, 1, 8, 574952) The practice of taxing aliens, if it is to be inaugurated at all, should surely commence with those races not under the British flag in their native land, and not with those who, whether we like the fact or not, are the subjects of the same Sovereign as ourselves.
('1', 253, 1, 9, 575217) These should be the last, not the first, to be placed by us under exceptional disabilities.
('1', 253, 1, 10, 575309) 18. Your Memorialists submit that the arrangement has not appealed to any fair minded men at all.
('1', 253, 1, 11, 575407) How the Indian Government could be persuaded by the Natal Delegates to make a promise to sanction an indefinite extension of the indentures, or compulsory return, no matter how reluctantly, your Memorialists do not profess to know.
('1', 253, 1, 12, 575639) But your Memorialists venture to hope that the case, as put here, on behalf of the indentured Indians will receive full attention from both Her Majesty's Government and the Indian Government, and that any sanction given on the representation of an ex parte Commission will not be allowed to prejudice the case of the indentured Indians.
('1', 253, 1, 13, 575976) 19. For the sake of ready reference your Memorialists beg leave to quote as follows from His Excellency the Viceroy's despatch to His Excellency the Governor of Natal, dated the 17th September, 1894:
('1', 253, 2, 14, 576176) I should myself have preferred the continuance of the existing system under which it is open to an immigrant at the termination of his period of indenture to settle in the Colony on his own account, and I have little sympathy with the views that would prevent any subjects of the Crown from settling in any Colony under the British flag.
('1', 253, 2, 15, 576514) But, in consideration of the feelings at present manifested in the Colony of Natal towards Indian settlers, I am prepared to accept the proposals (a to f) set forth by the Delegates in the memorandum of 20th January, 1894, referred to in the preceding paragraph, subject to the following provisions, viz.:
('1', 254, 0, 1, 576820) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 255
('1', 254, 1, 2, 576854) (a) That a Coolie when first recruited shall be required by the terms of his contract to return to India, within or immediately on the expiration of the period of his indenture, unless he may prefer to re enter into a further indenture on the same conditions;
('1', 254, 2, 3, 577114) (b) that such Coolies as may refuse to return should in no case be made subject to penalties under criminal law, and
('1', 254, 3, 4, 577231) (c) That all renewals shall be for a period of two years, and that a free passage should be secured to the immigrant at the end of the first term for which his engagement is made as well as at the end of every subsequent renewal.
('1', 254, 4, 5, 577461) The alterations in the existing system which I am prepared to sanction with the approval of Her Majesty's Government may be summarized as follows.
('1', 254, 5, 6, 577608) 20. Your Memorialists notice with a feeling of relief that Her Majesty's Government have not yet approved of the suggestions of the Delegates.
('1', 254, 5, 7, 577751) 21. To show yet further how grossly unjust the adoption of the compulsory return or re indenture has seemed from the first time that the idea was started, your Memorialists crave leave to quote from the report of and evidence taken before the Immigration Commission that sat in Natal in the year 1885. 22. Mr. J. R. Saunders, one of the Commissioners, forcibly puts his views on the matter in his additional report in the following terms:
('1', 254, 6, 8, 578190) Though the Commission has made no recommendation on the subject of passing a law to force Indians back to India at the expiration of their term of service unless they renew their indentures, I wish to express my strong condemnation of any such idea, and I feel convinced that many who now adv ocate the plan, when they realize what it means, will reject it as energetically as I do.
('1', 254, 6, 9, 578573) Stop Indian immigration and face results, but don't try to do what I can show is a great wrong.
('1', 254, 7, 10, 578669) What is it but taking the best out of servants (the good as well as the bad), and then refusing them the enjoyment of the reward!
('1', 254, 7, 11, 578799) Forcing them back (if we could, but we cannot) when their best days have been spent for our benefit.
('1', 254, 7, 12, 578900) Whereto?
('1', 254, 7, 13, 578909) Why, back to face a prospect of starvation from which they sought to escape when they were young.
('1', 254, 7, 14, 579007) Shylock like, taking the pound of flesh, and Shylock like we may rely on meeting—Shylock's reward.
('1', 254, 8, 15, 579106) 1 The original does not furnish the summary.
('1', 255, 0, 1, 579151) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 256
('1', 255, 1, 2, 579185) Stop Indian immigration if you will; if there are not enough unoccupied houses now, empty more by clearing out Arabs and Indians who live in them, and who add to the productive and consuming power of a less than half peopled country.
('1', 255, 1, 3, 579419) But let us trace results in this one branch of the enquiry, taking it as an example of others and trace out how untenanted houses depreciate the value of properties and securities—how, out of this must result stagnation in the building trade and those other trades and stores for supplies dependent on it— follow out how this leads to a reduced demand for white mechanics, and with the reduction in spending power of so many, how fall of revenue is to be expected next, need of retrenchment or taxation, or both.
('1', 255, 1, 4, 579932) Let this result and others, far too numerous to be calculated in detail, be faced, and if blind race sentimentalism or jealousy is to prevail, so be it.
('1', 255, 1, 5, 580085) The Colony can stop Indian immigration, and that perhaps far more easily and permanently than some ‘popularity seekers’ would desire.
('1', 255, 1, 6, 580219) But force men off at the end of their service, this the Colony cannot do.
('1', 255, 1, 7, 580293) And I urge on it not to discredit a fair name by trying.
('1', 255, 1, 8, 580350) 23. The late member of the late Legislative Council and the present Attorney General (the Hon.
('1', 255, 1, 9, 580445) Mr. Escombe), giving his evidence before the Commission, said (p.
('1', 255, 2, 10, 580511) With reference to time expired Indians, I do not think that it ought to be compulsory on any man to go to any part of the world save for a crime for which he is transported; I hear a great deal of this question; I have been asked again and again to take a different view, but I have not been able to do it.
('1', 255, 2, 11, 580818) A man is brought here, in theory with his own consent, in practice very often without his consent, (the italics are your Memorialists’) he gives the best five years of his life, he forms new ties, forgets the old ones, perhaps establishes a home here, and he cannot, according to my view of right and wrong, be sent back.
('1', 255, 2, 12, 581140) Better by far to stop the further introduction of Indians altogether than to take what work you can out of them and order them away.

('1', 255, 2, 14, 581395) The Indian people do no harm as far as I know; in certain respects they do a great deal of good.
('1', 255, 2, 15, 581492) I have never heard a reason to justify the extradition of a man who has behaved well for five years.
('1', 255, 2, 16, 581593) I do not think that the Indian, at the expiration of his five years’ service, should be placed under police supervision unless he is a criminal.
('1', 255, 2, 17, 581738) I know not why Arabs should be placed under police supervision more than Europeans.
('1', 255, 2, 18, 581822) In cases of some Arabs the thing is simply ridiculous.
('1', 255, 2, 19, 581877) They are men of large means, large connections, who are always used in trade if they can be dealt with more profitably than others.

('1', 256, 1, 3, 582273) 25. Mr. H. Binns, who went with Mr. Mason as a delegate to induce the Indian Government to sanction the compulsory return or re indenture, expressed the following opinion in giving his evidence before the Commission :
('1', 256, 2, 4, 582491) I think the idea which has been mooted, that all Indians should be compelled to return to India at the end of their term of indenture, is most unfair to the Indian population, and would never be sanctioned by the Indian Government.
('1', 256, 2, 5, 582723) In my opinion the free Indian population is a most useful section of the community.
('1', 256, 2, 6, 582807) A large proportion of them, considerably large than is generally supposed, are in service in the Colony, particularly employed as house servants in the towns and village.
('1', 256, 2, 7, 582978) Before there was a free Indian population the towns of Pietermaritzburg and Durban had no supply of fruit, vegetables and fish.
('1', 256, 2, 8, 583106) At present all these things are fully supplied.
('1', 256, 2, 9, 583154) We have never had any immigrants from Europe who have shown any inclination to become market gardeners and fishermen, and I am of opinion that but for the free Indian population, the markets of Pietermaritzburg and Durban would be as badly supplied now as they were ten years ago (pp.

('1', 256, 4, 18, 584649) 29. It has been said in the Colony, in defence of the measure, that there can be no injustice, where two parties voluntarily agree to do
('1', 257, 0, 1, 584786) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 258

('1', 257, 1, 4, 585004) the Legislative Assembly, and the Hon.
('1', 257, 1, 5, 585043) the Legislative Council, and your Memorialists venture to repeat that, when the contracting parties are not situated equally, the proposition is entirely inapplicable.
('1', 257, 1, 6, 585211) An Indian who, in order “to escape from starvation”, as Mr. Saunders has put it, seeks indenture can hardly be called a free agent.
('1', 257, 1, 7, 585343) 30. So recently as 1894, the evidence as to the indispensableness of the Indian has been dwelt upon in the Protector’s Report referred to above.
('1', 257, 1, 8, 585488) 15 he says:
('1', 257, 2, 9, 585500) If it were possible even for a short space of time to withdraw the whole of the Indian population from this Colony, I am convinced that, with but very few exceptions, every industry in existence at the present time would collapse, solely for the want of reliable labour.
('1', 257, 2, 10, 585771) There is no getting over the fact that the Native as a rule will not work, hence it is generally admitted throughout the Colony that without the Indian as a labourer, no industry, agricultural or otherwise, of any importance could possibly be carried on successfully, and not only this but almost every householder in Natal would be without domestic servants.
('1', 257, 2, 11, 586131) 31. If almost the whole current of what may be called expert opinion, from beginning up to date, goes to show the usefulness of the Indians, then, your Memorialists submit, it is not too much to say that to keep such people under perpetual bondage, or to make them pay a yearly tax of £3 whether they can afford it or not, is, to say the very least, absolutely one sided and selfish.
('1', 257, 2, 12, 586515) 32. Your Memorialists beg respectfully to draw your attention to the fact that, were the Bill to become law, the very object of immigration will be frustrated in all its aspects.
('1', 257, 2, 13, 586694) If it is to enable the Indians to improve their material condition ultimately, the object certainly will not be fulfilled by compelling them to remain under perpetual indenture.
('1', 257, 2, 14, 586872) If it be to relieve the overcrowded parts of India, that object also will be frustrated.
('1', 257, 2, 15, 586961) For, the object of the Bill is not to allow the number of Indians in the Colony to increase.
('1', 257, 2, 16, 587054) The desire is to replace those who can no longer bear the yoke of indenture by fresh importation, and to force the former back to India.
('1', 257, 2, 17, 587191) Thus your Memorialists humbly submit that the last state will be worse than the first.
('1', 257, 2, 18, 587278) For, while the number of Indians in the overcrowded districts, so far as Natal as an outlet is concerned, will remain the same, those who would return against their will cannot but be a source of additional
('1', 258, 0, 1, 587485) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 259
('1', 258, 1, 2, 587519) anxiety and trouble, because they, being without any prospect of work or any capital to maintain them, may have to be maintained at the public expense.
('1', 258, 1, 3, 587671) It may be said in reply to this objection that it presup poses a state of things which will never happen, that is to say, the Indians will gladly pay the annual tax.
('1', 258, 1, 4, 587837) Your Memorialists, however, beg leave to point out that such an argument, if advanced, would really go to prove that the clauses about re indenture and tax are absolutely useless, in so far as they will not produce the desired effect.
('1', 258, 1, 5, 588072) It has never been contended that the object is to raise any revenue.
('1', 258, 1, 6, 588141) 33. Your Memorialists, therefore, submit that, if the Colony cannot put up with the Indians, the only course, in your Memorialists’ humble opinion, is to stop all future immigration to Natal, at any rate for the time being.
('1', 258, 1, 7, 588365) Your Memorialists beg respectfully, but emphatically, to protest against an arrangement that gives all the benefit to one party only, and that, indeed, the least in need of it.
('1', 258, 1, 8, 588542) Such stopping of immigration will not, your Memorialists submit, materially effect the congested parts of India.
('1', 258, 1, 9, 588655) 34. Your Memorialists have so far discussed both the indenture and the licence clauses together.

('1', 258, 1, 11, 588997) There is only a licence of £3 10s to be taken out once for all.
('1', 258, 1, 12, 589061) And this too has, your Memorialists understand, among other things, formed the subject of a memorial 1 to Her Majesty’s Government.
('1', 258, 1, 13, 589193) Moreover, the licence in this case is an annual tax in its most obnoxious form.
('1', 258, 1, 14, 589273) This tax has to be paid whether the unfortunate victim has the means or not.
('1', 258, 1, 15, 589350) When a member, during the discussion, asked how the tax will be collected if any Indian objected to or did not pay it, the Hon.
('1', 258, 1, 16, 589478) Attorney General remarked that there would always be found sufficient in the defaulting Indian’s house to attach under a summary process!
('1', 258, 1, 17, 589616) Lastly, your Memorialists submit that the introduction of the licence clause goes beyond the limits laid down by the Viceroy’s Despatch referred to above.
('1', 258, 1, 18, 589771) In conclusion, your Memorialists most earnestly pray and confidently hope that Her Majesty’s Government will come to the conclusion that the clauses discussed herein are manifestly unjust, and

('1', 259, 8, 10, 590733) addressed to Her Majesty’s Government with regard to certain clauses of the Indian Immigration Law Amendment Bill which was recently passed by the Hon.

('1', 259, 8, 12, 590923) the Legislative Council of Natal, and which is partly based upon Your Excellency’s Dispatch to His Excellency the Governor of Natal on the subject thereof, a copy of which is annexed hereto.
('1', 259, 8, 13, 591114) Besides drawing Your Excellency’s attention to the above memorial, your Memorialists beg respectfully to state as follows with regard to the Bill: Your Excellency’s Memorialists have noticed with regret that Your Excellency is disposed to sanction the principle of compulsory re indenture, or compulsory return.
('1', 259, 8, 14, 591426) Your Memorialists also regret that they did not send a representation at the time the Delegates set out for India.
('1', 259, 8, 15, 591541) 1 It will be idle to discuss the causes that prevented such a course from being adopted.

('1', 260, 0, 1, 591717) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 261
('1', 260, 1, 2, 591751) inflicted would be so great, in case the Bill became law, that the above omission will not come in the way of its being averted.
('1', 260, 1, 3, 591880) Your Memorialists, with the greatest deference, venture to point out that, if the non compliance with the condition as to compulsory return could not set the criminal law in motion, the insertion in the contracts of such a clause is absolutely useless, if not actually harmful, in as much as it might encourage the contracting party to break his contract, and the law would connive at such a breach.
('1', 260, 1, 4, 592280) And since such extreme precaution pre supposes the injustice of the contract, your Memorialists respectfully submit that the reasons adduced for inducing the sanction are absolutely insufficient, if any reasons could justify it.
('1', 260, 1, 5, 592509) As has been hinted at in the annexure, your Memorialists implore Your Excellency not to sanction any of the clauses objected to, but, in accordance with the emphatically expressed opinions of Mr. J. R. Saunders and the Hon.
('1', 260, 1, 6, 592733) Mr. Escombe quoted in the annexure 1, to stop immigration to Natal.
('1', 260, 1, 7, 592801) Your Memorialists respectfully beg to protest against any section of Her Majesty’s subjects, be they the poorest, being practically enslaved or subjected to a special, obnoxious poll tax, in order that a body of Colonists, who already have been deriving the greatest benefits from such subjects, may be able to satisfy their whims or desire to exact more from the same men without any return whatsoever.
('1', 260, 1, 8, 593205) In calling the idea of compulsory re indenture, or in lieu thereof, of a poll tax, a whim, your Memorialists believe they have used the right expression.
('1', 260, 1, 9, 593359) For, your Memorialists firmly believe there would be no cause for alarm even if the Indian population were trebled in the Colony.
('1', 260, 1, 10, 593489) But, your Memorialists humbly submit that, in a matter like the above, the wish of the Colony cannot guide Your Excellency’s decision, but that the interests of the Indians affected by the clauses should also be considered.
('1', 260, 1, 11, 593713) And your Memorialists have no hesitation in submitting, with all due respect, that the clauses, if ever sanctioned, will be a grave injustice and wrong to the most helpless of Her Majesty’s Indian subjects.
('1', 260, 1, 12, 593920) Five years’ indenture, your Memorialists submit, is long enough to undergo.
('1', 260, 1, 13, 593996) To raise it to an indefinite period would mean that an

('1', 261, 4, 11, 595448) 72. REPORT OF THE NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS August, 1895
('1', 261, 5, 12, 595501) ITS FOUNDATION
('1', 261, 6, 13, 595516) During the month of June in the year 1894 the Natal Government introduced a Bill called the Franchise Law Amendment Bill in the Legislative Assembly.
('1', 261, 6, 14, 595666) It was recognized that it threatened the very existence of the Indians in the Colony.
('1', 261, 6, 15, 595752) Meetings were held on the premises of Messrs Dada Abdulla & Co.
('1', 261, 6, 16, 595816) to consider what steps should be taken to prevent the Bill from passing.
('1', 261, 6, 17, 595889) Petitions were sent to both the Houses, Members of which were interviewed by a representative who went from Durban to P.M. Burg.
('1', 261, 6, 18, 596018) The Bill, however,
('1', 261, 7, 19, 596037) 1 The appeal was infructuous.
('1', 261, 7, 20, 596067) The Government of India's feeble protest about the authority and functions of the Protector of Immigrants as provided for in the new Immigration Amendment Bill was ignored.
('1', 261, 7, 21, 596240) The Secretary of State sought the Viceroy's reconsideration of the Bill in the light of the Natal petitions pending Royal assent to it.
('1', 261, 7, 22, 596376) Lord Elgin only reiterated his earlier view.
('1', 261, 7, 23, 596421) (Vide The Early Phase, pp.
('1', 261, 7, 24, 596448) 521 2).
('1', 261, 7, 25, 596456) The Bill received Royal sanction and became Law on August 18, 1896.
('1', 262, 0, 1, 596524) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 263
('1', 262, 1, 2, 596558) passed both the Houses.
('1', 262, 1, 3, 596582) The effect of the agitation was that all the Indians recognized the absolute necessity of establishing a permanent institution that would cope with the legislative activity, of a retrograde character, of the first Responsible Government of the Colony with regard to the Indians, and protect Indian interests.
('1', 262, 1, 4, 596891) After a few preliminary meetings had been held on Messrs Dada Abdulla’s premises, the Natal Indian Congress was formally establi shed on the 22nd August amidst great enthusiasm.
('1', 262, 1, 5, 597069) All the leading members of the Indian community joined the Congress.
('1', 262, 1, 6, 597138) Seventy six members subscribed on the first evening.
('1', 262, 1, 7, 597191) The list gradually rose to 228. Mr. Abdulla Haji Adam was elected president.
('1', 262, 1, 8, 597268) Other prominent members were made vice presidents.
('1', 262, 1, 9, 597319) Mr. M. K. Gandhi was elected Hon.
('1', 262, 1, 10, 597353) Secretary.
('1', 262, 1, 11, 597364) A small committee, too, was formed.
('1', 262, 1, 12, 597400) But, as the other members of the Congress expressed a wish to attend the committee meetings during the early days of the Congress, the committee was tacitly abolished and all the members were invited to the meetings.
('1', 262, 1, 13, 597617) The minimum monthly subscription was 5/ .
('1', 262, 1, 14, 597659) There was no maximum limit.
('1', 262, 1, 15, 597687) Two members subscribed £2 each monthly, one 25/ , ten 20/ , twenty five 10/ , three 7/6, three 5/3, two 5/1, and one hundred and eighty seven subscribed 5/ each, monthly.
('1', 262, 1, 16, 597858) The following table shows the various classes of members with the subscriptions paid by them, the deficiency, etc.

('1', 263, 1, 2, 598725) It will be seen from the above that, out of a possible income of £900 8 0, the Congress has been so far successful in collecting only £500 17 6 or nearly 50%.
('1', 263, 1, 3, 598884) The 5/ subscribers have been the greatest defaulters.
('1', 263, 1, 4, 598938) The causes are many.
('1', 263, 1, 5, 598959) It should be borne in mind that some joined at a very late stage and, naturally, have not paid for the whole year.

('1', 268, 1, 2, 609353) 73. LETTER TO “THE NATAL MERCURY”
('1', 268, 2, 3, 609387) DURBAN, September 2, 1895
('1', 268, 3, 4, 609413) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Mercury
('1', 268, 4, 5, 609445) SIR, I would take the liberty to make a few remarks on your leader letters on the recent cables about the Indians in South Africa.
('1', 268, 4, 6, 609576) It is not for the first time that you have said that the people in South Africa object to give the Indians equal political rights because they do not enjoy them in India, and that you would not object to give them the same rights as they enjoy in India.
('1', 268, 4, 7, 609830) As I have said elsewhere, I repeat here that, in theory at any rate, the Indians do enjoy equal political rights with the Europeans in India.
('1', 268, 4, 8, 609972) The Charter of 1833 and the Proclamation of 1858 guarantee the Indians the same rights and privileges as are enjoyed by Her Majesty’s other subjects.
('1', 268, 4, 9, 610122) And the Indians in this Colony, as well as in other parts of South Africa, would be quite satisfied if they could only enjoy the same rights that they would enjoy under similar circumstances.
('1', 268, 4, 10, 610314) In India, whenever the Europeans are allowed to vote, the Indians are not excluded.
('1', 268, 4, 11, 610398) If the former have votes at the municipal elections, so have the latter.
('1', 268, 4, 12, 610471) If the former can elect or become elected members of the Legislative Council, so can the latter.
('1', 268, 4, 13, 610568) If the former can walk about freely after 9 p.m., so can the latter.
('1', 268, 4, 14, 610637) The latter cannot possess themselves with arms as freely as the former.
('1', 268, 4, 15, 610709) The Indians in South Africa also have no very great anxiety to arm themselves.
('1', 268, 4, 16, 610788) There is no poll tax in India.
('1', 268, 4, 17, 610819) Will you be good enough to protest against the recent Immigration Act and earn the gratitude of the helpless indentured Indians?
('1', 268, 4, 18, 610948) It is the same recognized principle of political equality that enabled Mr. Naoroji to enter the House of Commons.
('1', 268, 4, 19, 611062) If you object to the Indian having the same rights because “British energy and money” have built up this Colony, you should clearly object to the Germans and the French also.
('1', 268, 4, 20, 611237) On the same principle, the descendants of the pioneers who shed their blood may well object to even those coming from England and pushing them out.
('1', 268, 4, 21, 611385) Is this not a narrow and selfish view of the matter?
('1', 268, 4, 22, 611438) At times I read in your leaders expressions of very lofty and humanitarian sentiments.
('1', 268, 4, 23, 611525) Unfortunately for the poor Indian, these sentiments are set aside when you deal with
('1', 269, 0, 1, 611610) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 270
('1', 269, 1, 2, 611652) the Indian question.
('1', 269, 1, 3, 611673) And yet, whether you like it or not, he is your fellow subject.
('1', 269, 1, 4, 611737) England does not want to let go her hold of India, and at the same time she does not want to rule her with an iron rod.
('1', 269, 1, 5, 611857) Her statesmen say that they want so much to endear the English rule to the Indians that they would not have any other.
('1', 269, 1, 6, 611976) Would not views such as those expressed by you retard the fulfilment of those wishes?
('1', 269, 1, 7, 612062) I know very few Indians who, though they may be earning £1,000, live as if they were earning only £50. The fact is that, perhaps, there is no Indian in the Colony who alone earns £1,000 per year.
('1', 269, 1, 8, 612258) There are some whose trade would lead others to believe that they must be “making a pile”.
('1', 269, 1, 9, 612349) The trade of some of them is certainly very large; not so the profit, because it is shared by many.
('1', 269, 1, 10, 612449) The Indian loves trade, and so long as he can earn a decent living, he does not mind sharing his profit largely with others.
('1', 269, 1, 11, 612574) He does not insist upon the lion’s share.
('1', 269, 1, 12, 612616) Just like the European, the Indian also loves spending his money, only not so recklessly.
('1', 269, 1, 13, 612706) Every merchant who has amassed a fortune in Bombay has built for himself palatial buildings.
('1', 269, 1, 14, 612799) The only palatial building in Mombassa has been built by an Indian.
('1', 269, 1, 15, 612867) Indian merchants have earned much in Zanzibar, and consequently have built palaces, and, in some instances, pleasure houses also.
('1', 269, 1, 16, 612997) If no Indian has done so in Durban of South Africa it is because he has not earned sufficient to enable him so to do.
('1', 269, 1, 17, 613115) Sir, if you will only study the question a little more closely (pardon me for so saying), you will find that the Indians spend in this Colony quite as much as they can without coming to grief.
('1', 269, 1, 18, 613308) To say that those earning well sleep on the floors of their shops is, I venture to say, rather incorrect.
('1', 269, 1, 19, 613414) If you would undeceive yourself, and if you will leave your editorial chair for a few hours, I would escort you to some Indian stores.
('1', 269, 1, 20, 613549) Then, perhaps, you would think much less harshly of them than now.
('1', 269, 1, 21, 613616) I humbly believe that the Indian question, at any rate for the British Colonies, has a local as well as Imperial significance, and I submit that to lose temper over it, or to shut one’s eyes to actual facts, in order to form preconceived ideas, is not exactly the way to solve it satisfactorily.
('1', 269, 1, 22, 613912) It behoves responsible persons in the Colony not to widen the gulf between the two communities, but, if possible, to bridge it.
('1', 269, 1, 23, 614040) Having invited the Indians to the Colony, how can the responsible Colonists curse them?
('1', 269, 1, 24, 614128) How can they escape the natural consequences of the introduction of the Indian labour?
('1', 269, 2, 25, 614215) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Natal Mercury, 5 9 1895
('1', 270, 0, 1, 614268) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 271
('1', 270, 1, 2, 614302) 74. LETTER TO “THE NATAL MERCURY 11
('1', 270, 2, 3, 614338) DURBAN, September 15, 1895
('1', 270, 3, 4, 614365) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Mercury
('1', 270, 4, 5, 614397) SIR, I would venture to make a few remarks in reply to Mr. T. Marston Francis’s letter on the Indian question.
('1', 270, 4, 6, 614508) I believe your correspondent’s description of the Indian municipalities, as also of the Legislative Councils, is not quite accurate.
('1', 270, 4, 7, 614641) To mention only one instance, I do not think that the chairman of an Indian municipality must be a covenanted civilian.
('1', 270, 4, 8, 614761) The present president of the Bombay Corporation is an Indian solicitor.
('1', 270, 4, 9, 614833) I have never contended—nor do I contend now—that the franchise is as extensive in India as it is here.
('1', 270, 4, 10, 614936) It would also be idle for me to say that the Legislative Councils in India are as representative as the Legislative Assembly here.
('1', 270, 4, 11, 615067) What I do contend, however, is that, whatever the limits of the franchise in India, it is extended to all without distinction of colour.
('1', 270, 4, 12, 615204) The fact that the Indian’s ability to understand representative government has been recognized cannot be gainsaid.
('1', 270, 4, 13, 615319) What Mr. Francis says, viz., that the qualifications for the franchise are not the same in India as in Natal, has never been denied.
('1', 270, 4, 14, 615452) Under such a test no one coming from even Europe would be entitled to the franchise, for the qualifications in the different European States are not surely the same as here.
('1', 270, 4, 15, 615626) This week’s mail brings the latest proof that the Indians have never failed in the real and only test, viz., whether or not they understand the principle of representation.
('1', 270, 4, 16, 615799) I quote from the article on “Indian Affairs” in The Times:
('1', 270, 5, 17, 615858) 1 Controverting Gandhiji's plea for granting the franchise to Indians in South Africa, Mr. Marston T. Francis, who had lived several years in India, wrote in The Natal Mercury, 6 9 1895, that though Indians in India could vote at municipal elections and become members of the Legislative Council, things were so constituted that they could never outvote the European members or arrogate to themselves supreme authority.
('1', 270, 5, 18, 616278) The chairman of a municipality, he said, was always a covenanted officer of the Indian Civil Service, and the Commissioner of the Division, the Governor, the Viceroy, the Secretary of State for India, and ultimately the British Parliament could impose checks on the municipalities and legislative bodies of India.
('1', 271, 0, 1, 616592) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 272
('1', 271, 1, 2, 616634) But if the gallantry of the native soldiers who obtained recognition stirs within us a pride in having such fellow subjects.
('1', 271, 1, 3, 616759) indeed, nothing could exceed their magnificent self devotion to their comrades in that deadly pass.
('1', 271, 1, 4, 616859) The truth is that the Indians are earning the right to be regarded as worthy fellow subjects in more ways than one.
('1', 271, 1, 5, 616975) The battle field has always formed the short cut to an honourable equality among races.
('1', 271, 1, 6, 617063) But the Indians are also proving their title to our respect by the slower and more difficult methods of civil life.
('1', 271, 1, 7, 617179) There was a greater experiment made in the constitutional government of dependencies than the expansion of the Indian Legislative Council on a partially elective basis three years ago.
('1', 271, 1, 8, 617364) Many of the discussions have been most helpful, and so far as Bengal is concerned—the province in which the elective system seemed fraught with the greatest difficulty—the experiment, after a severe trial, has proved a success.
('1', 271, 1, 9, 617592) This, as is well known, is from the pen of a historian 1 and Indian officer who has served in India for 30 years.
('1', 271, 1, 10, 617706) Disfranchisement by itself may seem to some to be very insignificant.
('1', 271, 1, 11, 617776) But its consequences to the Indian community are too dreadful to contemplate.
('1', 271, 1, 12, 617854) Its corresponding advantages to the European Colonists, I am convinced, are nil, unless there be anything gratifying in degrading or keeping under degradation a race or nation.
('1', 271, 1, 13, 618031) There is no question of “the white man or the yellow man ruling”, and I hope to be able to show, on a future occasion, that the fears entertained on that score are entirely groundless.
('1', 271, 1, 14, 618216) There are passages in Mr. Francis’s letter which would, perhaps, show that he must have left India very long ago.
('1', 271, 1, 15, 618330) There are very few posts more responsible than that of a civil commissioner, and yet the Secretary of State for India only recently thought it prudent to appoint an Indian to that post.
('1', 271, 1, 16, 618516) Mr. Francis knows what jurisdiction a Chief Justice in India enjoys, and an Indian has occupied that position both in Bengal and Madras.
('1', 271, 1, 17, 618653) Those who wish to bind the two races— the British and the Indian—with “the silken cord of love” will not find it difficult to notice innumerable points of contact between the two.
('1', 271, 1, 18, 618833) Even the three religions of the two, in spite of their apparent antagonism, have much in common, and would not form a bad unity in trinity.
('1', 271, 1, 19, 618973) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Natal Mercury, 23 9 1895
('1', 271, 2, 20, 619027) W. W. Hunter
('1', 272, 0, 1, 619040) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 273
('1', 272, 1, 2, 619074) 75. LETTER TO “THE NATAL ADVERTISER”
('1', 272, 2, 3, 619111) DURBAN, September 23, 1895
('1', 272, 3, 4, 619138) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Advertiser
('1', 272, 4, 5, 619173) SIR, Your remarks in your Saturday’s issue on the “Indian Congress”, or more correctly, “The Natal Indian Congress”.
('1', 272, 4, 6, 619290) are premature, seeing that the case 1 in which the name has been used is not yet over.
('1', 272, 4, 7, 619377) Were I not afraid of running the risk of committing contempt of court I would make a few remarks on the circumstances under which the Congress has been connected with the case.
('1', 272, 4, 8, 619554) I am, therefore, obliged to postpone any remarks on the matter till the case is over.
('1', 272, 4, 9, 619640) In the meanwhile, in order to remove any misimpression your remarks may create, I would with your kind permission, set out the objects of the Congress.
('1', 272, 4, 10, 619792) They are: “(1) To bring about a better understanding, and to promote friendliness between the Europeans and the Indians residing in the Colony.
('1', 272, 4, 11, 619936) “(2) To spread information about India and the Indians by writing to newspapers, publishing pamphlets, lecturing, etc.
('1', 272, 4, 12, 620055) “(3) To educate the Indians, especially [those] born in the Colony, about Indian History, and induce them to study Indian subjects.
('1', 272, 4, 13, 620187) “(4) To ascertain the various grievances the Indians are labouring under, and to agitate by resorting to all constitutional methods for removing them.
('1', 272, 5, 14, 620338) 1 The Natal Indian Congress leaders were said to have had a hand in intimida ting an Indian witness from giving evidence in a trial for assault.
('1', 272, 5, 15, 620483) The charge was actu ally against Padayachi, a member of the Natal Indian Congress, and it was stated that he did so at the instigation of leaders of the Congress.
('1', 272, 5, 16, 620646) It was further alleged that under Gandhiji's leadership the Congress was conspiring to fight the Government, that it set up Indian labourers to agitate against their grievances, that Gandhiji extracted mo ney from them and from Indian traders promising to help them obtain relief and used the funds for his own purposes.
('1', 272, 5, 17, 620967) Vide also"Letter to Colonial Secretary", 21 10 1895.
('1', 273, 0, 1, 621020) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 274
('1', 273, 1, 2, 621062) “(5) To enquire into the condition of the indentured Indians and to help them out of special hardships.
('1', 273, 1, 3, 621166) “(6) To help the poor and the needy in all reasonable ways.
('1', 273, 1, 4, 621226) “(7) And generally to do everything that would tend to put the Indians on a better footing morally, socially, intellectually, and politically.” The very constitution of the Congress prevented it from dealing with private grievances, unless they have a public significance.
('1', 273, 1, 5, 621499) To say that “it has been quite through accident that the existence of the ‘Indian Congress’ has been discovered” is hardly in accordance with known facts.
('1', 273, 1, 6, 621654) While the Congress was yet in process of formation, The Natal Witness announced the fact, and, if I am not mistaken, the paragraph announcing it was copied by you.
('1', 273, 1, 7, 621818) It is true that it has not been officially made known before.
('1', 273, 1, 8, 621880) This was not done because its organizers were not, and are not yet, sure of its permanent existence.
('1', 273, 1, 9, 621981) They thought it prudent to let time alone bring it to the public notice.
('1', 273, 1, 10, 622054) No attempts have been made to keep it secret.

('1', 277, 4, 5, 628417) TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY P. M. BURG
('1', 277, 5, 6, 628469) SIR, Certain remarks in the newspapers 2 and the judgment of the Durban Resident Magistrate in Regina v.
('1', 277, 5, 7, 628574) Rungasamy Padayachi recently tried before him render it necessary for me to write to you, in my capacity as Honorary Secretary for the Congress, in connection with the remarks and the judgment referred to above.
('1', 277, 5, 8, 628786) The judgment lays down that the Congress summoned an Indian named Asgara before it on a certain day in August and attempted to intimidate him from giving evidence in a case, and that it is an association of conspiracy, etc.
('1', 277, 5, 9, 629010) I have to submit that not only has the Congress never summoned the above named person or any other person before it with a view to prevent him from giving evidence, but that the presiding Magistrate had absolutely no grounds for making such remarks.
('1', 277, 5, 10, 629260) The judgment in which the remarks occur is under appeal.
('1', 277, 5, 11, 629317) That has prevented me from dealing with the matter at any length in the Press.
('1', 277, 5, 12, 629396) Unfortunately, the remarks being merely obiter dicta of the Magistrate, may not be fully dealt with by the judges.
('1', 277, 5, 13, 629511) During the examination, cross examination and re examination of the witness Asgara, the Congress was not even so much as mentioned.
('1', 277, 5, 14, 629643) After the re examination was finished, the Magistrate asked the witness questions about the Congress.
('1', 277, 5, 15, 629745) It was made clear from the questions
('1', 277, 6, 16, 629782) 1 This was Enclosure No.
('1', 277, 6, 17, 629807) 1 in Despatch No.

('1', 278, 1, 2, 629989) and answers that there was no meeting of the Congress during the week during which the intimidation is supposed to have taken place.
('1', 278, 1, 3, 630122) Two printed circulars were produced, one of which was dated the 14th August, the other the 12th September, inviting members of the Congress to attend the meetings on the Tuesdays following the prospective dates, i.e., on the 20th August and 17th September.
('1', 278, 1, 4, 630379) The intimidation was alleged to have happened on the 12th August.
('1', 278, 1, 5, 630445) The witness is said to have been sent for by Mahomed Camroodeen to Moosa’s office that day, where there were present M. C. Camroodeen, Dada Abdulla, Dowd Mahomed and two or three strangers.
('1', 278, 1, 6, 630635) Here, it is alleged, he was asked certain questions about the case.
('1', 278, 1, 7, 630703) And this the magistrate has connected with the Congress, in spite of the witness’s evidence to the effect that the Congress meetings are not held in Moosa’s office, that there was no circular inviting him to the meeting at Moosa’s office, that he did not attend the meetings convened in terms of the circulars, that the Congress meetings are held in the Congress Hall, that the circulars had nothing to do with the case, and that he was not present at the actual Congress meetings.
('1', 278, 1, 8, 631185) The only point that could in any way be used to support the Magistrate’s conclusion was the fact that three out of the six or seven men alleged to have been present at Moosa’s office were members of the Congress.
('1', 278, 1, 9, 631398) I beg to enclose herewith the extracts from the evidence bearing on the matter.
('1', 278, 1, 10, 631478) I venture to submit that, in some way or other, the Magistrate was biased.
('1', 278, 1, 11, 631553) In the case of Poonoosamy Pather and three others, without a particle of evidence, he has remarked in his reasons for judgment that the defendants are members of and have been backed up by the Congress.
('1', 278, 1, 12, 631756) As a matter of fact, all of them are not members of the Congress and the Congress had nothing whatever to do with the matter.
('1', 278, 1, 13, 631882) As a great deal has been made of my instructing Mr. Millar in the Rungasamy case, I may mention that I had no connection whatever with the case of Poonoosamy and others, nor did I know, till after the case had far advanced towards the final stage, that there was such a case at all.
('1', 278, 1, 14, 632165) My intervention was sought when Rungasamy was charged for the same offence for the second time and then, too, not in my capacity as Hon.
('1', 278, 1, 15, 632302) Secretary of the Congress but as a lawyer.
('1', 278, 1, 16, 632345) I beg to assure the Government that the intention of the organizers of the Congress is to make the Congress an institution
('1', 279, 0, 1, 632468) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 280
('1', 279, 1, 2, 632510) useful to both the communities in the Colony and a medium of interpretation of the feelings of the Indians on questions affecting them, and thus to help the existing Government and not to embarrass it, if it could embarrass it at all.
('1', 279, 1, 3, 632745) Holding such views, they naturally resent any remarks made about the Congress that may curtail its usefulness.
('1', 279, 1, 4, 632856) Nothing, therefore, will be more welcome to the members of the Congress than a thorough enquiry as to its constitution and working, should the Government be inclined to attach any weight to the Magistrate’s remarks.
('1', 279, 1, 5, 633072) I may state that the Congress has never yet interfered in any court matters between Indians and Indians and has refused to take up private grievances unless they have a public significance.
('1', 279, 1, 6, 633262) No individual member or members can do anything on behalf of, or in the name of, the Congress without the sanction of a majority of the members of the Congress assembled in accordance with the rules of the Congress, which can only meet on a written notification from the Honorary Secretary.
('1', 279, 1, 7, 633553) If the Government are satisfied that the Congress had nothing to do with the case in question, I, on behalf of the Congress, humbly beg to ask for some public notification of the fact; if, on the other hand, there be any doubt as to the matter I venture to ask for an enquiry.
