('1', 323, 4, 8, 735462) 92. LETTER TO “THE NATAL WITNESS” DURBAN, April 4, 1896
('1', 323, 5, 9, 735518) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Witness
('1', 323, 6, 10, 735550) SIR, I would be much obliged if you could find space for the following by way of answer to “G.W.W.”, who wrote to your under
('1', 323, 7, 11, 735675) 1 On April 10, in reply to a question by Mancherjee M. Bhawnaggree, in the House of Commons, Chamberlain promised to look into this memorial on receiving it.
('1', 323, 7, 12, 735833) The Imperial Government ultimately removed the prohibition.
('1', 324, 0, 1, 735893) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 325
('1', 324, 1, 2, 735927) date 11th March last, and did me the honour to criticize my pamphlet 1 on the Indian franchise.
('1', 324, 1, 3, 736023) While I thank “G.W.W.” for the personal fairness he has shown me in his treatment of the pamphlet, I wish he had treated the subject matter of the “Appeal” as fairly.
('1', 324, 1, 4, 736190) If he had read it with an unbiased mind, I think he would not have found any cause to differ from the views therein expressed.
('1', 324, 1, 5, 736317) I have endeavoured to treat the subject from such a standpoint as would induce the European Colonists to extend ungrudgingly the hand of fellowship to the Indians without being elbowed out of their present position in so doing.
('1', 324, 1, 6, 736545) I still maintain that there is no cause whatever for alarm, and if the European Colonists would only let the agitation die and consent to resume the status quo, they would find that their vote would not be swamped by the Indians.
('1', 324, 1, 7, 736775) I further submit that, if ever such a contingency were to arise, it could be dealt with in anticipation, without the necessity of introducing colour distinction directly or indirectly.
('1', 324, 1, 8, 736960) A real and reasonable educational test would perhaps for ever put a stop to the danger (if ever there be any) of the Indian vote swamping the European, and would, so far as possible, keep the Roll clear of the most objectionable European voters also, if any.
('1', 324, 1, 9, 737219) “G.W.W.” takes exception to the arguments drawn from the relative strength of the true votes and “calls attention to what the next year’s Roll may contain”.
('1', 324, 1, 10, 737376) I beg to call his attention to the fact that, although the Indians had every opportunity to “swamp” the List last year and the year before last, and every incentive to do so because of the fear as to the result of the Franchise Act, now about to be repealed, there were no additions to the number of Indian voters.
('1', 324, 1, 11, 737691) It must have been either extraordinary apathy or want of qualifications that could account for such a result, But it could not have been any such apathy, for the “Agitation” has been on foot for the last two years.
('1', 324, 1, 12, 737906) I, however, do not propose to examine “G.W.W.”’s letter in detail, for want of time and space, and will merely give the information he asks for, and apply it to the new Bill to be introduced during the forthcoming session.
('1', 324, 1, 13, 738129) Mr. Curzon, the then Under Secretary of State for India, in moving the second reading of the India Councils Act (1861) Amendment Bill, said, among other things:
('1', 324, 2, 14, 738290) 1 Vide "The Indian Franchise", 16 12 1895.
('1', 325, 0, 1, 738333) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('1', 325, 1, 2, 738375) The object of the Bill, which it is my duty to expound to the House is to widen the basis and extend the function of the Government of India, to give further opportunity than at present exists to the non official and the native element in Indian society to take part in the work of government and in this way to lend official recognition to that remarkable development, both in political industry and political capacity, which has been visible among the higher classes of Indian society since the Government of India was taken over by the Crown in 1858. This Bill is one to amend the Indian Councils Act of 1861. Legislative powers of some sort or other, but powers of a somewhat confused character and conflicting validity, have existed in India for a very long time.
('1', 325, 1, 3, 739144) They existed with the rule of the old East India Company dating from the date of the Charters of the Tudor and Stuart Sovereigns; but the modern legislative system, under which India at present exists, owns its origin to the viceroyalty of Lord Canning and to the Secretaryship of State of Sir C. Wood, who was afterwards elevated to the peerage.
('1', 325, 1, 4, 739491) Sir C. Wood, in 1861, carried through the House the India Councils Act of the year.
('1', 325, 1, 5, 739575) The Act of 1861 constituted three Legislative Councils in India—the Supreme Council of the Viceroy and the Provincial Councils of Madras and Bombay.
('1', 325, 1, 6, 739724) The Supreme Legislative Council of the Viceroy consists of the Governor General and his Executive Council, and is recruited by a minimum of six and a maximum of twelve additional members who are nominated by the Governor General, of whom at least half must be non official, whether they are drawn from the European or the native element.
('1', 325, 1, 7, 740062) The Legislative Councils of Madras and Bombay are also recruited by a minimum of four and a maximum of eight additional members, who are nominated by the Provincial Governor, of whom at least half must be non official.
('1', 325, 1, 8, 740281) Since the passing of that Act, Legislative Councils have also been called into existence in Bengal and the North West Provinces.
('1', 325, 1, 9, 740410) In the case of Bengal, the Council consists of the Lieutenant Governor and twelve nominated Councillors and, in the case of the North West Provinces, of the Lieutenant Governor and nine nominated councillors, of whom one third in each case must be non official.
('1', 325, 1, 10, 740672) A number of native gentlemen of intelligence and capacity and public spirit have been persuaded to come forward and to lend their services to the function of government, and undoubtedly the standard of merit of these Legislative Councils has stood high.
('1', 325, 1, 11, 740926) The Amending Act gives the right to discuss the Budget and the right of interpellation (rights hitherto not enjoyed).
('1', 325, 1, 12, 741044) It also increases the number of members of the Council, and provides (vaguely) for a system of election.
('1', 325, 1, 13, 741149) Of course, the Act is merely permissive.
('1', 325, 1, 14, 741190) According to the regulations issued under the above Act, out of eighteen seats for additional members for the Bombay Council, eight seats are filled by election.
('1', 325, 1, 15, 741352) And the Corporation of Bombay (itself a
('1', 326, 0, 1, 741392) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 327
('1', 326, 1, 2, 741426) representative body), such Municipal Corporations, or group or groups thereof, other than the Bombay Corporation, as the Governor in Council may from time to time prescribe, District Local Boards, or groups as above prescribed, the Sardars of the Deccan, or such other class of large landholders as above prescribed, associations of merchants, tradesmen or manufacturers, prescribed as above, and the Senate of the University of Bombay, have the power to elect those members by a majority of votes.
('1', 326, 1, 3, 741925) Similar rules are published for the election by or “nomination on the recommendation of” the various representative bodies of the various provinces which have Legislative Councils.
('1', 326, 1, 4, 742106) There is no class or colour distinction as to the franchisee or the representatives elected.
('1', 326, 1, 5, 742199) The member (Indian) for the Bombay Council in the Supreme Legislative Council having resigned, the candidates are Indians and a European.
('1', 326, 1, 6, 742337) The result should be known by the next week’s mail.
('1', 326, 1, 7, 742389) I will only give one extract showing how this and municipal representation have been viewed by the most eminent men qualified to speak on such subjects with authority.
('1', 326, 1, 8, 742557) Delivering a lecture before the Society of Arts, Sir William Wilson Hunter said on the 15th February, 1893.
('1', 326, 2, 9, 742665) The Indian Municipalities, to which our Chairman, Lord Ripon, gave so memorable an impulse, had under their administration in 1891 a population of 15,000,000 and of the 10,585 members who sat on their Boards or Councils, more than one half were elected by the ratepayers.
('1', 326, 2, 10, 742937) The representative principle is now being cautiously extended under Lord Cross’s Act of 1892 to the Legislative Councils both of the Supreme and Provincial Governments.
('1', 326, 2, 11, 743106) Portion of the Proclamation of 1858 runs:
('1', 326, 3, 12, 743148) We hold ourselves bound to the natives of our Indian territories by the same obligations of duty which bind us to all our other subjects,.
('1', 326, 3, 13, 743287) .and it is our further will that, so far as may be, our subjects, of whatever race or creed, be freely and impartially admitted to offices in our service, the duties of which they may be qualified by their education, ability, and integrity duly to discharge.
('1', 326, 3, 14, 743546) Looking at the new Franchise Bill in the light of these facts, it is very difficult to understand it.
('1', 326, 3, 15, 743648) The question before the Colonists is very simple.
('1', 326, 3, 16, 743698) Is it necessary to disfranchise the Indian community?
('1', 326, 3, 17, 743752) If it is, I submit that the proof of the fact that they enjoy representative
('1', 327, 0, 1, 743829) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 328
('1', 327, 1, 2, 743871) institutions in India will not make it less so.
('1', 327, 1, 3, 743919) 1 If it is not, why harass Indians by ambiguous legislation?
('1', 327, 1, 4, 743980) If the answer to the question whether or not the Indians enjoy representative institutions in India is to decide the franchise question, I submit that the materials of knowledge about the subject are by no means so slender that the Colonists cannot decide the question now and for ever, without the necessity of an Act leaving it an open question to be decided hereafter in a Court of Law, involving a useless waste of money.
('1', 327, 1, 5, 744406) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Natal Witness, 17 4 1896
('1', 327, 2, 6, 744460) 93. MEMORIAL TO NATAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY
('1', 327, 3, 7, 744503) DURBAN, April 27, 1896
('1', 327, 4, 8, 744526) TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HONOURABLE THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF NATAL IN PARLIAMENT ASSEMBLED, PIETERMARITZBURG
('1', 327, 5, 9, 744662) THE MEMORIAL OF THE UNDERSIGNED INDIANS RESIDING IN THIS COLONY
('1', 327, 6, 10, 744726) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT: Your Memorialists as representing and on behalf of the Indian community in Natal respectfully approach this Honourable House with regard to the Franchise Law Amendment Bill now before you for consideration.
('1', 327, 6, 11, 744954) Your Memorialists assume that the Bill is meant chiefly, if not solely, to affect the Indian community in that it repeals and replaces
('1', 327, 7, 12, 745089) 1 There was some discussion in the Natal Assembly on April 9 whether Indians had “representative institutions”.
('1', 327, 7, 13, 745201) The Prime Minister's observation that they were not possessed of representative institutions “founded on the franchise” was consi dered inadequate.
('1', 327, 7, 14, 745349) In draft Bill, the words “Parliamentary institutions” were substituted by “elective representative institutions” words used in the Governor's address to the Assembly.
('1', 327, 7, 15, 745516) The second reading of the Bill, which was to have been on April 22, was postponed for a break in order that relevant correspondence between the Colonial and Home Governments could be made available and assessed by them; vide The Early Phase, pp.
('1', 328, 0, 1, 745762) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 329
('1', 328, 1, 2, 745796) the Act 25 of 1894 which was intended to disfranchise the Indians in the Colony.
('1', 328, 1, 3, 745877) In the Memorial 1 that was presented to this Honourable House on behalf of the Indian community on the same subject when the Act 25 of 1894 was under consideration, it was contended that the Indians did possess elective representative institutions in India.
('1', 328, 1, 4, 746135) The present Bill disfranchises natives of countries, not being of European origin, which have not possessed elective representative institutions in their own native land.
('1', 328, 1, 5, 746306) The position of your Memorialists, therefore, is painfully awkward in opposing the present Bill.
('1', 328, 1, 6, 746403) Yet, seeing that the Bill tacitly proposes to deal with the Indian franchise, your Memorialists consider it to be their duty respectfully to express their views about the Bill and also to show further on what grounds they believe that the Indians possess elective representative institutions in India.
('1', 328, 1, 7, 746705) In moving the second reading of the “India Councils Act (1861) Amendment Bill” in the House of Commons on the 28th day of March, 1892, the then Under Secretary of State for India, said: 2
('1', 328, 2, 8, 746893) The Amending Act, besides increasing the number of nominated members in each Council, gives the power of discussing the financial statement every year and the power of “interpellation”.
('1', 328, 2, 9, 747079) It embodies the elective principle.
('1', 328, 2, 10, 747115) The Legislative Councils have from their inception enjoyed the representative character.
('1', 328, 2, 11, 747204) The honourable mover of the second reading, with reference to the increase of nominated members, said:
('1', 328, 3, 12, 747307) The object of this addition is very easily stated and will, I think, be very easily understood by the House.
('1', 328, 3, 13, 747416) It is simply by expanding the area of selection, in which case you are adding to the strength of the representative character of the Councils.
('1', 328, 3, 14, 747559) But now these Councils, your Memorialists venture to submit, enjoy the representative character “founded on the franchise”.
('1', 328, 3, 15, 747683) Speaking on an Amendment by Mr. Schwann, M.P., to the Bill to the effect that “no reform of Councils that does not embody the elective principle will be satisfactory”, Mr. Curzon said:
('1', 328, 4, 16, 747868) 1 This was dated June 28, 1894. 2 Not reproduced here.
('1', 328, 4, 17, 747923) For the text of the speech, vide “Letter to “The Natal Witness”, 4 4 1896
('1', 329, 0, 1, 747997) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 330
('1', 329, 1, 2, 748039) I should like to point to him that our Bill does not necessarily exclude some such principle as the method of selection, election or delegation.
('1', 329, 1, 3, 748184) With the permission of the House, I will read the words of the sub section of Clause I. It runs as follows: The Governor General in Council may from time to time on the approval of the Secretary of State in Council make regulations as to the conditions under which such nominations or any of them shall be made by the Governor General, Governors and Lieutenant Governors, respectively, and prescribe the manner in which such regulations shall be carried into effect.
('1', 329, 1, 4, 748651) .” Lord Kimberley 1 has expressed himself about that clause.
('1', 329, 1, 5, 748712) He said: I am bound to say that I express my whole satisfaction with regard to this elective principle.
('1', 329, 1, 6, 748816) The opinions expressed by Lord Kimberley are shared by the Secretary of State under this Act: It would be in the power of the Viceroy to invite representative bodies in India to elect or select or delegate representatives of those bodies of their opinion to be nominated to these Councils and by elective measures The Right Honourable Mr. Gladstone, speaking on the same subject, after explaining the speeches of the honourable mover of the Second Reading of the Bill and its amendment, said:
('1', 329, 2, 7, 749309) I think I may fairly say that the speech of the Under Secretary appears to me to embody the elective principle in the only sense in which we should expect it to be embodied.
('1', 329, 2, 8, 749483) It is evident that the great question—and it is one of great and profound interest—before the House is that of the introduction of the elective element into the Government of India.
('1', 329, 2, 9, 749665) What I wish is that their first steps shall be of a genuine nature and that whatever scope they give to the elective principle shall be real; there is no difference of principle.
('1', 329, 2, 10, 749844) I think that the acceptance of the elective principle by the honourable gentleman (Mr. Curzon) though guarded was not otherwise than a frank acceptance.
('1', 329, 2, 11, 749997) Turning to the Regulations made and published in accordance with the above Act, your Memorialists submit that the remarks herebefore quoted are fully borne out.
('1', 329, 2, 12, 750158) To take the Bombay Legislative Council, for instance, out of the eighteen nominated members, eight are elected by, or as it is put in the Regulations, “nominated on the recommendation of” the various representative bodies which are enfranchised for the purpose of Legislative Councils.
('1', 329, 2, 13, 750444) The Corporation of Bombay (itself an elective body), Municipal Corporations other than the Bombay Corporation in the Bombay
('1', 329, 3, 14, 750568) 1 Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, 1894 5
('1', 330, 0, 1, 750617) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 331
('1', 330, 1, 2, 750651) Presidency prescribed by the Governor in Council, District Local Boards prescribed as above, the Sardars of the Deccan or other class of large landholders prescribed as above, associations of merchants, tradesmen, etc., prescribed as above, and the Senate of the University of Bombay recommend or elect these eight members by a majority of votes or in the case of associations not established by law in the manner laid down in their rules for carrying resolutions or recording decisions upon questions of business brought before such associations.
('1', 330, 1, 3, 751199) In the Sardars of the Deccan, this Honourable House will notice, there are even direct voters for the election of members of the Council.
('1', 330, 1, 4, 751337) The regulations for the other Councils are much the same.
('1', 330, 1, 5, 751395) Such is the character of the Legislative Councils in India and the political franchise.
('1', 330, 1, 6, 751483) The difference, therefore, your Memorialists beg respectfully to point out, is not one of kind but of degree only.
('1', 330, 1, 7, 751598) The reason is not because the Indians do not know or understand the representative principle.
('1', 330, 1, 8, 751692) Your Memorialists cannot do better than quote again from the speech of the Right Honourable Mr. Gladstone, partly quoted above; he thus explained the reasons for the restrictive character of the elective principle:
('1', 330, 2, 9, 751907) Her Majesty’s Government ought to understand that it will be regarded as a most grave disappointment if, after all the assurances we have received that an attempt will be made to bring into operation this powerful engine of Government (i.e., the elective principle), there should not be some result such as we anticipate from their action.
('1', 330, 2, 10, 752247) I do not speak of its amount, I speak more of its quality.
('1', 330, 2, 11, 752306) In an Asiatic country like India, with its ancient civilization, with its institutions so peculiar, with such a diversity of races, religions and pursuits, with such an enormous extent of country, and such a multitude of human beings as probably except in China were never before under a single Government, I can understand that there should be difficulties in carrying out what we desire to see accomplished.
('1', 330, 2, 12, 752716) But great as the difficulties are the task is a noble one, and will require the utmost prudence and care in conducting it to a successful consummation.
('1', 330, 2, 13, 752868) All these things induce us to look forward cheerfully to a great future for India, and to expect that a real success will attend the genuine application, even though it may be a limited one, of the elective principle to the government of that vast and almost immeasurable country.
('1', 330, 2, 14, 753149) The opinion of those who are qualified to speak on Indian subjects seems to be unanimous as to the representative character of the Indian Councils.
('1', 331, 0, 1, 753297) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 332
('1', 331, 1, 2, 753339) Sir William Wilson Hunter, the greatest living authority on Indian subjects, says:
('1', 331, 2, 3, 753422) The representative principle is now being cautiously extended, under Lord Cross’s Act of 1892, to the Legislative Councils both of the Supreme and the Provincial Governments.
('1', 331, 2, 4, 753597) The Times, dealing with the Indian franchise in Natal, says:
('1', 331, 3, 5, 753658) The argument that the Indian in Natal cannot claim higher privileges than he enjoys in India and that he has no franchise whatever in India is inconsistent with the facts.
('1', 331, 3, 6, 753830) The Indian has precisely the same franchise in India which the Englishman enjoys.
('1', 331, 3, 7, 753912) After dealing with the Municipal franchise the article goes on to say:
('1', 331, 4, 8, 753983) A similar principle applies, with the modification incidental to our system of government in India, to what may be called the Higher Electorate.
('1', 331, 4, 9, 754128) The elected members of the Supreme and the Legislative Councils, which deal with 221 millions of British subjects are mainly elected by native bodies.
('1', 331, 4, 10, 754279) Apart from the official representatives of Government in the Supreme and Provincial Legislatures about one half the members are natives.
('1', 331, 4, 11, 754416) It would be wrong to push this analogy too far.
('1', 331, 4, 12, 754464) But it answers the argument against allowing British Indian subjects a vote in British Colonies on the ground that they have no vote in India.
('1', 331, 4, 13, 754607) So far as government by voting exists in India, Englishmen and Indians stand on the same footing and, like in the Municipal, the Provincial and the Supreme Councils, the native interests are powerfully represented.
('1', 331, 4, 14, 754822) The Municipal franchise is very broad in India, and almost the whole of British India is studded by Municipal Corporations and Local Boards.
('1', 331, 4, 15, 754963) Speaking of the class of Indians already on the Voters’ Rolls in Natal, The Times article, referred to above, says:
('1', 331, 5, 16, 755079) It is precisely this class of men who form the most valued element in the municipal and other electorates in India.
('1', 331, 5, 17, 755195) Throughout the 750 municipalities of India the British and the native voters have equal rights, and 9,790 Municipal Commissioners (Councillors) in 1891 were natives as against 839 Europeans.
('1', 331, 5, 18, 755386) The European vote on the Indian Municipal Boards was therefore only one to 8 Indian votes, while in the Natal Electorate there are 37 European votes to one British Indian.
('1', 331, 5, 19, 755558) It must be remembered that Indian Municipalities administer a population of 15 millions and an expenditure of 50 million rupees.
('1', 331, 5, 20, 755687) As to the acquaintance of the Indian with the nature and responsibilities of representative institutions, the same article says:
('1', 332, 0, 1, 755816) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 333
('1', 332, 1, 2, 755850) There is probably no other country in the world in which representative institutions have penetrated so deeply into the life of the people.
('1', 332, 1, 3, 755990) Every caste, every trade, every village in India had for ages its council of five which practically legislated for and conducted the administration of the little community which it represented.
('1', 332, 1, 4, 756184) Until the introduction of the Parish Councils’ Act last year, there was no such rural system of self administration even in England.
('1', 332, 1, 5, 756317) Mr. Schwann., M.P., on the same subject says: Do not suppose that the question of election is a new one in India.
('1', 332, 1, 6, 756431) There is no question which is more specially Indian than the question of election.
('1', 332, 1, 7, 756514) Most of our civilization has come from India.
('1', 332, 1, 8, 756560) And there is not the slightest doubt that we ourselves are practising a development of the Eastern principle of election.
('1', 332, 1, 9, 756682) Under such circumstances the Indian community whom the Bill is intended to affect find it most difficult to understand it.
('1', 332, 1, 10, 756805) Your Memorialists submit that the vagueness and ambiguity of the Bill are very undesirable and fair neither to the European community nor the Indian.
('1', 332, 1, 11, 756955) They leave both in a state of suspense which is painful to the latter.
('1', 332, 1, 12, 757026) Your Memorialists respectfully draw the attention of this Honourable House to the fact that according to the present Voters’ Roll, there is one Indian to every 38 Europeans, and that the Indian voters belong to the most respectable element in that community and are residents of long standing with large stakes in the Colony.
('1', 332, 1, 13, 757352) It is said, however, that the present List is no guide to what proportions the Indian vote may assume in future.
('1', 332, 1, 14, 757465) But the fact that, during the two years that the disfranchisement of the Indian community has been threatened, no more Indians have had their names placed on the Voters’ Roll, in your Memorialists’ humble opinion, sufficiently disposes of the argument.
('1', 332, 1, 15, 757718) The truth is, and your Memorialists venture to speak from personal experience, there are not very many Indians in the Colony who have got the legal property qualification, low as it is.
('1', 332, 1, 16, 757904) Your Memorialists respectfully submit that the Bill under discussion is open to more objections than one.
('1', 332, 1, 17, 758010) In your Memorialists’ humble opinion, it introduces the colour distinction in a most invidious manner.
('1', 332, 1, 18, 758113) For, while natives of other countries not enjoying elective representative institutions may not become voters, natives of the States of Europe, even though they may not enjoy such institutions in the countries they come from, may become voters under the General Franchise Law of the Colony.
('1', 333, 0, 1, 758404) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 334
('1', 333, 1, 2, 758446) It would make the sons of non European women of questionable reputation eligible as voters so long as the father is a European, while it would prevent the son of a European lady of noble birth, should she choose to marry a nobleman belonging to a non European race, from becoming a voter under the General Franchise Law of the Colony.
('1', 333, 1, 3, 758781) Assuming that the Indians come under the scope of the Bill, the method by which they may get themselves placed on the Voters’ Roll will be a source of constant irritation to the Indian community, and may give rise to a system of favouritism and cause serious dissensions among the members of the Indian community.
('1', 333, 1, 4, 759095) The Bill is moreover calculated to involve the Indian community in endless litigation in order to enable them to vindicate their rights, which your Memorialists think, are capable of definition without any recourse to the law courts of the Colony.
('1', 333, 1, 5, 759343) Above all, it will transfer the agitation from the hands of the Europeans, who now wish to see the Indians disfranchised, into those of the Indian community.
('1', 333, 1, 6, 759501) And the agitation, your Memorialists fear, has to be perpetual.
('1', 333, 1, 7, 759565) It is most humbly submitted that such a state of things is very undesirable in the interests of all the communities inhabiting this Colony.
('1', 333, 1, 8, 759705) Your Memorialists, after a careful investigation for over a year, have ventured to come to the conclusion that the fear about the Indian vote swamping the European is absolutely imaginary, and, therefore, fervently pray and venture to hope that this Honourable House, before assenting to any Bill specially restrictive of the Indian vote or directly or indirectly introducing any colour distinction, would institute an inquiry into the real state of affairs which would show how many resident Indians there are in this Colony who possess the legal property qualification necessary for being placed on the Voters’ Roll.And for this act of justice and mercy, your Memorialists, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, etc., etc.

('1', 336, 9, 13, 765644) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT : Your Memorialists hereby respectfully beg to lay before your Honour the following for your consideration with regard to the Franchise Law Amendment Bill introduced by the Natal Government in the Natal Legislative Assembly, which was read a third time on the 13th day of May, 1896, with certain amendments.
('1', 336, 9, 14, 765972) The following is the text of the Bill as it appeared in the Natal Government Gazette dated the 3rd March, 1896:
('1', 336, 10, 15, 766084) To amend the Law relating to the Franchise:
('1', 336, 11, 16, 766128) 1 Referring to this letter, Sir John Robinson said in Parliament that he had no explanation to offer and furnished a gist of the correspondence.
('1', 337, 0, 1, 766273) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 338
('1', 337, 1, 2, 766315) Whereas it is expedient to amend the law relating to the Franchise,
('1', 337, 2, 3, 766383) Be it therefore enacted by the Queen’s Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly of Natal, as follows:
('1', 337, 3, 4, 766555) 1. Act No.
('1', 337, 3, 5, 766566) 25, 1894, shall be and the same is hereby repealed.
('1', 337, 4, 6, 766618) 2. Save those who come under the operation of Section 3 of this Act, no persons shall be qualified to have their names inserted in any List of Electors or in any Voters’ Roll, or to vote as Electors within the meaning of Section 22 of the Constitution Act of 1893, or of any law relating to the election of members of the Legislative Assembly, who (not being of European origin) are Natives, or descendants in the male lines of Natives of countries which have not hitherto possessed active representative institutions, unless they shall first obtain an order from the Governor in Council exempting them from the operation of this Act.
('1', 337, 5, 7, 767253) 3. The provisions of Section 2 of this Act shall not apply to persons of the class mentioned in that Section whose names are rightly contained in any Voters’ Roll in force at the date of the promulgation of this Act, and who are otherwise competent and qualified as electors.
('1', 337, 5, 8, 767529) The Act repealed by Section I of the above Bill is as follows:
('1', 337, 6, 9, 767592) Be it therefore enacted by the Queen’s Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly of Natal, as follows:
('1', 337, 7, 10, 767764) 1. Save as in Section 2 of this Act excepted, persons of Asiatic Extraction shall not be qualified to have their names inserted in any List of Electors or in any Voters’ Roll or to vote as Electors within the meaning of Section 22 of the Constitution Act of 1893, or of any law relating to the election of members of the Legislative Assembly.
('1', 337, 8, 11, 768107) 2. The provisions of Section I of this Act shall not apply to persons of the class mentioned in that Section whose names are rightly contained in any Voters’ Roll in force at the date of the promulgation of this Act, and who are otherwise competent and qualified as electors.
('1', 337, 9, 12, 768383) 3. This Act shall not come into operation unless and until the Governor notifies by Proclamation in the Natal Government Gazette that it is Her Majesty’s pleasure not to disallow the same, and thereafter it shall come into operation upon such day as the Governor shall notify by the same or any other Proclamation.
('1', 337, 9, 13, 768698) A Memorial 1 setting forth the views of the Indian community in reference to the Bill under discussion was presented to the Legislative
('1', 337, 10, 14, 768834) 1 Vide “Memorial to Natal Legislative Assembly”, 27 4 1896
('1', 338, 0, 1, 768893) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 339
('1', 338, 1, 2, 768927) Assembly on the 28th day of April, 1896. A copy thereof is hereto annexed marked ‘A’.
('1', 338, 1, 3, 769013) On the 6th day of May, 1896, the Bill was read a second time.
('1', 338, 1, 4, 769075) During the course of his speech, the Prime Minister, the Honourable Sir John Robinson, said that the Ministers had taken steps to ascertain whether you would be agreeable to an insertion in the aforesaid Bill of the words “founded on the franchise” after “Elective representative institutions” and that you were so agreeable.
('1', 338, 1, 5, 769401) Thereupon, on the 7th day of May, 1896, your Memorialists sent to Your Honour a cablegram to the following effect:
('1', 338, 2, 6, 769516) The Indian community earnestly request you not to accept Natal Franchise Bill or Ministerial alteration thereof proposed last night; memorial preparing.
('1', 338, 2, 7, 769669) In Committee, however, the Honourable Sir John Robinson announced on the 11th day of May, 1896, that Your Honour had agreed to a further addition viz, ‘Parliamentary’ between ‘the’ and ‘franchise’.
('1', 338, 2, 8, 769867) The Bill, therefore, as to representative institutions would now read “elective representative institutions founded on the Parliamentary franchise”.
('1', 338, 2, 9, 770016) Your Memorialists humbly venture to think that the present Bill, so far as the Indian community and, indeed, all the communities are concerned, is worse than the Act it repeals.
('1', 338, 2, 10, 770194) Your Memorialists, therefore, feel aggrieved that you have been pleased to approve of the Bill, but they trust that the facts and arguments placed before you hereinbelow are such as would induce you to reconsider your views.
('1', 338, 2, 11, 770419) Your Memorialists have all along contended that the Indians did enjoy “elective representative institutions” in India.
('1', 338, 2, 12, 770538) But the papers published in connection with the franchise question seem to show that you do not think that the Indians possess such institutions.
('1', 338, 2, 13, 770684) With the greatest deference to Your Honour’s view, your Memorialists crave leave to draw your attention to the extracts quoted in the annexure ‘A’ upholding the opposite view.
('1', 338, 2, 14, 770860) Your approval of the present Bill, coupled with the view held by Your Honour regarding “elective representative institutions” in India, places the Indian community in Natal in a very painful and awkward position.
('1', 338, 2, 15, 771073) Your Memorialists venture to submit:
('1', 339, 0, 1, 771110) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 340
('1', 339, 1, 2, 771152) 1. That no legislation restrictive of the Indian franchise in Natal is necessary.
('1', 339, 1, 3, 771234) 2. That, if there be any doubt with regard to this point, an enquiry should be first instituted as to whether such a necessity does exist.
('1', 339, 1, 4, 771373) 3. That, assuming that the necessity exists, the present Bill is not calculated to meet the difficulty in a straightforward and open manner.
('1', 339, 1, 5, 771514) 4. That, if her Majesty’s Government are absolutely satisfied that the necessity exists and that no Bill could be conceived that would solve the difficulty without a resort to class legislation, it is better that in any Franchise Bill the Indians should be specially named.
('1', 339, 1, 6, 771788) 5. That the present Bill is likely to give rise to endless litigation owing to its ambiguity and vagueness.
('1', 339, 1, 7, 771896) 6. That it would involve the Indian community in expenses almost beyond their control.
('1', 339, 1, 8, 771983) 7. That assuming the Bill affects the Indian community, the method provided in the Bill whereby any member thereof may be exempted from its operation is, your Memorialists respectfully submit,arbitrary, unfair, and likely to create dissensions among the members of the Indian community.
('1', 339, 1, 9, 772270) 8. That the Bill, like the Act repealed, makes an invidious distinction between Europeans and others.
('1', 339, 1, 10, 772372) Your Memorialists humbly submit that the present condition of the Voters’ List in Natal renders it absolutely unnecessary to embark on any legislation to restrict the Indian franchise.
('1', 339, 1, 11, 772557) There seems to be needless hurry about passing a measure that affects a large portion of Her Majesty’s subjects.
('1', 339, 1, 12, 772670) It is admitted that as against 9,309 European voters there are only 251 Indian voters; 201 are either traders or clerks, assistants, schoolmasters, etc., and 50 are gardeners and others, and that most of these voters are settlers of long standing.
('1', 339, 1, 13, 772918) These figures, your Memorialists submit, do not warrant any restrictive legislation.
('1', 339, 1, 14, 773003) The Bill under discussion is intended to deal with a remote and probable and possible danger.
('1', 339, 1, 15, 773097) A danger is really assumed which does not exist.
('1', 339, 1, 16, 773146) His Honour, Sir John Robinson, in moving the second reading of the Bill, based his fears about the danger of the European vote being swamped by the Indian vote on three grounds, viz.:
('1', 340, 0, 1, 773330) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 341
('1', 340, 1, 2, 773364) 1. The fact that the petition to Her Majesty’s Government in connection with the Franchise Act, repealed by the present Bill, was signed by nearly 9,000 Indians.
('1', 340, 1, 3, 773526) 2. The approaching general election in the Colony.
('1', 340, 1, 4, 773577) 3. The existence of the Natal Indian Congress.
('1', 340, 1, 5, 773624) As to the first ground, even in the correspondence on the subject, the Natal Government have argued that the 9,000 signatories wanted to be placed on the Voters’ Roll.
('1', 340, 1, 6, 773792) The first paragraph of that petition is a sufficient answer to the argument.
('1', 340, 1, 7, 773869) The Petitioners, your Memorialists humbly submit, never contended for any such thing.
('1', 340, 1, 8, 773955) They certainly protested against the wholesale disfranchisement of the Indians.
('1', 340, 1, 9, 774035) Your Memorialists humbly venture to think that every Indian, whether he had the property qualifications or not, was very materially affected by that Bill.
('1', 340, 1, 10, 774190) Your Memorialists admit that the fact show a degree of organizing power among the Indians, alluded to by the Hon.
('1', 340, 1, 11, 774304) mover, but your Memorialists respectfully contend that no matter how powerful the organizing power might be, it cannot overcome the natural barriers.
('1', 340, 1, 12, 774454) Out of the 9,000 signatories, not a hundred, besides those who were already on the Voters’ Roll, possessed the legal property qualifications.
('1', 340, 1, 13, 774596) With regard to the second ground, the Hon.
('1', 340, 1, 14, 774639) mover said:
('1', 340, 2, 15, 774651) He might remind members that before long there must be a general election, and they would have to consider upon what register that general election was to take place.
('1', 340, 2, 16, 774818) It was not for him to say how many Indian electors might or might not be on the ensuing electoral roll, but the Government thought it was high time that no further delay should take place in seizing this question by the throat and setting it once for all, without further delay.
('1', 340, 2, 17, 775097) Your Memorialists submit, with all due respect to the Hon.
('1', 340, 2, 18, 775156) mover, that all these fears have no foundation in fact.
('1', 340, 2, 19, 775212) According to the Report of the Protector of Immigrants for 1895, out of 46,343 Indians in the Colony, only 30,303 are free Indians.
('1', 340, 2, 20, 775344) To that may be added the trading Indian population of, say, 5,000. Thus there are only 35,000 Indians, as against over 45,000 Europeans, who can at all compete with the latter.
('1', 340, 2, 21, 775521) The 16,000 indentured Indians, it is easy to see, never can vote, while they are under indenture.
('1', 340, 2, 22, 775619) But a large majority of the 30,303 are only a stage higher than the indentured Indians.
('1', 340, 2, 23, 775707) And your Memorialists venture to say from personal experience that there are in this Colony thousands of Indians who do not pay £10 per year in rents.
('1', 340, 2, 24, 775858) In fact, there are thousands who have to
('1', 341, 0, 1, 775899) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 342
('1', 341, 1, 2, 775941) drag on their existence on that amount.
('1', 341, 1, 3, 775981) Where then, your Memorialists ask, is the fear of the Indians swamping the Voters’ List next year?
('1', 341, 1, 4, 776080) The disfranchisement has been threatened for the last two years.
('1', 341, 1, 5, 776145) The Electoral Roll has twice undergone revision since.
('1', 341, 1, 6, 776200) The Indians had every incentive to add to the Indian vote, lest many may be shut out.
('1', 341, 1, 7, 776286) And yet there has been not a single addition to the Voters’ List from the Indian community.
('1', 341, 1, 8, 776378) But the Hon.
('1', 341, 1, 9, 776391) mover went on to say:
('1', 341, 2, 10, 776413) Members might not be aware that there was in this country a body, a very powerful body in its way, a very united body, though practically a secret body—he meant the Indian Congress.
('1', 341, 2, 11, 776595) That was a body which possessed large funds, it was a body presided over by very active and very able men, and it was a body the avowed object of which was to exercise strong political power in the affairs of the Colony.
('1', 341, 2, 12, 776816) Your Memorialists venture to say that this estimate of the Congress is not justified by facts.
('1', 341, 2, 13, 776911) The charge of secrecy, as would appear from the correspondence between the Honourable the Prime Minister of Natal and the Honorary Secretary of the Congress, was made under an erroneous impression (Appendices B,C, D 1).
('1', 341, 2, 14, 777131) A statement with regard to the matter also was made by him in the Legislative Assembly on the 20th instant.
('1', 341, 2, 15, 777239) Nor has the Congress in any shape or form intended or attempted to “exercise strong political power”.
('1', 341, 2, 16, 777341) The following are the objects of the Congress, which were published in almost every paper in South Africa last year: “1. To bring about a better understanding and promote friendliness between the Europeans and the Indians residing in the Colony.
('1', 341, 2, 17, 777587) “2. To spread information about India and the Indians by writing to newspapers, publishing pamphlets, lecturing, etc.
('1', 341, 2, 18, 777705) “3. To educate the Indians, especially [those] born in the Colony about Indian History, and induce them to study Indian subjects.
('1', 341, 3, 19, 777835) 1Vide “Letter to Prime Minister” 14 5 1896, and “Letter to C. Bird”, 18 5 1896.
('1', 342, 0, 1, 777915) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 343
('1', 342, 1, 2, 777949) “4. To ascertain the various grievances the Indians are labouring under and to agitate by resorting to all constitutional methods for removing them.
('1', 342, 1, 3, 778098) “5. To enquire into the condition of the indentured Indians and to help them out of special hardships.
('1', 342, 1, 4, 778201) “6. To help the poor and the needy in all reasonable ways.
('1', 342, 1, 5, 778260) “7. And generally to do everything that would tend to put the Indians on a better footing morally, socially, intellectually, and politically.” It would thus appear that the object of the Congress is to resist degradation, not to gain political power.
('1', 342, 1, 6, 778511) As to funds the Congress has a property worth £1,080 and a balance of £148 7s 8d in the Bank, at the time of writing this.
('1', 342, 1, 7, 778634) These funds have to be used in charity, printing memorials and working expenses.
('1', 342, 1, 8, 778715) In your Memorialists’ humble opinion they are hardly sufficient to fulfil the objects of the Congress.
('1', 342, 1, 9, 778818) The educational work is greatly hampered owing to want of funds.
('1', 342, 1, 10, 778883) Your Memorialists, therefore, venture to submit that the danger which the present Bill is intended to guard against does not exist at all.
('1', 342, 1, 11, 779022) Your Memorialists, however, do not request Her Majesty’s Government to accept the above facts as correct on their ipse dixit.
('1', 342, 1, 12, 779148) If there is any doubt about any of them—and the most important fact is that there are thousands who do not possess the necessary property qualifications for becoming voters—then the proper course, your Memorialists submit, is to enquire about them, particularly to enquire how many Indians there are in the Colony who possess immovable property of the value of £50 or who pay a yearly rent of £10. To prepare such a return would neither cost much time nor much money, and would be a very material help towards a satisfactory solution of the franchise question.
('1', 342, 1, 13, 779709) The hot haste to pass some measure is, in your Memorialists humble opinion, detrimental to the best interests of the Colony as a whole.
('1', 342, 1, 14, 779845) Your Memorialists, so far as they, as representatives of the Indian community, are concerned and speaking authoritatively for the organization of which they have the honour to be members, hereby beg to assure Her Majesty’s Government that they have no intention to endeavour to place a single Indian voter on the Voters’ List for the general election next year.
('1', 342, 1, 15, 780207) The Government organ, dealing with the present Bill in a presumably inspired article, supports the view that the danger is “a chimerical one”.
('1', 342, 1, 16, 780350) It says:
('1', 343, 0, 1, 780359) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 344
('1', 343, 1, 2, 780401) Moreover, we feel sure that should the Asiatic vote ever endanger the stability of European rule in this Colony, the Imperial Government will find ways and means out of such a difficulty.
('1', 343, 1, 3, 780589) The new Bill imposes certain limitations on the acquirement of the franchise by all who are not of European origin, and as now even with the franchise open to British subjects of all races and classes, except the Natives under Native law, there are only some 250 Indians on the Voters’ Roll out of a total of 9,560 registered voters, or in the proportion of one Indian voter to every 38 Europeans in possession of the franchise, we think the new Bill will fully meet the requirements of the case for very many long years at all events, if not for all time.
('1', 343, 1, 4, 781146) In South Carolina, for instance, the Negroes over 21 years old number 132,949, while the whites over 21 only number 102,567, yet the whites have retained the dominant power, although in the minority.
('1', 343, 1, 5, 781346) The fact of the matter is that apart from numbers altogether the superior race will always hold the reins of Government.
('1', 343, 1, 6, 781467) We are inclined to the belief, therefore, that the danger of the Indian vote swamping the European is a chimerical one.
('1', 343, 1, 7, 781587) From what we know of the matter, we are inclined to think that it will be held that India is a country possessing “Elective representative institutions”.
('1', 343, 1, 8, 781741) In fact, the argument so often advanced that the Indian is unacquainted with their nature and responsibilities is really wide off the mark, as in India there are some 750 municipalities in which British and native voters have equal rights, and in 1891, there were 9,790 native municipal commissioners (councillors) as against 839 Europeans.
('1', 343, 1, 9, 782082) .Even assuming, however, that natives of India will be held as coming from a country possessing “elective representative institutions”, we do not consider that the danger of being swamped is at all a likely one, as past experience has proved that the class of Indians coming here, as a rule, do not concern themselves about the franchise, and further, the majority of them do not even possess the small property qualification required.
('1', 343, 1, 10, 782518) In addition to all this, the obligations of the Empire of which we form a part do not permit of Indians as Indians being excluded from the exercise of such a privilege as the franchise.
('1', 343, 1, 11, 782704) So far as we are concerned, therefore, such attitude is a non possumus and may, therefore, be dropped.
('1', 343, 1, 12, 782807) Should the restrictions of the new law not prevent the introduction of an undesirable element onto the Voters’ Roll, there is nothing at all to prevent us raising the franchise qualification.
('1', 343, 1, 13, 782999) At present it is very low.
('1', 343, 1, 14, 783026) The property qualification could, therefore, be easily increased, even doubled and an educational test imposed which, while it would not remove a single European from the Voters’ Roll, would have a sweeping effect on Indian voters.
('1', 343, 1, 15, 783258) The number of the later possessing immovable property of the value of say, £100 or paying a rent of £20 per annum and able to read and write English must be exceedingly small, and should this fail, there would be nothing to hinder us from adopting the Mississippi plan, or a modification of it to suit the circumstances (5th March, 1896).
('1', 344, 0, 1, 783597) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 345
('1', 344, 1, 2, 783631) It is clear, therefore, that according to the Government organ the present property qualifications are sufficiently high to prevent any undue influx of Indian voters on the Roll, and that the only object of th e present Bill is to harass the Indian community—to land them in expensive litigation.
('1', 344, 1, 3, 783928) According to the Mauritius Almanac for 1895, the population of that island in 1894 was 259,224 Indians as against 106,995 persons under the heading ‘general population’.
('1', 344, 1, 4, 784098) The franchise qualification there is as follows:
('1', 344, 2, 5, 784147) Every male person shall be entitled to be registered in any year as a voter for any electoral district and, when, registered, to vote at the election of a member of the Council for such district who is qualified as follows, that is to say:
('1', 344, 3, 6, 784387) 1. That he has attained the age of twenty one years.
('1', 344, 4, 7, 784440) 2. Is under no legal incapacity.
('1', 344, 5, 8, 784473) 3. Is a British subject by birth or naturalization.
('1', 344, 6, 9, 784525) 4. Has resided in the Colony for three years at least previous to the date of registration and possesses some one of the following qualifications:
('1', 344, 7, 10, 784672) (a) Is on the 1st day of January in each year, and has, during the preceding six calendar months, been the owner of immovable property within such district of the annual value of Rs. 300 or the monthly value of Rs. 25 above all charges and encumbrances affecting the same.
('1', 344, 8, 11, 784945) (b) Is at the date of registration paying, and has for the six calendar months previous to the 1st day of January in such year paid, rent in respect of immovable property situate within such district at the rate of at least Rs. 25 per month.
('1', 344, 9, 12, 785187) (c) Has for three calendar months previous to the 1st of January in such year resided, or had his principal place of business or employment within such district, and is the owner of movable property within the Colony of the value of at least Rs. 3,000.
('1', 344, 10, 13, 785440) (d) Is the husband of a wife, or the eldest son of a widow, possessing any one of the above qualifications.
('1', 344, 11, 14, 785548) (c) Has for three calendar months previous to the 1st day of January in such year resided, or had his principal place of business or employment within such district, and is in receipt of a yearly salary of at least Rs. 600, or a monthly salary of at least Rs. 50.
('1', 344, 12, 15, 785812) (f) Has for three calendar months previous to the 1st of January in such year resided, or has his principal place of business or employment within such district, and pays licence duty to the amount of at least Rs. 50 per annum.
('1', 345, 0, 1, 786040) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 346
('1', 345, 1, 2, 786082) Provided— 1. That no person shall be registered as a voter, or be entitled to vote for the election of a member of the Council who has been convicted of perjury in any Court in our Dominions or who has been sentenced by any such Court to death, or penal servitude, or imprisonment with hard labour, or for a term exceeding twelve months, and has not either suffered the punishment to which he was sentenced or such other punishment as by competent authority may have been substituted for the same or received a free pardon from us.
('1', 345, 2, 3, 786614) 2. That no person shall be registered as a voter in any year who has, within twelve calendar months immediately preceding the first day of January in that year, received any relief from public or parochial funds.
('1', 345, 3, 4, 786827) 3. That no person shall be registered as a voter in any year unless he shall, in the presence of the registering officer or of a magistrate, with his own hand subscribe his name to his claim to be registered and write thereon the date of such subscription and the qualification, in respect of which he claims to be registered.
('1', 345, 4, 5, 787154) 4. That no person claiming to be registered in the district in which he resides in respect of any of the qualifications (c), (d), (e) and (f), shall be registered in respect of the same qualification in the district in which he has his principal place of business or employment or vice versa.
('1', 345, 4, 6, 787447) With these qualifications there is evidently no trouble in Mauritius, although the Indian population is twice as large as the general population, and the Indians in Mauritius belong to the same class as the Indians in Natal.
('1', 345, 4, 7, 787672) Only, there they are far more prosperous than their Natal brethren.
('1', 345, 4, 8, 787740) Assuming, however, that the necessity to deal with the Indian franchise does exist, your Memorialists respectfully beg to say that the present Bill is not calculated to meet it in a straightforward and open manner.
('1', 345, 4, 9, 787955) The Honourable and learned Attorney General of Natal, referring to a suggestion to slightly alter the existing law in course of the debate on the Second Reading, is reported to have said:
('1', 345, 5, 10, 788143) The reason why he refused to do this was because it was apparently doing it by a side wind and quietly, and the Government intended to do it in the full light of day.
('1', 345, 6, 11, 788310) It is difficult to conceive a better mode of doing a thing by a “side wind and quietly” than that of passing the present Bill, which leaves everybody in the dark.
('1', 345, 6, 12, 788473) The Natal Advertiser of the 8th May, 1896, says:
('1', 346, 0, 1, 788522) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 347
('1', 346, 1, 2, 788556) What is the present Bill if not a side wind?
('1', 346, 1, 3, 788601) Its whole object is to endeavour quietly and by a side wind to effect that which the measure of last session failed to accomplish.
('1', 346, 1, 4, 788732) Mr. Escombe admitted that the measure was brutally blunt and to this he rightly ascribed its failure to obtain acceptance by the Imperial Government.
('1', 346, 1, 5, 788882) He further admitted that the present Bill has precisely the same object in view as the “brutal” Bill, only it does not state its object honestly and straightforwardly; in other words, it seeks quietly and by a side wind to reach the goal apparently unattainable by plain sailing.
('1', 346, 1, 6, 789162) If Her Majesty’s Government are convinced that a real necessity exists for legislation restricting the Indian franchise in Natal, and if Her Majesty’s Government are satisfied that the question cannot be dealt with but by class legislation, and if Her Majesty’s Government further accept the Colonial view that Indian British subjects, in spite of the gracious Proclamation of 1858, may be treated on a different footing from that on which the European British subjects are treated, then, your Memorialists submit that it would be infinitely better and more satisfactory to exclude the Indians by name from any rights and privileges that they in the opinion of Her Majesty’s Government, should not be allowed to enjoy, than that by ambiguous legislation the door should be left open for litigation and trouble.
('1', 346, 1, 7, 789973) That the Bill, if assented to, would give rise to endless litigation owing to its ambiguity is an admitted fact.
('1', 346, 1, 8, 790086) It is admittedly also of the first importance that the question of the Indian franchise should be “settled once for all”.
('1', 346, 1, 9, 790208) to quote the words of the Honourable the Prime Minister of Natal.
('1', 346, 1, 10, 790274) And yet, in the opinion of the majority of the leaders of opinion in Natal, the Bill will not settle the question once for all.
('1', 346, 1, 11, 790402) Mr. Binns, the leader of the Opposition in the Natal Assembly, after quoting chapter and verse to show that the Indians in India did possess elective representative institutions, founded on the parliamentary franchise, is reported to have said this:
('1', 346, 2, 12, 790652) He hoped he had shown clearly that on that ground this Bill was wrong.
('1', 346, 2, 13, 790723) There were representative institutions and the elective principle was acknowledged in India.
('1', 346, 2, 14, 790816) They had a Parliamentary franchise and there was an enormous municipal franchise which affected local government, and if this was the case, what was the use of their passing this Bill?
('1', 346, 2, 15, 791001) The facts he had stated to the Assembly were taken from the best authorities he could find and they proved most conclusively that these institutions did exist.
('1', 346, 2, 16, 791161) There was no doubt on one point, that if a Bill of this kind passed into law it would lead them into endless litigation, difficulties, and trouble.
('1', 346, 2, 17, 791309) The Bill was not
('1', 347, 0, 1, 791326) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 348
('1', 347, 1, 2, 791368) sufficiently clear or definite.
('1', 347, 1, 3, 791400) They wanted something more clear and definite.
('1', 347, 1, 4, 791447) He wanted to see this question settled and he would do all he could to assist at a settlement.
('1', 347, 1, 5, 791542) But he thought this Bill was framed on wrong lines, contained a fact that was not correct, and it would lead them into endless litigation, difficulty, and trouble.
('1', 347, 1, 6, 791706) It would be impossible for him to vote for the second reading of this Bill.
('1', 347, 1, 7, 791782) Mr. Bale, a leading member of the Assembly and a leading lawyer in Natal, agreeing with Mr. Binns’ views, opposed as he is to the Indians retaining the franchise rights under the general law of the Colony, thus feelingly appealed to the House, as well on behalf of the Indians as for the Colony generally, not to pass the Bill:
('1', 347, 2, 8, 792110) It would give rise to litigation and produce a feeling of hostility and create a ferment amongst the Indians themselves.
('1', 347, 2, 9, 792231) It would also have the further effect of inducing appeals to the Privy Council and would prejudice the election of members to this House.
('1', 347, 2, 10, 792369) Having regard to the great issues involved in this measure he hoped the second reading of this Bill would not be carried.
('1', 347, 2, 11, 792491) The Natal Witness of the 8th May thus sums up the situation:
('1', 347, 3, 12, 792552) Our warning that, if the Bill passes into law as it stands, the Colony will be involved in serious litigation, had the support of Mr. Binns and Mr. Bale, and Mr. Smythe’s half loaf, which is better than, nothing, would be dearly purchased at that price.
('1', 347, 3, 13, 792806) What leads us to think the Bill has not been considered by the legal advisers of the Crown are the exceedingly delicate questions which it raises and which will undoubtedly be fought out unless the wording be altered so as not to leave the possibility of a resort to law.
('1', 347, 3, 14, 793078) Amongst these questions are the following: Can a Colony make laws which contravene the Naturalization Law of England?
('1', 347, 3, 15, 793196) Are British Indians British subjects or not?
('1', 347, 3, 16, 793241) In other words the Bill raises the whole question of the position of the British Indians in the Empire.
('1', 347, 3, 17, 793345) Can special laws be passed in Natal, since the issue of the Proclamation of 1858, [to] take away any part of the privileges conferred by that document?
('1', 347, 3, 18, 793497) After deploring the ambiguity and vagueness of the Bill, The Natal Advertiser, in its leader of the 8th May, says:
('1', 347, 4, 19, 793612) The truth of the position is [that] each line of the present Bill is an ambuscade of disputes, which will all come out in the open some day, to perpetuate for years, and probably with increased bitterness, the struggle between the Indians and the Europeans in this Colony with regard to the vote.
('1', 347, 4, 20, 793909) Your Memorialists appeal to Her Majesty’s Government to save the Indian community, if not the whole Colony, from such a dismal
('1', 348, 0, 1, 794036) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 349
('1', 348, 1, 2, 794070) outlook—from perpetual agitation—and all this to avoid a danger that does not exist.
('1', 348, 1, 3, 794155) That the expenses of such a struggle to the Indian community must be beyond their control needs no argument to prove.
('1', 348, 1, 4, 794273) The whole struggle is unequal.
('1', 348, 1, 5, 794304) Now, assuming further, that the highest legal tribunal has recorded its opinion that the Indians do not possess “elective representative institutions founded on the Parliamentary franchise”, the method provided in the Bill whereby the Indians may be placed on the Voters’ Roll is, in your Memorialists’ humble opinion, in every way unsatisfactory.
('1', 348, 1, 6, 794652) The disapproval of that portion of the Bill which confers the power on the Governor is very emphatic on the part of the Europeans also.
('1', 348, 1, 7, 794788) The Natal Witness, in dealing with that branch of the subject, says:
('1', 348, 2, 8, 794857) It attacks great constitutional principles, and further introduces into the working of representative institutions in Natal what may be termed an unknown quantity—that is to say, the effect which the third clause, providing for an electorate of six to choose fit and proper Asiatics for the Voters’ Roll, will have upon them.
('1', 348, 2, 9, 795183) The Ministry appeared to have caught on to the idea (i.e., of indirect election), but in making themselves and the Governor an indirect electorate, they are not only doing what is decidedly preposterous but highly improper.
('1', 348, 3, 10, 795407) Reverting to the same question again, it says:
('1', 348, 4, 11, 795454) The Assembly has not gained in public estimation by passing a Bill which most of the leading members are distrustful of, which they can see is a compromise and a compromise which may prove quite ineffectual and which, as we pointed out when it was first published, is a most dangerous invasion of the privileges of the Assembly as well as an attack upon constitutional principles which it might have been assumed that every member would have held himself to be under a solemn obligation to maintain unimpaired.
('1', 348, 4, 12, 795965) There was no need to remind some of the members of the last objection.
('1', 348, 4, 13, 796036) Mr. Bale said that the Franchise ought to be vested in the people alone, to be exercised of course by their representatives.
('1', 348, 4, 14, 796161) But what the press is concerned about is not the present Parliament but all future ones.
('1', 348, 4, 15, 796250) .When a great constitutional principle is once broken through, however slightly it may be, there is the imminent risk of the breach being widened by a Government greedy of power.
('1', 348, 4, 16, 796429) That is the objection from the European point of view.
('1', 348, 4, 17, 796484) Your Memorialists, while agreeing with that view, have a yet more
('1', 349, 0, 1, 796550) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 350
('1', 349, 1, 2, 796592) formidable objection to the principle of the clause.
('1', 349, 1, 3, 796645) It is not so much the number of Indian voters that the Indian community wish to see on the Voters’ Roll as the vindication of their rights and privileges as British subjects and the equal status with European British subjects that is assured to the British Indians by Her Most Gracious Majesty the Queen Empress on more occasions than one, and that has been specially assured to the Indian community in Natal by Her Majesty’s Government in a special despatch by the Right Honourable the late Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('1', 349, 1, 4, 797184) If other British subjects having certain qualifications can claim the franchise as of right, why, your Memorialists humbly ask, should not the Indian British subjects?
('1', 349, 1, 5, 797352) The method is cumbrous and will tend to keep up the franchise agitation for ever.
('1', 349, 1, 6, 797434) It would, moreover, transfer the agitation from the Europeans to the Indians.
('1', 349, 1, 7, 797512) The speeches in the Assembly on the second reading show that the power will be exercised very sparingly, if at all, by the Governor in Council.
('1', 349, 1, 8, 797656) It is calculated to create dissensions among the Indian community, for the applicant who is rejected may resent the favour granted to a brother applicant if the one considers himself as good as the other.
('1', 349, 1, 9, 797861) Education, intelligence, and stake, are mentioned in Your Honour’s despatch relating to the franchise question as entitling the Indians to the franchise.
('1', 349, 1, 10, 798015) Your Memorialists submit that if a certain amount of education, intelligence or stake is to be sufficient to qualify an Indian to become a voter in the Colony, then such a test could be introduced instead of leaving the power in the hands of the Governor in Council.
('1', 349, 1, 11, 798282) Hereon, your Memorialists beg to draw your attention to a portion of the leading article in The Natal Mercury hereinbefore quoted.
('1', 349, 1, 12, 798413) If the necessary qualifications for those coming under the operation of that Bill were stated, it would do away with the contentious character of that part of the Bill, and those coming under its operation will then know exactly what qualifications would entitle them to a vote.
('1', 349, 1, 13, 798692) The position is well summed up in The Natal Advertiser of the 8th May.
('1', 349, 2, 14, 798763) A still further proof of the duplicity of the present Bill lies in its provision that the Governor in Council shall have the power to place certain Indians on the Voters’ Roll.
('1', 349, 2, 15, 798940) This clause is obviously inserted with the idea of leading the Imperial Government to suppose that this power of exemption would
('1', 350, 0, 1, 799069) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 351
('1', 350, 1, 2, 799103) occasionally be used—sparingly perhaps, but still used.
('1', 350, 1, 3, 799159) Yet the Attorney General declared that “the power of inclusion given in such circumstances under the present Bill could not, however, he wished to point out, be attained, except through the Governor in Council.
('1', 350, 1, 4, 799370) Every section of the community had begun to realize what the true meaning was of the responsibility of Ministers and knew quite well that no Ministers could hold office for fourteen days if they took upon themselves the responsibility of watering the constituencies by the introduction of Indian electors.” Further on he said, “There would be no other voice throughout South Africa than that the electoral rolls of the country should be absolutely confined to persons of the European race.
('1', 350, 1, 5, 799860) That was the starting point from which they began and the goal they had in view all along.” .
('1', 350, 1, 6, 799954) if these ministerial declarations mean anything, it is that this Government have no intention to exercise their right of exemption.
('1', 350, 1, 7, 800086) Then why is it placed on the Bill?
('1', 350, 1, 8, 800121) Is there not at least an appearance of dissembling, or utilizing a side wind, if the phrase is more expressive, in inserting a provision in a measure, which its framers declare in submitting it for adoption, they mean to treat as a dead letter?
('1', 350, 1, 9, 800366) It would be hardly pleasant for a wealthy Indian merchant to have to apply for a permit to be exempted from the operation of the Bill and also to risk the rejection of his application.
('1', 350, 1, 10, 800551) It is difficult to understand why Europeans, not coming from countries which have not hitherto possessed elective representative institutions founded on the Parliamentary franchise, should exercise the right of voting, while the non Europeans similarly placed cannot under the general law of the Colony.
('1', 350, 1, 11, 800855) The present Bill, according to the view of the Government, is an experimental measure,.
('1', 350, 1, 12, 800943) “If”, said the honourable and learned Attorney General on the second reading, “contrary to their belief, and their firm belief, the Bill should fall short of what was intended, then there never would be rest in the Colony,” etc.
('1', 350, 1, 13, 801172) The Bill, therefore, is not finite.
('1', 350, 1, 14, 801208) Under such circumstances, your Memorialists submit that unless all the resources, without resort to class legislation, are tried and have failed (i.e., assuming that there is a danger of the Indian vote swamping the European), a Bill like the present one should not be passed.
('1', 350, 1, 15, 801485) Your Memorialists venture to submit that this is not a question that affects a mere handful of Her Majesty’s subjects, but it affects 300,000,000 of Her Majesty’s loyal subjects.
('1', 350, 1, 16, 801664) The question is not how many or what Indians shall have the vote, but the question, your Memorialists humbly submit, is what status the British Indians shall occupy outside India and in the Colonies and allied States.
('1', 350, 1, 17, 801882) May a respectable Indian venture out of India in pursuit of trade or other
('1', 351, 0, 1, 801957) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 352
('1', 351, 1, 2, 801999) enterprise and hope to have any status?
('1', 351, 1, 3, 802039) The Indian community do not want to shape the political destiny of South Africa, but they may be allowed to carry on their peaceful avocations quietly without any degrading conditions being imposed upon them.
('1', 351, 1, 4, 802248) Your Memorialists, therefore, submit that if there is the slightest danger of the Indian vote preponderating, a simple educational test may be imposed on all alike, either with or without an increase in property qualifications.
('1', 351, 1, 5, 802476) That would, in the opinion of the Government organ also, effectually remove all fear and if such a test failed, a more severe test may be imposed, which would tell.
('1', 351, 1, 6, 802641) Against the Indians without materially affecting the European vote.
