('1', 351, 1, 8, 803032) Your Memorialists, however, beg to draw your attention to the fact that the European Colonists as a body make no such demand.
('1', 351, 1, 9, 803158) They seem to be absolutely indifferent.
('1', 351, 1, 10, 803198) The Natal Advertiser thus rebukes the indifference:
('1', 351, 2, 11, 803250) Perhaps the manner in which this all important subject has been treated by Parliament also brings out a fourth point—the indifference of the Colony to its own politics.
('1', 351, 2, 12, 803419) It would be highly interesting to discover, if such could be done, how many of the Colonists have taken the trouble even to read the Bill in question.
('1', 351, 2, 13, 803570) Perhaps the proportion who have not read it would be a striking one.
('1', 351, 2, 14, 803639) The general unconcern of Colonists in this matter is demonstrated by the fact that meetings have not been held in every centre—not to say every nook and corner of the Colony for its ventilation, and to formulate a demand that Parliament should only pass such a Bill as would render abortive all further controversy over the subject.
('1', 351, 2, 15, 803972) Had the Colony been fully alive to the real gravity of the issue, the columns of the newspaper would also have teemed with a serious and intelligent correspondence on the question.
('1', 351, 2, 16, 804153) Neither of these things, however, has happened.
('1', 351, 2, 17, 804201) As a consequence, the Government have been able to get through a measure supposed to effectually deal with the matter, but which in reality puts it in a far worse and dangerous position than ever it was before.
('1', 351, 2, 18, 804412) It would appear from the extracts quoted above that the present Bill satisfies neither party.
('1', 351, 2, 19, 804506) With the utmost deference to the Natal Ministry and to both the Legislative bodies here, your Memorialists submit that the fact that the Bill has been accepted by them does not
('1', 352, 0, 1, 804683) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 353
('1', 352, 1, 2, 804717) signify much.
('1', 352, 1, 3, 804731) The very members who refrained from any active opposition to the measure are, as The Natal Witness puts it, distrustful of it.
('1', 352, 1, 4, 804858) Your Memorialists hope that they have shown to your satisfaction that the danger referred to above is imaginary and that the present Bill is unsatisfactory from the point of view of those who wish to see the Indians disenfranchised as also from that of the Indians themselves.
('1', 352, 1, 5, 805135) In any case, however, your Memorialists claim that sufficient facts and arguments have been brought out to show that the question should not be hastily disposed of, and that there is no necessity for so doing.
('1', 352, 1, 6, 805345) The Natal Witness thinks that “no explanation, at least no satisfactory one, has been given for the anxiety to rush the Bill through.” The Natal Advertiser opines that “this Indian franchise question is a most vital one and there should be no haste in settling it for ever.
('1', 352, 1, 7, 805619) Indeed the best course would be to postpone the proposed Bill and have the whole matter for the consideration of the constituencies when they have accurate information before them” (28 3 1896) The feelings of the Indian community may be well expressed in the words of the London Times.
('1', 352, 1, 8, 805905) The Times (Weekly edition, 20th March, 1896) says:
('1', 352, 2, 9, 805956) If the Indians are allowed to carry with them their status as British subjects to foreign countries and British Colonies whither they go in quest of work, the opening up of Africa holds out new possibilities to Indian labour.
('1', 352, 2, 10, 806182) The Indian Government and the Indians themselves believe that it is in South Africa that this question of their status must be determined.
('1', 352, 2, 11, 806321) If they secure the position of British subjects in South Africa, it will be almost impossible to deny it to them elsewhere.
('1', 352, 2, 12, 806445) If they fail to secure that position in South Africa it will be extremely difficult for them to attain it elsewhere.
('1', 352, 2, 13, 806562) They readily acknowledge that Indian labourers who accept a contract of service for a period of years, as the price of aided immigration, must fulfil the conditions of their contract, however it may curtail their rights.
('1', 352, 2, 14, 806783) But they hold that after the period of contracted labour has expired, they are entitled to the status of British subjects in whatever Colony or country they have fixed their abodes....
('1', 352, 2, 15, 806968) The Indian Government may reasonably ask that after Indian labourers have given their best years to South Africa they should not be forced back upon India by denying to them the status of British subjects in their adopted homes.
('1', 352, 2, 16, 807197) Whatever the decision may be, it will seriously affect the future development of emigration in India.
('1', 353, 0, 1, 807299) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 354
('1', 353, 1, 2, 807341) Dealing particularly with this question of franchise and the figures compiled from the Natal Government Gazette and now accepted as correct, the same paper says, under date 31st January, 1896 (Weekly edition):
('1', 353, 2, 3, 807551) According to this return, there are in the Colony 9,309 European registered voters against 251 registered voters of British Indian origin.
('1', 353, 2, 4, 807690) Nor, if Mr. Gandhi’s statements are correct, does it seem possible that the Indian vote can swamp the European at any period within the range of practical politics.
('1', 353, 2, 5, 807855) Not only are all Indian immigrants under labour contracts excluded but also all British Indians whatsoever, except an extremely small class, who, by intelligence and industry, have raised themselves to the position of well to do citizens.
('1', 353, 2, 6, 808094) The returns show that even under the existing law it takes a long time for a British Indian to attain the franchise in Natal.
('1', 353, 2, 7, 808220) With the exception of 63 British Indians, many of whom started with capital, and whose residence in the Colony is under ten years, the rest of the 251 voters seem to have resided during more than 10 years and the majority over 14. An analysis of the British Indian Voters’ List according to occupation yields equally encouraging results to those who wish to see this question settled.
('1', 353, 2, 8, 808605) It is precisely this class of men who form the most valued element in the municipal and other electorates in India.
('1', 353, 2, 9, 808721) The argument that the Indian in Natal cannot claim higher privileges than he enjoys in India and that he has no franchise whatever in India is inconsistent with the facts.
('1', 353, 2, 10, 808893) So far as government by voting exists in India, Englishmen and Indians stand on the same footing, and alike in the Municipal, the Provincial, and the Supreme Councils the native interests are powerfully represented.
('1', 353, 2, 11, 809109) Nor does the plea that the British Indian is unacquainted with the nature and responsibilities of representative government beat inspection.
('1', 353, 2, 12, 809250) There is probably no other country in the world in which representative institutions have penetrated so deeply into the life of the people.
('1', 353, 2, 13, 809390) The question now before Mr. Chamberlain is not an academic one.
('1', 353, 2, 14, 809454) It is not a question of argument but of racefeeling.
('1', 353, 2, 15, 809507) The Queen’s Proclamation of 1858 gave the full rights of British subjects to the Indians and they vote in England and sit in the British Parliament on the same terms as Englishmen.
('1', 353, 2, 16, 809688) But these questions are inevitable in a vast Empire made up of many peoples and as the steamship brings the component population of Greater Britain into closer contact they will present themselves in more acute forms.
('1', 353, 2, 17, 809906) Two things are clear.
('1', 353, 2, 18, 809928) Such questions will not settle themselves by being ignored, and a strong Government at home affords the best Court of Appeal to adjudicate upon them.
('1', 353, 2, 19, 810078) We cannot afford a war of races among our own subjects.
('1', 353, 2, 20, 810134) It would be as wrong for the Government of India to suddenly arrest the development of Natal by shutting off the supply of immigrants as it would be for Natal to
('1', 354, 0, 1, 810296) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 355
('1', 354, 1, 2, 810330) denythe rights of citizenship to British Indian subjects, who, by years of thrift and good work in the Colony, have raised themselves to the actual status of citizens (the italics throughout are your Memorialists’).
('1', 354, 1, 3, 810546) Your Memorialists now leave their case in your hands, and in so doing earnestly pray, and confidently hope, that the Royal assent to the Bill hereinbefore referred to will be withheld, and, if there be any fear as to the European vote being swamped by the Indian, an enquiry be ordered to ascertain whether there actually exists any such danger under the existing law, or such other relief will be granted as may meet the ends of justice.
('1', 354, 1, 4, 810985) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Memorialists, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, etc., etc.

('1', 355, 4, 8, 813415) In reply to various questions Mr. Gandhi said the present membership of the Congress was 300. The annual subscription was £3, payable in advance.
('1', 355, 4, 9, 813561) The Congress aimed at enrolling members who were not only able to pay their subscriptions, but who would also work for the objects of the Congress.
('1', 355, 4, 10, 813709) They wanted to collect a large fund which would be invested in property so that a permanent income might be available to carry on the objects of the Congress.
('1', 355, 5, 11, 813868) “What are these objects?” asked the interviewer.
('1', 355, 5, 12, 813917) They are of twofold character—political and educational.
('1', 355, 5, 13, 813974) As to the educational part, we want to teach the Indians born in the Colony by inducing them with the offer of scholarships to study all subjects pertaining to their welfare as a community, including Indian and Colonial history, temperance, etc.
('1', 355, 6, 14, 814220) Is there any other qualification for membership in the Congress?
('1', 355, 6, 15, 814285) Yes, one is that members should be able to read, write and speak English, but this condition has not been strictly enforced of late.
('1', 355, 7, 16, 814418) Financially how does the Congress stand?
('1', 355, 7, 17, 814459) There is a balance in hand of £194, and it possesses, besides, a property in Umgeni Road.
('1', 355, 7, 18, 814549) I want the members to raise this balance to £1,100, during my absence, and see no reason why it should not be done.
('1', 355, 7, 19, 814665) This would do much to make it a permanent institution.

('1', 358, 1, 2, 818540) 101. THE GRIEVANCES OF THE BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA : AN APPEAL TO THE INDIAN PUBLIC 1
('1', 358, 2, 3, 818634) RAJKOT, KATHIAWAR, August 14, 1896 This is an appeal to the Indian public on behalf of the 100,000 Indians in South Africa.
('1', 358, 2, 4, 818758) I have been commissioned by the leading members representing that community in South Africa to lay before the public in India the grievances that her Majesty’s Indian subjects are labouring under in that country.
('1', 358, 2, 5, 818971) South Africa is a continent by itself and is divided into many States of which the Colonies of Natal and the Cape of Good Hope, Zululand, a Crown Colony, the South African Republic of the Transvaal, Orange Free State and the Chartered Territories, are inhabited, more or less, by the Indians together with the Europeans and the natives of those countries.
('1', 358, 2, 6, 819327) The Portuguese territories, viz., Delagoa Bay, Beira and Mozambique, have a large Indian population, but there the Indians have no grievances, apart from the general population.
('1', 358, 2, 7, 819505) NATAL From an Indian standpoint, Natal is the most important portion of South Africa.
('1', 358, 2, 8, 819591) It has a native population of about 400,000, a European population of nearly 50,000 and an Indian population of about 51,000, of whom about 16,000 are those at present serving their indenture, about 30,000 are those who, having once been under indenture, are freed therefrom and have settled in the Colony on their own account, and about 5,000 belong to the trading community.
('1', 358, 2, 9, 819968) These latter, of course, came to the Colony on their own means and some of them brought capital also into the country.
('1', 358, 2, 10, 820087) The indentured Indians are drawn from the labouring population of Madras and Calcutta and are nearly equally divided.
('1', 358, 2, 11, 820205) Those from Madras speak, as a rule, the Tamil language, and those from Calcutta, the Hindi.
('1', 358, 2, 12, 820297) Most of them are Hindus, a good few are Mahomedans.
('1', 358, 2, 13, 820349) Strictly speaking, they do not observe caste restrictions.
('1', 358, 2, 14, 820408) After becoming free, they either take to gardening or hawking vegetables and earn from 2 to 3 pounds
('1', 358, 3, 15, 820509) 1 This was brought out as a pamphlet which later became known as the Green Pamphlet on account of the colour of its cover.
('1', 359, 0, 1, 820632) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 359, 1, 2, 820674) sterling per month.
('1', 359, 1, 3, 820694) A few become petty storekeepers.
('1', 359, 1, 4, 820727) That business, however, is practically in the hands of the 5,000 Indians, who are drawn chiefly from the Mahomedan community in the Bombay Presidency.
('1', 359, 1, 5, 820878) Some of these latter are doing well.
('1', 359, 1, 6, 820915) Many are large landowners, two are now shipowners also.
('1', 359, 1, 7, 820971) One of them has a small oil machine worked by steam.
('1', 359, 1, 8, 821024) They come either from Surat, or districts surrounding Bombay, or Porbandar.
('1', 359, 1, 9, 821100) Many merchants from Surat have settled in Durban with their families.
('1', 359, 1, 10, 821170) Most of them, including the assisted immigrants, can read and write their own language to a greater extent than one would think they do.
('1', 359, 1, 11, 821307) I venture to quote the following from my ‘Open Letter’ 1 to the Members of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of Natal to show what treatment the Indian receives at the hands of the general run of Europeans in the Colony:
('1', 359, 2, 12, 821547) The man in the street hates him, curses him, spits upon him, and often pushes him off the foot path.
('1', 359, 2, 13, 821648) The Press cannot find a sufficiently strong word in the best English dictionary to damn him with.
('1', 359, 2, 14, 821746) Here are a few samples.
('1', 359, 2, 15, 821770) “The real canker that is eating into the very vitals of the community”, “these parasites”, “wily, wretched semi barbarous Asiatics”, “A thing black and lean and a long way from clean, which they call the accursed Hindoo”, “He is chock full of vice and he lives upon rice.
('1', 359, 2, 16, 822042) I heartily cuss the Hindoo”, “Squalid coolies with truthless tongues and artful ways”.
('1', 359, 2, 17, 822129) The Press almost unanimously refuses to call the Indian by his proper name.
('1', 359, 2, 18, 822205) He is “Ramysamy”.
('1', 359, 2, 19, 822223) He is “Mr. Samy”.
('1', 359, 2, 20, 822241) 2 He is “Mr. Coolie”.
('1', 359, 2, 21, 822263) He is “the black man”.
('1', 359, 2, 22, 822286) And these offensive epithets have become so common that they (at any rate, one of them, “Coolie”) are used even in the sacred precincts of the courts, as if “the Coolie” were the legal and proper name to give to any and every Indian.
('1', 359, 2, 23, 822520) The public men, too, seem to use the word freely.
('1', 359, 2, 24, 822570) I have often heard the painful expression “coolie clerk” from the mouths of men who ought to know better.
('1', 359, 2, 25, 822676) 3 The tramcars are not for the Indians.
('1', 359, 2, 26, 822716) The railway officials may treat the Indians as beasts, No matter how clean, his very sight is such an offence to every White man in the Colony that he would object to sit, even for a short time, in the same compartment with the Indian.
('1', 359, 2, 27, 822952) The hotels shut their doors against them.
('1', 359, 2, 28, 822994) 4 Even the public baths are not for the Indians no matter who they are.
('1', 359, 2, 29, 823066) The vagrant law is needlessly oppressive and often puts respectable Indians in a very awkward position.
('1', 359, 3, 30, 823170) 1 For the full text of this, vide”Open Letter”, 19 12 1894 2 The original has “Ramsamy” and “Sammy”.
('1', 359, 3, 31, 823271) 3 Two sentences following this, in the original, have been omitted in the Green Pamphlet.
('1', 359, 3, 32, 823361) Vide “Open Letter”, 19 12 1894 4 A sentence following this has been omitted.

('1', 360, 1, 2, 823502) I have quoted this because the statement has been before the South African public for nearly one year and a half, has been commented upon freely by almost every newspaper in South Africa and remains practically uncontradicted (indeed, it has even been endorsed by one newspaper with approval) and because, during the interval that has elapsed, I have seen nothing to change that view.
('1', 360, 1, 3, 823887) The Right Honourable Mr. Chamberlain 1, however, while in full sympathy with its object, in his reply to the deputation headed by the Hon’ble Mr. Dadabhai 2 is said to have stated that our grievances were more sentimental than material and real and that, if he could be shown any instances of real grievance, he should deal with them effectively.
('1', 360, 1, 4, 824234) The Times of India, which has done us much service and has laid us under deep obligation to it by its persistent advocacy on our behalf, rebuked Mr. Chamberlain for calling our grievances sentimental.
('1', 360, 1, 5, 824435) To give, however, proof of real grievances and to strengthen the position of the advocates of our cause in India, I shall beg leave to cite my own testimony and that of those who have undergone grievances personally.
('1', 360, 1, 6, 824652) Every word of every statement to be made immediately can be established beyond the shadow of a doubt.
('1', 360, 1, 7, 824754) In Dundee last year, during the Christmas time, a gang of White men set fire to the Indian stores without the slightest provocation, in order to enjoy themselves.
('1', 360, 1, 8, 824917) Mr. Abdulla Haji Adam, a shipowner and one of the leading members of the Indian community in South Africa, was travelling with me as far as Krantzkloof Station.
('1', 360, 1, 9, 825078) He alighted there to go by postal cart to Natal.
('1', 360, 1, 10, 825127) No one there would sell him even bread.
('1', 360, 1, 11, 825167) The hotelkeeper would not allow him a room in his hotel and he had to sleep in the coach, shivering the whole night with cold.
('1', 360, 1, 12, 825294) And the winter in that part of Africa is no joke.
('1', 360, 1, 13, 825344) Mr. Haji Mohamed Haji Dada, another leading Indian gentleman, was travelling in a coach some time ago from Pretoria to Charlestown.
('1', 360, 1, 14, 825476) He was forced out of the coach and had to walk a distance of three miles because he had not got a pass— whatever that may mean.
('1', 360, 2, 15, 825604) A Parsee gentleman, Mr. Rustomjee, whose generosity goes much further than his purse would allow, has been unable to take a Turkish bath for the sake of his health in Durban, although the public
('1', 360, 3, 16, 825799) 1 Joseph Chamberlain (1836 1914); Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1895 1902 2 Dadabhai Naoroji 3 For a fuller account of the incident, vide “Petition to Lord Ripon”, 5 5 1895
('1', 361, 0, 1, 825979) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 361, 1, 2, 826021) baths are the property of the Durban Corporation, to which Mr. Rustomjee pays his rates just as well as the other ratepayers.
('1', 361, 1, 3, 826147) In Field Street, Durban, last year during Christmas time, some youths threw burning crackers in the Indian stores doing some damage.
('1', 361, 1, 4, 826280) Three months ago, in the same street, some youths shot lead bullets into an Indian store with a sling, hurting a customer who nearly lost his eye.
('1', 361, 1, 5, 826427) Both these matters were brought to the notice of the Superintendent of Police who promised to do all he could.
('1', 361, 1, 6, 826538) Nothing more has been heard of the matter.
('1', 361, 1, 7, 826581) Yet the Superintendent is an estimable gentleman, anxious to protect all the communities in Durban.
('1', 361, 1, 8, 826681) But what could the poor man do against the tremendous odds?
('1', 361, 1, 9, 826741) Will his subordinates take the trouble to find out the miscreants?
('1', 361, 1, 10, 826808) When the aggrieved gentleman saw the constables at the police station, they first laughed and then asked him to get a warrant from the Magistrate for their arrest.
('1', 361, 1, 11, 826972) No warrant is required in such cases when a constable wants to do his duty.
('1', 361, 1, 12, 827048) Only the day before I left Natal, the son of an Indian gentleman, spotlessly dressed, was walking along the pavement in the principal street in Durban.
('1', 361, 1, 13, 827200) Some Europeans pushed him off the pavement without any reason but to amuse themselves.
('1', 361, 1, 14, 827287) Last year, the Magistrate at Estcourt, a village in Natal, had an Indian who was a prisoner in the dock forced out of it.
('1', 361, 1, 15, 827409) His cap was forcibly removed and he was brought back bare headed, in spite of the protest from the man that the removal of the cap was contrary to Indian custom and it offended his religious feeling also.
('1', 361, 1, 16, 827614) A civil action was brought against the Magistrate.
('1', 361, 1, 17, 827665) And the judges held that the Magistrate was not civilly liable for acts done by him in his capacity as such.
('1', 361, 1, 18, 827774) When we went to law, we knew that such would be the decision.
('1', 361, 1, 19, 827836) Our object was to have the matter thoroughly thrashed out.
('1', 361, 1, 20, 827895) This question at one time was a very great question in the colony.
('1', 361, 1, 21, 827962) An Indian official, whenever he accompanies his superior during his periodical tours, is unable to secure accommodation in the hotels.
('1', 361, 1, 22, 828097) He is obliged to sojourn in huts.
('1', 361, 1, 23, 828131) The grievance had reached such a stage, when I left Natal, that he was seriously thinking of sending in his resignation.
('1', 361, 1, 24, 828252) A Eurasian gentleman, Mr. DeSilva by name, who was for some time employed in a responsible position in Fiji, happened to come to Natal to seek fortune.
('1', 361, 1, 25, 828404) He is a certified chemist.
('1', 361, 1, 26, 828431) He received an appointment as chemist by letter.
('1', 361, 1, 27, 828480) When, however, his employer saw that he was not quite White, he dismissed him.
('1', 361, 1, 28, 828559) I know other Eurasians
('1', 362, 0, 1, 828582) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 363
('1', 362, 1, 2, 828616) who, being fair enough to pass as “White men”, are not molested.
('1', 362, 1, 3, 828681) This last instance I have quoted to show how unreasonable the prejudice is in Natal.
('1', 362, 1, 4, 828766) I could go on relating such instances.
('1', 362, 1, 5, 828805) But, I hope, I have adduced sufficient instances to show that our grievances are real and as one of our sympathizers in England says in a letter, “They have only to be known to be removed.” Now, what is our mode of action in such cases?
('1', 362, 1, 6, 829042) Are we to go to Mr. Chamberlain in every case and turn the Colonial Office into one for hearing petty complaints from Indians in South Africa?
('1', 362, 1, 7, 829185) I have used the word “petty” advisedly, for I admit that most of these cases are cases of petty assault and inconvenience.
('1', 362, 1, 8, 829308) But when they occur pretty regularly, they assume a sufficiently big shape to be a source of constant irritation to us.
('1', 362, 1, 9, 829428) Just picture a country where you never know you are safe from such assaults, no matter who you are, where you have a nervous fear as to what would happen to you whenever you undertake a journey, where you cannot be accommodated in a hotel even for a night and you have a picture of the state we are living in Natal.
('1', 362, 1, 10, 829744) I am sure I am not exaggerating when I say that, if any of the Indian High Court Judges came to South Africa, I doubt very much whether any hotel would admit him, unless he took extraordinary precautions, and I am almost positive that he will have to travel from Charlestown to Pretoria in a Kaffir compartment, unless he is dressed in European clothing from top to toe.
('1', 362, 1, 11, 830115) I am aware that in some of the instances cited above Mr. Chamberlain could not very well afford relief, as for example the case of Mr. DeSilva, but the fact is clear that such instances occur because of the rooted prejudice against the Indians in South Africa, which is due to the indifference of the Home and the Indian Governments to the complaints of the Indians.
('1', 362, 1, 12, 830482) In all the cases of assault, our mode of action, as a rule, is not to take any notice of them.
('1', 362, 1, 13, 830577) We follow the principle, so far as we can, of going two miles when we are asked to go one.
('1', 362, 1, 14, 830668) Sufferance is, really and sincerely, the badge of the Indians in South Africa, especially in Natal.
('1', 362, 1, 15, 830768) I may state, however, that we follow this policy not from philanthropic but from purely selfish motives.
('1', 362, 1, 16, 830873) We have found by painful experiences that to bring the offenders to justice is a tedious and expensive process.
('1', 362, 1, 17, 830985) The result is often contrary to our expectations.
('1', 362, 1, 18, 831035) The offender would either be discharged with a caution or fined“five shillings or one day”.
('1', 362, 1, 19, 831127) The very man, after getting out of the box, assumes a more threatening attitude and puts
('1', 363, 0, 1, 831216) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 363, 1, 2, 831258) the complainant in an awkward position.
('1', 363, 1, 3, 831298) And the publication of such acts incites others to similar ones.
('1', 363, 1, 4, 831363) We, therefore, do not, as a rule, even mention them before the public in Natal.
('1', 363, 1, 5, 831443) Such a feeling of deep seated hatred towards the Indians is reproduced all over South Africa, in special legislation for Indians, which has for its object the degradation of the Indian community in that country.
('1', 363, 1, 6, 831655) The Attorney General of Natal wants to keep the Indians for ever “hewers of wood and drawers of water”.
('1', 363, 1, 7, 831759) We are classed with the natives of South Africa—Kaffir race.
('1', 363, 1, 8, 831820) He defines the status of the Indians in the following words: “These Indians were brought here for the purpose of supplying labour for development of local industries and were not intended to form portion of the South African nation which was being built up in the various States.” The policy of the Orange Free State, which, in the words of its leading organ, “has made the British Indian an impossibility by simply classifying him with the South African natives”, is cherished by the other States as a model policy.
('1', 363, 1, 9, 832337) What that State has completely accomplished, the other States would accomplish within a very short time but for the vigilance of the Indian public.
('1', 363, 1, 10, 832485) We are passing through a crisis now.
('1', 363, 1, 11, 832522) We are hemmed in on all sides by restrictions and high handed measures.
('1', 363, 1, 12, 832594) I shall now show how the feeling of hatred above described has been crystallized into legislation.
('1', 363, 1, 13, 832693) An Indian cannot leave his house after 9 o’clock at night unless he has a pass signed by someone showing that he is out under instructions or can give a good account of himself.
('1', 363, 1, 14, 832871) This law applies to the natives and Indians only.
('1', 363, 1, 15, 832921) The police use their discretion and do not, as a rule, trouble those who are dressed in the Memon costume, as that dress is supposed to be the Indian trader’s dress.
('1', 363, 1, 16, 833087) Mr. Aboobaker, now deceased, was the foremost Indian trader in Natal and much respected by the European community.
('1', 363, 1, 17, 833202) He, with his friend, was once arrested by the police.
('1', 363, 1, 18, 833256) When he was brought to the police station for being out after 9 p.
('1', 363, 1, 19, 833323) m., the authorities knew at once that they had committed a mistake.
('1', 363, 1, 20, 833391) They told Mr. Aboobaker that they did not want to arrest gentlemen like himself, and asked him if he could point out any distinguishing mark between a trader and a labourer.
('1', 363, 1, 21, 833565) Mr. Aboobaker pointed to his robe, and, ever since, it has been a tacit understanding between the police and the public that those wearing the flowing robe should not be arrested, even though they may be out after 9 p.m.
('1', 363, 1, 22, 833786) But there are Tamil and Bengali traders, equally respectable, who do not wear the
('1', 364, 0, 1, 833868) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 365
('1', 364, 1, 2, 833902) There are, again, the Christian Indian educated youths—a most sensitive class—who do not wear robes.
('1', 364, 1, 3, 834003) They are constantly molested.
('1', 364, 1, 4, 834033) A young Indian, well educated and a Sunday school teacher, another a schoolmaster, were arrested only four months ago and locked up in a dungeon the whole night, in spite of their protestations that they were on their way home.
('1', 364, 1, 5, 834261) They were discharged by the Magistrate but that was a poor consolation.
('1', 364, 1, 6, 834333) An Indian lady, a teacher, the wife of the Indian Interpreter at Ladysmith, was a short time ago on her return from the church on a Sunday evening, arrested by two Kaffir policemen and roughly handled, so much so that her dress was soiled, not to speak of all sorts of bad names she was called.
('1', 364, 1, 7, 834628) She was locked up in a cell.
('1', 364, 1, 8, 834657) She was promptly released when the Superintendent of Police came to know who she was.
('1', 364, 1, 9, 834743) She was carried home senseless.
('1', 364, 1, 10, 834775) The bold lady sued the Corporation for damages for wrongful arrest and got £20 and costs from the Supreme Court.
('1', 364, 1, 11, 834888) The Chief Justice remarked that her treatment was “unjust, harsh, arbitrary and tyrannical”.
('1', 364, 1, 12, 834981) The result, however, of these three cases is that the Corporations are now clamouring for more powers and an alteration of the law, in order that they may, to put it bluntly, subject all Indians, irrespective of their position, to restrictions so that, as a member of the Legislative Assembly said on the occasion of the passing of the Immigration Bill of 1894, “the intention of the Colony to make the Indian’s life more comfortable in his native land than in the Colony of Natal” may be fulfilled.
('1', 364, 1, 13, 835481) In any other country, such instances would have excited the sympathy of all right minded people and the decision quoted above would have been hailed with joy.
('1', 364, 1, 14, 835640) Some eight months ago, about 20 Indians, pure labourers on their way to the Durban market with vegetable baskets on their heads, a sufficient indication that they were not vagrants, were arrested at 4 o’clock in the morning under the same law.
('1', 364, 1, 15, 835884) The police prosecuted the case vigorously.
('1', 364, 1, 16, 835927) After a two days’ trial, the Magistrate discharged them, but at what cost to the poor people!
('1', 364, 1, 17, 836021) They were carrying their day’s earnings in prospect on their shoulders.
('1', 364, 1, 18, 836093) These were gone.
('1', 364, 1, 19, 836110) They were, I believe, detained for two days in gaol and had to pay their attorney’s fees in the bargain, for having ventured to be up and doing in the early morning, a fitting reward for industry!
('1', 364, 1, 20, 836307) And Mr. Chamberlain wants instances of real grievances!
('1', 364, 1, 21, 836363) There is a system of passes in Natal.
('1', 364, 1, 22, 836401) Any Indian who, whether in the day time or the night time, does not show a pass as to who he is,

('1', 365, 1, 3, 836561) This is meant to prevent desertion by the indentured Indians and to facilitate identification and is thus far, I believe, necessary, but the working of the law is extremely irritating and a crying grievance.
('1', 365, 1, 4, 836769) But for the cruel feeling, no injustice need occur under that law.

('1', 366, 1, 2, 839289) It will be only fair to state what the authorities have to say.
('1', 366, 1, 3, 839353) They admit the grievance but ask how they are to distinguish between an indentured Indian and a free Indian.

('1', 366, 1, 11, 840087) There is, again, a law which says that natives and Indians, when driving cattle, must be provided with certain passes; also a bye law in Durban which provides for the registration of native servants and “others belonging to the uncivilized races of Asia”.
('1', 366, 1, 12, 840343) This presupposes that the Indian is a barbarian.

('1', 366, 1, 21, 841154) We are doing what we can to have their rigour mitigated locally.
('1', 366, 1, 22, 841219) For the present, our efforts are concentrated towards preventing and getting repealed fresh legislation.
('1', 366, 1, 23, 841324) Before referring to that, I may further illustrate the proposition that the Indian is put on the same level with the native in many other ways also.
('1', 366, 1, 24, 841473) Lavatories are marked “natives and Asiatics” at the railway stations.

('1', 367, 0, 1, 841839) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 367, 1, 2, 841881) invidious distinction and they have now provided three separate entrances for natives, Asiatics and Europeans.
('1', 367, 1, 3, 841992) The Indians have, up to now, enjoyed the franchise rights under the general franchise law of the colony, which requires ownership of immovable property worth £50 or payment of an annual rental of £10 to qualify an adult male to be placed on the Voters’ Roll.
('1', 367, 1, 4, 842251) There is a special franchise law for the natives.
('1', 367, 1, 5, 842301) Under the former, in 1894, there were 9,309 European voters and 251 Indians, of whom only 203 were living at the time, the populations being equal.
('1', 367, 1, 6, 842449) Thus the European vote in 1894 was 38 times as strong as the Indian vote.
('1', 367, 1, 7, 842523) Yet, the Government thought or pretended to think that there was a real danger of the Asiatic vote swamping the Europeans.
('1', 367, 1, 8, 842646) They, therefore, introduced into the Legislative Assembly of Natal a Bill disfranchising all Asiatics save those who were then rightly contained in any Voters’ List, the preamble of the Bill stating that the Asiatics were not acquainted with elective representative institutions.
('1', 367, 1, 9, 842926) Against this Bill we memorialized both the Legislative Assembly 1 and the Legislative Council 2 of Natal but to no purpose.
('1', 367, 1, 10, 843050) We then memorialized Lord Ripon 3 and forwarded copies of the memorial to the Press and the public in India and England, with a view to enlist their sympathy and to secure their active support which, we are thankful to say, we received to some extent.
('1', 367, 1, 11, 843302) As a result, that Act has now been repealed and replaced by an Act which says “no persons shall be qualified to have their names inserted in any list of electors who (not being of European origin) are natives or descendants in the male line of natives of countries which have not hitherto possessed elective representative institutions founded on the parliamentary franchise unless they shall first obtain an order from the Governor in Council, exempting them from the operation of the Act.” It also exempts from its operation those persons that are rightly contained in any Voters’ List.
('1', 367, 1, 12, 843891) This Bill was first submitted to Mr. Chamberlain who has practically approved of it.

('1', 377, 1, 7, 868734) THE CAPE COLONY In the Cape Colony, the Mayoral Congress has passed a resolution signifying its desire for legislation prohibiting the influx of Asiatics in that Colony and hoping that prompt action will be taken.

('1', 378, 2, 10, 872256) THE TRANSVAAL
('1', 378, 3, 11, 872270) Coming now to the non British States, i.e., the Transvaal and the Free State, there were in the Transvaal nearly two hundred traders in 1894 whose liquidated assets would amount to £100,000. Of these, about three firms imported goods directly from England, Durban, Port Elizabeth, India and other places, and had thus branches in the other parts of the world whose existence mainly depended upon their Transvaal business.
('1', 378, 3, 12, 872692) The rest were small vendors having stores in different places.
('1', 378, 3, 13, 872755) There were,then, nearly two thousand hawkers in the Republic who buy goods and hawk them about.
('1', 378, 3, 14, 872851) Of the labouring Indian population, who are employed as general servants in European houses or hotels, there were about 1,500 men, of whom about 1,000 lived in Johannesburg.
('1', 378, 3, 15, 873025) Such, roughly, was the position at the end of 1894 A.D. The numbers have now considerably increased.
('1', 378, 3, 16, 873126) In the Transvaal, the Indians cannot own landed property; they can be ordered to reside in locations.
('1', 378, 3, 17, 873228) No new licences to trade are issued to them.
('1', 378, 3, 18, 873273) They are made to pay a special registration fee of £3. All these restrictions are unlawful, being in contravention of the London

('1', 382, 1, 2, 881199) The law, which is entitled “the law to prevent the inrush of Asiatic coloured persons”, prevents any Indian from remaining in the Orange Free State for more than 2 months, unless he gets the permission from the President of the Republic who cannot consider the application to reside before thirty days have elapsed after the presentation of the petition and other ceremonies have been performed.
('1', 382, 1, 3, 881595) He can, however, on no account, hold fixed property in the State or carry on any mercantile or farming business.
('1', 382, 1, 4, 881708) The President may or may not, “according to the state of things”, grant such mutilated permission to reside.
('1', 382, 1, 5, 881817) Any Indian resident, moreover, is subject to an annual poll tax of £10. The first contravention of the section relating to mercantile and farming business renders the delinquent liable to a fine of £25 or three months’ imprisonment, with or without hard labour.
('1', 382, 1, 6, 882079) For all subsequent contraventions, the punishment is to be doubled.
('1', 382, 2, 7, 882147) Such then is the position of the Indians in South Africa, except Delagoa Bay where the Indians are very much respected, labour under no special disability and are owners of nearly half the fixed property in the principal streets of that city.

('1', 385, 1, 4, 889170) We would often fall short of that ideal but we can adduce innumerable instances to show that we have acted in that spirit.

('1', 385, 1, 6, 889395) Generally, our prayers are not to demand compensation for past injuries, but to render a repetition of those injuries impossible and to remove the causes.
('1', 385, 1, 7, 889550) Our grievances have been laid before the Indian public in the same spirit.
('1', 385, 1, 8, 889625) If we have quoted instances of personal injuries, that we have done not for the purpose of seeking compensation but for that of laying our position vividly before the public in India.
('1', 385, 1, 9, 889809) We are trying to remove any causes that may be in us for such treatment.
('1', 385, 1, 10, 889882) But we cannot succeed without the sympathy and support of the public men in India, and without strong representations from the Home and Indian Governments.
('1', 385, 1, 11, 890038) The want of knowledge about India is so great in South Africa that the people would not even believe us if we said that India is not dotted by huts only.

('1', 386, 2, 9, 892575) The problem, therefore, when looked at as a whole from the imperial to the purely local standpoint, is a very large and complex one.

('1', 386, 2, 11, 893024) And further, as regards the purely local aspect of the case, it is quite as necessary, and perhaps as difficult, to discover whether a comprehensive view of the position is being taken or whether imperfect opinions are being formed on one side or the other through the acceptance of only such data as prejudice or self interest may find acceptable.
('1', 386, 2, 12, 893373) The general opinion existing throughout South Africa, as regards Indian emigration, may be summed up in the words, “We don’t want them”.
('1', 386, 3, 13, 893510) The first point to be weighed is this that, in belonging to the British Empire, we have to take whatever may be evil as well as whatever may be good as arising from that connection, provided, of course, it is inseparable therefrom.
('1', 386, 3, 14, 893742) Now, as regards the destinies of India’s population, it may be taken for granted that the Imperial Government will not readily permit of legislation in any British dependency which has for its avowed object the repulsion of India’s surplus population from any part of the British dominions; or, to put it the other way, which embodies the principle, so far as the particular legislating State is concerned, that India’s teeming and fast increasing millions must be confined, and ultimately smothered, within India itself.
('1', 386, 3, 15, 894264) On the contrary, the desire of the British Government is to remove from India the possibilities of such congestion, and to thereby render it a prosperous and happy, instead of a dangerous and discontented, portion of the British Empire.
('1', 386, 3, 16, 894501) If India is to be retained as an advantageous part of the Empire, then it is absolutely necessary that means shall be found for relieving it of much of its present population, and it may be taken to be a part of the
('1', 387, 0, 1, 894717) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 387, 1, 2, 894759) Imperial policy that India’s surplus population is to be encouraged, rather than discouraged, to find fresh outlets in those other portions of the Empire which are in need of a labouring population.
('1', 387, 1, 3, 894958) It will thus be seen that the question of coolie immigration into the British Colonies is one which reaches down to the deepest amelioration and salvation of India; it may even mean the inclusion or exclusion of that great possession in or from the British Empire.
('1', 387, 1, 4, 895223) That is the Imperial aspect of the question, and is one which points directly to a desire on the part of the Imperial Government to do all in its power to prevent the raising, in other portions of the Empire, of barriers for the prevention of Indian immigration.
('1', 387, 2, 5, 895486) As regards the local aspect of Indian immigration, what has to be considered is whether and if so, how far, does this Imperial policy conflict with what is desirable for this particular locality?
('1', 387, 2, 6, 895682) There are those who absolutely condemn Indian immigration into this Colony, but it is doubtful whether these have given full consideration on all the bearings of the case.
('1', 387, 2, 7, 895854) In the first place, those who so oppose Indian immigration have to answer the question: What would this Colony have done without them in those departments of industry in which they have undoubtedly proved useful?
('1', 387, 2, 8, 896067) There is unquestionably much that is undesirable about the coolie, but before his presence here is condemned as an unmixed evil, it has to be shown that the Colony would have been better without him.
('1', 387, 2, 9, 896267) This, we think, would be somewhat difficult to prove.
('1', 387, 2, 10, 896321) There can be no question that the coolie is the best fitted, under existing local conditions, for the field labour required in connection with the agriculture of the Colony.
('1', 387, 2, 11, 896495) Such work can never be undertaken in this climate by white men; our natives show little disposition or aptitude for it.

('1', 387, 2, 13, 896703) No one.
('1', 387, 2, 14, 896711) The work had either to be done by him or left undone altogether.

('1', 387, 2, 19, 897112) Further, the towns in Natal are almost entirely dependent for their supply of vegetables upon the coolies, who farm plots of ground in the vicinity.
('1', 387, 2, 20, 897261) With whom does the coolie interfere in this direction?
('1', 387, 2, 21, 897316) Certainly not with the white man.
('1', 387, 2, 22, 897350) Our farmers, as a body, have not yet acquired a taste for kitchen gardening sufficient to keep the market fully supplied.
('1', 387, 2, 23, 897472) Neither does he interfere with the native, who, being the incarnation of indolence, does not, as a rule, trouble about the cultivation of anything except mealies 1 for himself.
('1', 387, 2, 24, 897649) Our own natives ought to have been our labouring class, but the fact has to be faced that, in this respect, they are almost a dead failure.
('1', 387, 2, 25, 897789) Consequently, coloured labour of a more active and
('1', 387, 3, 26, 897840) 1 Maize or Indian corn
('1', 388, 0, 1, 897863) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 389
('1', 388, 1, 2, 897897) reliable kind had to be procured from some other source, and India has offered the necessary supply.
('1', 388, 1, 3, 897998) The debt which the white man owes to these coloured labourers is this that they, by occupying the lowest stratum of society in those mixed communities of which they form a part, raise the white man one stratum higher right through the social scale than he otherwise would have occupied, had the menial offices been discharged by a European class.
('1', 388, 1, 4, 898345) For instance, the white man, who is ‘boss’ over a gang of coolies, would have had himself to form one of the gang of labourers, had there been no black labourer.
('1', 388, 1, 5, 898507) Again, the man who, in Europe, would have been that man’s foreman, in this country develops into a master tradesman.
('1', 388, 1, 6, 898624) And as in every other direction, by the presence of a black labouring class, the whites are set free to throw their efforts into higher planes than they could have done, had the majority of them had to devote their lives to the arduous labours of toilers of the lowest order.
('1', 388, 1, 7, 898900) It will, therefore, probably yet be found that the removal of the drawbacks, at present incidental to the immigration of Indians into British Colonies, is not to be effected so much by the adoption of an obsolete policy of exclusion as by an enlightened and progressive application of ameliorating laws to those Indians who settle in them.
('1', 388, 1, 8, 899240) One of the chief objections to Indians in that they do not live in accordance with European rules.
('1', 388, 1, 9, 899339) The remedy for this is to gradually raise their mode of life by compelling them to live in better dwellings and by creating among them new wants, it will probably be found easier, because more in accord with the great onward movement of mankind, to demand to such settlers that they shall rise to their new conditions, than to endeavour to maintain the status quo ante by their entire exclusion.
('1', 388, 1, 10, 899735) Such articles (and they can be quoted by the dozen from the various newspapers) show that application of sufficient pressure from the Home Government can bring about a healthy change in the Indian policy of the Colonies, and that, even in the worst places, British love of justice and fair play can be roused.

('1', 389, 1, 2, 900835) From men who will puff rotten companies at the very moment they are selling out and individuals of a like character, it is, of course, perfectly absurd to expect any other result than that self will predominate, but with the average commercial man, justice is more often the victor in the ethical conflict.
('1', 389, 1, 3, 901142) Amongst the causes of these conflicts, as they affect South Africans generally and British Transvaalers in particular, is the question of the ‘coolie traders’, as our Indian and Arab fellow citizens are designated.
('1', 389, 1, 4, 901357) It is the position of these merchants, for so they really are, which has aroused so much attention and which is still productive of no little interest and hostility to this day.
('1', 389, 1, 5, 901535) And it is in considering their position that their rivals in trade have sought to inflict upon them, through the medium of the State, what looks, on the face of it, something very like an injustice for the benefit of self.

('1', 389, 3, 9, 902680) The impression, which is but too prevalent both in the Transvaal and this Colony, that the quiet and altogether inoffensive ‘Arab’ shopkeeper, and the equally harmless Indian, who carries his pack of dainty wares from house to house, is a ‘coolie’, is due largely to an indolent ignorance as to the race whence they sprang.
('1', 389, 3, 10, 903004) When one reflects that the conception of Brahminism, with its poetic and mysterious mythology, took its rise in the land of the ‘coolie trader’, that in that land, twenty four centuries ago, the almost divine Buddha taught and practised the glorious doctrine of self sacrifice, and that it was from the plains and mountains of that weird old country that are derived the fundamental truths of the very language we speak, one cannot but help regretting that the children of such a race should be treated as the equals of the children of black heathendom and outer darkness.

('1', 392, 2, 4, 909810) The Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa : An Appeal to Indian Public
('1', 392, 3, 5, 909893) 102. NOTES ON THE GRIEVANCES OF THE BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('1', 392, 4, 6, 909961) RAJKOT, September 22, 1896 South Africa, for our purposes, consists of the two British Colonies of the Cape of Good Hope and Natal, the two Republics, viz., the South African Republic or the Transvaal and the Orange Free State, the Crown Colony of Zululand, the Chartered Territories and the Portuguese territories comprising Delagoa Bay or Lorenzo Marques and Beira.
('1', 392, 6, 7, 910329) Natal is a British self governing Colony enjoying Responsible Government since 1893 A.D. Before September of 1893, Natal was a Crown Colony having a Legislative Council of 12 elective and 4 executive members, with a Governor representing the Queen, a Constitution not very unlike the Indian Legislative Councils.
('1', 392, 6, 8, 910642) In 1893, Responsible Government was granted, whereby an upper and a lower chamber were created.
('1', 392, 6, 9, 910738) The upper chamber, called the Legislative Council, consists of 11 members nominated by His Excellency the Governor of the colony, and the lower chamber, styled the Legislative Assembly, consists of 37 members elected by the Colonists possessing the legal qualifications to be hereafter described.
('1', 392, 6, 10, 911035) There is a movable ministry of five members based on the model of the British Cabinet.
('1', 392, 6, 11, 911122) Sir John Robinson is the present Prime Minister and the Honourable Mr. Harry Escombe, Q.C., the present Attorney General.
('1', 392, 6, 12, 911244) The Constitution Act provides that no Acts, which have for their object class legislation and which curtail the rights of non European British subjects, shall have the force of law unless they are sanctioned
('1', 393, 0, 1, 911452) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 393, 1, 2, 911494) by Her Majesty.
('1', 393, 1, 3, 911510) The Royal instructions to the Governor also include such prohibitory clauses.
('1', 393, 1, 4, 911588) Natal has an area of 20,851 square miles 1 and a European population of about 50,000, a native population of about 400,000, and an Indian population of about 51,000, according to the latest census.
('1', 393, 1, 5, 911786) The 51,000 Indians include 30,000 free Indians, i.e., those that have finished their indentured service and are engaged in the Colony in various pursuits of life as household servants, petty farmers, vegetable hawkers, fruiterers, goldsmiths, artisans, petty storekeepers, schoolmasters, photographers, attorneys’ clerks, etc., 16,000 who are at present serving their indenture, and 5,000 traders who came to the Colony on their own means and are either traders or shopkeepers’ assistants, the trade consisting in soft goods suitable to the natives of South Africa, called Zulus or Kaffirs, hardware, soft goods and groceries suitable to the Indian population.
('1', 393, 1, 6, 912447) The soft goods and groceries for the Indians are imported from Bombay, Calcutta and Madras.
('1', 393, 1, 7, 912539) The free and indentured Indians come from Madras and Calcutta and are pretty equally divided.
('1', 393, 1, 8, 912633) Indian emigration was resorted to when, as a member of the Legislative Assembly of Natal, Mr. Garland, says, “the existence of the Colony hung in the balance”.
('1', 393, 1, 9, 912793) The terms of the contract briefly are that the indentured man has to serve his employer for a period of 5 years, the monthly wages for the first year being £10 2 to be increased by £1 3 every succeeding year, with food, clothing and lodging during the period and the passage to Natal also paid by the employer.
('1', 393, 1, 10, 913104) If, after the first five years, he serves in the Colony as a free labourer for another five years, he becomes entitled to a free passage back to India for himself, his wife and children, if any.
('1', 393, 1, 11, 913299) The immigrants are imported to work on the sugar fields and tea estates and replace the Kaffirs who were found by the Colonists to be indifferent and unsteady.
('1', 393, 1, 12, 913459) They are also largely employed by the Government on the railways and for the sanitation of the Colony.
('1', 393, 1, 13, 913562) The Colonists at first assisted the sugar and tea industries of the Colony by granting Rs. [£?] 10,000 towards the cost of the importation of the Indian immigrants.
('1', 393, 1, 14, 913727) Almost the first act of the
('1', 393, 2, 15, 913755) 1 The area of Natal in 1960 according to Encyclopaedia Britannica was 33, 578 sq.
('1', 393, 2, 16, 913837) 2 ‘Pounds’ here is evidently a slip for ‘shillings’.
('1', 394, 0, 1, 913890) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 395
('1', 394, 1, 2, 913924) Responsible Government was to abolish this grant under the plea that the industries no longer required such support.
('1', 394, 1, 3, 914041) FIRST GRIEVANCE IN NATAL — FRANCHISE The Royal Charter, dated the 15th July, 1850, provides that any adult male, not being a native of South Africa, possessing property to the value of £50 or who rents any such property of the yearly value of £10, shall be entitled to be placed on the Voters’ Roll.
('1', 394, 1, 4, 914341) There is a separate law governing the Native Franchise which requires, among other things, 12 years residence on the part of the native in a particular electoral district and exemption from the native law of the Colony.
('1', 394, 1, 5, 914561) Under the general franchise law of the Colony, i.e., the Royal Charter referred to above, the Indians as British subjects enjoyed full electoral rights till after 1893. In 1894, in the Second Parliament under the Responsible Government, an Act was passed, No.
('1', 394, 1, 6, 914821) 25 of 1894, disqualifying persons of Asiatic extraction from having their names inserted in any Voters’ List, exempting those whose names were then already rightly contained in any Voters’ List.
('1', 394, 1, 7, 915016) The preamble of the Act stated that such persons were not accustomed to the Franchise rights.
('1', 394, 1, 8, 915110) The real reason for passing such an Act was to lower the status of the Indian and gradually to bring him down to the level of the South African natives so that, in time to come, the respectable Indian may become an impossibility.
('1', 394, 1, 9, 915340) A petition was presented to the Legislative Assembly combating the view that the Indians were not accustomed to representative institutions and asking for the withdrawal of the Bill, or an enquiry as to whether or not the Indians were fit to exercise the franchise.
('1', 394, 1, 10, 915606) (Enclosure I, App.
('1', 394, 1, 11, 915625) A) 1. The petition was rejected.
('1', 394, 1, 12, 915658) Another was sent to the Legislative Council when the Bill came before it.
('1', 394, 1, 13, 915732) That too was rejected and the Bill was passed.
('1', 394, 1, 14, 915779) (Enclosure I, App.
('1', 394, 1, 15, 915798) B) 2. It, however, required Her Majesty’s sanction before it could come into force.
('1', 394, 1, 16, 915882) The Indian community sent a memorial to Her Majesty’s Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies, protesting

('1', 396, 3, 17, 920607) SECOND GRIEVANCE — INDIAN IMMIGRATION In the year 1893, a Commission consisting of Mr. Binns, a member of the Legislative Assembly of Natal, and Mr. Mason, the present Protector of Indian Immigrants in Natal, was sent by the Government of Natal to India in order to induce the Indian Government to consent to the following alterations in the terms of indenture entered into by the Indians at present and referred to above, that is to say:
('1', 396, 4, 18, 921046) 1 This enclosure contained the Viceroy’s despatch referred to in the following pages.
('1', 397, 0, 1, 921132) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 397, 1, 2, 921174) (1) To raise the period of indenture from five years to an indefinite period, with a corresponding increase in wages up to twenty shillings per month.
('1', 397, 1, 3, 921325) (2) In the event of the Indian refusing to enter into such further indentures after the first five years’ indenture, to compel him to return to India at the Colony’s expense.
('1', 397, 1, 4, 921500) The present Viceroy, in his despatch to the Governor of Natal, says that, although personally he regrets that such a course should be desired by the Colonists, subject to the approval of the Home Government he would be prepared to consent to the alterations on the understanding that the breach of the clause about compulsory return should never become a criminal offence.
('1', 397, 1, 5, 921873) (Enclosure V.) On the lines of the report of the Commission that visited India, the Natal Government, in the year 1895, introduced the Indian Immigration Law Amendment Bill, which provides, amongst other things, for the indefinite period of indenture or the compulsory return of the immigrants, and further provides that any such immigrant failing to enter into the further terms of indenture or to return to India shall be liable to take out an annual licence costing £3 yearly.
('1', 397, 1, 6, 922353) Thus it would appear that this Bill goes further than the terms laid down in the Viceroy’s despatch above alluded to.
('1', 397, 1, 7, 922471) Memorials 1 were presented to both the Houses in Natal taking exception to this Bill but to no purpose.
('1', 397, 1, 8, 922575) (Enclosure V, App.
('1', 397, 1, 9, 922594) A and B.) A memorial has also been addressed to Mr. Chamberlain as well as to the Indian Government praying either that the Bill should be disallowed or that further Indian immigration to Natal should be stopped.
('1', 397, 1, 10, 922807) (Enclosure VI.) 2 These prayers have been strongly supported by the London Times in a leading article dated 3 5 95 [96?].
('1', 397, 1, 11, 922929) Over ten years ago, a Commission was appointed by the then Governor of Natal to report upon various matters connected with Indian immigration.
('1', 397, 1, 12, 923072) Evidence has been cited from this report to show that, at that time, the Commissioners as well as the best men of the day, including the present Attorney General, thought that any such measure would be a cruel wrong to the Indians and a disgrace to the British name.

('1', 398, 1, 3, 923611) (Enclosure VI.) THIRD GRIEVANCE — THE CURFEW There is a Law in Natal (No.
('1', 398, 1, 4, 923685) 15 of 1869), which provides that, in the boroughs, no ‘coloured person’, unless he can give a good account of himself or unless he can produce a pass from his employer, shall be out at night after 9 o’clock.
('1', 398, 1, 5, 923893) This Law is, perhaps, not absolutely unnecessary, but its working is often oppressive.
('1', 398, 1, 6, 923980) Respectable Indians, such as schoolmasters and others, have often been locked up in horrible dungeons for having ventured out after 9 p.m., no matter on what business.
('1', 398, 1, 7, 924148) FOURTH GRIEVANCE — THE PASS LAW The Law provides that every Indian can be asked to produce a pass.
('1', 398, 1, 8, 924247) It is really meant to detect indentured Indians who have deserted their masters, but is also used as an engine of oppression towards the Indians generally.
('1', 398, 1, 9, 924403) The Indian community in Natal have not yet moved with regard to the last two matters, but they may be brought under the general grievances and can be used to show the tendency of the Colonists to make it as uncomfortable as possible for the Indians in Natal.
('1', 398, 1, 10, 924662) As for the working of these two Laws, see Enclosure III, pp.
('1', 398, 1, 11, 924723) 6 and 7. 1
('1', 398, 2, 12, 924734) ZULULAND This country is a Crown Colony governed by the Governor of Natal in the Queen’s name.
('1', 398, 2, 13, 924829) The Natal ministry or the Governor of Natal as such has nothing to do with Zululand.
('1', 398, 2, 14, 924914) There is a small European and a large native (Kaffir) population in it.
('1', 398, 2, 15, 924986) There are townships established in Zululand.
('1', 398, 2, 16, 925031) The township of Melmoth was the first to be established.
('1', 398, 2, 17, 925088) In that township, in the year 1888, the Indians bought erven, i.e., specified pieces of land, worth about £2,000. The township of Eshowe was proclaimed in 1891 and that of Nondweni in 1896. The regulations for the purchase of erven in both these township are the same and they provide that only persons of European birth and descent shall be approved of as occupiers of erven or sites, (Enclosure VII.) 2
('1', 398, 3, 18, 925493) 1 Vide “London Diary”, 12 11 1888 2 The enclosure is not available.
('1', 399, 0, 1, 925561) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 399, 1, 2, 925603) A memorial 1 protesting against these regulations was presented to the Governor of Zululand last February, who declined to interfere.
('1', 399, 1, 3, 925737) Thereupon a memorial 2 was sent to Mr. Chamberlain, and the question is now engaging his attention.
('1', 399, 1, 4, 925837) These regulations, it will be noticed, go much further than what the Colonists in the self governing Colonies have been allowed to do, and follow the policy of total exclusion adopted by the Orange Free State.
('1', 399, 1, 5, 926047) Zululand gold mining laws make it criminal for an Indian to buy or possess native gold.
('1', 399, 1, 6, 926135) CAPE COLONY The Colony of the Cape of Good Hope is, like the Colony of Natal, a responsibly governed Colony with a Constitution similar to Natal’s.
('1', 399, 1, 7, 926283) Only, the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council contain a greater number of members, and the franchise qualifications are different, viz., the property qualification is occupation for 12 months of a building worth £75, the salary qualification is £50 per annum.
('1', 399, 1, 8, 926556) The person claiming to be registered must be able to sign his name and write his address and occupation.
('1', 399, 1, 9, 926661) This Act was passed in 1892 and was really passed to check the Indian and the Malay vote.
('1', 399, 1, 10, 926751) There would be no objection on the part of the Indian community to such educational qualifications being imposed or property qualifications being increased in Natal.
('1', 399, 1, 11, 926917) This Colony contains an area of 276,320 square miles and a total population of about 1,800,000 persons, of whom not more than 400,000 are Europeans.
('1', 399, 1, 12, 927066) The Indian population of the Colony would be roughly 10,000, consisting of traders, hawkers and labourers.
('1', 399, 1, 13, 927173) They are to be found chiefly in the ports, viz., Port Elizabeth, East London and Cape Town and also in the mines in Kimberley.
('1', 399, 1, 14, 927300) All the information relating to the disabilities placed on the Indians is not available.
('1', 399, 1, 15, 927389) In 1894, the Parliament passed a Bill authorizing the East London Municipality to frame bye laws prohibiting the Indians from walking on the foot paths and compelling them to live in specified locations.
('1', 399, 1, 16, 927593) No special representation on this head has been made to Mr. Chamberlain from South Africa.
('1', 399, 1, 17, 927684) But the matter was touched upon by the Indian deputation that waited upon Mr. Chamberlain last year.

('1', 400, 0, 1, 927879) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 401
('1', 400, 1, 2, 927913) In the various parts or districts of the Cape Colony, it is extremely difficult for an Indian to get trading licences.
('1', 400, 1, 3, 928032) In many cases the magistrates simply refuse the licences, declining to give reasons for so doing.
('1', 400, 1, 4, 928130) The Magistrates are within their rights in declining to give reasons, but it has been found almost invariably that the licences have been granted to Europeans when they have been withheld from the Indian.
('1', 400, 1, 5, 928335) The following is the position of the Indians in East Griqualand, a district in the Cape Colony, according to The Natal Mercury dated 3rd March, 1896:
('1', 400, 2, 6, 928485) An Arab named Ismail Suliman erected a store in East Griqualand, paid customs duty upon goods and applied for a licence which the magistrate refused.
('1', 400, 2, 7, 928635) Mr. Attorney Francis on the Arab’s behalf (as the Indians are sometimes called in South Africa) appealed to the Cape Government, who upheld the Magistrate and have issued instructions that no coolies or Arabs are to have trading licences in East Griqualand and one or two that have licences are to be closed up.
('1', 400, 2, 8, 928947) This is outdoing the Transvaal.
('1', 400, 2, 9, 928979) CHARTERED TERRITORIES
('1', 400, 3, 10, 929001) These territories include Mashonaland and Matabeleland.
('1', 400, 3, 11, 929057) About 100 Indian waiters and labourers have settled there.
('1', 400, 3, 12, 929116) A few traders have also gone, but they are refused licences to trade, in the first instance.
('1', 400, 3, 13, 929209) The law being in favour of the Indians, one enterprising Indian last year succeeded in securing a trading licence through the Superior Court at Cape Town.
('1', 400, 3, 14, 929364) The Europeans in the Chartered Territories have now applied for an alteration of the law so that the Indians may, henceforth, be prevented from getting trading licences in those territories.
('1', 400, 3, 15, 929555) The newspapers in South Africa say that the Cape Government favour such an alteration.
('1', 400, 3, 16, 929642) THE TRANSVAAL OR THE SOUTH AFRICAN REPUBLIC This is an independent republic governed by the Dutch or the Boers.
('1', 400, 3, 17, 929754) There are two chambers called the Volksraad, with an executive Government with the President at the head.
('1', 400, 3, 18, 929860) It contains an area of about 113,642 square miles and a white population of 119,228. Its black population is said to be 653,662. The chief industry of the Republic is gold mining in Johannesburg, the largest town in the Transvaal.
('1', 400, 3, 19, 930091) The total Indian population may be roughly put down at 5,000. They are traders, shopkeepers’ assistants, hawkers, cooks,
('1', 401, 0, 1, 930212) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 401, 1, 2, 930254) waiters or labourers, mostly settled in Johannesburg and Pretoria, the capital of the Republic.
('1', 401, 1, 3, 930350) Of the traders, there are nearly 200, whose liquidated assets would amount to nearly £100,000. Some of these traders have branches in other parts of the world whose existence mainly depends upon their Transvaal businesses.
('1', 401, 1, 4, 930573) There are nearly 2,000 hawkers in the Republic who buy goods and hawk them about.
('1', 401, 1, 5, 930655) About 1,500 are employed as general servants in European hotels or houses.
('1', 401, 1, 6, 930730) This estimate was formed in 1894. The numbers have since considerably increased in every department.
('1', 401, 1, 7, 930831) The Transvaal is subject to the Queen’s suzerainty.
('1', 401, 1, 8, 930883) There are two Conventions between the Governments of England and the Transvaal.
('1', 401, 1, 9, 930963) Article 14 of the London Convention of 1884 and Article 26 of the Pretoria Convention of 1881 1 provide as follows:
('1', 401, 2, 10, 931079) All persons, other than natives of South Africa, conforming themselves to the laws of the Transvaal State will have full liberty with their families to enter, travel or reside in any part of the Transvaal State.
('1', 401, 2, 11, 931291) They will be entitled to hire or possess houses, manufactories, warehouses, shops, premises.
('1', 401, 2, 12, 931384) They may carry on their commerce either in person or by any agents they may think fit to employ.
('1', 401, 2, 13, 931481) They will not be subject, in respect of their persons and property, in respect of their commerce and industry, to any taxes, whether general, or local, other than those which are or may be imposed upon the Transvaal citizens.
('1', 401, 2, 14, 931707) This Convention, thus, completely secures the trading and property rights of British Indian.
('1', 401, 2, 15, 931800) In January 1885, the Transvaal Government wanted so to interpret the word “natives”, occurring in the Art.
('1', 401, 2, 16, 931907) 14 of the Convention, as to include Asiatics.
('1', 401, 2, 17, 931953) Sir Hercules Robinson, the then High Commissioner for South Africa, after consultation with Sir Henry de Villiers, the Chief Justice of the Colony, considered that the interpretation put upon the word “native” by the Transvaal Government could not be sustained and “that Asiatics were persons other than natives”.
('1', 401, 2, 18, 932267) Negotiations then went on between the Transvaal Government and the Home Government with a view to an alteration in the Convention so as to except the Indians from the privileges secured to
('1', 401, 3, 19, 932456) 1 Following the British defeat at Majuba this Convention gave the Transva alers a qualified independence and was thus a prelude to the London Convention of 1884 which granted the Transvaal full internal autonomy except in its relations with foreign States.
('1', 402, 0, 1, 932713) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 403
('1', 402, 1, 2, 932747) “all persons other than natives”.
('1', 402, 1, 3, 932781) Sir Hercules Robinson was favourably disposed towards the Transvaal Government and, in response to his suggestion, received the following reply from Lord Derby 1 under date 19th March 1885:
('1', 402, 2, 4, 932971) I have carefully considered your suggestion as to the amendment of the Convention, and if you are of opinion that it would be preferable and more satisfactory to the Government of the South African Republic to proceed as you propose, Her Majesty’s Government will be willing to amend the Convention as suggested.
('1', 402, 2, 5, 933284) It seems to deserve consideration, however, whether it would be more correct for the Volksraad to legislate in the proposed sense, having received an assurance that Her Majesty’s Government will not desire to insist upon any such construction of the terms of the Convention as would interfere with reasonable legislation in the desired direction.
('1', 402, 2, 6, 933631) In accordance with Lord Derby’s suggestion, the Transvaal Volksraad passed bye law No.
('1', 402, 2, 7, 933718) 3 of 1885, which applies to all Indians and other coloured people, and provides that none of them could obtain the franchise, that they could not be owners of fixed property, that such coloured people, who settle in the Republic for the purpose of trading, must be separately registered within 8 days after the day of their arrival and that they should pay a registration fee of £25. Any contravention of this law subjects the defaulter to a fine of from £30 to £100 or, in default, from 1 to 6 months’ imprisonment.
('1', 402, 2, 8, 934235) It also provides that the Government shall have the right to point out to such coloured people streets, wards and locations for habitation.
('1', 402, 2, 9, 934375) In 1886, this law was amended so as to reduce the £25 fee to £3 and the other sections were kept as they were.
('1', 402, 2, 10, 934486) That now is the law with regard to the Indians in the Transvaal.
('1', 402, 2, 11, 934551) After the law was passed, the Indians sent representations, telegraphic and otherwise, to the Indian and the Home Governments protesting against the Law 3 of 1885 and its amendment and pointing out that they were in direct violation of the London Convention.
('1', 402, 2, 12, 934810) This brought out some representations from Lord Knutsford 2 on behalf of the Indians.
('1', 402, 2, 13, 934896) There has been voluminous correspondence between the two Governments with regard to the interpretation of the word ‘habitation’.
('1', 402, 2, 14, 935025) The Home Government insisted that the word ‘habitation’ meant residence only.
('1', 402, 2, 15, 935103) The Transvaal Government insisted that it included not only residence but trading stores also.
('1', 402, 2, 16, 935198) The ultimate result was that the whole became
('1', 402, 3, 17, 935244) 1 Edward Henry Smith Stanley (1826 93), 15th Earl of Derby; Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1882 85 2 Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1887 92
('1', 403, 0, 1, 935396) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 403, 1, 2, 935438) “confusion worse confounded”, and it was agreed between the two Governments that the question of the validity of the Law 3 of 1885 and its amendment, as also interpretation, should be submitted to arbitration.
('1', 403, 1, 3, 935648) The Chief Justice of the Orange Free State was selected as the sole arbitrator who gave his award last year and decided that the Transvaal Government was justified in passing Law 3 of 1885 and its amendments, but he left undecided the question of interpretation and held that, if the parties could not agree to interpretation, the Courts of the Transvaal were the proper tribunals to decide that question.
('1', 403, 1, 4, 936054) (Enclosure VIII.) The Indians in the Transvaal sent memorials 1 to the Home and Indian Governments.
('1', 403, 1, 5, 936154) Mr. Chamberlain has given his decision and has reluctantly accepted the award of the arbitrator, but sympathizes with the Indians and terms them “a peaceable, law abiding, meritorious body of persons” whose undoubted industry, intelligence and indomitable perseverance perhaps will suffice to overcome any obstacles which may now face them in the pursuit of their avocations, and reserves to himself the liberty, later on, to make friendly representations to the Transvaal Government.
('1', 403, 1, 6, 936639) The question rests there at present.

('1', 403, 1, 9, 936855) Will their stores be closed up?
('1', 403, 1, 10, 936887) If so, what will 200 or 300 traders do to earn a living?
('1', 403, 1, 11, 936944) Will they have to trade also in locations?
('1', 403, 1, 12, 936987) This, however, does not complete the list of disabilities in the Transvaal.
('1', 403, 1, 13, 937063) Act 25 (10th January 1893), section 38, says:
('1', 403, 2, 14, 937109) That it is not permitted to natives and other coloured people to travel in the carriage intended for the Whites, viz., the first and second class.
('1', 403, 2, 15, 937256) The most respectable Indian, spotlessly dressed, cannot, as of right, travel first or second class on the Transvaal Railways.
('1', 403, 2, 16, 937382) He is huddled together with the natives of all sorts and conditions in a third class compartment.
('1', 403, 2, 17, 937480) This is a cause of very great inconvenience to the Indian community in the Transvaal.

('1', 405, 1, 5, 940035) The Law of 1890, Chapter XXXIII, which is entitled the Law to prevent the inrush of the Asiatic coloured persons, prevents any Indian from remaining in that country for more than 2 months, unless he gets the permission from the President of Republic, who cannot consider the application to reside before 30 days have elapsed after the presentation of the application and other ceremonies have been performed.
('1', 405, 1, 6, 940444) The applicant can, however, on no account hold fixed property in the State or carry on any mercantile or farming business.
('1', 405, 1, 7, 940567) The President may or may not, according to the state of things, grant such mutilated permission to reside.
('1', 405, 1, 8, 940674) Any Indian resident moreover is subject to an annual poll tax of £10. The first contravention of the section relating to mercantile or farming business renders the delinquent liable to a fine of £25 or 3 months’ imprisonment with or without hard labour.
('1', 405, 1, 9, 940928) For all subsequent contraventions, the penalty is to be each time doubled.
('1', 405, 1, 10, 941003) (Enclosure X.) 1
('1', 405, 2, 11, 941020) This practically finishes the list of grievances.
('1', 405, 2, 12, 941070) These notes are not intended to replace the various enclosures.
('1', 405, 2, 13, 941134) It is respectfully submitted they are necessary for a proper study of the memorials and pamphlets which contain valuable information collected from various sources.
('1', 405, 2, 14, 941299) The whole question has been thus put by the London Times:
('1', 405, 3, 15, 941357) May the British Indians, when they leave India, have the same status before the law as other British subjects enjoy?
('1', 405, 3, 16, 941474) May they or may they not go freely from one British possession to another and claim the rights of British subjects in allied States?
('1', 405, 4, 17, 941607) The Indian Government and the Indians themselves believe that it is in Southern Africa that this question of their status must be determined.
('1', 405, 4, 18, 941749) If they secure the position of British subjects in South Africa, it would be almost impossible to deny it to them elsewhere.
('1', 405, 4, 19, 941874) If they fail to secure that position in South Africa, it will be extremely difficult for them to attain it elsewhere.
('1', 405, 4, 20, 941992) The question has been treated as an Imperial question and all parties without distinction have supported the British Indians in South Africa.
