('1', 406, 2, 5, 942688) 103. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('1', 406, 3, 6, 942728) September 26, 1896 I stand before you, today, as representing the signatories to this document 2, who pose as representative of the 100,000 British Indians at present residing in South Africa—a country which has sprung into sudden prominence owing to the vast gold fields of Johannesburg and the late Jameson Raid 3. This is my sole qualification.
('1', 406, 3, 7, 943076) I am a person of few words.
('1', 406, 3, 8, 943104) The cause, however, for which I am to plead before you this evening is so great that I venture to think that you will overlook the faults of the speaker or, rather, the reader of this paper.
('1', 406, 3, 9, 943295) The interests of 100,000 Indians are closely bound up with the interests of the 300 millions of India.
('1', 406, 3, 10, 943398) The question of the grievances of the Indians in South Africa affects the future well being and the future
('1', 406, 4, 11, 943505) 1 The meeting was held under the auspices of the Bombay Presidency Association at the Framji Cowasji Institute.
('1', 406, 4, 12, 943617) Sir Pherozeshah Mehta presided.
('1', 406, 4, 13, 943649) The printed text no longer being available, what follows has been collated from the reports of the speech published in The Times of India and Bombay Gazette.
('1', 406, 4, 14, 943807) 2 The reference is to “The Credentials”.
('1', 406, 4, 15, 943848) 3 So called after Leander Starr Jameson who led it, it was actually inspired by Rhodes, the Prime Minister of the Cape Colony, and had the tacit support, in the initial stages, of the British Government.

('1', 406, 4, 17, 944147) The Jameson raid was among the incidents that led to the Boer War.
('1', 407, 0, 1, 944214) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 407, 1, 2, 944256) immigration of Indians of India.
('1', 407, 1, 3, 944289) I, therefore, humbly venture to think that this question should be, if it is not already, one of the questions of the day in India.
('1', 407, 1, 4, 944421) With these preliminary remarks, I shall now place before you, as shortly as possible, the whole position of affairs in South Africa as affecting the British Indians in that country.
('1', 407, 1, 5, 944603) South Africa, for our present purposes, is divided into the following States: the British Colony of the Cape of Good Hope, the British Colony of Natal, the British Colony of Zululand, the Transvaal or the South African Republic, the Orange Free State, the Chartered Territories or Rhodesia, and the Portuguese Territories of Delagoa Bay and Beira.
('1', 407, 1, 6, 944951) In South Africa, apart from the Portuguese Territories, there are nearly 100,000 Indians, of whom the greater part belong to the labouring class, drawn from the labouring population of Madras and Bengal, speaking the Tamil or Telugu and the Hindi languages respectively.
('1', 407, 1, 7, 945222) A small number belongs to the trading class, chiefly drawn from the Bombay Presidency.
('1', 407, 1, 8, 945309) A general feeling throughout South Africa is that of hatred towards Indian, encouraged by the newspapers and connived at, even countenanced by, the legislators.
('1', 407, 1, 9, 945470) Every Indian, without exception, is a coolie in the estimation of the general body of the Europeans.
('1', 407, 1, 10, 945571) Storekeepers are “coolie store keepers”.
('1', 407, 1, 11, 945612) Indian clerks and schoolmasters are “coolie clerks” and “coolie schoolmasters”.
('1', 407, 1, 12, 945692) Naturally, neither the traders nor the English educated Indians are treated with any degree of respect.
('1', 407, 1, 13, 945796) Wealth and abilities in an Indian count for naught in that country except to serve the interests of the European Colonists.
('1', 407, 1, 14, 945920) We are the “Asian dirt to be heartily cursed”.
('1', 407, 1, 15, 945967) We are “squalid coolies with truthless tongues”.
('1', 407, 1, 16, 946016) We are “the real canker that is eating into the very vitals of the community”.
('1', 407, 1, 17, 946095) We are “parasites, semi barbarous Asiatics”.
('1', 407, 1, 18, 946140) We “live upon rice and we are chock full of vice”.
('1', 407, 1, 19, 946191) Statute books describe the Indians as belonging to the “aboriginal or semi barbarous races of Asia”, while, as a matter of fact, there is hardly one Indian in South Africa belonging to the aboriginal stock.
('1', 407, 1, 20, 946398) The Santhals of Assam will be as useless in South Africa as the natives of that country.
('1', 407, 1, 21, 946487) The Pretoria Chamber of Commerce thinks that our religion teaches us to “consider all women as soulless and Christians a natural prey”.
('1', 407, 1, 22, 946623) According to the same authority, “the whole community in South Africa is exposed to the dangers engendered by the filthy habits and immoral practices of these people.” Yet, as a
('1', 408, 0, 1, 946801) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 409
('1', 408, 1, 2, 946835) matter of fact, there has happened not a single case of leprosy amongst the Indians in South Africa.
('1', 408, 1, 3, 946936) And Dr. Veale of Pretoria thinks that “the lowest class Indians live better and in better habitations and with more regard to sanitation than the lowest class Whites”, and he, furthermore, puts on record that “while every nationality had one or more of its members at some time in the lazaretto, there was not a single Indian attacked.” In most parts of South Africa, we may not stir out of our houses after 9 p.m.— unless we are armed with passes from our employer.
('1', 408, 1, 4, 947403) An exception, however, is made in favour of those Indians who wear the memon costume.
('1', 408, 1, 5, 947489) Hotels shut their doors against us.
('1', 408, 1, 6, 947525) We cannot make use of the tram cars unmolested.
('1', 408, 1, 7, 947573) The coaches are not for us.
('1', 408, 1, 8, 947601) Between Barberton and Pretoria in the Transvaal, and Johannesburg and Charlestown, when the latter were not connected by railway, the Indians, as a rule, are and were not allowed to sit inside the coaches, but are and were compelled to take their seats by the side of the driver.
('1', 408, 1, 9, 947881) This, on a frosty morning in the Transvaal, where winter is very severe, is a sore trial apart from the indignity which it involves.
('1', 408, 1, 10, 948014) The coach travelling involves long journeys and, at stated intervals, accommodation and food are provided for passengers.
('1', 408, 1, 11, 948136) No Indian is allowed accommodation or a seat at the dining table in these places.
('1', 408, 1, 12, 948218) At the most, he can purchase food from behind the kitchen room and manage the best way he can.
('1', 408, 1, 13, 948313) Instances of untold miseries suffered by the Indians can be quoted by hundreds.
('1', 408, 1, 14, 948393) Public baths are not for the Indians.
('1', 408, 1, 15, 948431) The high schools are not open to the Indians.
('1', 408, 1, 16, 948477) A fortnight before I left Natal, an Indian student applied for admission to the Durban High School and his application was rejected.
('1', 408, 1, 17, 948610) Even the primary schools are not quite open to the Indians.
('1', 408, 1, 18, 948670) An Indian Missionary schoolmaster was driven out of an English Church in Verulam, a small village in Natal.
('1', 408, 1, 19, 948778) The Government of Natal have been pining to hold a “coolie conference”, as it has been officially called, in order to secure uniformity in Indian legislation throughout South Africa, and in order to present a united front against the blandishments of the Home Government on behalf of the Indian.
('1', 408, 1, 20, 949074) Such is the general feeling against the Indian in South Africa, except the Portuguese Territories, where he is respected and has no grievance apart from the general population.
('1', 408, 1, 21, 949251) You can easily imagine how difficult it must be for a respectable Indian to exist in such a country.
('1', 408, 1, 22, 949352) I am sure, gentlemen, that if our President went to South Africa, he would find it, to use a colloquial phrase, “mighty hard” to secure
('1', 409, 0, 1, 949488) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('1', 409, 1, 2, 949530) accommodation in a hotel, and he would not feel very comfortable in a first class railway carriage in Natal, and, after reaching Volksrust, he would be put out unceremoniously from his first class compartment and accommodated in a tin compartment where Kaffirs are packed like sheep.
('1', 409, 1, 3, 949814) I may, however, assure him that if he ever came to South Africa, and we wish our great men did come to these uncomfortable quarters, if only to see and realize the plight in which their fellow countrymen are, we shall more than make up for these inconveniences, which we cannot help, by according him a right royal welcome, so united, so enthusiastic we are, at any rate for the present.
('1', 409, 1, 4, 950202) Ours is one continual struggle against a degradation sought to be inflicted upon us by the Europeans, who desire to degrade us to the level of the raw Kaffir whose occupation is hunting, and whose sole ambition is to collect a certain number of cattle to buy a wife with and, then, pass his life in indolence and nakedness.
('1', 409, 1, 5, 950526) The aim of the Christian Governments, so we read, is to raise people whom they come in contact with or whom they control.
('1', 409, 1, 6, 950648) It is otherwise in South Africa.
('1', 409, 1, 7, 950681) There, the deliberately expressed object is not to allow the Indian to rise higher in the scale of civilization but to lower him to the position of the Kaffir; in the words of the Attorney General of Natal, “to keep him for ever a hewer of wood and drawer of water”, “not to let him form part of the future South African nation that is going to be built”; in the words of another legislator in Natal, “to make the Indian’s life more comfortable in his native land than in the Colony of Natal”.
('1', 409, 1, 8, 951175) The struggle against such degradation is so severe that our whole energy is spent in resistance.
('1', 409, 1, 9, 951272) Consequently, we have very little left in us to attempt to make any reforms from within.
('1', 409, 1, 10, 951361) I must now come to the particular States and show how the Governments in the different States have combined with the masses to persecute the Indians to make “the British Indian an impossibility”.
('1', 409, 1, 11, 951557) The Colony of Natal, which is a self governing British Colony with a Legislative Assembly consisting of 37 members elected by the voters, and a Legislative Council consisting of twelve members nominated by the Governor, who comes from England as the Queen’s representative, has a European population of 50,000, a native or Zulu population of 400,000, and an Indian population of 51,000. Assisted immigration of Indians was decided upon in 1860, when, in the words of a member of the Legislative Assembly of Natal, “the progress and almost the existence of the Colony hung in the balance”, and when the Zulu was found to be too indolent to work.
('1', 409, 1, 12, 952202) Now the chief industries and
('1', 410, 0, 1, 952231) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 411
('1', 410, 1, 2, 952265) sanitation of the whole Colony of Natal are entirely dependent upon the Indian labour.
('1', 410, 1, 3, 952352) The Indians have made Natal “the garden of South Africa”.
('1', 410, 1, 4, 952410) In the words of another eminent Natalian, “Indian immigration brought prosperity, prices rose, people were no longer content to grow or sell produce for a song”.
('1', 410, 1, 5, 952572) Of the 51,000 Indians, 30,000 are those that have served out their indenture and are now variously engaged as free labourers, gardeners, hawkers, fruiterers, or petty traders.
('1', 410, 1, 6, 952748) A few have, also, by their industry, educated themselves into fitness for the posts of schoolmasters, interpreters and general clerks in spite of adverse circumstances; 16,000 are at present serving their indenture, and about 5,000 are traders and merchants or their assistants who came first on their own means.
('1', 410, 1, 7, 953061) These latter belong to the Bombay Presidency and most of them are Memon Mahomedans.
('1', 410, 1, 8, 953145) A few are Parsees also, notable among whom is Mr. Rustomjee of Durban, who in his generosity would do credit to Sir Dinshaw 1. No poor man goes to his doors without having his inner man satisfied.
('1', 410, 1, 9, 953342) No Parsee lands on the Durban shores but is sumptuously treated by Mr. Rustomjee.
('1', 410, 1, 10, 953424) And even he is not free from molestation.
('1', 410, 1, 11, 953466) Even he is a coolie.
('1', 410, 1, 12, 953487) Two gentlemen are ship owners and large landed proprietors.
('1', 410, 1, 13, 953547) But they are coolie ship owners and their ships are called “coolie ships”.
('1', 410, 1, 14, 953622) Apart from the common interest that every Indian feels in every other Indian, the three chief Presidencies are specially interested in this question.
('1', 410, 1, 15, 953772) If the Bombay Presidency has not sent an equally large number of her sons to South Africa, she makes up for that by the greater influence and wealth of her sons who have really constituted themselves the guardians of the interests of their less fortunate brethren from the sister Presidencies.
('1', 410, 1, 16, 954066) And it may be that in India also Bombay will lead in endeavouring to help the Indians in South Africa out of their hardships.

In the Transvaal, which is a Dutch Republic, the seat of the Jameson Raid and the El Dorado of the gold hunters of the Western World, there are over 5,000 Indians, many of whom are merchants and storekeepers.
('1', 413, 1, 10, 961620) Others are hawkers, waiters and household servants.

In that year, however, after some correspondence with the Home Government, the Transvaal Volksraad passed a law which took away from the Indians the right of trading, except in specified locations, and owning landed property, and imposed a registration fee of £3 on every Indian intending to settle in that country.

('1', 414, 3, 18, 965068) The very reason that they have been so successful against the dominant race is sufficient to raise them above that degrading level.

('1', 415, 1, 2, 965242) If this was true in 1889, when the above was written, it is doubly so now, because the Legislatures of South Africa have shown phenomenal activity in passing measures restricting the liberty of the Queen’s Indian subjects.
('1', 415, 1, 3, 965465) To stem the tide of this opposition against us, we have formed an organization 1 on an humble scale so that we may take the necessary steps to have our grievances removed.
('1', 415, 1, 4, 965637) We believe that much of the ill feeling is due to want of proper knowledge about the Indians in India.
('1', 415, 1, 5, 965740) We, therefore, endeavour, so far as the populace is concerned, to educate public opinion by imparting the necessary information.
('1', 415, 1, 6, 965869) With regard to the legal disabilities, we have tried to influence the English public opinion in England and the public opinion here by placing our position before it.
('1', 415, 1, 7, 966036) As you know, both the Conservatives and the Liberals have supported us in England without distinction.
('1', 415, 1, 8, 966139) The London Times has given eight leading articles to our cause in a very sympathetic spirit.
('1', 415, 1, 9, 966232) 2 This alone has raised us a step higher in the estimation of the Europeans in South Africa, and has considerably affected for the better the tone of the newspapers there.
('1', 415, 1, 10, 966404) I may state our position a little more clearly as to our demands.
('1', 415, 1, 11, 966470) We are aware that the insults and indignities, that we are subjected to at the hands of the populace, cannot be directly removed by the intervention of the Home Government.
('1', 415, 1, 12, 966643) We do not appeal to it for any such intervention.
('1', 415, 1, 13, 966693) We bring them to the notice of the public, so that the fair minded of all communities and the Press may, by expressing their disapproval, materially reduce their rigour and, possibly, eradicate them ultimately.
('1', 415, 1, 14, 966904) But we certainly do appeal, and we hope not vainly, to the Home Government for protection against reproduction of such ill feeling in Colonial legislation.
('1', 415, 1, 15, 967060) We certainly beseech the Home Government to disallow all the Acts of the Legislative bodies of the Colonies restricting our freedom in any shape or form.
('1', 415, 1, 16, 967214) And this brings me to the last question, namely, how far can the Home Government interfere with such action on the part of the Colonies and the allied States.
('1', 415, 1, 17, 967373) As for Zululand, there can be no question, since it is a Crown Colony directly governed from Downing Street through a Governor.
('1', 415, 1, 18, 967501) It is not a self governing or responsibly governed Colony as the Colonies of Natal and the Cape of Good Hope are.
('1', 415, 1, 19, 967615) With regard to the latter, Clause 7 of the Constitution Act of Natal enacts that Her Majesty may disallow any Act of the local
('1', 415, 2, 20, 967742) 1 The Natal Indian Congress 2 Vide “Application for Enrolment as Advocate”, 16 11 1891
('1', 416, 0, 1, 967829) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 417
('1', 416, 1, 2, 967863) Parliament within two years, even after it has become law having received the Governor’s assent.
('1', 416, 1, 3, 967960) That is one safeguard against oppressive measures by the Colonies.
('1', 416, 1, 4, 968027) The Royal instructions to the Governor enumerate certain Bills which cannot be assented to by the Governor without Her Majesty’s previous sanction.
('1', 416, 1, 5, 968175) Among such are Bills which have for their object class legislation.
('1', 416, 1, 6, 968243) I shall venture to give an instance in point.
('1', 416, 1, 7, 968289) The Immigration Law Amendment Bill referred to above has been assented to by the Governor, but it can come into force only after her Majesty has sanctioned it.
('1', 416, 1, 8, 968449) It has not yet been sanctioned.
('1', 416, 1, 9, 968481) Thus, then, it will be noticed that Her Majesty’s intervention is direct and precise.
('1', 416, 1, 10, 968567) While it is true that the Home Government is slow to interfere with the Acts of the Colonial Legislatures, there are instances where it has not hesitated to put its foot down on occasions less urgent then the present one.
('1', 416, 1, 11, 968789) As you are aware, the repeal of the first Franchise Bill was due to such wholesome intervention.
('1', 416, 1, 12, 968886) What is more, Colonists are ever afraid of it.
('1', 416, 1, 13, 968933) And as a result of the sympathy expressed in England and the sympathetic answer given by Mr. Chamberlain to the deputation that waited on him some months ago, most of the papers in South Africa, at any rate in Natal, have veered round or think that the Immigration and other such Bills will not receive the Royal assent.
('1', 416, 1, 14, 969254) As to the Transvaal there is the Convention.
('1', 416, 1, 15, 969299) As to the Orange Free State, I can only say that it is an unfriendly act on the part of a friendly State to shut her doors against any portion of Her Majesty’s subjects.
('1', 416, 1, 16, 969469) And as such, I humbly think it can be effectively checked.
('1', 416, 1, 17, 969528) Gentlemen, the latest advice from South Africa show that the Europeans there are actively canvassing the ruin of the Indians.
('1', 416, 1, 18, 969654) They are agitating against the introduction of Indian artisans and what not.
('1', 416, 1, 19, 969731) 1 All this should serve as a warning and an impetus.
('1', 416, 1, 20, 969784) We are hemmed in on all sides in South Africa.
('1', 416, 1, 21, 969831) We are yet infants.
('1', 416, 1, 22, 969851) We have a right to appeal to you for protection.
('1', 416, 1, 23, 969900) We place our position before you, and now the responsibility will rest to a very great extent on your shoulders, if the yoke of oppression is not removed from our necks.
('1', 416, 1, 24, 970070) Being under it we can only cry out in anguish.
('1', 416, 1, 25, 970117) It is for you, our elder and freer brethren, to remove it.
('1', 416, 1, 26, 970176) I am sure we shall not have cried out in vain.
('1', 416, 2, 27, 970223) The Times of India, 27 9 1896, and Bombay Gazette, 27 9 1896
('1', 416, 3, 28, 970284) 1 The Europeans held mass meetings in Durban and protested against the Indian Immigration Trust Board’s decision to permit the importation of Indian artisans to work on the Tongaat Sugar Estates in Natal.
('1', 416, 3, 29, 970489) A ‘European Protection Association’ and a ‘Colonial Patriotic Union’ were set up to resist what was described as the ‘Asiatic Invasion’.

('1', 417, 2, 3, 970701) C/O MESSRS REVASHANKER JAGJIVAN & CO., CHAMPAGALI, BOMBAY, October 10, 1896 1

('1', 417, 3, 13, 971508) I sincerely hope that you will be able to see your way clear to join me in Natal.
('1', 417, 3, 14, 971590) I am sure it is a cause worth fighting for.
('1', 417, 3, 15, 971634) If you wish to write to me you may write to me at the above address and your letters will be redirected to me at Madras.
('1', 417, 3, 16, 971755) I do not know at which hotel I shall put up there.
('1', 417, 3, 17, 971806) The Natal hotels have made me quite nervous.
('1', 417, 3, 18, 971851) I remain, Yours truly,
('1', 417, 4, 19, 971874) M. K. GANDHI

('1', 419, 1, 2, 973627) 106. LETTER TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('1', 419, 2, 3, 973663) MADRAS, October 17, 1896
('1', 419, 3, 4, 973688) THE EDITOR The Times of India
('1', 419, 4, 5, 973718) SIR, I shall be obliged to you if you will be good enough to find space for the following in your influential paper.
('1', 419, 4, 6, 973835) The Natal Agent General has, it appears, told Reuter, with reference to my pamphlet on the grievances of the British Indians in South Africa, that it is not true to say that the railway and tramway officials treat the Indians as beasts, that the fact that the indentured Indians do not avail themselves of the return passage is the best answer to my pamphlet, and that the Indians are not denied justice in the law courts.
('1', 419, 4, 7, 974258) In the first place, the pamphlet deals with the grievances of the Indians in the whole of South Africa.
('1', 419, 4, 8, 974362) In the second place, I adhere to the statement that the railway and tram car official treat the Indians as beasts in Natal.
('1', 419, 4, 9, 974486) If there are exceptions, they prove the rule.
('1', 419, 4, 10, 974532) I have been witness myself to not a few such cases.
('1', 419, 4, 11, 974584) What is it if it is not being treated as a beast, to be removed three times during a single night journey from one compartment to another, to suit European passengers?
('1', 419, 4, 12, 974752) To see Indians, apparently respectable, kicked, pushed, and sworn at by the station master is not an extraordinary sight on the railway stations.
('1', 419, 4, 13, 974898) The Western station in Durban is the dread of the Indians, so over polite is the station master at that station, and this is not the only station where the Indians are kicked about like footballs.
('1', 419, 4, 14, 975095) Here is an independent testimony from The Natal Mercury (24 11 ’93) :
('1', 419, 5, 15, 975165) On our railway, we have noticed on more than one occasion that coloured passengers are not by any means killed with civility; and, although it would be unreasonable to expect that the White employees of the N.G.R. should treat them with the same deference as is accorded to European passengers, still, we think it would be in no way derogatory to their dignity if the officials were a little more suaviter in modo when dealing with the coloured travellers.
('1', 419, 5, 16, 975622) On the tram cars the Indians fare no better.
('1', 419, 5, 17, 975667) Spotlessly dressed and well behaved Indians have been pushed about from one place to
('1', 420, 0, 1, 975752) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 421
('1', 420, 1, 2, 975786) another to suit the fancy of European passengers.
('1', 420, 1, 3, 975836) Indeed, as a rule, the tram car officials compel “Sammy” to go “upstairs”.
('1', 420, 1, 4, 975911) Some would not allow them to take front seats.
('1', 420, 1, 5, 975958) Respect is out of the question.
('1', 420, 1, 6, 975990) An Indian official was compelled to stand on the tram car board, although there was ample room to accommodate him.
('1', 420, 1, 7, 976105) Of course, he was addressed as “Sammy” in the peculiarly offensive tone prevalent in Natal.
('1', 420, 1, 8, 976197) My statement has been before the public in Natal for the last two years, and the first contradiction comes now from the Agent General!
('1', 420, 1, 9, 976332) Why so late?
('1', 420, 1, 10, 976345) As to the unwillingness of the Indians to avail themselves of the return passage, I beg to say, with due deference to the Agent General, that the statement has been repeated ad nauseam in the Press, and the official dignity now given to it will not enable it to prove more than it actually can.
('1', 420, 1, 11, 976640) At the most it can prove that the lot of the indentured Indian cannot be very unhappy; and that Natal is a very good place for such Indians to earn their livelihood.
('1', 420, 1, 12, 976806) I am prepared to admit both.
('1', 420, 1, 13, 976835) That does not, moreover, disprove the existence of the Colonial legislation restricting the freedom of the Indians in various ways.
('1', 420, 1, 14, 976967) That does not disprove the existence of the terrible ill feeling towards the Indians in the Colony.
('1', 420, 1, 15, 977067) If the Indians remain in Natal, it is in spite of such treatment.
('1', 420, 1, 16, 977133) It proves their marvellous forbearance, which has been so eloquently praised by Mr. Chamberlain in his despatch in connection with, to use a South African phrase, “the coolie arbitration”.
('1', 420, 1, 17, 977322) The latest papers received from South Africa, unfortunately for the Natal Government, lend additional weight to my statement that the Indian is a cruelly persecuted being in South Africa.
('1', 420, 1, 18, 977510) In August last, there was a meeting of European artisans, held to protest against the intended introduction of Indian artisans.
('1', 420, 1, 19, 977638) The speeches made would form interesting reading for the Agent General of Natal.
('1', 420, 1, 20, 977719) The Indians were called “black vermin”.
('1', 420, 1, 21, 977759) A voice in the meeting said, “We will go to the Point1 and stop them.” A picnic party of European children used Indian and Kaffir boys as targets and shot bullets into their faces, hurting several inoffensive children.
('1', 420, 1, 22, 977978) So deep seated is the hatred that children have begun instinctively to look down upon Indians.
('1', 420, 1, 23, 978073) Moreover, it should be remembered that the return passage story has nothing to do with the trading class, who go to Natal on their own account, and who feel the hardships the most.
('1', 420, 1, 24, 978254) The thing is, one fact is stronger than a hundred statements of belief.
('1', 420, 1, 25, 978326) And the pamphlet
('1', 421, 0, 1, 978343) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 422
('1', 421, 1, 2, 978385) contains very little of my own.
('1', 421, 1, 3, 978417) It bristles with facts.
('1', 421, 1, 4, 978441) Mainly taken from European sources, to prove my assertion as against the naked statement of Mr. Peace the Agent General’s opinion.
('1', 421, 1, 5, 978572) If Mr. Peace’s statement is all that is to be said in reply to the pamphlet, then there remains much to be done before Natal can become a tolerably comfortable place for Indians.
('1', 421, 1, 6, 978751) As to the Indians receiving justice in the law courts, I do not wish to say much.
('1', 421, 1, 7, 978833) I have never stated that the Indians do not get justice in the law courts, nor am I prepared to admit that they get it at all times and in all courts.
('1', 421, 1, 8, 978984) Sir, I am not given to exaggerate matters.
('1', 421, 1, 9, 979027) You have asked for an official inquiry; we have done the same.
('1', 421, 1, 10, 979090) And if the Natal Government are not afraid of unpleasant revelations, let there be such an inquiry as soon as possible.
('1', 421, 1, 11, 979210) And I think I am safe in promising that much more will be proved than is mentioned in the pamphlet.
('1', 421, 1, 12, 979310) I have given therein only those instances which can be proved most easily.
('1', 421, 1, 13, 979385) Sir, our position is very precarious, and we will need your active support, which has been so liberally given to us till now, yet for a long time to come.
('1', 421, 1, 14, 979540) The Immigration Law Amendment Bill, which you and your contemporaries condemned last year in such forcible language, has received the Royal assent, as appears from the papers received this week.
('1', 421, 1, 15, 979735) To remind your readers, the Bill raises the period of indenture from the original period of five years to an indefinite period and, in default of re indenture after the completion of the first five years, makes it compulsory for the Indian to return to India, of course, at the employer’s expense, and, in case of non compliance with that term of his contract, renders the defaulter liable to an annual poll tax of £3, nearly half a year’s earnings on the indenture scale.
('1', 421, 1, 16, 980208) This Bill was, at the time it was passed, unanimously pronounced to be an iniquitous measure.
('1', 421, 1, 17, 980302) Even the Natal papers were doubtful whether the Bill would receive the Royal sanction.
('1', 421, 1, 18, 980389) Yet the Bill has been promulgated and it came into force on the 8th August.
('1', 421, 1, 19, 980465) Publicity is our best and perhaps the only weapon of defence.
('1', 421, 1, 20, 980527) “Our grievances,” says one of our sympathizers, “are so serious that they have only to be known in order to be removed.” I have now to beseech you and your contemporaries to express your opinion with regard to this action on the part of the Colonial Secretary.
('1', 421, 1, 21, 980788) The Colonial Office, we thought, was our safe resting place.
('1', 421, 1, 22, 980849) We may yet have to be undeceived.
('1', 421, 1, 23, 980883) We have prayed for suspension of State aided
('1', 422, 0, 1, 980928) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 423
('1', 422, 1, 2, 980962) immigration to Natal if the Bill could not be vetoed.
('1', 422, 1, 3, 981016) 1 That prayer has been supported by the public.
('1', 422, 1, 4, 981064) May we now rely upon the public to renew their support in our fresh efforts to have that prayer granted?
('1', 422, 2, 5, 981169) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Times of India, 20 10 1896
('1', 422, 3, 6, 981226) 107. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE BUCKINGHAM HOTEL, MADRAS, October 18, 1896 PROFESSOR GOKHALE POONA

('1', 423, 1, 2, 982730) 108. LETTER TO F. S. TALEYARKHAN
('1', 423, 2, 3, 982763) BUCKINGHAM HOTEL, MADRAS, October 18, 1896
('1', 423, 3, 4, 982806) DEAR MR. TALEYARKHAN, I have your important letter for which I thank you.
('1', 423, 3, 5, 982880) Your inquiry is certainly very pertinent.
('1', 423, 3, 6, 982922) And you may depend upon it that I shall answer it most frankly.
('1', 423, 3, 7, 982986) I start with the assumption that we work in partnership.
('1', 423, 3, 8, 983043) Starting on your own account at once will be out of the question.
('1', 423, 3, 9, 983109) There are cheques lying in my safe at Durban for about £300, the retainer 1 for 1897, ending 31st July.
('1', 423, 3, 10, 983213) These I propose to withdraw from the partnership to pay liabilities incurred here and if possible to pay the expenses that are now being incurred in connection with my office.
('1', 423, 3, 11, 983389) I say if possible, because the balance may not cover the expenses at Durban.
('1', 423, 3, 12, 983466) If past experience is any guide for the purpose, then I think I am safe in saying that the joint earnings for the first six months will be at the rate of £70 per month.
('1', 423, 3, 13, 983635) As against that I place the joint expenses at £50 per month, i.e., if we share the same house.
('1', 423, 3, 14, 983730) That would leave a clear profit of £120 to be divided equally between us after six months.
('1', 423, 3, 15, 983821) This is the lowest estimate.
('1', 423, 3, 16, 983850) And I should expect to earn that amount single handed doing the Indian work side by side.
('1', 423, 3, 17, 983940) It would not surprise me however if we earned £150 per month.
('1', 423, 3, 18, 984002) This much I can promise.
('1', 423, 3, 19, 984027) You should pay your own passage to Natal.
('1', 423, 3, 20, 984069) Your expenses of admission will be paid out of the office.
('1', 423, 3, 21, 984128) The expenses of your board and lodging also will be defrayed out of the office earnings.
('1', 423, 3, 22, 984217) That is to say, if there is any loss during the six months’ trial it shall be borne by me.
('1', 423, 3, 23, 984308) On the other hand if there are any profits you share them.
('1', 423, 3, 24, 984367) Thus at the end of six months if you do not gain in money you will have gained considerably in experience of a different kind from that available in India.
('1', 423, 3, 25, 984523) You will have realized the position of our countrymen in that part of the world and you will have seen a new
('1', 423, 4, 26, 984632) 1 The reference is to the professional fees Gandhiji received from Indian merchants in respect of their personal legal work.
('1', 424, 0, 1, 984757) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 425
('1', 424, 1, 2, 984791) country.
('1', 424, 1, 3, 984800) I have no doubt that your connection in Bombay is such that a six months’ absence from Bombay would not mar your future career there if you are disappointed in Natal.
('1', 424, 1, 4, 984967) The six months’ loss in Bombay will be requited by what I have stated above.
('1', 424, 1, 5, 985044) In any case, I cannot be too plain in saying that no one in our position should go to South Africa with a view to pile money.
('1', 424, 1, 6, 985170) You should go there with a spirit of self sacrifice.
('1', 424, 1, 7, 985223) You should keep riches at an arm’s length.
('1', 424, 1, 8, 985266) They may then woo you.
('1', 424, 1, 9, 985289) If you bestow your glances on them, they are such a coquette that you are sure to be slighted.
('1', 424, 1, 10, 985384) That is my experience in South Africa.
('1', 424, 1, 11, 985423) As for work, apart from pecuniary considerations, I promise that there will be more than sufficient to feed your activity—that too legal work.
('1', 424, 1, 12, 985566) Boarding together might present a slight difficulty.
('1', 424, 1, 13, 985619) If you could manage with vegetarian food, I could place on the table most palatable dishes cooked both in the English as well as the Indian style.
('1', 424, 1, 14, 985766) If, however, that be not possible, we shall have to engage another cook.

('1', 424, 1, 17, 985940) If there are any points requiring elucidation you have only to mention them.

('1', 424, 1, 19, 986092) I am sure you will be able to do much in South Africa—more indeed than I may have been instrumental in doing.
('1', 424, 1, 20, 986202) I have been seeing here the great men.

('1', 425, 5, 18, 987989) 110. SPEECH AT MEETING, MADRAS 2
('1', 425, 6, 19, 988022) October 26, 1896
('1', 425, 7, 20, 988039) MR. PRESIDENT AND GENTLEMEN, I am to plead before you this evening for the 100,000 British Indians in South Africa, the land of gold and the seat of the late Jameson Raid.
('1', 425, 7, 21, 988211) This document 3 will show you that I have been deputed to do so by the signatories to it, who profess to represent the 100,000 Indians.
('1', 425, 7, 22, 988347) A large majority of this number are people from Madras and Bengal.
('1', 425, 7, 23, 988414) Apart, therefore, from the interest that you would take in them as Indians, you are specially interested in the matter.
('1', 425, 8, 24, 988534) 1 The Hindu Theological High School 2 The meeting, held in Pachaiyappa’s Hall, was organized by the Mahajana Sabha.
('1', 425, 8, 25, 988650) 3Vide “The Credentials”, Vol1. “The Credentials”
('1', 426, 0, 1, 988699) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 427
('1', 426, 1, 2, 988733) South Africa may, for our purposes, be divided into the two self governing British Colonies of Natal and the Cape of Good Hope, the Crown Colony of Zululand, the Transvaal or the South African Republic, the Orange Free State, the Chartered Territories and the Portuguese Territories comprising Delagoa Bay and Beira.
('1', 426, 1, 3, 989050) South Africa is indebted to the colony of Natal for the presence of the Indian population there.
('1', 426, 1, 4, 989147) In the year 1860, when, in the words of a member of the Natal Parliament, “the existence of the Colony hung in the balance”, the Colony of Natal introduced indentured Indians into the Colony.
('1', 426, 1, 5, 989339) Such immigration is regulated by law, is permissible only to few favoured States, e.g., Mauritius, Fiji, Jamaica, Straits Settlements, Damarara and other States, and is allowed only from Madras and Calcutta.
('1', 426, 1, 6, 989547) As a result of the immigration, in the words of another eminent Natalian, Mr. Saunders:
('1', 426, 2, 7, 989635) Indian Immigration brought prosperity, prices rose, people were no longer content to grow or sell produce for a song, they could do better.
('1', 426, 2, 8, 989775) The sugar and tea industries, as well as sanitation and the vegetable and fish supply of the Colony, are absolutely dependent on the indentured Indians from Madras and Calcutta.
('1', 426, 2, 9, 989953) The presence of the indentured Indians, about sixteen years ago, drew the free Indians in the shape of traders, who first went there with a view to supply the wants of their own kith and kin; but afterwards found a very valuable customer in the native of South Africa, called Zulu or Kaffir.
('1', 426, 2, 10, 990245) These traders are chiefly drawn from the Bombay Memon Mahomedans and, owing to their less unfortunate position, have formed themselves into custodians of the interests of the whole Indian population there.
('1', 426, 2, 11, 990451) Thus, adversity and identity of interests have united in compact body the Indians from the three Presidencies, and they take pride in calling themselves Indians rather than Madrasees or Bengalees or Gujaratees, except when it is necessary to do so.
('1', 426, 2, 12, 990700) That, however, by the way.
('1', 426, 2, 13, 990727) These Indians have now spread all over South Africa.
('1', 426, 2, 14, 990780) Natal, which is governed by a Legislative Assembly consisting of 37 members elected by the voters, a Legislative Council represents the 11 members, nominated by the governor who represents the Queen, and a movable Ministry consisting of 5 members, contains a European population of 50,000, a native population of 400,000 and an Indian population of 51,000. Of the 51,000 Indians, about 16,000 are at present serving their indenture, 30,000 are those that have completed their indenture and are now variously engaged as domestic servants,
('1', 427, 0, 1, 991318) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 428
('1', 427, 1, 2, 991360) gardeners, hawkers and petty traders, and about 5,000 are those who emigrated to the Colony of their own account and are either traders, shopkeepers, assistants or hawkers.
('1', 427, 1, 3, 991533) A few are, also, schoolmasters, interpreters and clerks.
('1', 427, 1, 4, 991590) The self governing Colony of the Cape of Good Hope has, I believe, an Indians population of about 10,000, consisting of traders, hawkers and labourers.
('1', 427, 1, 5, 991742) Its total population is nearly 1,800,000, of whom not more than 400,000 are Europeans.
('1', 427, 1, 6, 991829) The rest are natives of the country and Malaya.
('1', 427, 1, 7, 991877) The South African Republic of the Transvaal, which is governed by two elective Chambers called the Volksraad and an Executive with the President at its head, has an Indian population of 5,000, of whom about 200 are traders with liquidated assets amounting to nearly £100,000. The rest are hawkers and waiters or household servants, the latter being men from this Presidency.
('1', 427, 1, 8, 992252) Its White population is estimated at roughly 120,000 and the Kaffir population at roughly 650,000. This Republic is subject to the Queen’s suzerainty.
('1', 427, 1, 9, 992403) And there is a Convention 1 between Great Britain and the Republic which secures the property, trading and farming rights of all persons other than natives of South Africa, in common with the citizens of the Republic.
('1', 427, 1, 10, 992621) The other States have no Indian population to speak of, because of the grievances and disabilities, except the Portuguese territories which contain a very large Indian population and which do not give any trouble to the Indians.
('1', 427, 1, 11, 992850) The grievances of the Indians in South Africa are twofold, i.e., those that are due to popular ill feeling against the Indians and, secondly, the legal disabilities placed upon them.
('1', 427, 1, 12, 993033) To deal with the first, the Indian is the most hated being in South Africa.
('1', 427, 1, 13, 993109) Every Indian without distinction is contemptuously called a“coolie”.
('1', 427, 1, 14, 993178) He is also called“Sammy”,“ Ramasammy”, anything but“Indian”.
('1', 427, 1, 15, 993239) Indian schoolmasters are called“coolie schoolmasters”.
('1', 427, 1, 16, 993294) Indian storekeepers are“coolie storekeepers”.
('1', 427, 1, 17, 993340) Two Indian gentlemen from Bombay, Messrs Dada Abdulla and Moosa Hajee Cassim, own steamers.
('1', 427, 1, 18, 993432) Their steamers are “coolie ships”.
('1', 427, 1, 19, 993467) There is a very respectable firm of Madras traders by name, A. Colandaveloo Pillay & Co.
('1', 427, 1, 20, 993556) They have built a large block of buildings
('1', 427, 2, 21, 993599) 1 The reference is to the London Convention of 1884.
('1', 428, 0, 1, 993652) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 429
('1', 428, 1, 2, 993686) in Durban; these building are called “coolie stores”, and the owners are “coolie owners”.
('1', 428, 1, 3, 993776) And I can assure you, gentlemen, that there is as much difference between the partners of that firm and a “coolie” as there is between anyone in this hall and a coolie.
('1', 428, 1, 4, 993945) The railway and tram officials, in spite of the contradiction that has appeared in official quarters which I am going to deal with presently, I repeat, treat us as beasts.
('1', 428, 1, 5, 994117) We cannot safely walk on the foot paths.
('1', 428, 1, 6, 994158) A Madrasi gentleman, spotlessly dressed, always avoids the foot paths of prominent streets in Durban for fear he should be insulted or pushed off.
('1', 428, 1, 7, 994305) We are the“Asian dirt”to be“heartily cursed”, we are “chock full of vice”and we “live upon rice”, we are “stinking coolie” living on“the smell of an oiled rag”, we are “ the black vermin”, we are described in the Statute books as“ semi barbarous Asiatics, or persons belonging to the uncivilized races of Asia”.
('1', 428, 1, 8, 994617) We “breed like rabbits” and a gentleman at a meeting lately held in Durban said he was sorry we could not be shot like them.
('1', 428, 1, 9, 994742) There are coaches running between certain places in the Transvaal.
('1', 428, 1, 10, 994809) We may not sit inside them.
('1', 428, 1, 11, 994837) It is a sore trial, apart from the indignity it involves and contemplates, to have to sit outside them, either in deadly winter morning, for the winter is severe in the Transvaal, or under a burning sun, though we are Indians.
('1', 428, 1, 12, 995064) The hotels refuse us admission.
('1', 428, 1, 13, 995096) Indeed, there are cases in which respectable Indians have found it difficult even to procure refreshments at European places.
('1', 428, 1, 14, 995222) It was only a short time ago, that a gang of Europeans set fire to an Indian store in a village called Dundee in Natal, doing some damage, and another gang threw burning crackers into the Indian stores in a business street in Durban.
('1', 428, 1, 15, 995456) This feeling of intense hatred has been reproduced into legislation in the various States of South Africa restricting the freedom of Indians in many ways.
('1', 428, 1, 16, 995611) To begin with, Natal, which is the most important from an Indian point of view, has, of late, shown the greatest activity in passing Indian legislation.
('1', 428, 1, 17, 995764) Till 1894, the Indians had been enjoying the franchise equally with the Europeans under the general franchise law of the Colony, which entitles any adult male, being a British subject, to be placed on the Voters’ List, who possesses immovable property worth £50 or pays an annual rent of £10. There is a separate franchise qualification for the Zulu.
('1', 428, 1, 18, 996115) In 1894, the Natal Legislature passed a Bill disfranchising Asiatics by name.
('1', 428, 1, 19, 996193) We resisted it in the local Parliament, but without any avail.
('1', 428, 1, 20, 996256) We them memorialized the Secretary of State for the Colonies, and, as a result,
('1', 429, 0, 1, 996336) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 430
('1', 429, 1, 2, 996378) that Bill was, this year, withdrawn and replaced by another which, though not quite so bad as the first one, is bad enough.
('1', 429, 1, 3, 996502) It says that no natives of countries (not being of European origin) which have not hitherto possessed elective representative institutions, founded on the parliamentary franchise, shall be placed on the Voters’ Roll unless they shall first obtain an exemption from the Governor in Council.
('1', 429, 1, 4, 996792) This Bill excepts from its operation those whose names are already rightly contained in any Voters’ List.
('1', 429, 1, 5, 996898) Before being introduced, it was submitted to Mr. Chamberlain, who has approved of it.
('1', 429, 1, 6, 996984) We have opposed it on the ground that we have such institutions in India, and that, therefore, the Bill will fail in its objects if it is to disfranchise the Asiatics and that, therefore, also it is a harassing piece of legislation and is calculated to involve us in endless litigation and expense.
('1', 429, 1, 7, 997283) This is admitted on all hands.
('1', 429, 1, 8, 997314) The very members who voted for it thought likewise.
('1', 429, 1, 9, 997366) The Natal Government organ 1 says in effect:
('1', 429, 2, 10, 997411) We know India has such institutions and therefore the Bill will not apply to the Indian.
('1', 429, 2, 11, 997500) But we can have that Bill or none.
('1', 429, 2, 12, 997535) If it disfranchises Indians, nothing can be better.
('1', 429, 2, 13, 997587) If it does not, then too we have nothing to fear!
('1', 429, 2, 14, 997637) For the Indian can never gain political supremacy and, if necessary, we can soon impose an educational test or raise the property qualifications which, while disfranchising Indians wholesale, will not debar a single European from voting.
('1', 429, 2, 15, 997875) Thus, the Natal legislature is playing a game of “Toss up” at the Indians’ expense.
('1', 429, 2, 16, 997959) We are a fit subject for vivisection under the Natal Pasteur’s deadly scalpel and knife, with this difference between the Paris Pasteur and the Natal Pasteur that, while the former indulged in vivisection with the object of benefiting humanity, the latter has been indulging in it for the sake of amusement out of sheer wantonness.
('1', 429, 2, 17, 998291) The object of this measure is not political.
('1', 429, 2, 18, 998336) It is purely and simply to degrade the Indians; in the words of a member of the Natal Parliament: “To make the Indian’s life more comfortable in his native land than in Natal”; in the words of another eminent Natalian: “To keep him for ever a hewer of wood and drawer of water”.
('1', 429, 2, 19, 998615) The very fact that at present there are only 251 Indian, as against nearly 10,000 European, voters shows that there is no fear of the Indian vote swamping the European.
('1', 429, 2, 20, 998784) For a fuller history of the question, I must refer you to the Green Pamphlet.
('1', 429, 2, 21, 998862) The London Times, which has uniformly supported us in our troubles, dealing with the franchise
('1', 429, 3, 22, 998957) 1 The reference is to The Natal Mercury.
('1', 430, 0, 1, 998998) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 431
('1', 430, 1, 2, 999032) question in Natal, thus puts it, in its issue of the 27th day of June of this year:
('1', 430, 2, 3, 999116) The question now put before Mr. Chamberlain is not an academic one.
('1', 430, 2, 4, 999184) It is not a question of argument but of race feeling.
('1', 430, 2, 5, 999238) We cannot afford a war of races among our own subjects.
('1', 430, 2, 6, 999294) It would be as wrong for the Government of India to suddenly arrest the development of Natal by shutting all supply of immigrants, as it would be for Natal to deny the right of citizenship to British Indian subjects who, by years of thrift and good work in the Colony, have raised themselves to the actual status of citizens.
('1', 430, 2, 7, 999620) If there is any real danger of the Asiatic vote swamping the European, we should have no objection to an educational test being imposed or the property qualifications being raised.
('1', 430, 2, 8, 999801) What we object to is class legislation and the degradation which it necessarily involves.
('1', 430, 2, 9, 999891) We are fighting for no new privilege in opposing the Bill.
('1', 430, 2, 10, 999950) We are resisting the deprivation of the one we have been enjoying.
('1', 430, 2, 11, 1000017) In strict accordance with the policy of degrading the Indian to the level of a raw Kaffir and, in the words of the Attorney General of Natal, “that of preventing him from forming part of the future South African nation that is going to be built”, the Natal Government, last year, introduced their Bill to amend the Indian Immigration Act which I regret to inform you, has received the Royal sanction in spite of our hopes to the contrary.
('1', 430, 2, 12, 1000456) This news was received after the Bombay meeting 1, and it will, therefore, be necessary for me to deal with this question at some length, also because this question more immediately affects this Presidency and can be best studied here.
('1', 430, 2, 13, 1000692) Up to the 18th day of August, 1894, the indentured immigrants went under a contract of service for five years in consideration for a free passage to Natal, free board and lodging for themselves and their families, and wages at the rate of ten shillings per month for the first year, to be increased by one shilling every following year.
('1', 430, 2, 14, 1001029) They were also entitled to a free passage back to India if they remained in the Colony another five years as free labourers.
('1', 430, 2, 15, 1001154) This is now changed and, in future, the immigrants will have either to remain in the Colony for ever under indenture, their wages increasing to 20 shillings at the end of the 9th year of indentured service, or to return to India or to pay an annual poll tax of £ 3 sterling, equivalent to nearly half a years’ earnings on the indentured scale.
('1', 430, 2, 16, 1001498) A Commission consisting of two
('1', 430, 3, 17, 1001529) 1 Held on September 26; vide “Speech At Public Meeting, Bombay”, 26 9 1896
('1', 431, 0, 1, 1001604) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 432
('1', 431, 1, 2, 1001646) members was sent to India in 1893 by the Natal Government to induce the Indian Government to agree to the above alterations with the exception of the imposition of the poll tax.
('1', 431, 1, 3, 1001824) The present Viceroy, while expressing his reluctance, agreed to alteration subject to the sanction of the Home Government, refusing to allow the Natal Government to make the breach of the clause about compulsory return a criminal offence.
('1', 431, 1, 4, 1002063) The Natal Government have got over the difficulty by the poll tax clause.
('1', 431, 1, 5, 1002137) The Attorney General, in discussing that clause, said that, while an Indian could not be sent to gaol for refusing to return to India or to pay the tax, so long as there was anything worth having in his hut it will be liable to seizure.
('1', 431, 1, 6, 1002374) We strongly opposed that Bill in the local Parliament and failing there, sent a memorial to Mr. Chamberlain, praying either that the Bill should be disallowed or emigration to Natal should be suspended.
('1', 431, 1, 7, 1002577) The above proposal was mooted 10 years ago and it was vehemently opposed by the most eminent Colonists in Natal.
('1', 431, 1, 8, 1002690) A Commission was then appointed to inquire into various matters concerning Indians in Natal.
('1', 431, 1, 9, 1002783) One of the Commissioners, Mr. Saunders, says in his additional report:
('1', 431, 2, 10, 1002854) Though the Commission has made no recommendation on the subject of passing a law to force Indians back to India at the expiration of their term of service unless they renew their indentures, I wish to express my strong condemnation of any such idea, and I feel convinced that many who now advocate the plan, when they realize what it means, will reject it as energetically as I do.
('1', 431, 2, 11, 1003236) Stop Indian emigration and face results, but don’t try to do what I can show is a great wrong.
('1', 431, 3, 12, 1003331) What is it but taking the best of our servants (the good as well as the bad) and then refusing them the enjoyment of the reward, forcing them back (if we could, but we cannot) when their best days have been spent for our benefit?
('1', 431, 3, 13, 1003561) Where to?
('1', 431, 3, 14, 1003571) Why, back to face prospect of starvation from which they sought to escape when they were young.
('1', 431, 3, 15, 1003667) Shylock like, taking the pound of flesh, and Shylock like we may rely on meeting Shylock’s reward.
('1', 431, 4, 16, 1003766) The Colony can stop Indian immigration, and that, perhaps, far more easily and permanently than some ‘popularity seekers’ would desire.
('1', 431, 4, 17, 1003902) But force men off at the end of their service, this the Colony cannot do.
('1', 431, 4, 18, 1003976) And I urge on it not to discredit a fair name by trying.
('1', 431, 4, 19, 1004033) The Attorney General of Natal, who introduced the Bill under discussion, expressed the following views while giving his evidence before the Commission:
('1', 432, 0, 1, 1004185) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 433
('1', 432, 1, 2, 1004219) With reference to time expired Indians, I do not think that it ought to be compulsory on any man to go to any part of the world save for a crime for which he is transported.
('1', 432, 1, 3, 1004393) I hear a great deal of this question; I have been asked again and again to take a different view, but I have not been able to do it.
('1', 432, 1, 4, 1004526) A man is brought here, in theory with his own consent, in practice very often without his consent, he gives the best five years of his life, he forms new ties, forgets the old ones, perhaps establishes a home here, and he cannot, according to my view of right and wrong, be sent back.
('1', 432, 1, 5, 1004811) Better by far to stop the further introduction of Indians altogether than to take what work you can out of them and order them away.
('1', 432, 1, 6, 1004944) The Colony, or part of the Colony, seems to want Indians but also wishes to avoid the consequences of Indian immigration.
('1', 432, 1, 7, 1005066) The Indian people do no harm as far as I know: in certain respects they do a great deal of good.
('1', 432, 1, 8, 1005163) I have never heard a reason to justify the extradition of a man who has behaved well for five years.
('1', 432, 1, 9, 1005264) And Mr. Binns, who came to India as one of the Natal Commissioners to induce the Indian Government to agree to the above mentioned alterations, gave the following evidence before the Commission ten years ago:
('1', 432, 2, 10, 1005473) I think the idea which has been mooted, that all Indians should be compelled to return to India at the end of their term of indenture, is most unfair to the Indian population and would never be sanctioned by the Indian Government.
('1', 432, 2, 11, 1005704) In my opinion, the free Indian population is a most useful section of the community.
('1', 432, 2, 12, 1005789) But, then, great men may change their views as often and as quickly as they may change their clothes, with impunity and even to advantage.
('1', 432, 2, 13, 1005928) In them, they say, such changes are a result of sincere conviction.
('1', 432, 2, 14, 1005996) It is a thousand pities, however, that, unfortunately for the poor indentured Indian, his fear or, rather, the expectation, that the Indian Government will never sanction the change was not realized.
('1', 432, 2, 15, 1006196) The London Star thus gave vent to its feelings on reading the Bill:
('1', 432, 3, 16, 1006264) These particulars are enough to throw light upon the hateful persecution to which British Indian subjects are being subjected.
('1', 432, 3, 17, 1006391) The new Indian Immigration Law Amendment Bill, which virtually proposes to reduce Indians to a state of slavery, is another example.
('1', 432, 3, 18, 1006524) The thing is a monstrous wrong, an insult to British subjects, a disgrace to its authors, and a slight upon ourselves.
('1', 432, 3, 19, 1006643) Every Englishman is concerned to see that the commercial greed of the South African trader is not permitted to wreak such bitter injustice upon men who, alike by proclamation and by statute, are placed upon an equality with ourselves before the Law.
('1', 433, 0, 1, 1006893) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 434
('1', 433, 1, 2, 1006935) The London Times, also, in supporting our prayer, has compared the state of perpetual indenture to a “state perilously near to slavery”.
('1', 433, 1, 3, 1007072) It also says:
('1', 433, 2, 4, 1007086) The Government of India has one simple remedy.
('1', 433, 2, 5, 1007133) It can suspend indentured immigration to South Africa as it has suspended such immigration to foreign possessions until it obtains the necessary guarantees for the present well being and the future status of the immigrants.
('1', 433, 2, 6, 1007357) It is eminently a case for sensible and conciliatory action on both sides.
('1', 433, 2, 7, 1007432) But the Indian Government may be forced to adopt measures in connection with the wider claim now being urged by every section of the Indian community and which has been explicitly acknowledged by Her Majesty’s Government at home, namely, the claim of the Indian races to trade and to labour with the full status of British subjects throughout the British Empire and in allied States.
('1', 433, 2, 8, 1007816) The letters from Natal, informing me of the Royal sanction to this Bill, ask me to request the Indian public to help us to get emigration suspended.
('1', 433, 2, 9, 1007965) I am well aware that the idea of suspending emigration requires careful consideration.
('1', 433, 2, 10, 1008052) I humbly think that there is no other conclusion possible in the interests of the Indians at large.
('1', 433, 2, 11, 1008152) Emigration is supposed to relieve the congested districts and to benefit those who emigrate.
('1', 433, 2, 12, 1008245) If the Indian, instead of paying the poll tax, return to India, the congestion cannot be affected at all.
('1', 433, 2, 13, 1008351) And the returned Indians will rather be a source of difficulty than anything else, as they must necessarily find it difficult to get work and cannot be expected to bring sufficient to live upon the interest of their capital.
('1', 433, 2, 14, 1008576) It certainly will not benefit the emigrants as they will never, if the Government can possibly help it, be allowed to rise higher than the status of labourers.
('1', 433, 2, 15, 1008736) The fact is that they are being helped on to degradation.
('1', 433, 2, 16, 1008794) Under such circumstances, I humbly ask you to support our prayer to suspend emigration to Natal unless the new law can be altered or repealed.
('1', 433, 2, 17, 1008937) You will naturally be anxious to know the treatment of the Indians while under indenture.
('1', 433, 2, 18, 1009027) Of course, that life cannot be bright under any circumstances; but I do not think their lot is worse than the lot of the Indians similarly placed in other parts of the world.
('1', 433, 2, 19, 1009202) At the same time, they, too, certainly come in for a share of the tremendous colour prejudice.
('1', 433, 2, 20, 1009297) I can only briefly allude to the matter here and refer the curious to the Green Pamphlet, wherein it has been more fully discussed.
('1', 433, 2, 21, 1009429) There is a sad mortality from suicides on certain estates in Natal.
('1', 433, 2, 22, 1009497) It is very difficult for an indentured Indian to have his services transferred on the ground of ill treatment.
('1', 433, 2, 23, 1009608) An indentured Indian, after
('1', 434, 0, 1, 1009636) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 435
('1', 434, 1, 2, 1009670) he becomes free, is given a free pass.
('1', 434, 1, 3, 1009709) This he has to show whenever asked to do so.
('1', 434, 1, 4, 1009754) It is meant to detect desertion by the indentured Indians.
('1', 434, 1, 5, 1009813) The working of this system is a source of much irritation to poor free Indians and often puts respectable Indians in a very unpleasant position.
('1', 434, 1, 6, 1009958) This law really would not give any trouble but for the unreasonable prejudice.
('1', 434, 1, 7, 1010037) A sympathetic Protector of Immigrants, preferably an Indian gentleman of high standing and knowing the Tamil, Telugu and Hindustani languages, would certainly mitigate the usual hardships of the indentured life.
('1', 434, 1, 8, 1010249) An Indian immigrant who loses his free pass is, as a rule, called upon to pay £3 sterling for a duplicate copy.

('1', 443, 3, 15, 1034594) You have only to take up your position strongly in order to be successful.
('1', 443, 3, 16, 1034669) That position is that the British Indian subjects in South Africa are, alike in our own colonies and in independent friendly States, being deprived of their status as British subjects guaranteed to them by the Sovereign and the British Parliament.
('1', 443, 3, 17, 1034917) An ex Liberal member of the House of Commons says:
('1', 443, 4, 18, 1034968) You are infamously treated by the Colonial Government and you will be so treated by the Home Government if they do not compel the Colonies to alter their policy: A Conservative member says:
('1', 443, 5, 19, 1035158) I am quite aware that the situation is surrounded with many difficulties, but some points stand out clear and, as far as I can make out, it is true to say that breaches of what in India is a civil contract are punishable in South Africa as though they were criminal offences.
('1', 443, 5, 20, 1035434) This is beyond doubt contrary to the principles of the Indian Code and seems to me an infringement of the privileges guaranteed to British subjects in India.
('1', 443, 5, 21, 1035592) Again, it is perfectly evident that in the Boer Republic and possibly in Natal, it is the direct obvious intention of the Government to “hunt” natives of India and to compel them to carry on their business under degrading conditions.
('1', 443, 5, 22, 1035826) The excuses which are put forward to defend the infringements of the liberties of British subjects in the Transvaal are too flimsy to be worth a moment’s attention.
('1', 444, 0, 1, 1035991) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 445
('1', 444, 1, 2, 1036025) Yet another Conservative member says:
('1', 444, 2, 3, 1036063) Your activity is praiseworthy and demands just.
('1', 444, 2, 4, 1036111) I am, therefore, willing to help you as far as lies in my power.
('1', 444, 2, 5, 1036176) Such is the sympathy evoked in England.
('1', 444, 2, 6, 1036216) Here, too, I know we have the same sympathy, but I humbly think that our cause may occupy our attention still more largely.
('1', 444, 2, 7, 1036340) What is required in India has been well put by the Moslem Chronicle in a forcibly written leader:
('1', 444, 3, 8, 1036438) What with a strong and intelligent public opinion here and a well meaning Government, the difficulties we have to contend with are not at all commensurate with those that retard the well being of our countrymen in that country.
('1', 444, 3, 9, 1036666) It is, therefore, quite time that all public bodies should at once turn their attention to this important subject to create an intelligent public opinion with a view to organize an agitation for the removal of the grievances under which our brethren are labouring.
('1', 444, 3, 10, 1036931) Indeed, these grievances have become and are day by day becoming so unbearable and offensive that the requisite agitation cannot be taken up one day too soon.
('1', 444, 3, 11, 1037090) I may state our position a little more clearly.
('1', 444, 3, 12, 1037138) We are aware that the insults and indignities that we are subjected to at the hands of the populace cannot be directly removed by the intervention of the Home Government.
('1', 444, 3, 13, 1037309) We do not appeal to it for any such intervention.
('1', 444, 3, 14, 1037359) We bring them to the notice of the public so that the fair minded of all communities and the Press may, by expressing their disapproval, materially reduce their rigour and, possibly, eradicate them ultimately.
('1', 444, 3, 15, 1037569) But we certainly do appeal, and we hope not vainly, to the Home Government for protection against reproduction of such ill feeling in legislation.
('1', 444, 3, 16, 1037716) We certainly beseech the Home Government to disallow all the Acts of the Legislative bodies of the Colonies restricting our freedom in any shape or form.
('1', 444, 3, 17, 1037870) And this brings me to the last question, namely, how far can the Home Government interfere with such action on the part of the Colonies and the allied States.
('1', 444, 3, 18, 1038029) As for Zululand, there can be no question, since it is a Crown Colony directly governed from Downing Street through a Governor.
('1', 444, 3, 19, 1038157) It is not a self governing or a responsibly governed Colony, as the Colonies of Natal and the Cape of Good Hope are.
('1', 444, 3, 20, 1038274) With regard to the last two, their Constitution Act provides that Her Majesty may disallow any act of the local Parliament within two years, even after it has become law having received the Governor’s assent.
('1', 444, 3, 21, 1038483) That is one safeguard against oppressive measures by the Colonies.
('1', 444, 3, 22, 1038550) The Royal instructions to the Government, as also the Constitution Act, enumerate certain Bills which cannot be assented to
('1', 445, 0, 1, 1038674) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 446
('1', 445, 1, 2, 1038716) by the Governor without Her Majesty’s previous sanction.
('1', 445, 1, 3, 1038773) Among such are Bills which have, for their object, class legislation, such as the Franchise Bill or Immigration Bill.
('1', 445, 1, 4, 1038891) Her Majesty’s intervention is, thus, direct and precise.
('1', 445, 1, 5, 1038948) While it is true that the Home Government is slow to interfere with the Acts of the Colonial legislatures, there are instances where it has not hesitated to put its foot down on occasions less urgent than the present one.
('1', 445, 1, 6, 1039170) As you are aware, the repeal of the first Franchise Bills was due to such wholesome intervention.
('1', 445, 1, 7, 1039268) What is more, the Colonists are ever afraid of it.
('1', 445, 1, 8, 1039319) And as a result of the sympathy expressed in England and the sympathetic answer given by Mr. Chamberlain to the Deputation that waited on him some months ago, most of the papers in South Africa, at any rate in Natal, have veered round considerably.
('1', 445, 1, 9, 1039568) As to the Transvaal, there is the Convention.
('1', 445, 1, 10, 1039614) As to the Orange Free State, I can only say that it is an unfriendly act on the part of a friendly State to shut her doors against any portion of Her Majesty’s subjects.
('1', 445, 1, 11, 1039784) And as such, I humbly think it can be effectively checked.
('1', 445, 1, 12, 1039843) It may not be amiss to quote a few passages from the London Times articles, bearing on the question of intervention as well as the whole question generally:
('1', 445, 2, 13, 1040000) The whole question resolves itself into this.
('1', 445, 2, 14, 1040046) Are Her Majesty’s Indian subjects to be treated as a degraded and an outcaste race by a friendly Government or are they to have the same rights and status as other British subjects enjoy?
('1', 445, 2, 15, 1040234) Are leading Mohammedan merchants, who might sit in the Legislative Council at Bombay, to be liable to indignities and outrages in the South African Republic?
('1', 445, 2, 16, 1040392) We are continually telling our Indian subjects that the economic future of their country depends on their ability to spread themselves out and to develop their foreign trade.
('1', 445, 2, 17, 1040567) What answer can our Indian Government give them if it fails to secure to them the same protection abroad which is secured to the subjects of every other dependency of the Crown?
('1', 445, 3, 18, 1040745) It is a mockery to urge our Indian fellow subjects to embark on external commerce if the moment they leave India they lose their rights as British subjects and can be treated by foreign governments as a degraded and an outcaste race.
('1', 445, 3, 19, 1040979) In another article it says:
('1', 445, 4, 20, 1041007) The matter is eminently one for good offices and for influence for that “friendly negotiation” which Mr. Chamberlain promises, though he warns the deputation that it may be tedious and will certainly not be easy.
('1', 445, 4, 21, 1041220) As to the Cape Colony and Natal, the question is to a certain extent simplified since, of course, the Colonial office can speak to them with greater authority.
('1', 446, 0, 1, 1041380) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 447
('1', 446, 1, 2, 1041414) The incident is one of those which suggest wider questions than any that directly offer themselves for official replies.
('1', 446, 1, 3, 1041535) We are at the centre of a world wide Empire at a period when locomotion is easy and is everyday becoming easier, both in time and cost.
('1', 446, 1, 4, 1041671) Some portions of the Empire are crowded, others are comparatively empty, and the flow from the congested to the under peopled districts is continuous.
('1', 446, 1, 5, 1041822) What is to happen when subjects differing in colour, religion and habits from ourselves or from the natives of a particular spot emigrate to that spot for their living ?
('1', 446, 1, 6, 1041992) How are race prejudices and antipathies, the jealousies of trade, the fear of competition to be controlled?
('1', 446, 1, 7, 1042100) The answer, of course, must be by intelligent policy at the Colonial Office.
('1', 446, 2, 8, 1042177) Small as are the requirements of the Indians, the steady growth of the population of India is such that certain outward movement is inevitable, and it is a movement that will increase.
('1', 446, 2, 9, 1042362) It is very desirable that our white fellow subjects in Africa should understand that there will, in all probability, be this current flowing from India, that it is perfectly within the rights of the British Indian to seek his subsistence at the Cape, and that he ought, in the common interest of the Empire, to be well treated when he comes there.
('1', 446, 2, 10, 1042710) It is indeed to be feared that the ordinary Colonist, wherever settled, thinks much more of his immediate interests than of those of the great empire which protects him, and he has some difficulty in recognizing a fellow subject in the Hindu or the Parsee.
('1', 446, 2, 11, 1042967) The duty of the Colonial office is to enlighten him and to see that fair treatment is extended to British subjects of whatever colour.
('1', 446, 3, 12, 1043102) In India, the British, the Hindu and the Mussalman communities find themselves face to face with the question as to whether at the outset of the new industrial movements which have been so long and anxiously awaited, Indian traders and workers are or are not to have the same status before the law as all other British subjects enjoy.
('1', 446, 3, 13, 1043437) May they or may they not go freely from one British possession to another and claim the rights of British subjects in allied states?
('1', 446, 3, 14, 1043570) Or are they to be treated as outcaste races subjected to a system of permits and passes when travelling on their ordinary business avocations and relegated, as the Transvaal Government would relegate them, to a ghetto at the permanent centres of their trade?
('1', 446, 3, 15, 1043829) These are questions which apply to all Indians who seek to better their fortunes outside the limits of the Indian Empire.
('1', 446, 3, 16, 1043951) Mr. Chamberlain’s words and the determined attitude taken up by every section of the Indian Press show that to such questions there can be but one answer.
('1', 446, 3, 17, 1044106) I shall take the liberty to give one more quotation from the same journal:
('1', 446, 4, 18, 1044181) The question with which Mr. Chamberlain was called upon to deal cannot be so easily reduced to concrete terms.
('1', 446, 4, 19, 1044292) On the one hand, he clearly laid
('1', 447, 0, 1, 1044325) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 448
('1', 447, 1, 2, 1044367) down the principle of the “equal rights” and equal privileges of all British subjects in regard to redress from foreign States.
('1', 447, 1, 3, 1044495) It would, indeed, have been impossible to deny that principle.
('1', 447, 1, 4, 1044558) Our Indian subjects have been fighting the battles of Great Britain over half the old world with a loyalty and courage which have won the admiration of all British men.
('1', 447, 1, 5, 1044727) The fighting reserve which Great Britain has in the Indian races adds greatly to her political influence and prestige, and it would be violation of the British sense of justice to use the blood and the valour of these races in war and yet to deny them the protection of the British name in the enterprise of peace.
('1', 447, 1, 6, 1045042) The Indian workers and traders are slowly spreading across the earth from Central Asia to the Australian Colonies and from the Straits Settlements to the Canary Islands.
('1', 447, 1, 7, 1045212) Wherever the Indian goes he is the same useful, well doing man, law abiding under whatever form of Government he may find himself, frugal in his wants and industrious in his habits.
('1', 447, 1, 8, 1045394) But these very virtues make him a formidable competitor in the labour markets to which he resorts.
('1', 447, 1, 9, 1045493) Although numbering in the aggregate some hundreds of thousands, the immigrant Indian labourers and small dealers have only recently appeared in the foreign countries or British Colonies in numbers sufficient to arouse jealousy and to expose them to political injustice.
('1', 447, 1, 10, 1045763) But the facts which we brought to notice in June, and which we urged on Mr. Chamberlain by a deputation of Indians last week, show that the necessity has now arisen for protecting the Indian labourer from such jealousy and for securing to him the same rights as other British subjects enjoy.
('1', 447, 1, 11, 1046055) Gentlemen, Bombay has spoken in no uncertain terms.
('1', 447, 1, 12, 1046107) We are yet young and inexperienced, we have a right to appeal to you, our elder and freer brethren, for protection.
('1', 447, 1, 13, 1046223) Being under the yoke of oppression, we can merely cry out in anguish.
('1', 447, 1, 14, 1046293) You have heard our cry.
('1', 447, 1, 15, 1046317) The blame will now lie on your shoulders if the yoke is not removed from our necks.

('1', 448, 2, 3, 1046649) MADRAS, October 27, 1896 THE EDITOR, THE HINDU MADRAS
('1', 448, 3, 4, 1046703) SIR, It would be ungrateful on my part if I did not thank the Madras public for rallying round the cause of the British Indians in South Africa as they did so admirably last evening.
('1', 448, 3, 5, 1046886) Indeed, all seemed to have vied with one another in making the meeting a huge success which it evidently was.
('1', 448, 3, 6, 1046996) I beg to thank you for your cordial support to the movement.
('1', 448, 3, 7, 1047057) It, perhaps, shows the absolute righteousness of the cause and the reality of our grievances.
('1', 448, 3, 8, 1047151) My special thanks are due to the courteous Secretaries of the Madras Mahajana Sabha, who worked with unremitting zeal in organizing the meeting and made the cause their own.
('1', 448, 3, 9, 1047325) Ionly hope that the sympathy and support, thus far extended, will be continued and we shall not be long in securing justice.
('1', 448, 3, 10, 1047450) I beg to assure you and the public that the news of the last night’s meeting, when it reaches South Africa, will fill the hearts of the Indians with gladness and joy and thankfulness.
('1', 448, 3, 11, 1047634) Such meetings will form a silver lining to the cloud of distress that is hanging over our heads.
('1', 448, 3, 12, 1047731) As it was very late last evening I was unable to give expression to the above sentiments.
('1', 448, 3, 13, 1047821) Hence this letter.
('1', 448, 3, 14, 1047840) The scramble for the copies of the pamphlet was a scene I will not easily forget.
('1', 448, 3, 15, 1047922) I am issuing a second edition of the pamphlet, and as soon as the copies are ready, they can be had from the obliging Secretaries of the Sabha.
