('1', 450, 7, 19, 1050682) 114. INTERVIEW TO “THE STATESMAN”
('1', 450, 8, 20, 1050716) CALCUTTA, November 10, 1896
('1', 450, 9, 21, 1050744) [REPORTER:] Will you please tell me, Mr. Gandhi, in a few words, something of the grievances of the Indians in South Africa?
('1', 450, 9, 22, 1050869) [GANDHIJI:] There are Indians in many parts of South Africa— in the Colonies of Natal, the Cape of Good Hope, the South African Republic, the Orange Free State, and elsewhere, in all of which, more
('1', 450, 10, 23, 1051067) 1 Vide Vol.I, “ Letter to F. S. Taleyarkhan”,18 10 1896
('1', 450, 11, 24, 1051123) 2 The letter is not traceable.
('1', 451, 0, 1, 1051154) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 452
('1', 451, 1, 2, 1051196) or less, they are denied the ordinary rights of citizenship.
('1', 451, 1, 3, 1051257) But I more particularly represent the Indians in Natal, who number about fifty thousand.
('1', 451, 1, 4, 1051346) The first Indians were, of course, the coolies who were taken over under indentures from Madras and Bengal for the purpose of labouring in the various plantations.
('1', 451, 1, 5, 1051510) They were mostly Hindus, but a few of them were Mohammedans.
('1', 451, 1, 6, 1051571) They served their contract time, and on obtaining their freedom they elected to stay in the country, because they found that, as market gardeners or hawkers of vegetables, they could earn from three to four pounds sterling per month.
('1', 451, 1, 7, 1051805) In this way, there are, at present, about thirty thousand free Indians settled in the Colony, while some sixteen thousand others are serving their indentures.
('1', 451, 1, 8, 1051964) There is, however, another class of Indians, numbering about five thousand, Mohammedans from the Bombay side who have been attracted to the country by the prospects of trade.
('1', 451, 1, 9, 1052139) Some of the latter are doing well.
('1', 451, 1, 10, 1052174) Many are landowners in a large way, while two own ships.
('1', 451, 1, 11, 1052231) The Indians have been settled in the country for twenty years and more, and, being prosperous, were contented and happy.
('1', 451, 2, 12, 1052352) [R.] What then, was the cause of all the present trouble, Mr. Gandhi?
('1', 451, 2, 13, 1052422) [G.] Simply trade jealousy.
('1', 451, 2, 14, 1052450) The Colony was desirous of securing all possible benefit from the Indians as labourers, because the natives of the country do not work in the fields, and the Europeans cannot.
('1', 451, 2, 15, 1052626) But the moment the Indians entered into competition with the European as a trader, he found himself thwarted, obstructed, and insulted by a system of organized persecution.
('1', 451, 2, 16, 1052799) And gradually, this feeling of hatred and oppression has been imported into the laws of the Colony.
('1', 451, 2, 17, 1052899) The Indians had been quietly enjoying the franchise for years, subject to certain property qualifications, and, in 1894, there were 251 Indian voters on the register against 9,309 European voters.
('1', 451, 2, 18, 1053096) But the Government suddenly thought, or pretended to think, that there was danger of the Asiatic vote swamping the European, and they introduced into the Legislative Assembly a Bill disfranchising all Asiatics save those who were then rightly contained in any Voters’ List.
('1', 451, 2, 19, 1053370) Against this Bill, the Indians memorialized both the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council; but to no purpose, and the Bill was passed into law.
('1', 451, 2, 20, 1053526) The Indians then memorialized Lord Ripon, who was in those days at the Colonial Office.
('1', 451, 2, 21, 1053614) As a result, that Act has now been repealed and replaced by an Act which says: ‘The natives, or descendants in the male line of natives, of countries which have not
('1', 452, 0, 1, 1053779) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 453
('1', 452, 1, 2, 1053813) hitherto possessed elective representative institutions founded on the parliamentary franchise shall not be placed on any Voters’ List unless they shall first obtain an order from the Governor in Council exempting them from the operation of the Act.’ It also exempts from its operation those persons who are rightly contained in any Voters’ List.
('1', 452, 1, 3, 1054160) This Bill was first submitted to Mr. Chamberlain who has practically approved of it.
('1', 452, 1, 4, 1054245) We have yet thought it advisable to oppose it, and with a view to secure its rejection, we have sent a memorial to Mr. Chamberlain, and hope to secure the same measure of support that has been extended to us hitherto.
('1', 452, 2, 5, 1054463) [R.] Then are we to understand that the Indians in Natal—the great bulk of whom are coolies, who would never have aspired to free institutions in their own country—are desirous of wielding political power in Natal?
('1', 452, 2, 6, 1054678) [G.] By no means.
('1', 452, 2, 7, 1054696) We are most careful to put out, in all our representations to the Government and the public, that the object of our agitation is merely the removal of vexatious disabilities devised, as we believe, to degrade us as compared to the European population.
('1', 452, 2, 8, 1054948) With the object of still further discouraging Indian colonization, the Natal Legislature has passed a Bill to keep indentured Indians under contract for the whole term of their stay in the Colony; and if they object to renew their contract at the end of their first term of five years, to send them back to India, or, if they decline to return, to compel them to pay an annual tax of £3 per head.
('1', 452, 2, 9, 1055345) Unfortunately for us, the Indian Government, on the ex parte representation of a Commission that visited India from Natal in 1893, have accepted the principle of compulsory indenture; but we are memorializing both the Home and the Indian Governments against it.
('1', 452, 3, 10, 1055607) [R.] We have heard much, Mr. Gandhi, of daily annoyances to which Indians in Natal are said to be subjected at the hands of the white Colonists.
('1', 452, 3, 11, 1055752) [G.] Oh, yes!
('1', 452, 3, 12, 1055766) And the law supports the Europeans in this system of persecution, either openly or covertly.
('1', 452, 3, 13, 1055859) The law says that an Indian must not walk on the foot paths but pass along the middle of the road; that he must not travel either first or second class on the railways; that he must not be out of his house without a pass after 9 o’clock at night; that he must take out a pass if he wishes to drive cattle; and so on.
('1', 452, 3, 14, 1056176) Imagine the tyranny of these special laws!
('1', 452, 3, 15, 1056219) For the infraction of them, Indians—men of the highest respectability who might sit in your Legislative Councils—are daily insulted, assaulted, and taken up by the police.
('1', 452, 3, 16, 1056391) And in addition to these legal disabilities, there are
('1', 453, 0, 1, 1056446) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 454
('1', 453, 1, 2, 1056488) social disqualifications.
('1', 453, 1, 3, 1056514) No Indian is permitted in the tramcars, in the public hotels, in public baths.
('1', 453, 2, 4, 1056593) [R.] Well, but, Mr. Gandhi, suppose you succeed in having the legal disabilities removed, what about the social disqualifications?
('1', 453, 2, 5, 1056724) Will they not pinch and gall and fret you a hundred times oftener than the thought that you cannot return a member to the Legislative Assembly?
('1', 453, 2, 6, 1056868) [G.] We hope that when the legal disabilities are removed, the social persecution will gradually disappear.
('1', 453, 2, 7, 1056976) The Statesman, 12 11 1896
('1', 453, 3, 8, 1057002) 115. LETTER TO “THE ENGLISHMAN” 1
('1', 453, 4, 9, 1057036) CALCUTTA, November 13, 1896 THE EDITOR, The Englishman CALCUTTA
('1', 453, 6, 10, 1057100) “Send Mohandas 2 (my Christian name) road enforcing Indians to locations.” These are the words of a telegram received yesterday from Natal by the agents, at Bombay, of Messrs Dada Abdulla and Co., a leading Indian firm in South Africa.
('1', 453, 6, 11, 1057336) The Agents very kindly telegraphed the message to me.
('1', 453, 6, 12, 1057390) This renders it absolutely necessary for me to leave Calcutta abruptly.
('1', 453, 6, 13, 1057462) “Road” is an error.
('1', 453, 6, 14, 1057482) I believe it means “Rhodes”, 3 meaning the Cape Government.
('1', 453, 6, 15, 1057542) The message means, therefore, that the Cape Government are enforcing Indians to locations.
('1', 453, 6, 16, 1057633) And it is not unlikely, as the Cape Parliament has empowered the East London Municipality to remove the Indians to locations.
('1', 453, 6, 17, 1057759) Yet, seeing that the whole Indian question is now pending before Mr. Chamberlain, such active operations might have been suspended for a time.
('1', 453, 6, 18, 1057902) The message shows the tremendous importance of the question as well as the feeling of the Indian community in South Africa about the matter.
('1', 453, 6, 19, 1058043) Had they not felt the indignity keenly they would not have

('1', 453, 8, 21, 1058165) 2 The source has “Mohanlal”, evidently a misprint.

('1', 454, 0, 1, 1058395) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 455
('1', 454, 1, 2, 1058429) sent an expensive message.
('1', 454, 1, 3, 1058456) The removal may even mean ruin to the Indian traders affected.
('1', 454, 1, 4, 1058519) But who cares for the welfare of the Indian in South Africa?
('1', 454, 1, 5, 1058580) The London Times says as follows:
('1', 454, 2, 6, 1058614) In India the British, the Hindu and the Mussalman communities find themselves face to face with the question as to whether, at the outset of the new industrial movements which have been so long and anxiously awaited, Indian traders and workers are or are not to have the same status before the law as all other British subjects enjoy.
('1', 454, 2, 7, 1058949) May they or may they not go freely from one British possession to another and claim the rights of British subjects in allied States?
('1', 454, 2, 8, 1059082) Or are they to be treated as outcaste races, subjected to a system of permits and passes when travelling on their ordinary business avocations, and relegated, as the Transvaal Government would relegate them, to a ghetto at the permanent centres of their trade?
('1', 454, 2, 9, 1059343) These are questions which apply to all Indians who seek to better their fortunes outside the limits of the Indian Empire.
('1', 454, 2, 10, 1059465) Mr. Chamberlain’s words and the determined attitude taken up by every section of the Indian Press show that to such questions there can be but one answer.
('1', 454, 2, 11, 1059620) It is clear therefore, that the question affects not only the Indians at present residing in South Africa but all who may wish to seek fortunes outside India, and that there can be but one answer to the question.
('1', 454, 2, 12, 1059833) I hope there will be only one answer.
('1', 454, 2, 13, 1059871) If all the Associations, Anglo Indian and Indian, were to protest against the disabilities that are being heaped upon the Indians in that country, and if every important town in India were to hold meetings to express disapproval of the ill treatment, I venture to think that it will not be doing too much.
('1', 454, 2, 14, 1060177) It is necessary that the public here should know what activity the various Governments in South Africa are showing and what pressure is being placed upon the Colonial Office at home to bring the matter to a successful issue from their standpoint.
('1', 454, 2, 15, 1060424) Public meetings are being held all over the country asking the Governments to put a stop to the ‘coolie’ immigration.
('1', 454, 2, 16, 1060542) Mayors of the different towns have been meeting in congress and passing resolutions desiring the restriction of the Asiatic influx.
('1', 454, 2, 17, 1060674) Sir Gordon Sprigg, the Cape Premier, is in active communication with the Colonial Office about the matter and is hopeful of a satisfactory result.
('1', 454, 2, 18, 1060821) Mr. Maydon, a prominent politician in Natal, has been telling his audiences that the friends of the Colony in England are doing every thing to vigorously put forward the Colonial
('1', 455, 0, 1, 1061000) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 456
('1', 455, 1, 2, 1061042) view before Mr. Chamberlain.
('1', 455, 1, 3, 1061071) Sir John Robinson, the Natal Premier, has gone to England to recoup his health and to discuss important State matters with Mr. Chamberlain.
('1', 455, 1, 4, 1061211) Almost all the newspapers in South Africa have been discussing the matter from the Colonial point of view.
('1', 455, 1, 5, 1061318) These are only some of the forces that are at work against us.
('1', 455, 1, 6, 1061381) As an ex member of Parliament says in a letter of sympathy: “The whole struggle is unequal,” but, “justice is on our side.” Were not the cause absolutely just and righteous it would have received its death blow long ago.
('1', 455, 1, 7, 1061602) One thing more.
('1', 455, 1, 8, 1061618) The matter demands immediate attention.
('1', 455, 1, 9, 1061658) The question is now pending.
('1', 455, 1, 10, 1061687) It cannot long remain undecided.
('1', 455, 1, 11, 1061720) And if it is decided unfavourably to the Indians it will be difficult to have it reopened.
('1', 455, 1, 12, 1061811) Now, therefore, is the time for the Anglo Indian and the Indian public to work on our behalf.
('1', 455, 1, 13, 1061905) Or it will be never.
('1', 455, 1, 14, 1061926) “The wrong,” says a distinguished Conservative 1, “is so serious that it has only to be known, I hope, to be remedied.” Yes, Sir, I implore the Anglo Indian public also to help us actively.
('1', 455, 1, 15, 1062116) We have not restricted our advances to one body or only one section of the community.
('1', 455, 1, 16, 1062202) We have ventured to approach all and so far we have received sympathy from all.
('1', 455, 1, 17, 1062282) The London Times and The Times of India have been advocating our cause for a long time.
('1', 455, 1, 18, 1062370) All the newspapers in Madras have fully supported us.
('1', 455, 1, 19, 1062424) You have given us your ungrudging support and laid us under deep obligation.
('1', 455, 1, 20, 1062501) The British Committee of the Congress has rendered us invaluable help.
('1', 455, 1, 21, 1062572) Ever since he entered Parliament, Mr. Bhownaggree has been on the alert on our behalf.
('1', 455, 1, 22, 1062659) He has been ventilating our grievance in season and out of season.
('1', 455, 1, 23, 1062726) Many other Conservative members of the House of Commons have extended their support to us.
('1', 455, 1, 24, 1062817) It is not therefore simply a matter of form that we appeal to the Anglo Indian public.

('1', 456, 0, 1, 1063096) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 457
('1', 456, 1, 2, 1063130) 116. INTERVIEW TO “THE ENGLISHMAN”
('1', 456, 2, 3, 1063165) [On or before November 13, 1896] 1
('1', 456, 3, 4, 1063200) There has always been a dislike of the Indian from the first days of their migration to Africa, but it was only when our people began to trade that the antipathy became marked and took shape in the imposition of disabilities.
('1', 456, 4, 5, 1063426) [Q.] Then all these grievances you speak of are the outcome of commercial jealousy and prompted by self interest?
('1', 456, 4, 6, 1063540) [A.] Precisely.
('1', 456, 4, 7, 1063556) That is just the root of the whole matter.
('1', 456, 4, 8, 1063599) The Colonists want us cleared out because they do not like our traders competing with them.
('1', 456, 5, 9, 1063691) [Q.] Is the competition a legitimate one?
('1', 456, 5, 10, 1063733) I mean, is it entered into and conducted on a fair and open basis?
('1', 456, 5, 11, 1063800) [A.] The competition is an open one and conducted by the Indians in a perfectly fair and legitimate manner.
('1', 456, 5, 12, 1063908) Perhaps a word or two as to the general system of trading may make matters clear.
('1', 456, 5, 13, 1063990) The bulk of Indians engaged in trafficking are those who get their goods from the large European wholesal houses, and then go about the country hawking them.
('1', 456, 5, 14, 1064148) Why, I may say that the Colony of Natal, of which I speak particularly from knowledge and experience, is practically dependent for its supplies on these travelling traders.
('1', 456, 5, 15, 1064321) As you know, shops are scarce in those parts, at least away from the towns, and the Indian gets an honest livelihood by supplying the deficiency.
('1', 456, 5, 16, 1064467) It is said that the petty European trader has been displaced.
('1', 456, 5, 17, 1064529) This is true to a certain extent; but then it has been the fault of the European trader.
('1', 456, 5, 18, 1064618) He has been content to stop in his shop, and customers have been compelled to come to him.
('1', 456, 5, 19, 1064709) It is not to be wondered at, therefore, that when the Indian, at no small trouble, takes the goods to the customers, he readily finds a sale.
('1', 456, 5, 20, 1064851) Moreover, the European trader, no matter in however small a way, will not hawk his goods about.
('1', 456, 5, 21, 1064947) Perhaps the strongest proof of the trading capabilities of the Indian and, generally speaking, of his integrity, is to be found in the fact that the great houses will give him credit, and, in fact, many of them do the bulk of their trade through his agency.
('1', 456, 5, 22, 1065205) It is no secret that
('1', 456, 6, 23, 1065226) 1 Gandhiji left Calcutta for Bombay on this date.
('1', 456, 7, 24, 1065276) 2 The question was when the antipathy of the South African whites to Indians first began to manifest itself
('1', 457, 0, 1, 1065384) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 458
('1', 457, 1, 2, 1065426) the opposition to the Indian in Natal is but partial, and by no means represents the real feelings of a good portion of the European community.
('1', 457, 2, 3, 1065570) [Q.] What, briefly, are the legal and other disabilities placed upon the Indian residents in Natal?
('1', 457, 2, 4, 1065670) [A.] Well, first there is the ‘curfew’ law which prohibits all ‘coloured’ persons being out after 9 o’clock at night without a permit from their master, if indentured servants, or unless they can give a good account of themselves.
('1', 457, 2, 5, 1065901) The great cause of complaint on this score is that this law may be used by the police as an engine of oppression.
('1', 457, 2, 6, 1066015) Respectable, well dressed, educated Indians are sometimes subjected to the humiliation of arrest by a policeman, being marched to the lock up, incarcerated for the night, brought before the magistrate next morning and dismissed without a word of apology when their bona fides have been established.
('1', 457, 2, 7, 1066314) Such occurrences are by no means rare.
('1', 457, 2, 8, 1066353) Then there is the deprivation of the franchise, which was brought out in the article you published.
('1', 457, 2, 9, 1066453) The fact is the Colonists do not want the Indian to form part of the South African nation— hence the taking away from him of franchise rights.
('1', 457, 2, 10, 1066596) As a menial he can be tolerated, as a citizen never.
('1', 457, 3, 11, 1066649) [Q.] What has been the attitude of the Indians on this question of the exercise of political rights in an alien country?
('1', 457, 3, 12, 1066770) [A.] Simply that of the person who claims to enjoy the same rights and privileges in a country as those who are not native to the country freely enjoy.
('1', 457, 3, 13, 1066922) Politically speaking, the Indian does not want the vote; it is only because he resents the indignity of being dispos sessed of it that he is agitating for its restitution.
('1', 457, 3, 14, 1067094) Moreover, the classifying of all Indians in one category and the non recognition of the just place of the better class is felt to be a great injustice.
('1', 457, 3, 15, 1067246) We have even proposed the raising of the property qualifications and the introduction of the education test, which would surely give the hall mark of fitness to every Indian voter, but this has been contemptuously rejected, proving that the sole object is that of discrediting the Indian and depriving him of all political power, so that he will be forever helpless.
('1', 457, 3, 16, 1067613) Then there is the crippling imposition of the £3 poll tax per annum on all who remain in the country after fulfilling their indenture.
('1', 457, 3, 17, 1067748) Again, the Indian has no social status; in fact, he is regarded as a social leper—a pariah.
('1', 457, 3, 18, 1067840) Indignities of all kinds are heaped upon him.
('1', 457, 3, 19, 1067886) No matter what his station may be, an Indian
('1', 458, 0, 1, 1067931) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 459
('1', 458, 1, 2, 1067965) throughout South Africa is a coolie, and as such he is treated.
('1', 458, 1, 3, 1068029) On the railway he is restricted to a certain class, and, although in Natal he is permitted to walk on the foot path, this is refused to him in other States.
('1', 458, 2, 4, 1068186) [Q.] Will you tell me something about the treatment of Indians in these States?
('1', 458, 2, 5, 1068266) [A.] In Zululand no Indians can buy landed property in the townships of Nondweni and Eshowe.
('1', 458, 3, 6, 1068359) [Q.] Why was the prohibition imposed?
('1', 458, 3, 7, 1068397) [A.] Well, in the township of Melmoth, which was the first established in Zululand, there were no regulations and the Natal Indians availed themselves of the right to buy landed property, which they did to the extent of over £2,000 worth.
('1', 458, 3, 8, 1068636) Then the prohibition was passed and made to apply to townships subsequently founded.
('1', 458, 3, 9, 1068721) It was purely trade jealousy, the fear being that the Indians would enter Zululand for trade purposes as they had done in Natal.
('1', 458, 3, 10, 1068850) In the Orange River Free State, the purchase of any property by an Indian has been made impossible by simply classifying him with the Kaffir.
('1', 458, 3, 11, 1068992) It is not permitted him to hold immovable property, and every Indian settler in the State has to pay an annual tax of ten shillings.
('1', 458, 3, 12, 1069125) The injustice of these arbitrary laws may be gauged from the fact that when they were promulgated the Indians, mostly traders, were compelled to leave the State without the slightest compensation, causing losses to the extent of £9,000. Matters in the Transvaal are hardly any better.
('1', 458, 3, 13, 1069410) Laws have been passed which prohibit the Indian from engaging in trade or residing otherwise than in specific localities.
('1', 458, 3, 14, 1069532) On the latter point, however, proceedings are pending in the law courts.
('1', 458, 3, 15, 1069605) A special registration fee of £7 has to be paid, the 9 o’clock rule is operative, walking on the foot path is forbidden (at least this is so in Johannesburg), and travelling first and second class on the railways is not permitted.
('1', 458, 3, 16, 1069836) So you will see that the Indian’s life in the Transvaal is not altogether a pleasant one.
('1', 458, 3, 17, 1069926) And yet, in spite of all these disabilities, nay, unwarrantable indignities and insults, the Indian, unless Mr. Chamberlain interferes, will be liable to compulsory military service.
('1', 458, 3, 18, 1070109) According to the Commandeering Treaty, all British subjects were exempted from this service, but, when the Transvaal Volksraad was considering the point, they added a resolution to the effect that the British subjects means “whites” only.
('1', 458, 3, 19, 1070348) The Indians, however, memorialized the Home Government on this question.
('1', 459, 0, 1, 1070421) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 460
('1', 459, 1, 2, 1070463) Colony, following on the same lines, has recently empowered the East London Municipality to prohibit trading by Indians, walking on the foot paths and limiting them to residence in certain locations.
('1', 459, 1, 3, 1070663) So you see almost everywhere in South Africa there is a dead set against the Indians.
('1', 459, 1, 4, 1070749) Yet we ask no special privileges, we only claim our just rights.
('1', 459, 1, 5, 1070814) Political power is not our ambition, but to be let alone to carry on our trading, for which we are eminently suited as a nation, is all we ask.
('1', 459, 1, 6, 1070958) This is, we think, a reasonable demand.
('1', 459, 2, 7, 1070998) [Q.] So much for these grievances, which seem to be general through out South Africa.
('1', 459, 2, 8, 1071084) Now tell me, Mr. Gandhi, how do Indian advocates fare in the law courts?
('1', 459, 2, 9, 1071157) [A.] Oh!
('1', 459, 2, 10, 1071166) there is no distinction between advocates and attorneys of whatever race; in the courts, it is only a question of ability.
('1', 459, 2, 11, 1071289) There are many lawyers in the Colony, but, on the whole, forensic talent cannot be said to be of a very high order.
('1', 459, 2, 12, 1071405) A good many European pleaders are to be found, and it goes without saying that those with English training and degrees monopolize the practice of the courts.
('1', 459, 2, 13, 1071563) But I suppose it is the English degree, for those of us who have taken it, which places us more on a level footing.
('1', 459, 2, 14, 1071679) Those with an Indian degree only would be out of place.
('1', 459, 2, 15, 1071735) There is scope, I believe, for Indian lawyers in South Africa, if at all sympathetically disposed to their fellow countrymen.
('1', 459, 3, 16, 1071861) As to the political aspect of affairs in South Africa, Mr. Gandhi preferred not to commit himself.
('1', 459, 3, 17, 1071960) The Englishman, 14 11 1896

('1', 472, 6, 7, 1082968) 119. TELEGRAM TO THE VICEROY 2
('1', 472, 7, 8, 1082999) November 30, 1896
('1', 472, 8, 9, 1083017) I RECEIVED WIRE FROM INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA SAYING THAT TRANSVAAL GOVERNMENT IS ENFORCING INDIANS TO LOCATIONS.
('1', 472, 8, 10, 1083130) THIS IS APPARENTLY DESPITE MR. CHAMBERLAIN’S REQUEST TO STAY ACTION UNTIL TEST CASE TRIED.
('1', 472, 8, 11, 1083221) I VENTURE TO THINK THAT THIS ACTION BY TRANSVAAL IS BREACH OF INTERNATIONAL COURTESY IF NOTHING MORE AND PRAY THAT IM MEDIATE ACTION WILL BE TAKEN TO STAY REMOVAL TO LOCATIONS.
('1', 472, 8, 12, 1083398) THE EXISTENCE OF HUNDREDS OF BRI TISH INDIANS IS AT STAKE.
('1', 472, 9, 13, 1083457) The Bengalee, 1 12 1896
('1', 472, 10, 14, 1083481) 1 Totals carried forward from page to page in the source have been omitted.
('1', 472, 11, 15, 1083557) 2 This was also published in The Times of India, 30 11 1896, with minor cha nges and without the last sentence.
('1', 473, 0, 1, 1083669) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 474
('1', 473, 1, 2, 1083711) 120. LETTER TO “THE ENGLISHMAN” 1
('1', 473, 2, 3, 1083745) BOMBAY, November 30, 1896
('1', 473, 3, 4, 1083771) THE EDITOR, The Englishman CALCUTTA
('1', 473, 5, 5, 1083807) With reference to my letter in connection with the grievances of the Indians in South Africa, dated the 13th instant, 2 I happened to read the original telegram received from South Africa.
('1', 473, 5, 6, 1083996) It reads “raad” and not “road” as in the message received by me in Calcutta.
('1', 473, 5, 7, 1084073) The meaning is now quite clear.
('1', 473, 5, 8, 1084105) It is that the Transvaal Government are enforcing Indians to locations.
('1', 473, 5, 9, 1084177) This makes the matter still more serious, if possible.
('1', 473, 6, 10, 1084232) The High commissioner for South Africa, in accepting the award of the arbitrator in connection with the Indian question in that Republic, writes as follows in a telegram, dated the 24th June, 1895,
('1', 473, 8, 11, 1084430) The Secretary of State has received a telegram from the Indians stating
('1', 473, 9, 12, 1084502) that they have received notice to remove and praying that action may be
('1', 473, 10, 13, 1084574) stayed.
('1', 473, 10, 14, 1084582) I therefore urge Your Honour’s Government to stay action until the
('1', 473, 11, 15, 1084649) resolution and circular of 1893 have been cancelled and the law brought in
('1', 473, 12, 16, 1084724) harmony with the award when a test case can be tried in the courts of the South
('1', 473, 13, 17, 1084804) African Republic.
('1', 473, 13, 18, 1084822) The resolution and the circular referred to have been cancelled, but so far as I know, and I have been receiving here the South African papers regularly, a test case has not been tried.
('1', 473, 13, 19, 1085008) Evidently, therefore, the action of the Transvaal Government is premature, and, I venture to think, constitutes a breach of international courtesy, if nothing more.
('1', 473, 13, 20, 1085173) I venture to remind you that the assets of the Indians in the Transvaal amount to over £100,000, and that removal to locations would practically mean ruin to the Indian traders.
('1', 473, 13, 21, 1085351) The question, therefore, in its immediate aspect involves the very existence of hundreds of Her
('1', 473, 14, 22, 1085447) 1 This appeared under the title "The Indians in South Africa".
('1', 473, 15, 23, 1085510) 2 Vide “ Letter to “The Englishman”,13 11 1896.
('1', 474, 0, 1, 1085558) VOL.1: 1884 30 NOVEMBER, 1896 475
('1', 474, 1, 2, 1085592) Majesty’s subjects whose only fault is that they are “sober, thrifty and industrious”.
('1', 474, 1, 3, 1085679) I submit that the matter demands the most urgent and immediate attention of the whole public in India.
('1', 474, 2, 4, 1085782) M. K. GANDHI The Englishman, 8 12 1896
